HEADLINE: Public & Private;
No There There

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
On a campaign trip to a South Carolina college campus 12 years ago, George Bush told his audience, "I'll be glad to reply to or dodge your questions, depending on what I think will help our election most."
At the time it was a throwaway line. In retrospect it sounds like something that should have been needlepointed on a pillow. Maybe that's unnecessary; the do-what-sells gene in George Bush's character seems so overdeveloped as to be ineradicable. 
 Last week, watching the President on the first day after the Rodney King verdict was like watching a man in sweatsocks negotiate a freshly waxed floor. Slip, slip, slide. Slip, slip, slide. He went from saying the jury system had worked to expressing shock at the verdict. You could picture him studying the polls and modifying the stance.
He finally gave a neat little speech, a generic speech with no real sense of what the most powerful leader in our nation was thinking and feeling at one of the most powerful moments in recent history. Instead of reaching deep inside himself for some anecdote about his own feelings on racism, he had a generic tale of black samaritans superimposed on a law and order riff. He announced a Federal investigation. He called up the Guard. He committed money.
That is government.
The difference between government and leadership is that leadership has a soul.
Supporters of Gov. Bill Clinton have asked over and over when those of us who crank out copy are going to bring character questions to bear upon George Bush. And by that they seem to mean questions about the President's personal life or about his son's business dealings.
But the truth is there is an enormous character issue here. The problem is that it is not true/false or multiple choice. It is an essay question.
What does Mr. Bush stand for?
His old friend C. Fred Chambers, an oil company executive, once said, "George understands that you have to do politically prudent things to get in a position to do what you want." Problem is, Mr. Bush has been in position for three years and we still don't know what he wants to do other than be politically prudent for seven more months so he can win re-election. It is the opposite of the emperor's new clothes. There are clothes, all right, depending on the prevailing winds, but nothing inside the empty suit.
Mr. Bush couldn't bring his great personal passions and ruling principles about race to bear on this crisis because he has none. Early this year The New York Review of Books ran a history of Mr. Bush's stands on civil rights issues that is a kind of road map of political expediency, from leading a campus drive at Yale for the United Negro College Fund in 1948, to campaigning for the Senate in Texas in 1964 by opposing the Civil Rights Act, to embracing a 1970 plan that advocated goals and timetables for hiring and promoting minorities, what the President today denigrates as quotas.
In fact he has done this on many of the great issues of our time. From the day in 1980 when the New York State Right to Life Party said that his presence on the ticket ruled out an endorsement for Ronald Reagan, to his position today as an anti-abortion ally -- but not a champion, never a champion, champion is risky, champion is out there -- Mr. Bush has slid from one politically convenient abortion stance to another.
My most enduring memories of the first Bush Administration will be of a man needing principle and having only polls. He waffled on raising taxes. He went from being part of an Administration that had propped up Saddam Hussein to dubbing Saddam a Hitler figure. He seemed at first flummoxed by how to react to the Soviet coup and then half-hearted in his support for economic aid, as though even the traditional Red Menace philosophy was too rich for his blood.
Trollope, who created fictional politicians the mirror image of real ones, wrote in his autobiography that a successful politician "must be able to confine himself and conform himself, to be satisfied with doing a little bit of a little thing at a time. . . . If he have grand ideas, he must keep them to himself, unless by chance he can work his way up to the top of the tree." But by that time a fellow may have gotten out of the habits of grand ideas and nonconformity. There is a character issue for Mr. Bush in this campaign. The clothes have no emperor. There is no there there.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Treasury Auction Well Received

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The first leg of the Treasury's $36 billion quarterly refunding auctions went well yesterday, as a $15 billion offering of new three-year notes was met with good demand.
The securities were sold at an average yield of 5.96 percent, up from an average yield of 5.54 percent at the last three-year note sale on Feb. 11. 
 The success of the debt sale, as well as fresh signs of economic weakness, helped to lift prices of outstanding Treasury securities, and interest rates fell slightly.
But traders said the firmer tone said little about today's 10-year note auction and the sale of 29 1/2-year bonds tomorrow. With important employment statistics not scheduled to be released until Friday, the outlook for these auctions is much more problematic, they said.
"The three-year was the easy one," one government bond trader noted. "The 10-year and the bond auction are entirely different stories, because there is a general nervousness in the market about the direction of long-term rates."
Prices were basically flat after results of the three-year auction were announced, but improved later on after auto makers reported mediocre car sales for the final 10 days of April and a closely watched survey of department and chain stores showed that retail sales fell in April.
At 6.1 million units, auto sales were a bit better than the anemic 5.5 million sold in mid-April. But for the entire month a meager 6.0 million vehicles were sold, a slight decline from March.
"The fascinating thing to me is that the auto companies are sounding much more optimistic than the selling rates suggest they should," said Ram Bhagavatula, chief financial economist at Citicorp Global Finance.
The survey of retailers was conducted by Johnson Redbook, and showed that the pace of sales growth slowed to 6.4 percent in April from 7.8 percent in March.
Analysts have been saying that consumers were unlikely to sustain the spending pace recorded in the first two months of the year. But yesterday they cautioned that the magnitude of any decline in April would be distorted by unseasonably cold weather that enveloped much of the country, as well as the earthquakes and riots that shook California.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 1/32 , up 7/32 , to yield 7.99 percent, compared with 8.01 percent late Monday.
Among outstanding note issues, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 15/32 late yesterday, up 5/32 , to yield 6.76 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 5.25 percent.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the 10-year notes to be auctioned today were offered at a price to yield 7.49 percent.
Short-term Treasury bills edged lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.60 percent late yesterday, down 3 basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 3.75 percent.
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part, $430 million offering of high-yield securities for the MGM Grand Hotel Finance Corporation.
The first part consists of $200 million worth of seven-year first-mortgage notes. The 11.75 percent notes, which are noncallable for five years, were priced at $100, or par.
 
10-Year First-Mortgage Notes
 The remaining $230 million of securities were sold as 10-year first-mortgage notes. Noncallable for five years, the 12 percent notes were priced at $100.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
The securities are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Southtrust Corporation, a bank holding company, offered $100 million worth of 12-year subordinated notes through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 8 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.446, to yield 8.70 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing when-issued yield on the 10-year Treasury notes to be auctioned today.
The noncallable securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Denver City and County priced $315 million worth of airport system revenue bonds in a negotiated offering led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.
Yields on serial bonds offered range from 6.90 percent in 2000 to 7.20 percent in 2003.
The maximum yield on term bonds is 7.66 percent on securities maturing in 2025. Those bonds are callable in five years at a price of 102.
Interest on the securities sold is subject to Federal alternative minimum tax provisions.
Moody's has affixed a conditional rating of Baa-1 to the bonds. Standard & Poor's has a BBB rating on the securities.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most investment-grade issues rose by about 1/8 point. Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by a similar amount.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-year Treasury notes:

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Accused Looters Are Varied As Greatly as Things Stolen

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 6

 BODY:
In hectic round-the-clock proceedings, thousands of men and women who were in the mobs that ravaged Los Angeles have crowded courthouses here, facing arraignments on charges of looting, arson, assault and curfew violations.
Some have long criminal records; some, in the parlance of their lawyers, are "virgins," never having broken the law before. All of them -- a fisherman, a sales clerk, a graphic designer, a homeless man -- are accused of discovering within themselves an impulse to anarchy when the city came apart.
 
Beginning With Anger
 That impulse took many forms, from angry gang members intent on settling scores to poor immigrant families unable to resist the lure of what one police officer called "the basic luxuries that we all take for granted." 
 In the tenements of South-Central Los Angeles, the looting began with a convulsion of anger at the acquittal last Wednesday of four white police officers in the beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King. Today, the area's housing projects were sullen and tense, as word spread that stolen items were for sale even as the police were raiding houses to find the goods.
"A lot of people feel it's reparations; it's what already belongs to us," said Will M., a former gang member who spoke on the condition that his last name not be used. Regarding the destruction of many local businesses, he said, "A lot of people feel that in order to come together, we have to sacrifice the neighborhood."
Some critics said the authorities were themselves stretching the law by picking and choosing the people they arrested for curfew violations and by extending the deadline to arraign people already in custody. Tuesday night, Gov. Pete Wilson signed into law an emergency measure giving the courts seven days, rather than the usual two, to arraign those arrested in the riots.
Weary members of the district attorney's office said this evening that they had no idea of the number of cases processed today. By the close of business on Tuesday about 2,000 arrraignments had been completed, a spokesman for the district attorney's office said.
One police warehouse holding stolen goods seemed a veritable Smithsonian Institution of the modern American home, with a jumble of hardware, hoses, kitchen appliances, television sets, athletic shoes, diapers, dining room sets, panty hose, toys, auto supplies, rental videos, beer and popcorn.
In one crowded apartment building 75 percent of the tenants were found to possess looted goods and were swapping among themselves, trading television sets for toaster ovens, said Lieut. Rick Morton of the Los Angeles Police Department.
For the most part, he said, people stood by silently as the police removed the booty from their homes, speaking up to object only when officers reached for items that had belonged to them before the riots.
Their contrition -- or acquiescence, at least -- was in sharp contrast to the festival of greed that filled television screens last week as outnumbered police officers stood by while people loaded bags and shopping carts and station wagons.
Chaytor D. Mason, a professor of psychology at the University of Southern California, said that with the police scarcely in sight, the looters were able to indulge their inclinations, which are usually held in check. Only the fear of being caught has stopped them in the past, he said.
"The attitude here is: 'Here's my chance. There's no cops around,' " he said. "And the mob psychology of it is that people in anonymity in mobs will do things they would not ordinarily do because they think they can get away with it."
His observation echoed a common theme during the King trial, where defense lawyers argued that the police formed a fragile boundary between "society and chaos."
Though figures giving a racial breakdown of those arrested were not available yet, it was evident that most of those being arraigned over the past few days were poor people belonging to minority groups. Of the 1,628 people arrested by sheriff's deputies on various riot charges, said Los Angeles County Sheriff Sherman Block, 810 were black, 728 were Hispanic, 72 were white and 18 were listed as being of other races.
But Will M., the former gang member, said stereotypes could be wrong.
"You have to look at the people who didn't do it, like me," he said. "I could tell you about all the temptation that I felt. I could tell you about how many times I went to the door and had the temptation to go out. But I had to be a role model for my little brother."
In interviews at housing projects in Watts, where few businesses have returned since the riots and burning of 1965, it became clear that the most disadvantaged citizens of the city had once again failed to benefit from an economic windfall, though an illegal one.
Charles H. Drew, who runs an alcoholism program in the South-Central area said: "The very people who suffer the worst and get the least from society were the ones who got the least from the looting. If you live in the projects and you didn't have a car, you couldn't go across town and loot. And in their neighborhoods there's so little in the stores that after 10 people have been in there, there's nothing left to take."
Catalina Grier, 17 years old, struck a pose and showed off a tiny tube of lip gloss and a pocket-sized pack of Kleenex as part of her treasure. "I got on my new hair bands, my new house shoes and my new socks," she said.
Judge H. Dixon, owner of Watts Florist, said people were trundling shopping carts past his tiny shop all day Thursday, tossing him packets of salt pork and other souvenirs and calling out, "Ain't you going out with the boys and get something?"
Today, he said, the items were for sale: "Hey, Slim, you need an automatic car alarm? Hey, Slim, you need dog food?"
But for many young men here in the projects, anger rather than avarice seemed to be the motivation.
On Wednesday afternoon, as the verdicts in the beating of Mr. King were announced, said a young man who would identify himself only by his street nickname, J. B., "I was watching TV, and they were saying, 'Not guilty. Not guilty.'
"An hour later I saw these guys at Florence and Normandie beating up the guy in the truck. They're the ones that got it started off," he said. "I said, 'O.K., I'm down with that. If that's how they're going to do it, we're going to do it too.' "
As firefighters roved the area today, soaking the last smoking embers of more than 3,000 burned buildings, it was clear that the looters and arsonists had targeted businesses that they believed to be owned by outsiders, particularly by Koreans. They seemed to have mostly spared those that displayed signs or graffiti reading, "Black owned."
 
Rap Is Pointed To
 "Some of it was the rap groups," said Will M. "Certain rappers were already saying to burn the place down. They put the ideas in people's minds about burning stores down and coming together. A lot of gang members are not going to school; rap music is their school."
Mr. Dixon, from his vantage point at his flower shop, watched the rioting develop as young men from rival projects seemed to compete with one another.
"You could see as many as 8 to 12 of those mini-bicycles with these teen-agers pumping as hard as they could," he said. "If one in the group wants to hit a place, all the others join in, unless someone forceful in the group says: 'No, that's Slim's place. That's black-owned.' "
In the crisis atmosphere that now grips California, both houses of the State Legislature voted without a single dissent late Tuesday to extend to seven days from 48 hours, the period in which a suspect must be arraigned or released.
"It's illegal," said Melvyn Tennenbaum, a division chief in the downtown office of the Public Defenders. "You can't pass a law and then apply it to people after they've been arrested."
The public defenders struggling to match huge stacks of paperwork with defendants packed, standing, into holding pens, criticized the curfew law, which was in effect in Los Angeles and some nearby cities until Sunday night.
"The way the curfew is being applied is unconstitutional," said Greg P. Spano, a public defender. "It's been enforced in a discriminatory fashion." The overwhelming majority of people arrested for violating the dusk-to-dawn curfew were black and Hispanic, he said.
Members of the city attorney's office and the district attorney's office countered that extraordinary measures were needed at a moment of crisis.
But for many of those arrested, and their family members, the stance of the judicial system seemed another example of the inequities that had touched off the riot in the first place.
"He was just out getting some dog food, but it makes no difference now," said a 72-year-old retired California Highway Patrol officer who had spent the last two days trying without success to find his grandson in the Criminal Court building.

HEADLINE: PRESSURE BUILDING FOR AN AMENDMENT TO BALANCE BUDGET

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Momentum is building in Congress for a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget and that could take effect as early as 1995.
Even those who say the idea is just a cynical effort concede that Congressional approval is almost inevitable this year, as lawmakers who have failed to control Federal spending rush to give the appearance of fiscal responsibility in an election year. 
 The balanced-budget movement, fueled by a coalition of conservatives and liberals who say amending the Constitution is the only way to control the runaway deficit, was the dream of the Reagan Administration and has President Bush's strong support.
 
Attacking a 'Bias'
 "This is an amendment the President has long sought," Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, told the House budget committee today.
"Years ago I would never have imagined that we would need, or that I would end up supporting, a balanced-budget constitutional amendment," Mr. Darman said. "But our political system has demonstrated a consistent, a systemic bias toward short-term political convenience."
Robert D. Reischauer, Congress's chief economist, cautioned, however, that an amendment alone could not do the job.
"In this election year, it would be a cruel hoax to suggest to the American public that one more procedural promise in the form of a constitutional amendment is going to get the job done," Mr. Reischauer told the committee. "The deficit cannot be brought down without making painful decisions."
 
Reasons for Action
 Lawmakers on both sides of the issue say support for an amendment has been propelled by widespread voter disaffection over Washington's handling of the economy and the deficit. In addition, voters are hearing analysts warn that foreigners are gaining undue influence over the American economy when they buy the bonds that are used to finance the growing national debt.
And increasingly the lawmakers say they perceive the Federal deficit, which is nearing $400 billion, as a long-term problem for the country's economic growth.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is House majority leader, said Monday in a speech at Harvard University, that "in all likelihood" both houses would pass an amendment by the two-thirds majorities required by the Constitution.
Two versions of a balanced-budget amendment, one preferred by Democrats and the other by Republicans, are scheduled to reach the Senate floor early next month. The House is supposed to consider the issue soon afterward, and there could be months of difficult negotiations should the chambers pass different versions.
Senate Democrats are poised to try to block the Republican-inspired version, which would make it nearly impossible for future Congresses to raise taxes. They argue that tax increases should go along with spending cuts in reducing deficits.
The Democratic leaders say they wish they did not have to deal with such an amendment at all because it is both bad government and bad economic policy. But they concede they cannot force their will on the rank and file because the latter lawmakers are under so much election-year pressure to something about the economy.
 
Economists Are Divided
 Even if the amendment is not approved, it can hang over lawmakers' heads throughout this election year, making it difficult for them to talk in any constructive way about the economy and the growing deficit. State legislators would also be forced to address the issue.
Some economists say an amendment could help the economy, if it forces lawmakers to spend more judiciously, a move that they say could spur growth and investment by keeping interest rates low.
But other analysts worry that an amendment could hurt the economy by reducing the Government's flexibility to deal with unexpected problems like natural disasters or deep recessions. Some also worry that slashing spending or cutting taxes suddenly to reduce the deficit could precipitate a new recession.
If a balanced-budget amendment wins Congressional approval, it will then need ratification by three-quarters of the state legislatures, a process that proponents of the measure say will take about three years. Most of those supporters say enough states will approve, but the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other liberal groups have promised to fight the amendment.
It is also possible that further resistance could emerge once state lawmakers realize the amendment's potential impact on Federal spending in their jurisdictions.
Senator Bob Kasten, a Wisconsin Republican who is a sponsor of one of the Senate versions of the amendment, said some state lawmakers might initially fear that balanced-budget requirement would mean a reduction of Federal aid to their local governments. But, the Senator added, those lawmakers would eventually be persuaded that it was in their political interest to support it.
"There's an anti-Washington-spending feeling out there," Mr. Kasten said. "So I think legislators will jump on this as a political vote."
Critics of a balanced-budget amendment charge that its supporters are posturing as budget cutters for this election year while leaving the tough budget choices for future lawmakers.
"What people are looking for is a substitute for political will," said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts.
But Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, and Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, insist that their respective versions of the amendment -- one in the Senate and the other in the House -- give Congress ample flexibility to govern.
 
Action in Time of War
 The Stenholm version would allow the requirement for a balanced budget to be waived after a declaration of war. The waiver would require only a majority vote in both houses.
The Simon version does not require a declaration of war but would allow lawmakers to waive the balanced-budget requirement by a simple majority vote in fiscal years during which "the United States is engaged in military conflict which causes an imminent and serious military threat to national security."
The Simon and Stenholm versions also allow that in times of economic slowdown lawmakers could vote to lift the requirement if increased Federal spending was needed. In such cases, a 60 percent majority would be needed.
For each fiscal year, both versions would require the President to submit a balanced budget to Congress and would prohibit spending in excess of revenues unless 60 percent majorities in both houses voted to approve a deficit.
The Simon and Stenholm versions, which are very similiar and which have the most support in Congress, would go into effect in 1995, or the second year after enough states ratified the measure, whichever comes first.
 
The Republicans' Version
 The version proposed by Mr. Kasten and other Republicans would not only prohibit spending in excess of receipts unless Congress voted a 3-to-2 margin to permit it, but would also prohibit tax increases unless they were approved by a three-fifths majority of both houses. Mr. Kasten and other conservatives say the latter provision is needed to prevent liberals from exploiting the balanced-budget amendment as a cover to raise taxes.
A constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget has long been a goal of conservative politicians. It won 66 votes in the Senate in 1986, one short of the two-thirds needed. In 1990, it fell seven votes short in the House.
Prospects are better now, Republicans and Democrats say, because, absent the political will to make tough choices, the current system is insufficient to keep the deficit on a downward path.
With a few exceptions, the lawmakers who over the years have been most serious about trying to reduce the deficit either oppose the amendment or support it reluctantly. They believe that the main effect of approving a constitutional amendment would be to allow politicians to avoid the hard choices until the amendment took effect.
In an interview, Mr. Stenholm said Congress needed a constitutional provision mandating a balanced budget to stiffen its resolve.
"We're going to have to make these cuts either in an orderly way" or in the chaotic and the destabilizing fashion Argentina was forced to cut spending in recent years, Mr. Stenholm said. "We're not exempt."
 
Zeroing In on Tax Aspect
 Democratic Congressional leaders have decided to concentrate on stopping the tax restriction of the amendment, which they see as a threat to programs like Social Security. Some Republicans say they hope to attach the tax restriction to the Simon version.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said the Republican version of the amendment "would build in a constitutional block to the very decisions that need to be made" by practically preventing Congress from increasing taxes to balance the budget.
Passage of the anti-tax provision looks possible in the Senate, but is less likely in the House. It is possible that Democratic opposition could then stiffen enough to endanger the entire amendment, although most Democratsnow say the politics of the issue runs counter to that possibility.
Should the Republican version of the amendment pass one house but not the other, eventual enactment could be complicated if Democratic leaders appoint conferees to the Senate-House Conference committee that are hostile to it.
Democratic leaders in Congress are considering various strategies. In meetings last week, Mr. Panetta and Mr. Gephardt considered proposing legislation as a companion to the balanced-budget amendment that would impose severe cuts in military spending and in subsidies to corporations and ranchers, as well as cost-containment provisions to control the growth of Medicare and Medicaid, the Federal health care programs for the elderly and the poor.
They also considered altering the amendment to include one or more enforcement provisions like formulas to cap spending. Congressional officials said Democratic strategy meetings would probably continue in the Senate and the House until the amendment reaches the floor in both chambers next month.
Democratic strategists said they want members to face up to the sacrifices they are asking future lawmakers to make, and, as one aide put it, "expose the hypocrisy a little bit."

HEADLINE: At Site of 'Iron Curtain' Speech, Gorbachev Buries the Cold War

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FULTON, Mo., May 6

 BODY:
History came full cycle today as Mikhail S. Gorbachev added a postscript of global reconciliation to the "Iron Curtain" speech by Winston Churchill here 46 years ago, but pointedly contended that the United States was the "initiator" of the nuclear arms race.
Speaking at Westminster College, the scene of Churchill's warning in 1946 about Soviet imperialism, the former Soviet leader conceded that the Kremlin made a "major error" in assuming that the defeat of fascism in World War II would produce an inevitable triumph of Communism. 
 But he argued that the United States and other Western nations erred grievously in failing to realize that Stalin and the Soviet people were too exhausted from the war to indulge in military aggression against the West.
"By including the 'nuclear component' in world politics, and on this basis unleashing a monstrous arms race -- and here the initiator was the United States, the West -- 'defense sufficiency was exceeded,' as the lawyers say," Mr. Gorbachev declared. "This was a fateful error." [Excerpts, page A14.]
Speaking as the last President of the now-defunct Soviet Union and the Kremlin chief who led the world back from nuclear confrontation, Mr. Gorbachev spent much of his speech looking ahead to a better world strengthened through his prescriptions for a stronger United Nations.
But he also presented a blunt critique of some cherished American underpinnings of the cold war and warned against "the intellectual, and consequently political error, of interpreting victory in the cold war narrowly as a victory for oneself."
Rather than a lopsided victory, Mr. Gorbachev described the end of the cold war as "a shattering of the vicious circle into which we had driven ourselves."
"This was altogether a victory for common sense, reason, democracy, and common human values," he said.
Examining the roots of the cold war, Mr. Gorbachev cited a critical Soviet error in Stalin's inability to grasp postwar politics. But he contended that "the West, and the United States in particular, also committed an error."
"Its conclusion about the probability of open Soviet military aggression was unrealistic and dangerous," he said, differing with the basis of the West's collective defensive strategy of the postwar decades.
"This could never have happened, not only because Stalin, as in 1939-41, was afraid of war, did not want war, and never would have engaged in a major war," he contended. "but primarily because the country was exhausted and destroyed."
Visiting, like Churchill, as a politician rebuffed at home yet outspoken in retirement -- the British leader was ousted in the 1945 election by Clement Attlee and the Labor Party -- Mr. Gorbachev spoke to an outdoor gathering and offered a range of proposals for strengthening the United Nations. These included the enlargement of the Security Council and the application of stronger sanctions and military force against wayward members.
But the audience, watching him on a sunny day in a simple American heartland setting, was clearly more interested in his pronouncements on the end of the cold war. In this, Mr. Gorbachev was reflective and recanted a bit on his own views.
"Having long been orthodox Marxists, we were sure we knew," he said. "But life once again refuted those who claimed to be know-it-alls and messiahs."
 
A 'Watershed' Moment
 Mr. Gorbachev's speech was titled "The River of Time and the Imperative of Action," an allusion to his sense that a "watershed" moment had arrived, comparable in its way to the 1946 moment and its need for concerted action. He was repeatedly applauded, particularly in hailing the world's retreat from the abyss, urging global efforts to protect the environment and warning against triumphalist claims of cold war victory.
The Missouri countryside glistened, with a cluster of cold war nuclear-missile silos hundreds of miles to the west all but forgotten. Mr. Gorbachev obviously enjoyed the day, offering Churchill's V-for-victory signal to pleading photographers and giving thanks for a lunch of baked ham and potato salad provided by the administrators of the 140-year-old liberal arts college of 750 undergradutates.
It was the college, which gained international visibility after the famous 1946 speech, that invited him to speak today. Mr. Gorbachev, as in earlier addresses, warned against the excesses of nationalism reawakened at the end of the cold war, as well as against a "monocentric" view of post-cold-war politics. In that view, one dominant nation, the United States, might prevail over a "multipolar" political world.
The former Soviet leader was cheered as he arrived in the sunshine at the speaking platform set before a sculpture by Edwina Sandys, Churchill's granddaughter, celebrating the fall of the Berlin wall.
He came as a pensioned politician looking for a foothold in the West on a fund-raising tour for his new Gorbachev Foundation. He spoke gratis and beamed and touched his chest to demonstrate his gratitude, as a crowd estimated at 10,000 applauded the college's award to him of an honoray doctorate of laws.
 
Stronger U.N. Urged
 The mood in Fulton was serene, in severe contrast to the ominous one conjured up here on March 5, 1946 by Churchill.
"A shadow has fallen upon the scenes so lately lighted by the Allied victory," the British wartime leader said. "From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic, an iron curtain has descended across the Continent."
Today, Mr. Gorbachev stood in the Missouri sunshine to proclaim an end to Churchill's alarm, but also to press for a greatly strengthened United Nations to deal with the complicated post-Soviet world.
In particular, he called for creation of a "special body" to use economic and military means to prevent regional conflicts and for a greatly enlarged Security Council, with nations like India, Japan, Poland, Mexico, Germany, Brazil, Canada, Indonesia and Egypt as members, even if without veto power.
Churchill had declared, "Nobody knows what Soviet Russia and its Communist international organization intends to do in the immediate future, or what are the limits, if any, to their expansive and proselytizing tendencies."
Today, Mr. Gorbachev stood at the same lectern as Churchill to symbolize the Soviet Union's peaceful demise and to look no less uncertainly into the future, hoping this time that nations "made wise by bitter experience" might cast aside "egoistic considerations in order to arrive at the exalted goal that is man's destiny on earth."

HEADLINE: BUSH LIKELY TO GO TO ECOLOGY TALKS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Ending one of the more fractious debates within his Administration in recent months, President Bush is expected to announce soon that he will fly to Brazil for a United Nations environmental conference that his conservative advisers call a trap and his economic experts see as a fiscal debacle.
The prospect of that announcement is likely to cheer a worldwide alliance of environmental advocates and political figures involved in environmental issues, who have long feared that Mr. Bush might single-handedly wreck the meeting simply by staying home. 
 Environmentalists have resorted to advertising on national television to press Mr. Bush to attend, and the issue loomed as an important factor in the presidential campaign.
 
World's Biggest Polluter
 As the world's largest industrial economy and its largest energy user, the United States is both the Earth's most prolific polluter and far and away its prime source of clean-up technology and money, and thus is regarded as indispensable to the meeting, which convenes in Rio de Janeiro next month.
Some of the same environmentalists pressing the President to attend, however, now complain that Mr. Bush's own hardball negotiating tactics may make the conference more a symbolic triumph than a substantive success. The President has dangled the threat of a boycott while seeking major concessions on environmental agreements to be signed in Rio.
"It would be hard to imagine a more important event for the future of the global environment than this one," James Gustave Speth, president of the Washington-based World Resources Institute, said in an interview. "And so it's been one of the most discouraging experiences of my 10 years of working on international environmental issues to see my Government fail to give the kind of leadership that it gave 20 years ago."
Mr. Bush has yet to declare his intention to attend the Brazilian meeting, although White House officials have said for some weeks now that a decision was close. But several Administration officials, who refused to be named, said in interviews this week that Mr. Bush almost certainly will attend the meeting, although his stay may be brief.
Mr. Bush's aides insist that the United States has been a leader in negotiations leading up to the meeting by resisting treaties that would dictate rigid goals and methods for reducing global pollution; at the same time, it has advocated the sorts of free-market environmental strategies that the Administration has tried to push at home.
"My sense is that he will attend," said one Administration official at the center of the debate. "The President has nothing to be ashamed of -- we've got a good environmental record -- and we've told him he ought to make the case for the good methods of achieving these goals rather than the command-and-control methods they've been talking about."
The meeting, formally called the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, will be attended by at least 100 world leaders, including most Western leaders, and 6,000 experts on the global environment. Its centerpieces, now being negotiated, are a worldwide agreement to slow the production of chemicals that have accelerated the warming of the Earth's atmosphere and a second agreement on means to preserve plants and animal species.
Mr. Bush has repeatedly voiced great skepticism about the conference. For most of this year, while his aides haggled over the fine points of treaties and declarations, he has publicly fretted that the conference would become a soapbox for poor nations to demand billions in environmental technology and cash that the White House neither has nor intends to pledge.
Some aides also expressed alarm that the conference would commit the United States to actions intended to avert global warming, like reductions in emissions of carbon dioxide, that would cripple major industries at a time of fragile economic growth.
"I am not going to go to the Rio conference and make a bad deal or be a party to a bad deal. I'm not going to sign an agreement that does not protect the environment, and the economy of this country," the President told business executives last month.
But he is apparently going anyway, in no small part because a curious alliance of political advisers and policy experts has convinced him that he cannot afford to stay home.
That alliance includes his campaign manager, Robert M. Teeter; his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; senior officials at the State Department and the Environmental Protection Agency.
It also features a rising young official at the Office of Management and Budget, Robert Grady, who was the architect of not only Mr. Bush's environmental policy but his use of pollution in Boston harbor as a campaign issue in the 1988 presidential election.
That group is bound by an array of interests. State Department diplomats and Mr. Scowcroft are said to believe that Mr. Bush's absence would be an abdication of global leadership, since most major leaders will be at the conference and strongly support its goals. The meeting also bears potentially huge political implications for Mr. Bush. Aides believe that his failure to attend would blot his environmental record at a time when the issue has become a major factor in the votes of young people and in some large states, like California and Florida. His absence would weaken his ability to attack his likely opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, whose environmental record has also been criticized.

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
As Los Angeles Smoke Lifts, Bush Can See Kemp Clearly

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Suddenly, everyone wants to talk to the Housing Secretary, Jack F. Kemp. Members of Congress do. Television networks do. And what is most important, President Bush does, summoning him to three Cabinet meetings in three days and saving him a seat on today's plane ride to Los Angeles.
"It's nice to be needed," Mr. Kemp said in an interview today. 
 Most likely it is an uncommon feeling.
Beset by the accusation after the Los Angeles riots that the Bush Administration has let the problems of urban America fester, the White House has now reached out to Mr. Kemp, declared renewed interest in his proposals for a conservatives' war on poverty, and stepped up attacks on Congressional Democrats for not enacting them. Today, as he left for California, President Bush said the nation could "do better" than the Great Society programs. [Page A22.]
 
The Things Not Said
 What the White House has left unstated is that Mr. Kemp's moment in the sun comes after three years of a kind of internal exile.
Suspect for his enthusiasm for anti-poverty plans, the head of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has been shut out of the President's inner circle, ridiculed by the budget director and sent to fight lonely battles on Capitol Hill without White House reinforcements.
While the White House says Mr. Kemp's place in the Administration shows that it has had an urban policy all along, Mr. Kemp's admirers on both sides of the aisle say it shows the opposite.
"It's terrible that Jack has been relegated to a back seat up to now," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, one of Mr. Kemp's Republican allies in Congress.
Asked if the Administration has accomplished anything in anti-poverty policy, Mr. Weber said, "Not really."
 
The Critic Within
 That sentiment was shared by Stuart Butler, vice president for domestic policy at the Heritage Foundation, a Washington research organization. "Kemp is now being brought out and put on the talk shows, but when Kemp wanted to fight for his programs on the Hill, the White House was nowhere to be seen," Mr. Butler said.
Indeed, those looking for a vocal critic of Administration inaction need look no further than Mr. Kemp himself.
His confidential correspondence with White House advisers over the past two years, provided to a reporter without permission last year by someone outside his office, reads like the pleadings of an outside advocate.
In a letter dated May 1990 to the Domestic Policy Council, which was reviewing options for an anti-poverty effort, Mr. Kemp warned that the problems of urban America had reached "a moment of critical mass." He said it was "past time for the Administration to aggressively highlight a new comprehensive anti-poverty agenda."
White House aides then drafted a potential strategy for the President that made Mr. Kemp wince. "That's not a vision," he wrote back in July 1990, accusing them of "bureaucratizing the effort and sending it to oblivion."
He was particularly vexed at their plans to conduct technical studies of the way anti-poverty programs are financed and managed.
The White House was already criticized for "studying the problem to death and throwing up its hands," Mr. Kemp wrote. "Meanwhile, what's going on in our neighborhoods and on our streets?"
Part of what has set Mr. Kemp off from his Administration rivals is his view that the Republican Party can benefit politically from an anti-poverty effort, especially by attracting more minorities to the party. Few people in the Administration have spoken as crudely as Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential challenger, who said Mr. Kemp has "gone native." But many others have doubted in private that there is any political profit in his plans.
 
Pluses, Minuses and Poverty
 In their 1990 planning document, White House aides addressed the political calculus of an anti-poverty effort backed fully by the President.
On the plus side, they said it "takes the moral high ground." On the down side, they warned, the effort could give poverty "greater visibility," and bring new pressure to "increase spending and demonstrate concrete success."
Mr. Kemp wrote back in a complaining tone that "poverty already has a high public visibility."
While a year ago Mr. Kemp was coming as close as he could to criticizing a President, arguing that "all of us need to do more," he is now being careful not to pick fights.
Asked today if aides like Richard G. Darman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, had slowed his efforts, Mr. Kemp replied in a virtual whisper: "Are you crazy? You're trying to get me into an internecine warfare on the night I'm going out with the President to help implement these ideas."
 
A 'Cynical' Question?
 In interviews three times this week, Mr. Kemp was asked to specify what Mr. Bush has accomplished for urban America. First he called the question "cynical" and said, "I don't want to even answer that."
Next he made a joke, arguing "with tongue planted firmly in cheek," that Mr. Bush had had the good sense to make him the Housing Secretary.
Asked a third time, he lashed out at Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Mr. Bush's likely Democratic challenger.
Mr. Kemp's ideas themselves are part of what he likes to call "empowerment," a strategy to circumvent Government bureaucracies and use market forces to accomplish social ends.
He is most vocal about three policies in particular: those that will give tenants in public housing the chance to buy their units; those that will let parents choose the schools their children attend, public or private, and those that would give tax breaks to business that locate within inner-city "enterprise zones."
 
More Money Wanted
 Congress has given Mr. Kemp less money than he wants for the first program, and nothing for the others -- a situation the White House has been quick to highlight, in arguing that Democrats cling to failed, outdated policies.
While the White House set off a furor this week in criticizing the social policies of the 1960's, few seem to realize that Mr. Kemp's plans in some ways are quite similar.
Mr. Kemp's housing proposals include heavy doses of social services like job training and anti-drug counseling. More pointedly, Mr. Kemp's enthusiams for community organizing bears a striking, if unconscious, resemblance to the War on Poverty.
It is more than mere coincidence that anti-poverty planners in both the 1960's and 1990's used the same term: "empowerment."
 
What Impact on Policy?
 While Mr. Kemp has captured the limelight, it remains unclear whether he has gained a permanent upper hand in policymaking.
Mr. Kemp said this week's Cabinet debate was taking familiar turns between those who want to move fast on his proposals and those who counseled caution, when the President brought the discussion to "a screeching halt" by backing his agenda to the fullest. Mr. Kemp said that to divulge more might pre-empt the President's speech in Los Angeles.
But speaking to a group of foreign journalists Tuesday, Mr. Kemp himself said the "jury is out" on the long-term prospects of his plans, which are outlined in this year's budget.
He described himself as a strong supporter of President Bush, "very much a believer in him and his leadership." But he added, "If he were to turn his back on his own budget, I guess I'd have no reason to stay."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
BUSH SAYS LARGESS WON'T HELP CITIES

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
President Bush, whose Administration on Monday blamed failed Democratic social-welfare policies of the 1960's for the Los Angeles riots, said today as he left for California that this was no time for name-calling.
But he also contended that the nation could "do better" than Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society programs in combating urban ills, and he said that "it is far more important to give people a piece of the action than simply to have the Federal Government dump largess on them." 
 Government spending "has not solved many of the fundamental problems that plague our cities," the President declared this afternoon. "We need an honest, open national discussion about family, about values, about public policy and about race."
[Mr. Bush arrived in Los Angeles Wednesday night, assuring the city's residents that his Administration was already taking steps to help rebuild the city. "The Federal Government is committed to help this city, to help this city rebuild," he said in a statement delivered at the airport after he stepped off Air Force One.]
 
'A Do-Nothing Approach'
 In North Carolina, where he won one of three primary victories on Tuesday, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the almost certain Democratic Presidential nominee, said he approved of Mr. Bush's trip to Los Angeles because people in the riot area "need a President." But later, campaigning in Beckley, W. Va., Mr. Clinton returned the President's fire.
"We can do better than the Great Society, but now we're doing nothing, so we're doing worse than the Great Society," he said. "We need things that will let people at the local level shape their future in everything from houses to jobs to safe streets. But we can't do better with a do-nothing approach."
Other Democrats defended the anti-poverty campaigns of a quarter-century ago with greater vehemence.
Joseph A. Califano Jr., a key domestic policy adviser in the Johnson White House, said poverty had declined under the Democrats, then had risen again under the Republicans.
 
'An Untruth, a Lie'
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said the contention by Attorney General William P. Barr that the breakdown of family structure had been caused by the Great Society was "one of the most depraved statements I have ever heard from an American official." The statement, he said on the Senate floor, "is an untruth, a lie."
Mr. Bush said about half the 1,000 Federal law-enforcement specialists who were sent to Los Angeles last week had been withdrawn, and predicted that troops still on duty there "won't be much longer."
He has planned a tour of the burnt-out portions of South-Central Los Angeles and a meeting with Gov. Pete Wilson of California before returning to Washington on Friday evening.
Neither the President nor Mr. Clinton has looked terribly sure-footed in their early reactions to the acquittal of four white Los Angeles police officers charged with beating a black motorist, Rodney G. King, and the widespread arson and looting that followed. Each has seemed to be groping for solid footing in uncertain political terrain.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, began open political combat on the issues of racial tensions and urban breakdown on Monday when he said the riots were the result of Democratic policies. Senior Republican strategists, including officials of the President's campaign committee, laughed at him; one Republican Senator said that "next Marlin will blame the savings-and-loan crisis on Woodrow Wilson."
On Tuesday, Mr. Fitzwater pulled back from his remarks, but they suggested, and Mr. Bush in effect confirmed today, that the Republicans think they have found the formula they need to escape blame for the riots.
 
Vindication, Perhaps
 In a speech last year at the University of Michigan, the President criticized social-welfare programs originally enacted by the Democrats. He said then that "programs designed to insure racial harmony generated animosity," and "programs intended to help people out of poverty invited dependency."
Although he repeatedly denied during an impromptu news conference this morning that he was assigning blame for racial polarization, he told reporters, "If I said a year ago that these programs weren't working, perhaps I have been vindicated."
But he conceded that he could not "certify to the American people that we have tried the new ideas that might make urban America better."
The President has never said which programs he considered to be failures, but he has emphasized in his own Administration at least one of the Johnson-era programs, Head Start, which seeks to compensate for poverty by using special educational techniques with young children.
In remarks to the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention in New York, to which he spoke on television by a television hookup, Mr. Bush said: "I think we should certainly reconsider the status quo in terms of Federal aid to cities. I think we would all agree that it hasn't worked in the last 10 years, hasn't worked in the last 30."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Woolworth Reports a Profit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it earned $17 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $100 million a year earlier.
The retailer said its operating earnings, which reflect the health of its ongoing business, were up 20 percent in the quarter ended April 25. 
 Woolworth said its profit amounted to 13 cents a share. The company posted the $100 million loss in the first quarter of 1991 when it took a $113 million one-time charge for a change in accounting for post-retirement benefits.
Woolworth reported operating income of $59 million, up from $49 million a year earlier.
Revenue fell 1.5 percent, to just under $2.1 billion, from $2.13 billion, in part reflecting the planned closing of about 900 specialty and general merchandise stores.
Woolworth, hit hard by the recession in the United States and Canada, had uneven sales in the first quarter, which is generally the least significant period for retailers.
Woolworth's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $29.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: The Three Main Proposals For a Budget Amendment

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
For members of Congress who want to balance the Federal budget, there are currently three main proposals to amend the Constitution.
The amendment sponsored by Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, and a similar proposal by Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, have wide backing in Congress and are given a good chance of passing this year. A competing version, whose chief sponsor is Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, has less support in Congress and would erect greater obstacles to increasing taxes than the other proposals. 
 Here are the three versions:
 
The Simon Plan
 The amendment would require that total outlays not exceed total receipts for any fiscal year. The amendment, which would take effect beginning with the second fiscal year after its ratification by three-fourths of the state legislatures, would allow outlays to exceed receipts if 60 percent of all members of the Senate and the House approve it in a roll-call vote.
Taxes could be increased only if half of both the full House and Senate approve. The requirement for a balanced budget could be waived, by majority vote, for any fiscal year when the United States is engaged in a military conflict, whether or not it is officially declared a war.
 
The Stenholm Plan
 The amendment is generally the same as Mr. Simon's except that it would first require the President and Congress to agree on an estimate of total receipts for each fiscal year by enacting a law devoted to that subject. Outlays could not exceed the level of estimated receipts without approval of 60 percent of all the members of each house of Congress.
It would take effect in fiscal year 1995 or with the second fiscal year beginning after its ratification, whichever is later.
In addition, the limit on the debt of the United States shall not be increased unless 60 percent of all members of both houses of Congress approve.
It would allow the requirement for a balanced budget to be waived if war is declared.
 
The Kasten Plan
 Like Mr. Simon's version, Mr. Kasten's amendment would require total actual outlays and receipts to be balanced and would allow outlays to exceed receipts only if 60 percent of all the members of both chambers approve.
The major difference in the two versions is that Mr. Kasten's amendment would allow taxes to be raised at a rate greater than the rate of increase in nation's economic output only if 60 percent of all the members of both house of Congress approve.
It would allow the requirement for a balanced budgetto be waived if war is declared.
It would take effect in the fiscal year 1997 or the second fiscal year beginning after its ratification, whichever is later.
Like the Stenholm plan, Mr. Kasten's version would not allow the debt limit to increased unless 60 percent of all members of both houses of Congress approve.

HEADLINE: North Korea Reveals More About Its Nuclear Sites

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 6

 BODY:
Possibly resolving one of the biggest mysteries surrounding its secretive nuclear program, North Korea has described a web of previously unknown sites to the International Atomic Energy Agency, including a laboratory that appears to be the same building the United States asserts is the centerpiece of a nuclear-weapons project.
The agency said that in the detailed, 100-page document submitted on Monday, North Korea described a "radiochemical laboratory" designed for research on separating very small amounts of uranium and plutonium as a way to control nuclear wastes. 
 Though the true nature of the laboratory will not be known until inspectors arrive at the site -- a process that may begin as early as later this month -- experts say that it appears to be the same building that American intelligence agencies have described in far more sinister terms.
 
U.S. Calls It Deception
 Citing satellite photographs, the United States has alleged that the building at Yongbyon, about 60 miles north of the capital, Pyongyang, is a nearly completed plutonium reprocessing center, capable of producing large volumes of weapons-grade plutonium that could be fabricated into crude nuclear weapons.
North Korea has denied any such reprocessing center exists and said that all of its nuclear sites are for civilian purposes. Nonetheless, it has held off inspections for more than six years. Only in recent months, under strong political and economic pressure from the United States and Japan, has it begun to reverse course. Today officials of the nuclear agency said they were taken aback at the level of detail provided by North Korean authorities.
"The facilities listed were more than they needed to give us," David Kyd, a spokesman for the agency, said in a telephone interview from Vienna. "Our inspectors will go in by the end of the month, so things are beginning to roll."
He said a full report on the centers would be made to the agency's board of governors when it meets in Vienna in mid-June.
Assuming that the North Korean and American officials are talking about the same building, something that will not be certain until inspectors arrive, it raises a critical question: Did American intelligence services badly misjudge North Korea's capabilities and intentions, or is North Korea vastly understating what it has built?
If the North Koreans are telling the truth, it would be a major embarrassment for the Bush Administration, which has organized enormous international pressure again the Communist Government of Kim Il Sung to stop the North Korean bomb program. But American officials have repeatedly warned in recent weeks that it is still possible that North Korea is engaged in an elaborate deception, similar to Iraq's efforts to hide the scope of its nuclear weapons project.
 
Tokyo's Aid Stance
 It is unclear, for example, why North Korea would need what appears in satellite photographs to be a huge building to house a small research laboratory. One possibility is that production equipment has been removed in recent months to make the building's contents, which cannot be seen by satellite, appear innocuous. Another possibility is that North Korea determined that the technology of reprocessing was beyond its technological capabilities or no longer worth the political costs.
"It looks more like a production facility than a research facility," an American official deeply involved in the issue said today. "But this may be a face-saving way for the North Koreans to declare the facility exists" and begin to back away from the problems it is causing.
The issue has taken on new urgency in Washington in recent months with Robert Gates, Director of Central Intelligence, telling Congress that North Korea could be a few months to a few years away from producing its first bomb.
Japanese officials have also made it clear to North Korea that unless the nuclear issue is resolved, they cannot begin discussions of normalizing diplomatic relations with the North or providing economic aid to the country, whose economy seems near collapse.
The strongest signs that North Korea had changed course came this weekend, when two separate delegations visiting Pyongyang simultaneously -- a study group from the Carnegie Endowmment for International Peace, and a group of American and Japanese reporters traveling with an economic mission from Japan -- were told by officials that the nuclear agency would be able to examine any buildings it wished.
 
Keeping Reactors Running
 "We have nothing to hide," Song Rak Un, head of American affairs at the North Korean Foreign Ministry, told the reporters on Saturday. "Our intention is to allow inspection of any facility we have."
Choe Jong Sun, an official of the Ministry of Atomic Energy Industry, described the radiochemistry laboratory to the Caregie group and disclosed that the North Koreans had already conducted reprocessing experiments at Yongbyon, using spent fuel to produce "a little bit of plutonium for experimental purposes."
But when he was asked by Leonard Spector, head of the Carnegie Endowment's Nuclear Non-Proliferation Project, how much plutonium had been produced, he said "next to nothing." It would take six to nine kilograms, or 13 to 18 pounds, of plutonium to produce one weapon.
According to a report the Carnegie group issued this week, the North Korean officials also said that they had run into considerable troubles keeping their nuclear reactors running, suggesting that they have not yet built up a stockpile of spent fuel ready for conversion into plutonium. That contradicts Mr. Gates' recent testimony that at least one reactor in North Korea has been running continuously for several years.
 
3 Power Plants Planned
 In their filing to the agency, the North Koreans said they had four nuclear reactors currently running or under construction. One is an aging, small research reactor that has been under International Atomic Energy Agency inspection for 15 years. Another was described as a five-megawatt experimental nuclear power reactor at Yongbyon, which burns natural uranium -- easily mined in North Korea -- and is modified by graphite rather than expensive, imported "heavy water." Nearby is what the North Koreans said is a 50 megawatt reactor still under construction.
In addition North Korea said that it was constructing a 200-megawatt reactor in North Pyongan Province, in the northwestern corner of the coutnry near the border with China. It said that it hoped to build three 635-megawatt plants along the eastern coast. Those are believed to be plants that Pyongyang previously agreed to buy from the former Soviet Union.
But the deal has been delayed for years, apparently because of fears about the weapons project and because Russia is now demanding that North Korea pay for its purchases in scarce hard currency.
The report to the agency also said that North Korea currently runs several uranium mines and two centers for producing uranium concentrate, also known as "yellowcake."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
With Few Tools, Ueberroth Begins Mission in Riot Area

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 6

 BODY:
Peter V. Ueberroth, who was appointed last week by Mayor Tom Bradley to lead the rebuilding of the South-Central area, is full of ambitious ideas about luring industry back to the community, creating thousands of permanent jobs and giving new hope to residents who feel economically disenfranchised.
But for now, Mr. Ueberroth does not even have a telephone number. In fact, he said this week that he had only a skeletal staff, no specific commitments for government or private financing, few lines of communication to the city's minority leaders and only a vague notion of how to carry out his ideas. He was finally able to start moving into some donated office space in downtown Los Angeles late today, although it could be another day or two before the office is up and running. 
 More than anyone else, the 54-year-old Mr. Ueberroth is being looked to not just to help reopen stores and clear the charred rubble of what many residents here are referring to as "the rebellion," but to reverse a decadeslong decline in the economic opportunity available to the South-Central area's mostly black and Hispanic residents.
 
Vast Scope of Task
 Mr. Ueberroth is in many ways being asked to achieve what governments, community groups and corporations have failed to do in the years since the Watts riots of 1965 made clear the festering resentment of the city's blacks. It is, to say the least, a monumental undertaking for Mr. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, who gained prominence for his role in organizing the 1984 Summer Olympics, which came off nearly flawlessly.
His appointment to lead the rebuilding effort has been widely criticized by the leaders of the city's diverse and often fractious minority communities, who wonder whether a white Republican who lives in affluent Laguna Beach can fully understand their needs.
On Tuesday, Mr. Ueberroth agreed to a demand by Representative Maxine Waters, a black Democrat who represents much of the South-Central area, that he appoint as his second-in-command Brenda Shockley, a black lawyer who has been running an economic development program in the South-Central area, Ms. Waters said.
Even Mr. Ueberroth admits to some doubts about whether he will be able to rally the support necessary from both government and businesses to revitalize an area that was one of the nation's poorest urban communities even before being ravaged by looting, arson and violence.
"We don't want to raise false expectations and then not deliver," Mr. Ueberroth said at a meeting with a small group of reporters on Tuesday night. "These communities have had a lot of that over the years."
Mr. Ueberroth said he had spent his first days on the job crisscrossing the city and the nation, meeting with government officials and community leaders and flying to New York and Chicago to meet with corporate executives. He said hundreds of large companies, representing a wide array of industries, had been trying to get through to him with offers of help.
But he said he wanted to discourage corporate executives from thinking in terms of donations and to try to persuade them to make long-term commitments to the area's revival by locating new factories, stores or other enterprises there.
"I believe there are really substantial and responsible corporate citizens out there that wish to make contributions, but that's not what we're seeking," Mr. Ueberroth said. "We're seeking commitments long-term to an area that's been devastated. Part of that commitment is jobs, on a profitable basis, not a handout basis."
Mr. Ueberroth said he had heard estimates that 25,000 jobs had been lost, at least temporarily, because of the riots. But he said he believed those estimates were "very, very low." There has not yet been an official count of lost jobs or of what proportion of those losses might be permanent.
Mr. Ueberroth said his main goal was to attract companies that were not previously doing business in the area. Mr. Ueberroth said the rebuilding effort would depend to some extent on the ability of governments to offer companies tax incentives, funds for programs to train workers and other financial support.
