HEADLINE: Students Who Learn to Write Learn the Key to All Learning

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As educational consultants specializing in teaching writing, we were not surprised to read that, according to a Department of Education survey, "American children do not write much in school and when they do, they do it poorly" (news article, April 17). Having had the opportunity to put institute writing programs in hundreds of schools around the country, we have observed ways that curriculum and teaching contribute to poor writing skills in students.
Schools that spend three or four months of their school year coaching children on how to take short-answer, standardized reading tests will, obviously, have no time to teach writing, nor even to teach reading. 
 Even when these schools ask their children to write, they do just that -- ask them, but do not teach them. Under the guise of not wanting to stifle creativity, they prevent students from learning the developmental, systematic structures that must be practiced frequently and from kindergarten through high school.
Many of our nonwriting schools mirror the anti-intellectual ethos of our country, which looks for the quick and easy answer. Our children spend their school hours underlining, circling and bubbling in answers to questions likely to come from vapid, watered-down textbook material.
Fortunately, we have seen extraordinary changes in teaching and learning where writing is the unifier of the curriculum. We have seen that students can be taught to write and to write well by our experiences in such places as Kansas City, Mo.; Dade County, Fla; Spring Valley, N.Y., and Public School 46 in Brooklyn.
Furthermore, students who learn to write learn to read. Through writing, they explain what they have learned, they recreate new learning, they entertain their peers and themselves, they share ideas, beliefs and feelings and, above all, they build a sense of their own worth.
When we begin to value the writings of our students, rather than their multiple-choice test scores, as the hallmark of their achievement, our schools will produce a literate, intelligent thinking population that is fully capable of participating in the global economy coming in the 21st century.
 
EVELYN ROTHSTEIN, DIANE GESS
Nyack, N.Y., April 20, 1992

HEADLINE: The Talk of Seville;
In Expo Architecture, Mishmash Means Eclectic

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEVILLE, Spain

 BODY:
Imre Makovecz's Hungarian pavilion, widely regarded as the most inventive structure at Expo '92 here, soars free from the fair's architectural cacophony like some dizzy fantasy. Built from wood carved in folk styles and bearing a gray slate roof, it seems inspired by village churches but leaps beyond any one model with an exuberance that recalls the Catalan Antonio Gaudi.
Inside, the building's conceptual basis becomes clearer, with no loss of wit and style. The interior is divided, one portion symbolizing Hungary facing the West, with a simplified Baroque church front. Pass through that facade and one finds Hungary facing East, the wall exploding with undulating Slavic-style facades (more gray slate) and carved portals. 
 There is also a "Tree of Life" on the Western side, a jumble of roots and branches with a glass floor so that visitors can see the whole thing. The 22-minute tour is reinforced with pungent Hungarian folk music and vivid lighting and, on the Eastern side, a film and video show of the sort inescapable at this latest and most high-tech of international expositions.
 
Inevitable Diversity
 Ever since the first universal exposition in 1851 at the Crystal Palace in London, these fairs have been conceived as forums for technological achievement and advertisements for a utopian future. That most definitely includes architecture, and so the most ambitious world's fairs have always been intended as showcases for innovative buildings, landscaping and urban planning.
One trouble, however, is that with individual countries contributing their own pavilion designs, even the most stringent of guidelines cannot prevent a stylistic mishmash. In the age of high modernism, such jangling discrepancies contradicted the cool formalism on which modernist style was predicated.
Today's eclectic, post-modernist age means lots of junky ornamental froufrou, spangles and neon appliqued across what may be an utterly conventional neo-modernist box. If a country has tried to pinch its pennies, the result can be pretty mingy -- most embarrassingly for an American visitor, the United States pavilion and its decades-old geodesic domes.
But post-modernism can also mean wit and play and invention. And the stylistic diversity often contained within a single post-modernist structure makes the heterogeneity of a world's fair look like deliberate architectural principle.
"Diversity makes its own statement," said Gines Aparicio Soto, Expo's director general of projects and construction, in an interview. "We had some restrictions, but it is very difficult to put limits on creativity, especially in a time in which we have no single international style of architecture."
 
The High-Tech Prize
 Mr. Aparicio noted that the buildings at Expo, which opened on April 20, tended to be international or national. "I think the style that dominates is high-tech," he said, citing Nicholas Grimshaw's British pavilion. Expo organizers specified that fountains, pools and water walls proliferate to combat the southern Spanish heat both literally and psychologically. Mr. Grimshaw's building, itself a fairly anonymous (if ecologically sophisticated) high-tech construction, is graced with a particularly large, refreshing water wall by William Pye.
The prize for space-age architectural exotica, however, goes to Jean-Paul Viguier's French pavilion. At first it looks like a simple plaza with embedded lights, a floating, cooling roof and a single mirrored side wall several stories high. But there are secrets: the mirrored wall contains an exhibition highlighted by an ingenious scale model of separated sections of Paris. This is first seen beneath a glass floor, with a vertiginous effect of peering down through different parts of Paris at different distances. It turns out the model consists of one part facing upward and, stuck to its back, another part facing downward. The downward-facing part is reflected up by a mirror, creating the layered effect.
There is more: underneath the plaza is a mysterious pit, again done with mirrors. In it a film about the cosmos is projected, with eerie images in the darkened room doubled and redoubled. Visitors view the film either from the sides of the pit or from a moving walkway above it.
Although all the pavilions avail themselves of modern technology and practicality (gift shops and restaurants abound), some deliberately evoke traditional folk styles. Denmark, Norway and Finland are especially pleasing in this regard: elegant, simple buildings that speak clearly of their provenances. Tadao Ando's Japanese pavilion, billed as the world's largest wooden structure, has attracted attention, though its sheer size can seem overbearing.
Mr. Aparicio's favorite is the Moroccan pavilion, a gift from King Hassan II of Morocco to King Juan Carlos of Spain. It is intended to remain on the site, like 30 percent of all Expo structures, after the fair closes on Oct. 12 and was thus built with a greater richness of materials than some of the more overtly ephemeral constructs. The pavilion, designed by Michel Pinseau of France, blends ornate Moorish filigree, sweeping arches and chiseled stone pools with simple glass walls to enchanting effect. There is also an extensive formal garden.
Mr. Aparicio said that given the rapid shifts in the political life of Eastern Europe, the intentions and the designs of some pavilions from that part of the world had been altered. Even Hungary's design was changed in mid-planning. "It was originally supposed to be a glass box with live butterflies in it," Mr. Aparicio said.
 
Unifying Theme: Comfort
 As striking as many of the national pavilions may be, it is the overall layout and the attention to visitors' comforts that seems almost more impressive. Many of the Expo buildings (as opposed to the national pavilions) are distinctive, especially the cockeyed tentlike roof of Jose Miguel de la Prada Poole's Palenque, a breezy entertainment venue, or Gerardo Ayala's simply handsome Teatro Central, devoted to avant-garde events. The most appealing exploitation of the water theme is an undulating wall by the New York team of architects known as SITE. Its cascade effect, as in all the water walls, is obtained by a tiny angling, causing the falling water to gather in rippling sheets.
Mr. Aparicio is by training a civil engineer, and his deepest interest in the Expo constructions is their utility for Seville after October, post-Expo. In the long run, aside from the extra tourist income and national pride Expo is providing, its legacy will be a radical transformation of this lovely town into an international mecca. Cartuja Island, where Expo is situated, was until recently a flood plain for the Guadalquivir River. Now the river has been controlled upstream and opened up near Seville, where it had been blocked and stagnant. Riverside train tracks have been replaced by a combination esplanade and flood wall, soaring new bridges span the river and a ring of highways circles the city. There are 19 new hotels, whole new suburbs and an elegant high-speed train to Madrid.
All of Seville's social problems have hardly been solved. Perhaps the development, instead of energizing the local economy, will merely subvert Seville's charm.
But right now, late night in old Seville still finds balmy, orange-scented evening air, narrow streets, broad boulevards, bubbling fountains, strumming guitarists, stylish youths zipping by on roller skates and, everywhere, loving couples. If Seville can sustain this balance of new and old, international and regional, buoyant display and timeless beauty, Expo will have made its most important mark of all.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Imre Makovecz's Hungarian pavilion at Expo '92 in Seville, Spain. (Erica Lansner/Black Star for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Strike Over, Germans Pay;
Beyond Wage Accord, Fissures Haunt Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 7

 BODY:
The 10-day strike by public employees in Germany ended today, having made one thing clear: Germans may be united in fact, but they are far from it in spirit.
Western Germany's 2.3 million public employees settled for a 5.4 percent pay increase and a lump sum payment of up to $650, down from the 9.5 percent raise they had originally sought. [Page A6.] 
 But this strike was not so much about money as about the dark side of unification. Workers in the western part of the country walked off their jobs in part against the higher taxes they have had to pay for unification, and the inflation that it has caused.
Those in the east, who didn't strike this time, say they will later -- because they are still not paid the same wages that their colleagues in the west get and because they still want the fruits of unification that most of them have not yet been enable to enjoy.
The Government in Bonn is in disarray, and not only because Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher is resigning next week, after 18 years in the post. With unification, German foreign policy has lost much of its direction and sense of purpose, having achieved the goal it had sought above all others since the end of World War II.
But unity, it seems, brought not the end of postwar German history but the beginning of a range of new and unexpected problems. "A new orientation of German foreign policy was and is necessary," the Berliner Zeitung said in an editorial today, "not because political opponents are calling for it but because the world has changed dramatically."
The economic problems of the eastern part of Germany were so unexpectedly vast after unification that they threw the Government into a deficit of more than $27 billion and pushed the inflation rate above 4 percent -- small figures when compared with those of the United States and some of Bonn's European Community neighbors, but grating on a public grown accustomed to robust economic health.
So the Germans got what they were asking for and are already tired of paying for it.
The economic problems are made worse by a property law that put past claims of ownership ahead of future plans for investment, according to a range of public figures from former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt on down.
 
A Country Still Divided
 But perhaps more critical to the country's future, the strike has laid bare a wide gulf that still divides the two parts of Germany.
Where two and a half years ago demonstrators in East Berlin brought down the wall the Communists had built in 1961, strikers in West Berlin in effect erected it again during the 10 days of the strike.
The red-and-yellow elevated trains and the subways worked in the eastern part of the reunited capital, but, just as during the decades when the city was divided, people had to get out at Friedrichstrasse station, once the main crossing point between Communism and capitalism for the few people allowed to make that journey in the old days.
For most of the last 10 days, Berliners traveling from the eastern half of the city into the west had to get there by foot or by car or bicycle, leading to huge traffic jams and street scenes.
 
Post Offices Closed
 Most post offices in western Germany have also been closed for the last 10 days, but were still open in the eastern part of Berlin.
"I don't know why," said a clerk at the post office at Friedrichsfelde Ost, a district about five miles east of where the wall once divided the city.
It certainly wasn't out of a feeling of solidarity with their western colleagues, said Wolfgang Schumacher, a bus driver who was waiting to begin his route at the station a few feet away.
"I work on this side for 40 hours a week for 60 percent of what a driver on the western side can make," he said. "Over there, they only have to work 38 1/2 hours a week and with 10 years of service a driver can easily make 3,500 marks a month." The sum is equal to about $2,150.
"We're not striking now, but we will be soon, because we want 80 percent of what they get on the western side sooner than the Mayor has promised to give it to us."
 
Parity in Stages
 Mayor Eberhard Diepgen had promised to bring public service workers in eastern half of the city up to 100 percent of what those in western Berlin get, but only in stages.
Rents and wages in the eastern part of Germany remain far below those in the west, a legacy of the difficult transition from decades of Communism to unfamiliar and expensive capitalism that began with economic unification in July 1990.
The streets in the eastern sections of the city today were, unusually, cleaner looking than those in western Berlin. Those looked, to a New Yorker, disconcertingly familiar -- littered with bits of paper and other rubbish instead of spotlessly clean.
"Berlin is facing huge problems," said David Anderson, an American who is director of the Aspen Institute in Berlin, "and the Germans have only begun to realize the full implications of unification."

HEADLINE: Paying Budget Piper;
A Constitutional Amendment to Avert Deficits Would Involve Painful Steps

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
An embattled Congress and angry voters are rushing to embrace a balanced-budget amendment, but hardly anyone is talking about the long-term economic complications it would probably produce.
Because the Federal Government spends $4 for every $3 it takes in, any serious effort to balance the budget would necessarily involve a disconcerting array of bitter measures that are likely to include raising taxes and putting tough ceilings on Medicaid and Medicare spending. In straining to balance the Federal budget, Washington might also slash aid to the states, forcing them to cut services or raise taxes in turn. 
 What is more, cutting spending and raising taxes to bring down the Federal deficit, which is expected to near $400 billion this year, could weaken the nation's already sluggish economic growth.
Still, many economists who opposed the amendment idea when it began circulating in the mid-1980's, now support it because they have concluded that something more than politics as usual -- something more than budget agreements and the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law -- is needed.
 
Pain of Amendment
 Pain, they say, is inevitable whenever people living beyond their means are forced to tighten their belts. More important, many say, if an amendment forces the White House and Congress to eliminate the Federal deficit, this would bring down long-term interest rates and spur home building and business investment.
"As year after year drags on and we have failed to solve the deficit problem, one has to face that failure and maybe an amendment is the way to face it," said Benjamin M. Friedman, a Harvard economics professor who has written extensively about the dangers of the Federal deficit.
Economists who support the amendment confess to one lurking worry: that the politicians will use it as a gimmick. The fear is that once lawmakers vote for such an amendment, they can boast that they vigorously support balanced budgets, while shunning any serious efforts to reduce the deficit until the amendment is ratified later this decade.
 
No Help for Deadlocks
 After Congress and the White House have for more than a decade been unable to agree on how to end the deficit, many analysts wonder why a constitutional amendment would magically enable the two sides to agree. Many people fear the two sides will stick doggedly to their positions, amendment or not, with the Republicans wanting to slash spending and the Democrats leaning toward raising taxes.
One criticism of the proposed amendments is that they do not provide a mechanism to resolve such deadlocks. The competing amendments sponsored by Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, and Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, would allow Congress to waive the balanced budget requirement in any given year if 60 percent of all the members of Congress approve. But there is no guarantee they would approve such a waiver even in the event of a stalemate.
Legal scholars fear that if the amendment is approved and then ignored, the Constitution would be cheapened. The amendment, many analysts say, might not cause the Administration and Congress to abandon their hobby of budget gimmickry, like using optimistic economic assumptions, placing certain programs off-budget or moving the cost of certain programs to future years.
The amendment "could make the situation worse by encouraging even more gimmickry and fraudulent budgeting," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior economists at DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting concern in Lexington, Mass. "It is not possible to legislate leadership, courage and caring -- these are the bottom-line reasons why the deficit problem has not been addressed until now."
Mr. Chimerine opposes the amendment, saying it would divert the nation's attention away from trying to improve productivity and competitiveness. He said that if Washington sought to reduce its deficit to zero over three years, that would reduce the nation's economic growth by 1 percent a year.
Other economists oppose the bill on the ground that it may tie the Government's hands if the nation falls into recession. They feared that an amendment might, for instance, limit Washington's ability to pay unemployment benefits.
Some economists say that the proposed amendment should be accompanied by legislation that would require automatic spending cuts or tax increases if Congress and the White House failed to agree on eliminating the deficit. Others predicted that in the event of deadlocks, the White House and Congress might turn to the courts to resolve their disputes.
Laurence H. Tribe, a constitutional law expert at Harvard Law School, suggested that no matter what the courts did would create problems. On one hand, he said, the courts might consider the amendment unenforceable "because they might treat it as hortatory and advisory, in which case it would generate still more cynicism." On the other hand, he said, if the courts decided to enforce the amendment "it would implicate them in the extremely thorny problem of budget management in ways that would be hard to reconcile with any sense of institutional limits on the Federal judiciary."
In Congressional testimony on Wednesday, Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, said a balanced-budget amendment was needed because future generations were going to have to pay for the massive deficits Washington is accumulating today. "The interest of future generations are not adequately being protected by the representatives of current voters," he said. "Future interests require the protection of a constitutional amendment."
He hinted that Medicare and Medicaid might be targets for saving money, saying that "people who are knowledgeable about the Federal budget appreciate that the deficit cannot be addressed seriously unless the growth of mandatory programs is slowed." He noted that Medicaid costs grew by more than 15 percent a year over the past decade, and Medicare costs by more than 10 percent a year.
His testimony noted, for instance, that if Medicare hospital insurance costs were capped so that they rose by no more than the inflation rate that would reduce the deficit by a total of $72 billion from 1993 and 1997.
With many legislators saying the amendment has a strong chance of passing this year, economists stress that it is important to start whittling down the deficit now. They say that if the deficit remains at astronomic levels the year before the amendment takes effect, then Draconian spending cuts or tax rises would have to be implemented to balance the budget.
"If the amendment takes effect with the deficit still in the hundreds of billions of dollars," Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the lawmakers this week, "The Congress would be faced with the Hobson's choice of enforcing the new rule and inducing a deep recession or waiving the rule from the start, which would clearly be an inauspicious beginning for the new era."

HEADLINE: ACCORD ON LIMITS ON GAS EMISSIONS IS SAID TO BE NEAR

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 7

 BODY:
Hoping to break a longstanding deadlock between the United States and Europe, negotiators were closing in today on a compromise that would limit industrialized countries' emissions of gases tied to global warming, according to officials involved in the talks.
The proposal, circulating among delegates in draft form, would be a centerpiece of the Earth Summit meeting next month in Rio de Janeiro. Failure to come to an agreement in the preliminary talks here would seriously undermine the success of the conference. 
 Under the proposal, industrialized countries would limit emissions of greenhouse gases, with the aim of capping them at 1990 levels, a point the Administration has long resisted. But, yielding to Washington's position, the draft does not set a deadline or timetable for reaching the goal.
 
Shifts by Both Sides
 Instead, it calls for industrialized countries merely to recognize that returning to "earlier levels" of emissions by the end of the decade would contribute to the long-term objective of stabilizing the amounts of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere.
Both sides are thus prepared to modify their positions, with the Europeans seeming to yield more in practical terms.
The draft treaty would also call for a framework, governing body and long-term process for continually assessing and responding to climate change as its nature becomes clearer in coming decades.
 
Catastrophic Warming
 The tentative deal was seen as unlikely to satisfy any parties fully. Environmentalists denounced it as unacceptably weak, even as a first step. Spokesmen for the coal and electric utility industries, which have opposed any restrictions on emissions, said yesterday they would not comment on the draft compromise.
The treaty would be signed by heads of government at Rio.
Scientists who are advising the talks here say that if the heat-trapping greenhouse gases continue to build up in the atmosphere at present rates, the earth's climate will warm by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century, with possibly catastrophic effects on the world's climate. Carbon dioxide, the most important of the gases, is emitted by the burning of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas, the energy underpinnings of the industrial economy. The United States emits more than 20 percent of the world's carbon dioxide.
The text of the draft circulating today said the compromise on emissions would "demonstrate" that the industrialized countries are taking the lead in working toward the long-term objective of stabilizing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations at safe levels.
The prospective compromise on emission of the gases bridges the long-held positions of the European Community and the United States.
The community had argued for action to firmly halt carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. The Bush Administration insisted that for the United States to enact limits on emissions were unnecessary because energy-efficiency measures already being taken by the United States would nearly achieve the desired level in practice. The United States had resisted being forced to adopt targets and timetables it was not sure it could meet without causing economic harm.
In the compromise under discussion today, the Europeans would also accede to an American preference that all heat-trapping greenhouse gases, not just carbon dioxide, be included in the emissions agreement. The United States believes that its performance is improved when all heat trapping gases are taken into consideration.
Though the compromise aims for a return to 1990 levels of greenhouse gas emissions, something the United Staes had opposed, it would not actually set a deadline for doing so. According to the text, it calls for the industrialized countries to report periodically on their actions and results in limiting emissions, "with the aim" of returning to 1990 levels.
 
Treaty 'Is Now a Shell'
 The parties, according to a separate paragraph of the text, would "recognize" that returning to "earlier levels" of emissions by the end of this decade would contribute to the treaty's long-term objective of stabilizing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations. The years 2000 and 1990 are not directly linked.
Some environmentalists attacked the compromise on the ground that it appeared to allow governments too much latitude and room to wiggle out.
"It contains no meaningful commitment to reduce greenhouse gases," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "At best, it provides a procedure which could lead to real commitments in the future."
Others were stronger in their critcism.
"The climate treaty is now a shell that will allow continued degradation of the global atmosphere," said Richard Mott, treaties officer of the World Wildlife Fund. "Faced with an ultimatum from the U.S., the Europeans have abandoned their promise to include binding commitments in the treaty."
 
Aid to the Third World
 The compromise was reportedly emerging from intensive negotiations by a steering commmittee, representing 25 key nations and a representative of small island states. They are part of the larger, 130-member Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Climate Change, a body that reports to the United Nations General Assembly. The emerging compromise must still be approved by the full committee before the concluding round of treaty talks ends tomorrow.
Moreover, still to be resolved was the equally critical issue of the way in which industrialized countries will provide financial and technological aid to third-world countries in attacking the problem of climate change. The third-world countries' greenhouse-gas emissions are much lower than those of the industrialized world. But they are expected to grow rapidly in the decades ahead, and the draft treaty requires developing countries to undertake national programs for limiting the gases.

HEADLINE: Finland in $3 Billion Deal for 64 McDonnell Douglas Combat Jets

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Finland, no longer constrained by Soviet pressure to tailor its military strength to an international image of neutrality, is about to rebuild its air force with a fleet of American fighter aircraft.
The Finnish Defense Ministry said Wednesday that it was placing a $3 billion order with McDonnell Douglas Corporation for 64 FA-18 Hornet fighter-bombers, Finland's first purchase of American combat planes. 
 A spokesman for McDonnell Douglas described the order today as a "very important sale for the company." The FA-18 was chosen over four rival aircraft, and delivery is expected to begin in 1995.
"Until now, Finland's neutrality made defense procurement diffcult," a Finnish diplomat said. "But from now on, Finland will defend herself by her own means."
 
Questions of Security
 The purchase of such a large number of fighter planes by a country facing severe economic problems raises questions about Finland's security concerns. Although the collapse of the Soviet Union freed Finland from the neutral stance imposed by Moscow, it also stirred fears in Helsinki about the stability of Russia and the safety of the former Soviet arsenal.
"If you're Finland, you aren't just located anywhere," said Paul Goble, a former State Department specialist on the Soviet Union who is now a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "If you're Finland, you're located next to the Kola Peninsula, one of the most heavily armed places on earth."
Mr. Goble said that former Soviet military forces withdrawing from Europe are being "stacked up" along with weapons and equipment in the area bordering Finland.
"For Finland, there is a very specific threat," Mr. Goble said. "If something goes very wrong in Russia, one of the things that could happen is not the emergence of a right-wing central Government but the development of a local warlord situation."
The sudden expansion and updating of Finland's air force is symbolic first of all, he said, "and second, it is an insurance policy."
 
Used in Persian Gulf War
 The FA-18 Hornet, introduced into the United States Navy in 1983, serves as both a combat and attack plane and was used extensively in the Persian Gulf war. Finnish officials said one attraction of the plane was that it has two engines rather than one, an advantage when an aircraft flies missions in a harsh climate or over rough terrain.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee and House Foreign Affairs Committee have been notified of the deal on the FA-18's because of its size and political significance, Congressional aides said. Finland has already signed a letter of intent on the purchase, and no challenges to the sale are anticipated.
Under the old formula, one-third of the Finnish Air Force planes were Soviet Migs, one third came from neutral countries, mostly Sweden, and the rest were bought from the West, mainly Britain.
Now Helsinki is apparently seeking a long-term relationship with one American company. McDonnell Douglas also sells the Finns most of the national airline's passenger aircraft.
 
Finland to Assemble Planes
 A majority of Finland's FA-18's -- 57 full combat aircraft and seven trainer versions -- will be assembled in Finland under an industrial cooperation agreement between McDonnell Douglas and the Valmet Corportion of Halli, Finland. The first seven planes will be built in St. Louis and the rest will be assembled from kits by Valmet. Additional work will go to a variety of Finnish subcontractors, according to McDonnell Douglas.
The only other European nation whose air force flies the FA-18 is Spain, which has 72, the company said.
The United States Navy and Marine Corps have about 1,000 of the planes. Canada has 132 and Australia 75. Kuwait has ordered 40 and Switzerland is negotiating for 34, according to McDonnell Douglas.
A Finnish Embassy spokesman said the other aircraft considered were: the American F-16, the French Mirage 2000-5, the Russian Mig-29 and a new Swedish plane -- the JAS-39 Gripen made by Saab-Scania A.B. Sweden had hoped that Finland would be the plane's first foreign buyer.

HEADLINE: Bosnia's Besieged Government Near Disintegration

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 7

 BODY:
With exploding Serbian mortar shells and automatic gunfire rattling their office windows and sometimes shattering them, the dozen or so officials running this rapidly disappearing country are more like a panic-seized crisis committee than a government.
"The Prime Minister is pacing the halls and doesn't know what to do," said a Muslim Slav woman standing in a bustling hallway in the republic's nerve center, the Presidency Building. 
 Here, President Alija Izetbegovic, a moderate Muslim Slav, makes decisions night and day with the heads of the republic's teetering military and security operations.
"There is no policy," said a senior presidential adviser, Izet Serdarovic. "There is no long term. Decisions are made each second as events dictate."
 
Losing Hope in Outside World
 For months, Bosnia and Herzegovina put its faith in the European Community and the United States to support its independence from Yugoslavia and its territorial integrity. But as Serbian guerrillas backed by Serbia and the Yugoslav Army have consumed more of the republic's territory with each passing day, the Sarajevo Government has lost almost all hope in the outside world.
"Bosnia and Herzegovina's Government played by the rules set down by the international community," a Western diplomat said. "They do not deserve this fate."
Ejup Ganic, a Presidency member, said: "What does the United States want of us? The West has only given us words and promises to apply pressure. Nothing else."
"We are surrounded," he said. "We've got limited amounts of food and a limited number of weapons. We cannot hold out indefinitely."
A land of high mountains populated by 1.9 million Muslim Slavs, 750,000 Roman Catholic Croats and 1.4 million Eastern Orthodox Serbs, Bosnia and Herzegovina was recognized by the United States and European Community as an independent country last month.
Most of the republic's Serbs oppose having an international border separating them from their 7.1 million kinsmen in Serbia.
 
Threats by West Ignored
 Serbia's rulers and their guerrilla proxies have ignored threats by Western countries to isolate Serbia politically and economically if the land grab in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not halted.
The Serbs' territorial conquest has left hundreds of people dead or wounded and driven about 500,000 from their homes. It has also left this country on the brink of economic anarchy.
Most Serbian ministers and administrators have abandoned the Government, leaving huge gaps in chains of responsibility. Worse, Serbian policemen have set up parallel police forces and driven out the legitimate law-enforcement authorities over most of the republic.
Bosnia and Herzegovina's "army," a popular-defense force made up of Muslim Slavs, Croats and many Serbs, has been thrown together so hastily that its troops wear sticker-paper emblems.
"Forty kilometers outside the city, there are men with no uniforms or emblems," said Mirsad Tokaca, a spokesman for Sarajevo's police department. "We have problems with criminals in our ranks. We have war profiteers, and there are people waging their own private wars. But we are fighting to deal with this."
The capture of a dozen armored cars and other weaponry has slightly improved the Bosnian forces' firepower, but it is still no match for the Serbs' arsenal, including tanks to multiple-rocket launchers supplied by the Yugoslav Army.
"The defense of Sarajevo is really the work of two local commanders," said Zlatko Lagumdzija, vice president of the republic's largest opposition party, the Social Democrats. "Both are convicted criminals who did their time and volunteered for the territorial defense."
"They take their orders from a guy who certainly arrested them five or six times," he said. "They're on the same side now, and we can thank them for being able to sit here in some kind of security."
Outside the Presidency Building, armed security men lurk behind trees and sand-bag barriers, staying out of the gun scopes of Serbian snipers perched on a hillside several hundred yards away.
On Wednesday, even a United Nations Under Secretary General, Marrack Goulding, came under sniper fire as he toured the burned-out hulks of buildings in Sarajevo left by days of Serbian bombardments.
 
Much Territory Lost
 Five weeks of Serbian attacks have left Mr. Izetbegovic and his forces in control of only a fraction of Bosnia and Herzegovina's territory. Serbian gunmen at barricades block normal food and medicine deliveries throughout the republic and have trapped thousands of people in several Sarajevo suburbs for more than two weeks.
Serbian leaders claim 70 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina's territory for a "Serbian Republic" despite the fact that Serbs here make up only 31 percent of the population. The Serbian leaders are also insisting on the partition of Sarajevo, whose population is more than half Muslim-Slav.
"It is the policy of the Serbs to rip apart the multi-ethnic social fabric here, to turn Serbs against their neighbors," said a senior Yugoslav journalist whose life has been threatened by the Serbian leadership. "They want Muslim Slavs and Croats to turn on the Serbs. They want to make life together here an impossibility."
Administratively, the Sarajevo Government is severely handicapped. The country lacks its own currency, passports and even an accurate roll of its citizenry. Sarajevo has no tax-collecting ability and no postal service.
 
Communications Disrupted
 Shelling of the capital on Saturday and Sunday left the Presidency itself with no telephone lines.
Communications disruptions have often forced government leaders and European Community mediators to negotiate with representatives of the pro-Serbian army over television and radio hookups, and amateur ham radio operators provide the Government's only communications link with most of the republic.
"Absolutely nothing functions," Mr. Lagumdzija said. "The banks work, but they haven't got any cash."
"The payment system doesn't exist," he said, "so practically everyone is working voluntarily."
A presidential adviser, who asked not to be identified, said: "Right now, the key problem is the most fundamental problem -- control of territory. This is a struggle for survival, and the only way we can win is with international support."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
From Riots of 60's to Riots of the 90's, a Frustrating Search to Heal a Nation

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 7

 BODY:
The battles in the streets of Los Angeles have ended, and the political battles have begun. At their core is the nation's most famous report on urban violence, which looked at burning cities a quarter century ago and called for a major Government effort to heal them.
"Only a greatly enlarged commitment to national action -- compassionate, massive and sustained, backed by the will and resources of the most powerful nation on this earth -- can shape a future that is compatible with the historic ideals of American society," concluded the Kerner Commission, convened by President Lyndon B. Johnson to examine the causes of riots that shook more than 150 American cities in 1967. 
 Since then everything has changed, and nothing has changed. Today, the Kerner Commission serves as a monument to a more optimistic era when the nation felt it had the will and the ability to heal its urban ills.
 
Era of Optimism Is Just a Memory
 "There's a fundamental difference in the attitude of the nation," said Anthony Downs, a Brookings Institution fellow who was one of the authors of the report. "The report was written at a time of rapidly rising living standards when people believed almost anything was possible. We no longer have the optimism we had then, and the kind of commitment to improving America's domestic life is totally absent from the present leadership."
In the wake of the riots in Los Angeles, President Bush and his spokesman Marlin Fitzwater have set the tone for the political aftermath by attributing the riots in part to the social programs of the 1960's and 1970's. But a quarter century later, a larger question looms about the Kerner Commission report: If that era of optimism, prosperity and commitment has left the nation with cities mired in poverty, violence and despair, what is the current environment likely to produce?
Headed by Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois, the 11-member panel, officially known as the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, was appointed by President Johnson July 27, 1967, after major riots in Newark and Detroit.
 
Panel's Warning On Split Society
 The report found that "white racism" was the underlying cause of the problems of the ghettos. And, in its most famous line, it warned that the United States ran the risk of becoming "two societies, one black, one white -- separate but unequal."
"For a good while we made progress on virtually every front in regard to the report," said former Senator Fred Harris, an Oklahoma Democrat who was on the commission. "But the progress slowed in the mid-70's and then stopped, and now we've begun to go backward in many ways. And I think there are very serious consequences for the path we've taken."
Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany, and the commission's associate director for program research, said the report was essentially an endorsement of the social activism of the Great Society. Its policy recommendations centered on four areas: jobs, housing, education and welfare.
President Johnson, suspicious the commission was being critical of him, declined to endorse its findings.
The report called for building six million housing units for low- and moderate-income people within five years. The nation did not meet that goal, but the report did lead to a major increase in Federal housing that produced 1.6 million units from 1970 and 1973.
The report also helped produce the landmark open housing legislation of 1968. There was also momentum for subsidized housing for low-income tenants, under which Federal funds were used to help them pay for privately owned housing. The momentum continued until the Reagan Administration worked to reverse it in the 1980's.
In jobs, the commission called for the creation of 2 million jobs over three years, half in Government and half in the private sector. The recommendations helped spur a series of public employment programs. By the peak under the Carter Administration in 1978, programs such as the Public Service Employment (PSE) program of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA) were providing 750,000 jobs.
The programs, which were at times dogged by allegations of waste, were entirely eliminated in the Reagan Administration.
The report also advocated spending for urban schools, remedial and adult education and school desegregation. And it provided proposals for welfare, most of which supported greater availability of benefits. It did not address the potential problems of welfare dependency.
 
Push for Cutbacks In Reagan Years
 Over all, the tide for urban aid began to turn in 1978 when President Jimmy Carter's proposed three-year, $30 billion urban plan was rejected by Congress. The mood changed completely in 1980 when the Reagan Administration cut real spending for grants and aid to local and state government by 11 percent. Since 1980, Federal direct aid to cities has been slashed by 60 percent.
To many critics, liberals and conservatives, the main failing in the report and the era was an inability to foresee negative consequences of welfare dependency.
"There was an explosion of the welfare rolls during this period and that coincided with the emergence of the underclass," said Mickey Kaus, a senior editor at The New Republic, who is completing a book on welfare and social policy.
But Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University, whose book "Rethinking Social Policy: Race, Poverty and the Underclass (Harvard University Press, 1992), said welfare policies, while deeply flawed, cannot be blamed for the riots in Los Angeles.
"You've got to remember, Watts occurred before all these things happened," he said. "Detroit erupted in 1919. Racial and ethnic conflict in the U.S. wasn't invented along with the welfare state."
He said, rather than a profligate rush to throw money at urban problems, the report helped produce a relatively modest array of programs targeted at the urban poor that in the end did not go far enough to satisfy their proponents and provided targets for their critics.
 
The Racial Division Obscures Answers
 One of the report's most famous and controversial findings was its conclusion that: "White racism is essentially responsible for the explosive mixture which has been accumulating in our cities since the end of World War II."
To some critics, the emphasis on racism, in both the report and the national civil rights debate, has obscured the degree to which the answers to the problems of the ghettos must come from within.
"The assumption was that white America was the problem and therefore white America was the solution," said Robert Woodson, a black who heads the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington, which calls for conservative, self-help solutions to inner-city problems. "It set up the proposition that the destiny of black America rested with what white America did."
Representative Gary Franks of Connecticut, the only black Republican in Congress, said welfare dependency, crime and drugs are far more of a threat to the urban poor than white racism.
But civil rights leaders say the case of Rodney G. King shows how pervasive and how misunderstood racism remains.
Earl Shinhoster, southeast regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the commission was not talking about whites as bigots but of an institutionalized system content to allow all the economic, social and educational advantages factors that produce success to flow away from the ghettos.
"Rather than an individual in a sheet and hood, we're dealing with a system that places a value and a value system on individuals and on groups," he said.
In 1968, President Lyndon Johnson appointed the head of the N.A.A.C.P., Roy Wilkins, to the commission.
This week, after Mr. Fitzwater blamed the social policies of the 1960's and '70's for the riots in Los Angeles, the current N.A.A.C.P. president, Benjamin Hooks, responded: "That's just a cavalier, irresponsible, irrational, right-wing, Republican no-answer to a serious problem. It's beneath the dignity of the White House to do that."
The exchange reflects the degree to which race has become perhaps the most explosive weapon in electoral politics.
"I don't think politics has dealt honestly with race in 25 years," said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey. "Republicans have used race in a divisive way to get votes, speaking in code words to targeted audiences. Democrats have essentially ignored self-destructive behavior of parts of the minority population and covered that self-destructive behavior in a cloak of silence and self-denial."
 
Urban Problems Back Into Politics
 Since the report come out, the status of many blacks has changed for the better. In households headed by a married couple, the median income for blacks has gone from 68 percent of whites in 1967 to 84 percent in 1990. But, reflecting the breakdown of the black family, for all blacks, the median family income was 59 percent of the white family income income in 1966 and was 56 percent in 1989.
Experts say the disparity reflects one way in which the commission's most famous line fails to describe fully the reality of American life today.
"The great line about the two nations, that's not what happened," said Professor Nathan. "Instead, there's been a bifurcation and trifurcation and fragmentation of the black and Hispanic communities which has left the underclass behind."
Many analysts say that instead of the two nations talked of in the report, the past two decades have seen substantial progress by many blacks and an increasingly visible and troubled, but numerically shrinking remnant left behind.
For those left behind in the inner cities, nearly all the changes since the Kerner report have been for the worse. More jobs and influence have moved out to the suburbs, which now provide the largest group of voters in a Presidential race. From 1970 to 1990 more than four million whites left the nation's big cities.
Drugs, gangs and and guns are a factor in ghetto life to a degree that no one imagined 25 years ago. In 1960, 20 percent of all black children were living in fatherless families; now the figure is 60 percent. Economic growth under the Bush Administration will be lower than at any time since World War II.
 
A New Approach Is Called For
 Mr. Bradley said that what is needed is a new approach to problems of the inner city that borrow ideas from the left and right.
"There are some elements of what was begun in the late '60's and early '70's that clearly work," he said. "There are some that haven't worked. If we're serious about dealing with these problems we have to take that which works, both liberal ideas and conservative ones, and invest them with their full potential. We have to be clear that the answer to injustice is not mob violence. But the answer to injustice is not ignoring the conditions."
Representative John Lewis, Democrat of George, one of the leaders of the civil rights movement of the 1960's, said what the nation does not need is another Kerner report for the 90's.
"We've been down that road," he said. "We need to take actions that will give people hope. If we don't, I fear for our future."

HEADLINE: After Long Wait, New Boston Garden Planned

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 7

 BODY:
It's playoff time, and Red Auerbach fired up his cigar this morning, a gesture that generations of basketball fans have come to associate with the moment the Boston Celtics clinch another victory.
But Mr. Auerbach was standing outside the Boston Garden, not inside on its ancient parquet floor. He was there to celebrate an even bigger triumph -- the announcement that after 25 years of blundering, bickering and Yankee parsimony, Boston will finally have a modern sports arena, a new Boston Garden. 
 The $160 million building will be financed by an unlikely consortium of three local banks, signifying the first major sign of optimism about New England's economy after four years of recession.
"We went from a miracle to a nightmare and this is the morning after," said Ira Jackson, a senior vice president of the Bank of Boston, one of the three banks that will evenly split $120 million in loans to Delaware North Companies Inc., owner of the Garden and the Boston Bruins hockey team, for the new arena. "The region is saying we're back," Mr. Jackson said.
 
City's Spiritual Heart
 Construction on the new arena, on a site adjacent to the present Garden, will begin next year and is scheduled to be finished before the start of the fall hockey and basketball seasons in 1995.
"It's great, because the Boston Garden is not just a building, it's a shrine," Mr. Jackson said. Sixteen National Basketball Association championship banners won by the Celtics hang from its ceiling, along with five Stanley Cup banners won by the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League. The Garden was also where John F. Kennedy spoke the night before he won the 1960 Presidential election.
With this combination of sports and politics, the two passions of Boston, the Garden is something of the spiritual heart of the city, more important to many Bostonians than august institutions like the Boston Symphony.
The other two banks participating in the loan are the Fleet Bank of Massachusetts, a subsidiary of the Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group, whose headquarters are in Providence, R.I., and the Shawmut National Corporation of Hartford.
 
Region Ready to Reinvest
 Since 1988 New England has lost 10 to 12 percent of its jobs, in the worst economic slump since the Depression in the 1930's, and the region's banks, saddled with huge losses from bad real estate loans, had virtually stopped making new loans.
But the three banks' decision to back the new Boston Garden, made only in the last few weeks, "shows they have regained confidence in themselves, and the region is ready to reinvest in itself," Mr. Jackson said.
Bankers and city officials alike expressed pride today that this will be a New England venture, without government funds, outside American banks or Japanese capital -- unlike new arenas under construction in Phoenix, Chicago or Tampa, Fla.
Last December the only banks interested in financing the new arena were Fuji Bank and Tokyo Trust, both of Japan, according to Lawrence C. Moulter, president of the New Boston Garden Corporation, which also is owned by Delaware North.
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, a former college basketball star who once had a tryout with the Celtics, said he was pleased not only that the new Garden would lift the region's economy but also that "it will be done by our own banks."
 
700 Construction Jobs
 Mr. Flynn and Gov. William F. Weld, who both attended this morning's announcement ceremony, estimated that building the new Garden would create 700 construction jobs, at a time when huge numbers of construction workers have been laid off here.
It will also provide Boston's first large modern building for rock concerts and conventions, which they estimated would generate $350 million a year in new spending.
The old Garden, built in 1928, is a grimy structure without air-conditioning or escalators.
Mr. Auerbach joked about it today. "I've been here since 1950 and we always had a competitive edge," he said. "Lousy dressing rooms, the heat off in winter, too hot in June, all the dead spots on the floor. Now all our advantages are going to be gone, so I have mixed emotions about this."
The new arena will be built just behind the old Garden, above an underground parking garage and railroad tracks going into a new North Station.
While the new Garden will certainly be modern, it may still not be comfortable for visiting basketball teams. "The old parquet floor comes with us," said Mr. Moulter.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Boston basketball and hockey fans, as well as construction workers and business leaders, received good news yesterday with the announcement that three local banks will finance a new $160 million Boston Garden. All were on hand to listen outside the old arena. (Evan Richman for The New York Times)

Companies

The alliance will unite two groups, one with General Instrument and M.I.T., the other with Zenith Electronics and A.T.& T. [Page D1.] 
 A big increase in airline bookings of business travelers for full coach fares has followed American's fare restructuring. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Ecological Plea From Executives

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 7

 BODY:
Hoping to influence the outcome of next month's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, a group of powerful international business leaders, including top American executives, called today for greater environmental awareness from governments and private businesses.
The group said business executives had to start addressing environmental issues to survive. 
 The group, organized by a maverick Swiss billionaire, Stephan Schmidheiny, issued a report today called "Changing Course," the result of more than 20 months of debate in the United States, Europe and Japan.
 
Linking Environment to Business
 The report argues that environmental and business efficiency are inextricably linked and that the most successful companies in the future will be those that are most "eco-efficient," because good ecological behavior uses fewer resources, generates less waste and pollution and produces more profits.
In what is likely to be the most controversial proposition, the group proposes changes in use and prices of energy. It proposes a value-added tax on energy -- as the European Community wants -- and an end to price subsidies for coal and electricity in many countries and to tax breaks for travel such as commuting.
The group also embraces a longstanding demand of environmentalists by recommending that the prices of all goods and services gradually be adjusted to reflect environmental costs -- the cost of production, use, recycling and disposal. Because such costs were not integrated in prices by government and business in the past, it says, industrialization has generally been characterized by depletion of resources and high levels of pollution.
 
Report Given to Bush
 Mr. Schmidheiny and other corporate chiefs gave a copy of the report to President Bush on Monday. Several chief executives at the presentation in Geneva today said they had pressed Mr. Bush for the United States to take a leading role in Rio.
"Our message to the President was that we hoped U.S. leadership will be reflected in what happens in Rio," said Frank Popoff, the president and chief executive of the Dow Chemical Company.
The group stopped short of saying they had urged the President to attend the United Nations-sponsored Rio summit, which is expected to approve broad actions to create fundamental changes in world economic and environmental behavior.
"Essentially we told President Bush, 'You have allies in a camp where you may not have expected them, that is, allies who support more environmental efficiency,' " Mr. Schmidheiny said.
Members of the group, which consists of 48 leading industrialists and is called the Business Council for Sustainable Development, plan to attend the Rio Earth Summit next month to promote their ideas and present a declaration signed by all of them.
It is the first time such high-level business chiefs have raised their voice as a group in the worldwide environmental debate.
"It has been a pioneering effort," said Mr. Schmidheiny of the work of the group, which includes such American chief executives as Kenneth Derr of Chevron, Paul O'Neill of Alcoa, Edgar Woolard of Du Pont, and Samuel Johnson, chairman of Johnson Wax.
Participants from Japan are Akira Miki, chairman of Nippon Steel; Shinroku Morohashi, chairman of Mitsubishi, and Yutaka Kume, president of Nissan Motor. From Europe, the list includes Carl Hahn of Volkswagen and Lodewyk van Wachem of Royal Dutch Shell.
Study of energy use in the former Soviet Union, the United States and Japan shows that low energy prices make consumers less concerned about the efficiency of products, the report says, adding that "the time has come for energy prices to reflect full environmental and economic costs."
The council argues that business executives are under a rising tide of pressures from government regulations, laws, environmental groups, stockholders, employees, consumers, banks and insurance companies.
"Banks are more willing to lend to clean companies, and insurance companies are more prone to cover clean companies," Mr. Schmidheiny said.
Mr. Schmidheiny, who is 45 years old, has sizable interests in Swiss makers of scientific instruments and watches, and in engineering and trading companies. He founded the council in the summer of 1990 after he was approached by Maurice Strong, a Canadian millionaire who is the secretary general of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio.
Mr. Schmidheiny said Mr. Strong had asked him to provide the business perspective for the conference and to stimulate business interest around the world. Since then the Swiss businessman has traveled the globe and met with 15 heads of state and many business leaders on his "mission of common sense."
 
'Not Just a Fad'
 "It takes not much imagination to see that environmental concern is not just a fad, but a serious trend," he said in an interview today. "It will shape the future of our business, and to learn to understand it and shape it is really in our interest."
Mr. Schmidheiny and other members of the council said they were convinced that changes would come as a result of environmental awareness. "We have two options: either we resist and we will suffer, or we anticipate the changes and we will have more profits and more personal satisfaction," he said.
By going on the offensive rather than resist change, he argues, business leaders "will have the chance to promote self-regulation, provided we do it in time, we do it convincingly and in a transparent way. If we fail to do it in time, we face government regulations under pressure from the public."
Mr. Popoff of Dow Chemical said that United States Government support for the agreements to be proposed in Rio would be beneficial for his company in the long run. "We need to harmonize environmental issues and rules," he said.
The report addresses a range of issues including trade, population trends, the need for new accounting principles for pricing the environment and the need for the transfer of technology to developing nations which, it says, is best handled on a company-to-company basis.
The Business Council has not set targets like dates or levels to control environmental emissions and waste, saying that such targets will be set by politicians. As for the financing for the changes it envisions, it says that business executives will provide financing and investment to reach "eco-efficiency."
The report has already drawn fire from business critics and environmentalists. Greenpeace International, the environmental organization, said today that the report was a "veiled attempt to minimize international environmental controls."

HEADLINE: How a Union Won an Appalachian Struggle

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAVENSWOOD, W.Va., May 1

 BODY:
In early April, Caterpillar's mere threat to put 12,600 strikers out of their jobs for good drove the workers back to the assembly lines in Peoria, Ill. They returned on the company's terms while a new contract is negotiated, and they had nothing but wrath and unpaid bills to show for five months of picketing.
At Caterpillar, as at more and more unionized companies, management has found that to stop labor disputes it can simply replace workers. But in this dowdy, one-stoplight hamlet of 4,200 in the Ohio River Valley, the United Steelworkers of America has shown that a union can still break an employer. 
 The employer is the Ravenswood Aluminum Corporation. To end what it calls a strike and the workers call a lockout, the company capitulated. The chairman and chief executive, the man who had replaced his 1,700 workers, was dismissed. Two associates also left.
The company's owners called for new negotiations. The steelworkers union expects most of its workers to be back on the job soon and the 1,000 or so replacement workers to be removed.
 
At Least, a Sign of Hope
 Labor leaders say most unions are not as rich as the United Steelworkers, and most managements do not make the easy target that Ravenswood Aluminum did. They say the chairman's dismissal does not mean that labor has found an answer to replacement workers. But they say it does show that unions are not necessarily doomed to lose every big battle.
In Ravenswood, the steelworkers union had made the struggle with the chairman, R. Emmett Boyle, as crucial a test as the United Automobile Workers had made the battle in Peoria.
The United Steelworkers went a long way to help a local under siege. It provided much of the members' food. It paid their utility bills and in many cases their rents and mortgages. More important, it put the company's business, already ailing in the recession, at risk by inducing major customers like Anheuser-Busch and Coca-Cola to stop buying Ravenswood aluminum or face boycotts by pro-union consumers.
Finally, it exposed Mark Rich, a billionaire commodities dealer living as a fugitive in Switzerland, as the power behind Mr. Boyle. And it dispatched emissaries to foreign banks and governments to call attention to Mr. Rich's designation by Forbes Magazine as a "champion sleaze" and discourage their doing business with him.
The union had another edge in Ravenswood: the local members, mostly hardy Appalachian folk, 53 years old on average, many sons and daughters of coal miners, with a Depression-era respect for unions.
Steelworkers Local 5668 says only 17 members of about 1,700 gave in to management's invitation to return to their jobs over the 18 months of the work stoppage. By contrast, in the final days of the five-month strike in Peoria, when the management at Caterpillar said it would hire permanent replacements, several hundred crossed the picket lines.
"We're isolated in this valley here," said Ken Dean, one of three brothers, all in their 50's, who worked at the plant. "We have more togetherness than you do in larger cities."
Management and the union disagree over whether the workers voluntarily went out on strike, making them ineligible for unemployment benefits of roughly $200 a week, or whether Mr. Boyle locked them out. Though some issues are still to be decided, the State of West Virginia has agreed that the dispute is a lockout, and therefore has been paying unemployment benefits.
At midnight on Oct. 31, 1990, the union's last contract expired. During the previous month, the company had proposed a new one that changed seniority rules, eliminated the cost-of-living adjustment the workers received if consumer-price increases exceeded 3 percent a year, and eliminated additional pay when the price of aluminum went high enough to create generous profits for the company.
Charles McDowell, a top officer of Local 5668, says the company refused to negotiate in any detail. Management says the union balked at all its proposals. The company declared the talks stalemated and, the union says, workers were told to pick up their tools and go home minutes before the contract expired. The company brought in its first replacement crew, 100 workers whom it had recruited weeks before and trained at a nearby motel.
The National Labor Relations Board has accused the company of a lockout and several other violations of fair-labor practices. The former management asserts that a board administrative judge will rule in its favor eventually, and that Mr. Rich and the people close to him should have held out. "If we had stayed the course, we would have won the judge's ruling," said Debbie Boger, the former vice president of administration who left with Mr. Boyle.
Mr. Boyle and Ms. Boger have other aluminum businesses that they manage from Wheeling, W. Va. She said Mr. Boyle was not at liberty to comment.
 
Tracing a Long Decline
 Organized labor attributes the long erosion of its membership and power in part to the Reagan and Bush Administrations, the first to condone business's use of permanent replacement workers. A strike, normally a union's ultimate weapon, usually succeeds in forcing compromises, and tempers usually subside because each side can claim to have won something.
But unions say employers who hire permanent replacements gain a huge advantage. The Bureau of Labor Statistics recorded 40 stoppages involving 1,000 or more workers last year, compared with hundreds each year in the three decades before the 1980's. Unions say the decline of their influence is one reason why wages, which soared in the 1950's and 1960's, are no higher now in buying power than they were in the early 1970's.
Unions are pressing for legislation, so far opposed by President Bush, to ban the use of replacement workers in strikes. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the probable Democratic nominee for President, supports such legislation.
Joe Uehlein, special projects director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and an adviser to the steelworkers here, said using permanent replacements can stretch out labor disputes for years, impoverishing employers as well as unions. Indeed, it is an open question whether Ravenswood Aluminum can recover from its losses in the stoppage.
 
The Cost of Preparing
 One illustration of the cost of using replacement workers is the extreme to which the company went to prepare for a strike.
The company occupies hundreds of acres stretching almost a mile along the Ohio River in the rural outskirts of town. At first, the complex looks like any modern industrial site -- low, windowless, gray and blue buildings with chimneys, asphalt and labyrinths of pipe. But closer up, it looks like a medium-security prison.
Two and three rows of eight-foot-high chain-link fence topped with barbed wire surround the principal plants: a reduction factory, where ore is melted and converted to ingots, and a fabrication plant, where the ingots are rolled into coils of aluminum sheet, much of which eventually ends up as beer and soft-drink cans.
Tall, thick steel plates have been installed in front of the electric power transformers. Television cameras are mounted on the corners of the buildings, and security men in Army boots and midnight-blue battle fatigues man the gatehouses.
 
Living Where They Work
 In the first weeks of the struggle, management nailed plywood over all the windows of its administration building. For three weeks everyone there was required to stay put, day and night, sleeping on cots.
There has been only one serious injury related to the conflict over the 18 months: a security guard lost an eye in a shooting, although the origin of the bullet is in dispute. A company spokesman, Patrick M. Gallagher, said there had been "thousands" of incidents.
Mr. Boyle became chairman in 1989, when he, an associate of Mr. Rich and another investor bought the companyfrom the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation. In the 31 years that Kaiser owned the business, the only work stoppages were a few wildcat strikes of less than a week, and Kaiser never invited replacement workers to take the jobs of strikers. But when Ravenswood Aluminum did, the company jarred an Appalachian sense of fair play.
"It's basic honesty," said Dan Fewell, 45, one of the replaced workers. "You don't go and steal a man's car. You don't go and steal a man's job."
 
Sustained by Faith
 Religion in this community -- the Yellow Pages list 18 churches, or 1 for every 230 residents -- seems to have helped sustain the workers. "I'd say we're far above average as far as God-fearing people," said Richard C. Johnson, 52, a millwright.
Jim Derrick, 62, a welder who conducts prayer services at the union hall, said: "I just talk to the Lord. He tells me to forget about it. He'll take care of my needs. Not my wants. My needs."
A knack for getting by in the state that leads the nation in unemployment also helps. "A country boy can survive," Mike Asbury, 42, said. "We can grow potatoes and beans. We can go shoot a deer."
Vera Smith, whose husband, James, is an equipment operator, was one of the Ravenswood women who lobbied the state legislature for better plant safety. In December, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration assessed the company one of its highest penalties ever, $604,500 for safety violations.
"This had turned into a real unsafe plant," Mrs. Smith said. Five men died there in the 18 months before the strike. The union says only one died in the years of Kaiser's stewardship.
 
Working 'Like a Mule'
 After Mr. Boyle took over, supervisors started driving the workers harder and forcing many to work double shifts, said Mark Hager, a 32-year-old plant worker. "It's a tough enough job anyway, with outrageous temperatures," he said. "But they started raw-dogging you and working you like a mule."
The union appears to have provoked Mr. Boyle's dismissal by going after Mr. Rich; the union believes Mr. Boyle reported to him. Mr. Rich fled the country nine years ago under indictment on charges of tax evasion, racketeering and trading oil with Iran during the embassy-hostage crisis, when the Government ordered an embargo.
Ravenswood Aluminum is privately held, so few details of its business need be disclosed publicly. But the union says that abundant circumstantial evidence suggests that Mr. Rich controls the company through a close associate, Willy Strothotte. Mr. Strothotte, the union says, took over Mr. Boyle's 27 percent share in the company with Mr. Boyle's dismissal and now has at least 75 percent. The union says four other investors are closely connected to Mr. Rich and Mr. Strothotte. Mr. Gallagher insists that Mr. Rich has no "direct" interest in the company.
To put pressure on Mr. Boyle, the steelworkers union and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. went after Mr. Rich. They dispatched emissaries, including several from the plant, to Czechoslovakia, the Netherlands, Britain, Venezuela and Switzerland to lobby banks and governments not to do business with Mr. Rich.
Labor leaders think Mr. Rich wants to clean up his image. He has hired lawyers in Washington, presumably, union officials say, to make peace with the Justice Department so he can return to the United States. Peace in Ravenswood, they say, might help.

Workers on a picket line outside the plant expressed optimism for a settlement. (Gary Truman for The New York Times) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Olympia Offers Stakes to Banks

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 7

 BODY:
Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the cash-short real estate giant, today offered its lending banks equity stakes in both its huge Canary Wharf development here and the parent company in return for debt-payment relief and new funds.
The meeting with 15 of Olympia's largest lenders on restructuring $12 billion in debts continued into the night and how the banks would respond was not clear. 
One pressing issue is whether the banks that have lent about 950 million ($1.71 billion) to the Canary Wharf office-development project in East London will provide additional money, which is needed for construction to continue. The 5 million ($8.5 million) they provided last week will reportedly run out in a matter of days and Olympia is believed to have asked for an additional 30 million ($53.9 million) to see it through the next month.
If Olympia does not get the money, Canary Wharf will probably be forced into bankruptcy, and the Olympia empire, which includes vast holdings in the United States and Canada, could crumble.
"We need funding fairly soon, and we are optimistic we will get it," Michael Dennis, the head of Canary Wharf, said at a news conference.
Bankers said today that most lenders to Canary Wharf were willing to provide more money but that there was at least one holdout: the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
The Olympia proposal calls for lenders to receive nonvoting stakes of up to 30 percent in the current phase of Canary Wharf and up to 20 percent in Olympia, which is owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto. This marks the first time the Reichmanns have been willing to share ownership -- but not control -- of the private company.
Under the proposed plan, Olympia would have the right to buy back the shares within seven years at a price determined by a set formula. If it did not, the banks could presumably sell their shares in the open market.
 
Called a 'Milestone'
 Gerald Greenwald, president of Olympia, and Robert S. Miller Jr., its financial adviser, announced the proposal at the news conference held during a break in their meeting with bankers at Canary Wharf.
Calling the offer "a significant milestone" in Olympia's history, Mr. Greenwald said Olympia was "inviting its lenders to join hands as partners in the business."
Asked how lenders could be considered equal partners if their shares lacked voting rights, Mr. Miller said that was not significant. "The actual agreements between the banks on how the company will be operated will be embedded in" new loan covenants, he said.
While he did not attend the news conference, Paul Reichmann, Olympia's leader, was at the meeting with the bankers, where the company presented a five-year business plan. The banks at the session included Citibank, Hongkong and Shanghai, Barclays, Credit Lyonnais, Canadian Imperial and Credit Suisse.
Bankers have been criticizing Olympia for providing outdated and inadequate financial information, and Mr. Greenwald indicated today that the bankers were not completely pacified by the latest information. "We know we haven't satisfied them yet, but we're moving quickly and we're certainly trying," he said.
 
Five-Year Extension
 The proposal by Olympia calls for most of its debt-principal payments to be extended for five years.
Interest payments on about $4 billion of the parent company's debt would be limited to the dividend and cash flow from the operations serving as collateral for the loans. Any shortfall would be paid in Olympia shares.
From what Mr. Miller said, it appeared that the banks that could end up owning as much as 30 percent of Canary Wharf were the 11 that had made 500 million ($898.2 million) in construction loans backed by the project's buildings.
The remaining 450 million in Canary Wharf loans came from a smaller group of banks, including four Canadian institutions.
Olympia is also asking for 300 million ($538.9 million) in new funds to complete the current phase of Canary Wharf. The vast majority of that space is completed or in an advance stage of construction, including the 812-foot tower that is Britain's tallest building.
 
Additional $700 million
 All in all, Olympia has asked banks for an additional $700 million for the Canadian and British operations, Mr. Miller said. "At this point," he added, Olympia does not think it will need additional credit lines in the United States.
Olympia is also seeking permission to draw the remaining $130 million of an existing $240 million credit line provided by Canadian banks.
The plan also calls for the sale of some assets, but Olympia officials did not identify them at the news conference. Earlier this week, Olympia announced plans to sell an 18 percent stake in the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, the American railroad and natural resources conglomerate, and a 63.5 interest in the Home Oil Company of Calgary, Alberta. The stakes could fetch more than $740 million.
When Olympia embarked on the Canary Wharf project in 1987, it planned to build 26 buildings with 10 million square feet of office space by 1997.
That was before the current recession hit Britain, and the developer now has tenant commitments for only 60 percent of the 4.6 million square feet. Mr. Dennis said Olympia would not proceed with further construction until most of the existing space had been let.
Mr. Miller said that "it will take weeks, if not a month or more," to reach a debt-restructuring agreement. That prediction, however, seemed to assume that the banks will react favorably to Olympia's proposal.
