Miller Jr., Olympia's financial adviser; Gerald Greenwald, its president, and Michael Dennis, head of Canary Wharf. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: DELIVERY DISPUTE;
Veteran Players Battle In News Drivers Fight

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A New Jersey trucking magnate who once planned to build a grandiose new riverfront city on the Hudson across from Manhattan, and two iron-willed drivers' unions that have been linked by investigators to rackets and underworld mobs are the principal players in the high-stakes confrontation that has brought New York City's major newspapers to the brink of a labor war.
There are other players -- 1,000 members of a union that has delivered New York's newspapers since the turn of the century, whose jobs are jeopardized; and hundreds of newly hired members of a teamsters' local with no newspaper-delivery experience, who find themselves in a potentially bruising inter-union fight for jobs . 
 And, since the confrontation threatens strikes that could disrupt the distribution of The New York Times, The Daily News, The New York Post, The Wall Street Journal and many other publications, readers across the New York metropolitan region may also be drawn into the maelstrom.
The complex confrontation arose Wednesday when members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and Vicinity rejected a series of proposed contracts covering drivers for four wholesale newspaper delivery companies -- two of them being acquired by The New York Times and two being bought by Arthur E. Imperatore, the trucking magnate.
The Times yesterday was considering an option to assign its agreement to buy the wholesalers to a third party, probably Mr. Imperatore. But Mr. Imperatore went ahead with his purchase and hired teamsters' union members in place of 210 newspaper union deliverers who had refused to accept lower terms. The teamsters' union represents drivers at his other trucking enterprises.
 
Complex Labor Fight
 Like many labor confrontations, this one pitted a powerful and determined management against strong-willed unionists. But it was also marked by unusual complexity, with two unions at odds over the same jobs. And it was noteworthy for the sheer toughness of the combatants: a self-made millionaire, a drivers' union that has seen leaders jailed for bribery, and a teamsters' local whose president currently stands charged with embezzlement.
Mr. Imperatore, a 64-year-old trucking and real estate entrepreneur who began as a truck driver and built a fortune estimated at $200 million, owns the APA Transpsort Corporation of North Bergen, N.J., which hauls freight everywhere in the East, and about 350 acres of prime waterfront real estate in Weehawken, N.J., across from Manhattan.
He bought the big parcel during the liquidation of the Penn Central's holdings in 1981 for a bargain price of $7.75 million -- a value that has multiplied many times in the years since. In succeeding years, Mr. Imperatore made plans to develop a $5 billion commercial and residential mini-city, a "Venice on the Hudson," that was to include 15,000 housing units, 10 million square feet of retail space and a yachtsman's paradise.
Mr. Imperatore got things moving by establishing a ferry service between Weehawken and Manhattan with a license from the New York City Department of Transportation. Anthony R. Ameruso, the Transportation Commissioner, was later indicted for perjury in a municipal scandal and it was disclosed that eight days after the ferry permit was granted he had invested $250,000 in a real estate company with ties to the company that got the permit. Mr. Ameruso withdrew the investment and Mr. Imperatore denied any connection between it and the permit.
 
Agreement in Principle
 Meanwhile, the recession and other problems upset the timetable for the mini-city project, and Mr. Imperatore opened a golf driving range and miniature golf course on the land. Last November, expanding into yet another business, Mr. Imperatore agreed to buy Newspaper Distributors Company of East Farmingdale, L.I., which serves Long Island, and Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle, N.Y., which serves Westchester County and Fairfield County in Connecticut.
In February, The Times agreed in principle to buy the two other major news wholesalers in the area -- Metropolitan News, which distributes in the city, and Newark Newsdealers Supply Company, which serves north and central New Jersey.
Under an asset sale, a buyer is not bound by existing contracts unless it specifically states that they survive a sale. Drivers were upset at the prospect of losing good wages -- most earn at least $40,000 and some with overtime as much as $100,000 -- and benefits.
But faced with a loss of jobs, their leaders negotiated new contracts last month giving concessions on staffing levels, work rules and overtime in exchange for job guarantees. But members rejected the agreements, setting the stage for the battle.
The drivers' union, which was born in horse-and-buggy days in 1901, has a history tainted with corruption, father-son nepotism and rules that kept blacks and Hispanic drivers out of its ranks for decades. But it also has struggled to improve its hiring practices and to bring security and a decent life to a membership that now totals about 2,900.
 
Cold, Lonely Nights
 Heavy traffic, cold nights and bad weather are the regular companions of drivers, who often work two on a truck. Because many work at night to deliver morning newspapers, they see their families only at odd hours or on days off, which are often in midweek and not consecutive.
The fiercely independent drivers' union never joined the powerful International Brotherhood of Teamsters. In recent decades, a dozen leaders of the drivers' union, including Carl Levy, who was president from 1969 to 1976, and Douglas LaChance, who was president from 1976 to 1980 and is currently the president again, were convicted of accepting illegal payoffs to assure labor peace. Mr. LaChance spent five years in prison.
Law-enforcement officials say a new investigation of the union has found evidence of underworld influence and various crimes, but Mr. LaChance, who has not been implicated, has denied the allegations.
The union that has emerged as the potential rival of the drivers is Local 917 of the teamsters, which has its headquarters in Manhattan and represents freight truck drivers, automobile mechanics and helpers at gasoline stations, parking attendants, automobile transporters and warehousemen in the metropolitan area.
Under a broad rackets investigation undertaken with the consent of the teamsters' union to root out corruption, Local 917's president, John T. Burke Jr., was charged last year with embezzlement of union funds. A ruling is pending.

HEADLINE: Top Executives Say Recovery Has Begun

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7

 BODY:
Top executives from a dozen of the nation's largest corporations said this evening that with the exception of riot-torn Los Angeles, the United States appeared to have begun a slow recovery from last year's recession.
All the executives who spoke this evening thought that an economic recovery had begun, but they differed on whether its progress was assured. The most optimistic was Robert E. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. "I don't think we're going to have a booming recovery, but I think it may exceed most economists' expectations," he said. 
 One of the most pessimistic executives was John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company, who said that while the long-term competitiveness of American industry was improving, the recovery appeared to have been less strong last month than in the three preceding months.
 
No Enthusiasm for Cities
 However, none of the executives expressed any enthusiasm when asked if they had any immediate interest in investing in inner cities. After a moment of silence, Walter V. Shipley, the president and chief operating officer of the Chemical Banking Corporation, pointed out that some areas in Newark and Washington that were damaged in riots years ago had never been rebuilt.
Howard P. Allen, chairman of the executive committee of the Southern California Edison Company, said that until the riots his region had appeared to be slowly following the rest of the country into recovery. But a significant pause is likely now before tourism and investment recover.
"The riots put a cloud not only on other things but on the economy of the Southern California area," Mr. Allen said.
The answer, Mr. Allen said, was a national experiment in creating free enterprise zones, cultural centers and other programs in Los Angeles to persuade businesses that investments there would be safe and at least somewhat profitable. With such assurances, businesses might be willing to invest even for returns below those available elsewhere, Mr. Allen insisted.
 
More Jobs Are Needed
 Mr. Welch said that businesses' main response to the riots should be to create more jobs and increase the diversity of the American work place.
Mr. Welch heads the Business Council, a group of 100 chief executives of large corporations who are meeting here over the next two days to discuss the economy and foreign trade. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, will address the group Friday in an effort to rally support for the Administration's attempts to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a global free-trade pact.
The chief executives spoke after reviewing a very cautious report on the nation's economy by chief economists from 19 large corporations. The economists' views are important not only as an indication of the economy's direction, but also because they influence the assumptions being made by America's corporate leaders as they decide whether to expand investment and other spending this year or remain cautious.
 
Slow, Halting Progress
 The recession appears to have ended last year, they said, but the recovery will be slow and halting, and the economies of other industrialized countries are growing more slowly than expected last autumn.
The weakening of the Japanese, German and other European economies is hurting American exports.
But the economists also drew some optimism from the steep fall in interest rates late last year, the wider availability of credit and, above all, increasing consumer confidence.
They predicted 2.5 percent economic growth through the rest of this year. The prediction, "is faster than the meager growth actually achieved during the past year," the economists said in their report to the chief executives. "But it remains well below the pace typical of previous economic recoveries."

HEADLINE: Rise Seen In Lending By Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 7

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the ill effects on the economy from bankers' reduced willingness to extend new loans was abating.
While standing by his comments earlier this year that weakness in the financial system, including banks, was hurting the economy, Mr. Greenspan said the regulators were not to blame. He said the tougher financial standards for banks did not cause banks to reduce business lending and instead to increase their holdings of government securities sharply. Rather, he said, that trend "reflects mainly weak loan demand." 
 Although the economy and bank lending habits are not back to normal, Mr. Greenspan said, "Things are improving." He said the stronger financial condition of businesses, consumers and banks would bode well for future economic growth.
Mr. Greenspan's comments, made at a conference here sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, appeared to counter critics in Congress who attribute the weakness in bank lending to regulators' rules, which do not count investments in government securities when calculating a bank's capital requirement, but do count all business loans.
The Fed chairman noted that tougher capital requirements were imposed on banks at about the time the economy turned down, and added that banks traditionally increased securities purchases when loan demand slackened. He said that another reason for the drop in bank loans was that some businesses had raised money to repay loans by selling more stock or issuing long-term bonds.
Mr. Greenspan also took a broad swipe at the banking law approved last year, saying that it is so restrictive that it could harm the economy.
He also strongly implied that when it came to writing the scores of regulations to enforce the act, he intended to promote looser regulations on everything from compensation and loans to bankers to record-keeping, lending and capital standards.
The new law, he said, "requires the agencies to establish highly undesirable regulations that involve substantial micro-management" and puts the Government perilously close to being in the business of "credit allocation," referring to decisions about whom banks lend to and in what amounts.
 
Not the Government's Job
 "Credit allocation is -- and I fervently hope will remain -- the job of bankers, not Government," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has long sought legislation to make it easier and cheaper for banks to enter the securities and insurance industries. Congress rejected such legislation last year. It had been proposed by the Administration, but fell victim to a heavy lobbying campaign against it by community bankers and securities and insurance interests.
Instead, Congress adopted the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act, which gave regulators the authority to borrow billions of dollars from the Treasury to bail out insolvent banks and generally tightened restrictions on the industry. The Federal Reserve and the other bank regulatory agencies have begun writing dozens of regulations to enforce the Act.
"We must work to be sure that all of these provisions are implemented in a way that preserves the decision-making role of bankers," Mr. Greenspan said, "while permitting agencies to identify institutions that take what would be widely agreed are excessive risks or engage in inappropriate practices."
 
Glimmer of More Demand
 David J. Vitale, executive vice-president at the First National Bank of Chicago noted that "there are glimmerings of improved loan demand" as more companies are talking about their credit needs with the bank, although they are not yet increasing their borrowings.
Mr. Vitale, who attended the conference, said in an interview that he expected that when lending increases, it might not increase the size of the Chicago bank. Like many other large banks, First Chicago has been an active seller of loans to reduce the amount of capital it needs to satisfy regulatory requirements.
Mr. Vitale said that capital requirements would probably rise for large banks that are active in the securities and foreign exchange markets and in selling interest rate swaps and options on interest rates and currencies. "They may not require the additional capital all at once, but my gut feeling is that when regulators have an opportunity to require more capital, they will," Mr. Vitale said.
Mr. Greenspan said American regulators would probably issue early this summer proposals for capital requirements based on the risks banks face from fluctuating interest rates.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Reporter's Notebook;
Bill Clinton, Crusading Cub Reporter

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 7

 BODY:
Sometimes, as Bill Clinton's political caravan jumps from state to state in a frenetic quest for votes and publicity, it seems that television news correspondents are as important as the candidate himself, or more so.
Since inspecting the damage from the riots in Los Angeles on Monday, Mr. Clinton has been trying to engage President Bush in a debate over social welfare policy. The debate is conducted not through speeches or manifestoes, but through an exchange of "sound bites." Journalists ask Mr. Clinton, the likely Presidential nominee of the Democratic Party, for his reaction to some statement by the Bush Administration, and within hours Mr. Clinton's comments are broadcast across the country, often provoking, in turn, a reply from the White House. 
 The importance of television news to the campaign was reflected in a witty parody performed aboard Mr. Clinton's plane as the Arkansas Governor flew back to Little Rock from Charleston, W.Va., on Wednesday.
In a reversal of roles, Governor Clinton and the press secretary for his campaign, Dee Dee Myers, interviewed Gene Randall, a correspondent for the Cable News Network who has been following the campaign since early this year.
Mr. Clinton and Ms. Myers posed as television journalists, and Mr. Randall played the role of candidate. "This is the most important interview our fledgling network has ever done," said Governor Clinton, who described Mr. Randall as "a major figure in our time."
Among the questions posed to Mr. Randall by Ms. Myers were these: "Is it true you wore the same necktie the previous six days in a row?" (Yes.) "Is it true you don't sit in your assigned seat here on the plane every day?" (True.) "Can you name three areas where you disagree with Ted Turner," the founder of the Cable News Network? ("No, I can't," Mr. Randall replied tactfully.)
At the conclusion of the interview, Governor Clinton said: "Gene has done a wonderful job of evading every question. I think that this man has been so evasive, so slick in his evasion, that I have decided to withdraw in his favor. He should be President of the United States. Let's hear it for Randall for President."
 
Oratory, Loud and Clear
 In the antiseptic corridors of Washington, Federal officials are debating the merits of Great Society programs begun in the 1960's by President Lyndon B. Johnson. But in the hills and hollows of West Virginia, where there is chronic high unemployment, people love those programs, and Mr. Clinton's visit to Charleston was the occasion for full-throated old-fashioned Democratic oratory.
West Virginia holds a Presidential primary on Tuesday. Governor Clinton attended a rally with hundreds of people at the National Guard Armory on Coonskin Road in Charleston, the state capital. Behind the stage was a huge American flag.
Warming up the crowd, Cecil E. Roberts, vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, compared George Bush to Herbert Hoover. "Hoover believed in the trickle-down theory of economics," Mr. Roberts shouted at the top of his lungs. "That didn't work in 1929, and it don't work today. That caused a Depression in 1929. Down here in the coal fields of West Virginia, there's a depression again, and we are sick of it."
Mr. Clinton was not the first choice of organized labor, but he won over the crowd Wednesday in West Virginia by emphasizing the parts of his platform that correspond to the old-time religion of the Democratic Party.
Mr. Clinton was introduced by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, who said: "I am probably not one of the world's leading experts on growing up poor, but Bill Clinton did. He's with us, folks. He understands us."
Despite the differences in their economic backgrounds, Governor Clinton likened himself to Mr. Rockefeller, a former Governor of West Virginia, saying: "We are both seriously over-married. We've learned to live with it with as much humility as possible." Neither Hillary Clinton, a lawyer, nor Sharon Percy Rockefeller, the president of a public television station in the Washington area, attended the rally.
 
Love Him Tender
 "Clinton: Young Man in a Hurry" is the title of a new book that appeared this week in Little Rock bookstores. It is a pastiche of facts, anecdotes and impressions of the Governor, culled from people who have known him over the last 45 years.
The authors, Jim Moore, who grew up in western Arkansas and now lives in Hillsboro, Tex., and Rick Ihde portray Mr. Clinton as a progressive force in a politically backward state.
The book, published by the Summit Group of Fort Worth and on sale for $22.95, discloses that one of young Billy Clinton's favorite pastimes was "to cruise around Hot Springs doing impersonations of Elvis Presley." Mr. Clinton is reported to have done an especially good rendition of "Love Me Tender."
Mr. Moore also reports that Billy liked to experiment with various foods. "Peanut butter and bananas constituted his favorite sandwich creation during his high school years," the book says.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Perot Hires Businessman To Be Issues Coordinator

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 7

 BODY:
Ross Perot, who said this week he would step back from public forums to study policy positions for a likely Presidential campaign, has hired a business executive with broad connections in the Federal Government to head his effort.
John P. White, general manager since 1989 of the computer-based products division at the Eastman Kodak Company, took an indefinite leave from the company in Rochester earlier this week to join the slowly-widening circle of Perot advisers in North Dallas, said a Kodak spokesman, Ron Roberts. 
 "Issue coordinator" is the best description of Mr. White's assignment, although he has not been given a title, said James Squires, a spokesman for the Perot Petition Campaign. "The real function is to line up and assemble for Mr. Perot the various experts and all the information that we can possibly get to him."
Mr. White did not respond to a request for an interview that was left on his answering machine at the Perot office. Mr. White, 54 years old, helped convert the nation's military from a draft system to an all-volunteer force as an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the first years of the Carter Administration. He later transferred to Deputy Director at the Office of Management and Budget, where he was responsible for budgets at the Pentagon as well as the State, Treasury and Labor Departments.
Before entering government, he rose quickly as a research economist in the Rand Corporation, a research organization in Santa Monica, Calif. He analyzed transportation issues and Air Force manpower and training programs after joining Rand as a research economist in 1968. He was later named a senior vice president and trustee.
Returning to Santa Monica in 1981, Mr. White was chairman and chief executive of a software-development company, the Interactive Systems Corporation, until Kodak acquired the company in 1988.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Bond Sale Goes Well

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An auction of $10 billion worth of 29 1/2-year bonds, the final part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, went well yesterday.
Despite the successful auction, traders began to sell securities after the auction results were announced as a defense against the chance that April employment data, to be released today, would show unexpected strength. 
 Concern that the employment figures might show that the economy was growing faster than currently anticipated were alleviated somewhat late yesterday when the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on April 27.
 
Unexpectedly Large Drops
 The declines in the monetary aggregates were much larger than expected, especially a $9.7 billion drop in M-2, the money measure followed most closely by the Fed.
The drop in M-2 put its growth since the fourth quarter below the low end of the Fed's target range for the growth of that category this year of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent .
Prices of outstanding bonds and notes came off their lows after the money numbers were released, and closed little changed on the day.
Analysts said the weak money report seemed to increase the chances the Fed may choose to cut short-term interest rates again soon.
"Unless money supply, which is a leading economic indicator, reverses recent weakness over the next two to three weeks, it would be increasingly likely that the Fed will ease," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago.
"And the decline in money supply will probably take some of the sting out of an unusually strong employment report, if that happens," he added.
In advance of the employment report, most Wall Street economists were forecasting that nonfarm payroll employment rose by between 50,000 and 75,000 jobs last month. An increase of that size would be consistent with the sluggish, halting recovery most analysts say is unfolding.
The money supply report partly overshadowed the Treasury bond auction, which was the concluding piece of what turned out to be a highly successful quarterly refunding for the Treasury.
At the auction, the bonds were sold at an average yield of 8 percent, up from an average of 7.91 percent at the last bond sale on Feb. 13.
 
Existing Issue 'Reopened'
 Rather than issue a new bond, the Treasury chose to "reopen" an existing issue -- the 8 percent bonds of November 2021 -- that were originally sold in November 1991. The decision was made because current market conditions were not conducive to a new issue.
It was the first time since 1984 that the Treasury had chosen to reopen an outstanding bond more than once. The reopening created a huge, $32 billion issue.
"Even though this is the third time the Street has bid for this issue, there was surprisingly good demand," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Given the fact that the bonds have a record floating supply and that the employment report is imminent, this was an excellent auction."
 
Outstanding Issues Rise
 As Mr. Kahan suggested, the money supply report did seem to allay traders' concerns about the employment statistics, because prices of outstanding notes and bonds moved higher late in the session.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 3/8, down 1/32 , to yield 7.96 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 10019/32 , down 1/32 , to yield 6.73 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 1/32 , to yield 5.24 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.58 percent late yesterday, unchanged from late Wednesday. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 3.70 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late rate of 3.99 percent.
 
High-Yield Issue
 Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by a $400 million offering of high-yield securities issued by the Adelphia Communicactions Corporation.
The 12.50 percent senior notes mature in 2002 and were priced at $100, or par.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which, because of heavy demand, was increased in size from $275 million.
The securities are rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was sluggish, traders said, partly because of the Treasury's refunding auctions.
Prices of most investment-grade corporate bonds were unchanged on the day, according to market participants. And municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
New York's transit agency says lawyers are taking it for a very expensive ride.

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
Of all the feelings one can muster for the New York City Transit Authority, solidarity must be pretty low on the list. But that is precisely what the organization is seeking to foster these days, by choosing a target even less popular than the Broadway Local at rush hour: lawyers.
"LAWSUIT ABUSE!" shriek the more than 20,000 posters that began popping up on the city's buses and subways in March. "Guess who picks up the tab? You do!" This month the notices, now found alongside advertisements for acne specialists and beauty academies, will spread to Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road. 
 Every year, 3,000 new claims are made against the authority, and it pays out $50 million in damages. That is to say nothing of the cost of paying 125 staff members, including 50 lawyers, to handle such suits, which are especially tempting in bad economic times. "People view it as a chance to hit the lottery," said the authority's executive general counsel for torts, Wallace D. Gossett.
Transit officials say they hope strap-hangers who are tempted to take on the much-maligned agency will realize that the deep pocket they are digging into is actually their own. They add that they hope to cultivate a new crop of whistle-blowers, who will report instances of fraud to them.
There are plenty of legitimate beefs with the T.A., including 145 claims stemming from last year's fatal accident at the 14th Street station. At the same time, there are at least some people who hobble into court asserting they have suffered crippling injuries, only to be spotted later changing tires or painting houses or running marathons, sometimes with their lawyers jogging alongside them.
At first blush, weeding out such fraud seems as beyond reproach as Mother's Day. But personal injury lawyers say the effort is a particularly pernicious form of jury tampering. They assert that while the posters have been plastered everywhere, they seem to pop up more frequently in those subway stations closest to courthouses, where potential jurors are likely to see them.
Bert Bauman, president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, saw one in the Borough Hall station in Brooklyn, directly beneath the State Supreme Court. "I saw it and I fumed because of the poison that it instills in the minds of jurors," he said. "Every juror gets off at that stop."
He took his gripe to the New York Law Journal. In a recent letter to the publication, he wrote, "The ad suggests that jurors should microscopically scrutinize each plaintiff's case to a greater extent than the court might charge them to; all plaintiffs are tarred with the same brush of presumptive fraud." Mr. Gossett called his charges "absolutely ridiculous."
An even sorer subject for the trial lawyers is the sponsor of the campaign: the American Tort Reform Association, a consortium of corporations, insurance companies and trade associations that include Dow Chemical, the Boy Scouts of America and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. The tort reform group supplied the posters, which cost $10,000 to produce. The authority donated the space and labor.
Last year, a similar campaign in Philadelphia reduced new claims against the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority by 18 percent. At least four more cities are considering similar efforts, while placards declaring "Put the Brakes on Fakes" will appear on all buses in Richmond later this month. The group has also had hundreds of thousands of "Lawsuit Abuse" bumper stickers printed.
The Philadelphia campaign aroused barely a whimper from personal injury lawyers there. But as Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential contender, discovered not long ago, the rules of engagement are slightly different in New York.
Mr. Bauman asserted that it was improper for a public agency to give free space to an interest group to advance a partisan message. After consulting with the American Trial Lawyers Association, he said he had decided not to challenge the advertisements on constitutional grounds, but he said he might go to court to demand equal time and space.
The tort reform group's president, Martin F. Connor, complained to the National Law Journal, "Here we are protesting litigiousness, and he wants to sue."
Mr. Bauman said he had little use for the phonies and frauds of the bar. "Take away their licenses, for all I care," he said. But he called the alliance between the authority and the tort reform group "outrageous" and "an impermissible use of public funds."
"I'm looking around for a good firm of attorneys to take this on pro bono," he said. Thus far, he added, there have been no volunteers within the trial lawyers group, which has nearly 4,000 members.

HEADLINE: Trenton Sees Budget Gap Of Millions

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 7

 BODY:
State Treasurer Samuel F. Crane said today that lower-than-expected revenue from the state income tax has left a $342 million gap in the state budget just seven weeks before the end of the current fiscal year.
Mr. Crane projected an additional $310 million revenue loss from a $15.7 billion budget proposed by Gov. Jim Florio for the next fiscal year. 
 The announcement will further complicate the effort by the Legislature's Republican majority to roll back the sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent at a cost of $610 million in revenue.
At a news conference, Mr. Crane outlined a belt-tightening plan that he said would leave the state with a surplus at the end of the current fiscal year and next year despite the tax revenue shortfall.
 
'We Will Not Compromise'
 "While the lingering effects of the national recession require that we make these adjustments, we will not compromise on the Governor's budget priorities," he said. "Our budget proposals will continue to follow through on the Governor's commitment to property-tax relief, local school funding, college tuition stabilization and affordable mass transit."
The treasurer said Governor Florio's administration would take $207 million from a school aid fund and decrease the amount of office space the state leases to deal with the problem this year, all of which can be done administratively. But to close the projected gap for the 1993 fiscal year, which begins July 1, Mr. Florio, a Democrat, must depend on the Republican-controlled Legislature to agree to a host of legislation.
The chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, Robert E. Littell, and his counterpart in the Assembly, Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, issued the Republican response to Mr. Crane's announcement.
"We need time to analyze the revenue numbers as well as the remedies offered by the administration," they said in a joint statement. "We will be prepared to make a formal response on Tuesday."
Privately, however, some Republicans said Mr. Crane's announcement had set the stage for another round of fierce, partisan fighting.
 
A Pivotal Period
 Mr. Crane said he had briefed Mr. Littell and Mr. Frelinghuysen on the revised revenue figures only hours before his public announcement.
Last month was a pivotal reporting period in which to gauge the state's finances because of the April 15 state income-tax filing deadline.
Mr. Crane said income-tax collections were down by $350 million and the corporate tax fell short by $30 million, but both losses were partly offset by gains from other taxes for a net gap of $342 million from a budget of $15 million for this fiscal year.
"From what we see today, these figures will hold," he said.
The shortfall projected for the 1993 fiscal year is $310 million.
Mr. Crane said the administration hoped to cover the 1993 shortfall by cutting the state work force through attrition, adding a new five-digit Lotto game, and reducing the amount of leased office space, which currently costs the state $250 million a year.
But he said Mr. Florio would have to depend on the Republicans for the major money-saving or revenue-producing parts of the plan for 1993. They include a proposal to expand the current "cheater-beater" program against delinquent taxpayers.
Mr. Crane said the administration also proposes cutting $7.8 million from the subsidy it gives to N. J. Transit. Officials hope that money will be covered by increased ridership and lower gasoline prices.
But the most controversial idea would have the state expand and accelerate the phase-in of a plan to tap into the state's over-financed pension system to raise $278 million for the next fiscal year's budget.
Mr. Florio first made the proposal in his budget speech in January. After weeks of studying the idea, Republicans legislative leaders cautiously agreed, although bills to approve the change in the pension system have not reached the floor for a vote.
Despite warnings from Republican legislators that they intended to roll back the tax rate to 6 percent, Mr. Florio based his proposed $15.7 billion budget for the 1993 fiscal year on a 7 percent tax rate.
"We project a surplus at the end of fiscal year 1993 of $226 million, the same level as our original budget proposal in January," Mr. Crane said today.
He said he expected the state to end the current fiscal year with a surplus of $289 million. But he said that depended on $380 million in retroactive Medicaid payments from the Federal Government and $38 million in promised Federal transportation funds.

HEADLINE: Corporations Ask Bush to Lift Vietnam Ban

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Eight large United States corporations, among them four oil companies, asked President Bush today to lift restrictions on business with Vietnam and allow Americans to compete in its growing market.
"The United States economic sanctions with respect to Vietnam have become unilateral, with our allies and trade partners investing heavily and trading vigorously," said the letter from executives of Caterpillar, Boeing, Hunt Oil, Chevron, Amoco, Phillips Petroleum, Windmere, American International Group and the Coudert Brothers law firm. 
 "Accordingly," the letter continued, "the effect of the American embargo is not to deny Vietnam access to Western technology and financing, but rather to penalize U.S. companies to the benefit of foreign competitors. The United States is rapidly losing ground and is forfeiting to foreign competition a market where we could have a competitive edge."
The executives requested a White House meeting to press their case.
In April, after a trip to Vietnam by an Assistant Secretary of State, Richard Solomon, the Administration concluded that Hanoi was making greater efforts to solve the cases of Americans missing or unaccounted for since the Vietnam War, and permitted telephone service to resume.
At the same time it also allowed American businesses to sell goods of a humanitarian nature -- medicines, food and clothing -- to the Vietnamese. But all other trade is prohibited.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
B.P.'s Earnings Plummet 82%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, May 7

 BODY:
British Petroleum's earnings fell 82 percent in the first quarter as the company felt the effects of the recession, lower oil prices and lower profit margins on sales of petroleum products and chemicals.
The company's results were made public in the United States through its subsidiary, BP America, based in Cleveland. 
 British Petroleum reported first-quarter income of 95 million, or $168 million, down from 521 million, or $922 million, a year earlier. At that time, oil prices were higher because of the Persian Gulf War.
Earnings per share came to 36 cents, down from $2.22 a year earlier.
Revenues were 654 million, or $1.16 billion, down from 1.01 billion, or $1.8 billion.
David Simon, deputy chairman and chief operating officer, said in a statement that B.P.'s business outlook in the months ahead "suggest trading conditions will be just as difficult as in the recent past."

HEADLINE: Dow Off 6.04 Ahead of Jobs Data Today

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks slipped yesterday in quiet trading, with Wall Street edgy ahead of key April employment figures that will provide a solid gauge of the economy's strength.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.04 points to close at 3,363.37, and losers narrowly outpaced gainers, 821 to 817, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Volume was a slight 168.9 million shares, evidence that many traders were unwilling to enter the market ahead of today's jobs report, which will offer the first official sign of the economy's performance last month.
"The bets have been placed," said one trader at a major Wall Street firm. "Now the wheel is spinning, and everyone is just waiting to see where the ball drops."
There have been numerous signs of the economy's slow comeback, but the question is whether the early signs -- higher retail sales, rising housing starts, healthier industrial production -- will mean more jobs. Employment growth is key to the strength of the rebound. If the job outlook stagnates, consumers might be reluctant to increase spending.
The market had also hoped in recent days that the Federal Reserve would ease credit, offering an insurance policy for the recovery. But so far the Fed has stood firm.
"The market is fractious, and at the moment, people are concerned whether short-term rates will go lower," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Reich & Company.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told bankers in Chicago that there was room for the economy to grow faster in the coming quarters as consumers, corporations and banks put their finances in shape.
"There is evidence that things are improving," Mr. Greenspan said. "But I would scarcely argue, however, that we are anywhere back to normal."
Retailers posted strong sales figures for April in what analysts called a sign consumers are emerging from their long hibernation to buy a broad range of goods. But weekly jobless claims edged higher, by 11,000, to 415,000 in late April, a sign the job market remains under pressure.
Economists expect the April unemployment rate will remain unchanged at 7.3 percent, and they expect that nonfarm payrolls will expand by 72,000.
"Everybody is being cautious in front of the numbers," said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C.L. King & Associates. "We are in a narrow range here, but the market has been acting really well."
Many retail stocks were active after stores reported April sales figures. Sears, Roebuck dropped 1 3/8, to 42, after its overall sales for the four weeks that ended May 2 dropped 3.9 percent. The Gap added 1 5/8, to 42 1/8, with April sales up 13 percent, relieving Wall Street fears of a slump for the store chain.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.94 to 415.85. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.35 to 394.12.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.48 points to 229.08. The average share fell 8 cents.
The Nasdaq over-the-counter index fell 2.20 to 587.16. The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 4,032.884, down 8.214 or 0.20 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amdahl Shifts Some Duties Among Its Top Executives

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7

 BODY:
The Amdahl Corporation today promoted E. Joseph Zemke, its president and chief operating officer, to chief executive. Mr. Zemke, who is 51 years old, succeeds John C. Lewis, 56, who will continue as chairman.
Amdahl, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is a leading maker of I.B.M.-compatible mainframe computers. 
 Mr. Lewis, who had been chief executive since 1983, said in a statement that the promotion of Mr. Zemke was consistent with the company's management succession plan for expanding the responsibilities of senior executives as Amdahl grows and diversifies.
"I don't regard this as indicative of change," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a Phoenix-based consulting concern that follows the mainframe market. "This is nothing more than a natural succession and recognition of a guy who's done well for Amdahl.
"Joe has been the hands-on guy when it comes to operational management, while Lewis is largely strategic. Prior to Zemke coming on board, Lewis kind of wore both hats."
Mr. Zemke, who joined Amdahl in 1985 as chief operating officer and was named president in 1987, said in a telephone interview that he expected to take on additional responsibility for long-range strategy and would turn over some day-to-day operations to other executives.
"I've been pretty much running the company for the past 18 months, even though I didn't have the title," he said.
Like its two competitors in the mainframe business, I.B.M. and Hitachi Data Systems, Amdahl has experienced a decline in earnings because of the recession and the transition to a new generation of products.
Mr. Zemke said Amdahl shipped the first of its new products in the fourth quarter, shipped about 20 units in the second, and will ship in volume in the third.
"We are not completely through that, but are now very much on the up slope," he said, adding that he expects earnings growth to resume in the second half of the year.
 
Gaining Market Share
 So-called plug-compatible manufacturers, like Amdahl and Hitachi, offer mainframes that can replace I.B.M. machines without modification. The plug-compatibles have been gaining market share from I.B.M. for several years, primarily by offering lower prices, superior performance or new features in advance of I.B.M. Amdahl, for example, was the first to offer a complete mainframe version of Unix, the industry standard software popular on workstations.
Before coming to Amdahl, Mr. Zemke had been president and chief executive of Auto-Trol Technology, a computer-aided design and manufacturing company based in Denver. Before that, he had been with I.B.M. for 18 years in a variety of sales and marketing management positions.
Mr. Zemke holds a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a bachelor's degree from the University of Detroit.

HEADLINE: Consumers Reduce Debt

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Consumers cut their debts in March and avoided taking on new loans that require monthly payments, figures published by the Federal Reserve Board showed today.
Federal policy makers say the steady whittling down of obligations taken on during the free-spending 1980's has been a brake on economic expansion but the trend means that Americans are getting their financial houses in order. 
 During March, total oustanding consumer installment credit dropped by a seasonally adjusted $1.61 billion, or at a 2.7 percent annual rate. That followed a smaller, $465 million decline at an eight-tenths of 1 percent rate in February.
Installment credit is any type of loan from borrowing for a new car to a personal loan that requires a consumer to pay it back in regular installments.
In Chicago today, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a banking conference that the drag on the economy from over-indebted consumers was waning.
Consumers fuel about two-thirds of national economic activity by purchasing goods and services, but consumption was restrained last year as a trend toward cutting debt loads became apparent.
The restraint continued in March, with consumers paying off $263 million more in outstanding auto loans than they took out in new ones. That followed a $489 million reduction in auto credit in February.
Similarly, in a category the Fed calls other loans, which includes all sorts of personal bank loans but not home mortgages, a huge $1.45 billion was paid off in March. In February, consumers reduced these loan balances by $721 million.
There was a slight expansion in outstanding credit-card debt, which grew by $55 million in March after a $1.14 billion increase in February, the Fed said.
Outstanding credit for buying mobile homes was up by $53 million in March. That was in sharp contrast to February, when mobile-home credit was reduced by $390 million.
The raw figures for the total of all debts owed by Americans have steadily fallen in each month so far this year.
Before seasonal adjustment, total outstanding consumer installment credit in March was $720.39 billion, down from $725.51 billion in February and from $733.26 billion in January.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Up a Bit

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The Government said today that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose a moderate 11,000, to 415,000, in late April, signaling persistent weakness in the jobs market.
Massachusetts and New Jersey, long mired in a downturn, bore the brunt of layoffs in the week ended April 25 because of cutbacks in the service sector, the Labor Department said. 
 The rise in initial claims broke a string of declines.
But the four-week average fell to 409,750 from 414,250, its lowest level in 18 months.
"We are moving ahead in fits and starts in the jobs market, just as we are in the rest of the economy," said Jean Sundrla, an analyst at Evans Economics Inc. in Washington.
In another hopeful sign, the latest bimonthly survey of business executives conducted by the United States Chamber of Commerce showed confidence about the economy at its highest level in two years. The chamber's Business Confidence Index rose in April to 63.3 percent from 59.1 percent in February, the last month it was measured.
The overall decline in claims the last four weeks also suggests that the unemployment rate for April, due out Friday, likely remained stable at 7.3 percent with a slight growth in the number of jobs in the economy, analysts said.
"We still have recovery, but one that is a meandering and plodding," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher as Germany Forgoes Interest-Rate Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher on worldwide markets yesterday after Germany's central bank decided against raising interest rates.
Gold prices lost ground here and abroad. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $335.60 an ounce, down $1.60 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $335.15 an ounce, off $1.45. 
 Currency traders said the dollar received a lift from the Bundesbank's policy makers, who left Germany's key Lombard and discount rates unchanged. Traders had been concerned that interest rates would rise because of the difficult wage negotiations between public-sector employees and the Government.
Higher German rates would have supported the German mark at the dollar's expense. In New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.6375 marks, from 1.6285 on Wednesday.
Traders, meanwhile, showed little reaction to yesterday's unemployment data, in which the Labor Department said that initial jobless claims rose 11,000 in the week that ended on April 25. Instead, attention remains focused on today's release of the April unemployment rate.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 132.18 Japanese yen, down from 132.70 yen on Wednesday. It traded higher in London, at 132.70 yen, and at 132.85 yen in New York, up from 132.25 yen on Wednesday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared with Wednesday's levels. Sterling rose to $1.7965 from $1.7940 in London, and fell to $1.7945 from $1.7970 in New York.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Wednesday, included: 1.5135 Swiss francs, up from 1.4980; 5.5165 French francs, up from 5.4860; 1,232 Italian lire, up from 1,224, and 1.19875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19705.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with those of late Wednesday, were: 1.6355 German marks, up from 1.6320; 1.5115 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.5100 French francs, up from 5.4950; 1.8420 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8365; 1,230.75 Italian lire, up from 1,226.50, and 1.1987 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1965.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Riots Put Focus On Economic Ills

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHAT effect will the Los Angeles riots have on the nation's economic and social agenda?
It is too early to say whether the outbreak of violence, looting and burning that followed the acquittal of four members of the Los Angeles Police Department in the beating of Rodney King will have any lasting effect. 
 Nevertheless, the crisis in Los Angeles has wrenched the public out of its boredom and cynicism about the political campaign and focused the minds of public and politicians alike on the social and economic ills that have been afflicting the nation -- and particularly on its poorest and most excluded members, the blacks and other minorities.
Coming in the midst of the Presidential campaign, this crisis appeared to deepen the ideological divisions between the Republican and Democratic party leaders.
President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, blamed failed Democratic policies of the 1960's for the riots. And Mr. Bush, flying to Los Angeles, said, "It is far more important to give people a piece of the action than it is to have the Federal Government dump largesse on them."
Gov. Bill Clinton, on the other hand, said the rioting in Los Angeles and other cities was caused by "12 years of denial and neglect" of festering social problems by Republican administrations.
Thus, a political campaign that started as a contest for the votes of the middle class has suddenly been transformed into a fight over the issues of poverty, urban neglect, jobs and race -- and how to deal with them. A solution is critical to the recovery of the United States, which has been long haunted by fears of national decline. There are no simple or single-dimensional answers.
On the economic front, the most important need is for more jobs. As Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, stressed even before the riots, these can be created quickly by expanding the Job Corps, combining employment with training, and by outlays on roads, highways, bridges, conservation and other public projects.
Private enterprise also has an important role to play in rebuilding the central cities. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp's urban enterprise zones deserve support not only from the Bush Administration, whose attention he has at last captured, but from Democrats as well.
For the longer run, solving the jobs problem will require the combined efforts of government, business and community groups, especially to improve the quality and scope of American education at every level, to enable the future work force to produce more effectively, to raise living standards and meet the tests of worldwide competition.
Excellent foreign models exist for reforming United States vocational education. A Federal tax credit for business investment in human resources would help many workers, including the young and unemployed, to improve their skills.
Policies for long-run growth in jobs and living standards will demand a higher rate of national savings and investment. That in turn will require a steady narrowing of the Federal budget deficit, and a restructuring of the budget to meet the nation's most urgent domestic needs.
Support is growing in Congress for a balanced-budget amendment, with alternative plans being offered by Democrats and Republicans. This could prove to be another failure, like the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, but it demonstrates Congress's renewed shame over its past lack of political will and discipline. No budget law can be a Procrustean bed, forcing budget cuts regardless of national needs. There is no substitute for political will, intelligence and guts.
The age of excuses and rationalizations, whether by politicians or their economic advisers, for slipshod budgetary policies may be coming to an end. But the harder job is to trim unneeded programs, whether in the military or civilian areas. And if essential programs are needed to deal with the urgent needs of the the poor, the jobless, the cities, education and infrastructure, and cannot be financed by deep enough cuts in other areas, taxes must be raised to pay for them. Better fiscal policy will clear the way for stronger economic growth.
The Los Angeles riots should serve as a reminder that economic growth is no cure-all. America's problems of race and poverty, crime and family disintegration festered and worsened during the Reagan years of growth. These problems cannot be solved by trickle-down economics but will need to be addressed directly, as through improved local police forces, Job Corps programs for youthful offenders, Head Start programs for young children, prenatal and neonatal care for mothers and children, equitable distribution of resources among school districts and other measures.
Most important of all is a heightened national concern for those left behind by national economic progress, and a recognition that progress will cease and give way to anger, despair and retrogression unless the nation acts to repair the growing split between rich and poor, white and black.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Stephanie Zimbalist as a Victim of Harassment

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
A sure sign that the subject of sexual harassment is not about to disappear soon: It has become the stuff of television movies. This weekend's pat but pointed example is "Sexual Advances," the "ABC Sunday Night Movie" at 9. Stephanie Zimbalist dispenses with much of her normal icy poise to portray a happily married woman who finds herself transformed rather rapidly from rising corporate star to shaken victim.
Paula Pratt (Ms. Zimbalist) works for Hyper Velocity, a Tacoma, Wash., company specializing in athletic shoes. As promotion manager, she focuses on athlete endorsements. When one athlete threatens to break his contract because of patronizing treatment from the company attorney Jack French (William Russ), the account is given exclusively to Paula. Although Jack seems unruffled, he soon starts bombarding Paula with sexual propositions, not in the least put off by her continued insistence that she is not interested. 
 Complicating matters, Paula's unemployed husband, Marshall (Patrick James Clarke), a former football player, is looking for a college coaching job and her company might be able to help. Paula is trapped, and the marriage begins to suffer. She does go to the top boss, Cliff (Terry O'Quinn), and explain what is happening. Cliff is sympathetic, but Jack is a top-notch negotiator and is considered extremely valuable to the company. When Paula finally reaches the breaking point, after a smarmy telephone call to her home, she ponders filing a sexual-harassment suit. A company lawyer soon appears with an offer for a very generous financial settlement, contingent on her leaving quietly.
Being a television movie, "Sexual Advances" is not so much written as nailed together, the carpentry intended to deliver a message but with as much understanding as possible for everyone involved. Jack is a dreadful lout, but there may be mitigating circumstances. He was recently divorced and the loss of that account has left him, literally, sick to his stomach. Some female co-workers sympathize with Paula; some don't. And, just to be on the safe side, Paula herself is no prude. Cliff has a habit of patting her buttocks and grasping her warmly, but she has no objections. It is all a question, evidently, of attitude.
Will Paula settle and walk away, or will she stay and fight? My lips are sealed, but the outcome should strike fear into those politicians who, up until recently, have been grossly underestimating the fallout from an explosive issue.
 
'Abbado in Berlin
The First Year'
PBS
Tonight at 8
The first hour of this "Great Performances" presentation offers an intriguing video-verite portrait of the Italian conductor Claudio Abbado, who succeeded Herbert von Karajan as music director of the Berlin Philharmonic. The delicate transition teeters on the demands of the musicians for more democracy, fueled by the still lingering bitterness over Karajan's dictatorial reign. Abbado's diplomacy and sensitivity, especially evident in his nurturing of a teen-age East German pianist named Siiri Schutz, eventually triumph. In the second hour, Abbado conducts the Berlin in a complete performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 1. As one German critic says of the conductor, "One could do things differently, but I doubt if they could be done better."
 
'Dame Edna's Hollywood'
NBC
Tomorrow at 10 P.M.
Festooned in glittering gown, purple-hued bouffant wig and sparkling eyeglasses, the Australian performer Barry Humphries is back for his second American special as eagerly naughty Dame Edna. The character is very popular in England. This time, Dame Edna's guests, who keep showing up despite canceled invitations, include Kim Basinger wearing a tattoo on her right breast and very little else (she left modeling, a giggly Ms. Basinger reveals, because "I wanted my inside to come out"), George Hamilton trapped in a tanning machine ("He'll be beef jerky soon," promises Dame Edna), and Chevy Chase looking increasingly sulky as the host keeps out-quipping him. Best bit: Robin Williams as a pizza deliverer convinced that Dame Edna is Elizabeth Taylor and that her frumpy, dour housekeeper is Nancy Reagan. "Just a picture of you and Nancy," he begs, pulling out his camera. "I can pay for my house." Says Dame Edna: "This is ridiculous, possums." Exactly. But enough of a hoot nonetheless.

HEADLINE: At (or on) a TV Show: Free Fun For a Few

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
THE hottest ticket in New York this weekend is actually free. But there's no point in asking what line you can stand in to try to get one. You had to get in line last August. And you had to have the luck of Sky Masterson.
About 200 people have free tickets to see Bruce Springsteen perform three songs tomorrow night. They'll also see Tom Hanks doing comedy for no extra charge. 
 These people had no idea whom they would be seeing when they learned they were the winners of the lottery that deals out the tickets to NBC's "Saturday Night Live." The tickets were drawn at the end of last August.
The 16-year-old late-night comedy show provides one of the half-dozen or so opportunities to take part in national television as it is being made in New York City. It often isn't easy to get tickets to attend these shows: the sooner you start the process, the better, even for next season's programs. But the rewards are significant for the patient. And the fortunate.
Not only do you get to watch an occasional great performance or see a famous face up close, but you may end up on the small screen yourself, in the company of Dave, Phil, Sally, Joan, Geraldo, or Regis and Kathie Lee on a national talk show.
In fact, all the talk shows that are based in Manhattan need and seek studio audiences. Many of them, including "Sally Jessy Raphael" and "Donahue," actually incorporate questions from the audience into each show. But the wait between the time tickets are requested and when they are received obviously varies widely, and, not surprisingly, it is usually contingent on how well a show is doing in the ratings.
The long-running hit "Donahue," for example, which is broadcast from the NBC studios in Rockefeller Center, has a wait of two to five months for tickets. But representatives of the less popular "Geraldo," which is taped at CBS Broadcast Center on West 57th Street, say fans have to wait only about six weeks to get into their show. The wait for seeing Joan Rivers, whose show is also taped at CBS Studios, is reasonably short, too, usually less than two months.
But "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee," taped at WABC's studios in Lincoln Square, is one of the hottest shows right now, which translates into a long wait for tickets: up to 10 months.
One possible strategy for fans is simply to fly standby: show up on the day of the telecast and try for what are known as standby seats. "Late Night With David Letterman," which is so popular it holds a ticket lottery every four months, gives out standby tickets -- one to a customer -- Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8:15 A.M. Fans come and pick them up, show up in the afternoon for the taping at Rockefeller Center, and hope for enough no-shows that day to be able to squeeze into 1 of the 200 or so seats in the Letterman studio.
Because "Saturday Night Live" is performed just once a week and only 20 times a year (the last show of the season is May 16 at 11:30 P.M.), it is unquestionably the toughest television ticket in town. If anything, getting tickets will be harder next season, because the show has enjoyed a significant resurgence this season, with its highest ratings in 11 years.
Things have gone so well that the show's executive producer, Lorne Michaels, who created the series in 1975, is a bit worried. He says he has seen the cycle of dizzying success hit before, and it was always followed by a dispiriting deflation. "My hope is we'll get through this little period of success," he said.
The latest surge of success for the series has extended to Mr. Michaels personally. He was named the broadcaster of the year by the International Radio and Television Society, an honor that probably won't help much when he sets out to renegotiate with his cast of rising stars. At the moment, Mr. Michaels said, he expects every member of this year's regular cast to be back next season.
 
With a Little Help. . . .
 The easiest way to get a ticket to "Saturday Night Live," and the only way to procure one for a specific performance, is to be a client, friend or relative of somebody officially connected to the program. As with most other shows, this category accounts for a significant portion of the "Saturday Night Live" audience: about one-third of the house total of about 300.
But members of the public still have a chance to get a ticket to either the dress rehearsal or live show, as long as they know the rigidly enforced rules for applying. To get tickets for next season, here's the procedure: send a postcard (no letters or you're out), make sure it's postmarked this August, and be willing to drop everything else that's happening in your life to show up at NBC on whatever date comes up if you win. Each fan selected in the "Saturday Night Live" lottery -- held only once a year -- receives two tickets.
The odds on this lottery are certainly better than, say, a $30 million Lotto, but they're still not great. Rosemary Keenan, the spokeswoman for the show, says "Saturday Night Live" receives "many, many thousands" of requests for tickets, even though the series makes little effort to publicize its ticket process.
Clearly, "Saturday Night Live," even after all these years on the air, remains one of the biggest events on television, both for viewers and performers. In the past season, the show has attracted such hosts as Michael Jordan, Roseanne Arnold, Macaulay Culkin and Jason Priestly, and such musical guests as Bonnie Raitt, Nirvana, Hammer, Garth Brooks and Public Enemy. Then there were surprise appearances by stars like Madonna and Barbra Streisand.
 
Help From a Movie
 And when "Wayne's World," the movie made from the "Saturday Night" sketch starring Michael Myers and Dana Carvey, exploded at the box office this spring, the show got some extra sparks.
That was apparent three weeks ago when the host was Jerry Seinfeld, star of the increasingly popular NBC sitcom "Seinfeld." The fans who lined up in the lobby of 30 Rockefeller Center, the NBC headquarters, in their jeans and designer athletic shoes, buzzed with the anticipation of those about to go to a party they know they'll enjoy twice, the second time when they get to rub it in to their friends.
This weekend "Saturday Night" is even more of an event, with a Sunday-night special at 9 o'clock on NBC -- a collection of the best sketches of the season and special Mother's Day material with the real-life mothers of the cast -- complementing the coup of landing Mr. Springsteen for tomorrow night's show. He will be performing live on television for the first time ever. No edition of "Saturday Night" since 1978, when the Rolling Stones appeared, has had so many requests for tickets, Ms. Keenan said.
To be exact, Mr. Springsteen will be doing two shows tomorrow night. But the first one will be seen only in New York. Lottery-winning ticketholders are the only people to see the "Saturday Night Live" dress rehearsal, which, like the live version, is staged in NBC's Studio 8-H.
 
Longer Show at Rehearsal
 Mr. Michaels says he understands that some members of the rehearsal audience are "a little resentful that they're not at the live show." But in truth, getting rehearsal tickets instead of live tickets has certain benefits. Even though they don't get a chance to be seen clapping on camera everywhere from here to Nome, Alaska, the dress-rehearsal audience members do get something special: about 20 minutes more comedy. By design, the dress rehearsal includes three to five sketches too many to fit into the live show.
For example, on the Seinfeld show, the audience for the live version never saw Mr. Seinfeld as James Madison in a sketch about former Presidents coming back to life and facing a hostile press, or as an old high-wire performer reminiscing about the night the act bit the dust. The show's newscast spoof, "Weekend Update," runs almost twice as long at the rehearsal, and many of the sketches that do make it to the broadcast have been cut by a minute or more.
Then there's the material that doesn't get by the NBC censors. The rehearsal is almost always a bit wilder, a bit more over the edge than the live rendition. A recent show starring the actress Sharon Stone of "Basic Instinct" experienced some radical censor surgery between the rehearsal and the live performance.
 
Unused Material Is Saved
 A lot of the material that doesn't make the first cut is rewritten and eventually turns up in later shows. Only the Seinfeld rehearsal audience will know if Mr. Seinfeld was a better James Madison than some other host -- maybe Mr. Hanks this week -- who makes it on the air impersonating the fourth President.
The one real advantage of the live show, Mr. Michaels says, is that the performers clearly save something for the program the whole nation sees. "You don't want to peak too early," he says. "That's a rookie mistake."
Nevertheless, there's a crucial reason why some might prefer "Saturday Night Rehearsed": you get home before dawn. The rehearsal starts about 7:30 or 8 and ends by 10 to 10:30 P.M. Then the house is cleared and the live audience is admitted. They won't get out till 1 A.M. The live audience also can't watch the show as it goes over the air until the tape is rewound. The rehearsal audience is usually home in time to watch "Saturday Night Live" live.
That makes it possible to see how Mr. Michaels puts the show together, what he cuts, what he thinks worked. From the beginning, the idea of doing two shows in one night was to find out which of the sketches, all created in tiny rooms during the week by frenzied writers who sometimes lose touch with reality, really make people laugh.
During Mr. Seinfeld's stint, a sketch about a "Jeopardy"-like game show for stand-up comedians appeared two-thirds of the way through the rehearsal. It was so hilariously successful that for the live show Mr. Michaels made it the first sketch after the introduction, where he usually places what he considers the best bit of the night.
One last piece of advice for enjoying "Saturday Night Live" in person: arrive early. For either show. Studio 8-H is no stadium. Officially, it "holds" about 300; by no accident, the operative verb here is not "seats." The studio has about 200 seats: everybody else is squeezed in wherever possible. The last 50 or so people admitted usually wind up on the steps in the aisles or on the floor of what is known as "the ledge," behind the last row of seats.
No one ever asks for a refund.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonilla Hears the 2 Lonely Words: Strike 3!

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, May 7

 BODY:
The game was on the line, the pitch was on the corner, the bat was on Bobby Bonilla's shoulder. The umpire punched the air, and the latest, disquieting deflation for the Mets was complete.
Bonilla's strikeout against Rob Dibble with the bases loaded and two out in the seventh inning rendered almost certain the 4-2 loss the Mets suffered to the Reds, and left Bonilla standing and staring at the plate. Having lacked the resources to do anything with Dibble's 3-2 fastball, Bonilla was without the conviction to argue Mark Hirschbeck's called third strike. 
 "I told him I thought it was in the same spot as the ball-three pitch," said Bonilla. "He said it was nastier. It wasn't an objection."
 
Remains in Empty Dugout
 Bonilla's dejection afterward, though, sent him searching for solitude. The right fielder with the huge contract and the great taste for competitive moments sat in an empty dugout and looked out on an emptying Riverfront Stadium. On and on he stayed. At last, with all the seats in sight vacated, Bonilla got up and left his.
"I was trying to gather my thoughts," said Bonilla.
There was, though, no recovering the misspent last 72 hours for the Mets, no regathering of a road trip that deteriorated from 3-1 to 3-4, no reassembling of a defense that came apart, no repairing the botched mechanics that ended Dwight Gooden's afternoon after five innings.
"I'm not comfortable with the way we've played," said Manager Jeff Torborg.
Indeed, the Mets hadn't experienced the discomfort of losing more than one game in a row since the season's first weekend. But suddenly, the figure of straight losses is at three. There was no alarm in the clubhouse, but there was an absence of what had been a burgeoning bravado.
"Super pitching can allow you to overcome mistakes," said Torborg. "Pitching sets the tone."
 
Three Errors for Mets
 The afternoon's tone was discordant from the moment Gooden took the mound. The Reds got a man on in the first and had a run across instants later after Dave Magadan contributed the first of the club's three errors.
"Doc struggled -- with his mechanics and all game," said Torborg. "He got out of whack."
And then another inning got out of control in the third. The disorder began with Gooden walking pitcher Chris Hammond to start the inning and then yielding a double to Bip Roberts. Eddie Murray's error as he attempted to come up with Dave Martinez's bouncer to first led to one run, Reggie Sanders's single delivered another and then Gooden's pickoff attempt at second base resulted in another error and, one groundout later, another run.
"It was a bluff," Gooden said of shortstop Dick Schofield's terminated break to the bag at second for the pickoff play. "I should have held the baseball."
Gooden never felt right with the baseball in his hands all afternoon. The movement of his hips and the drive of his legs through his delivery had left him twisted in confusion and awkwardness. In what was his shortest outing of the season, Gooden was lifted by Torborg before the sixth inning, his total of walks at four, his pitch count disturbingly high.
"That's the time when someone could hurt themselves," said Torborg.
What bruised Gooden most wasn't his early removal, but his lack of control. His fastball since surgery is not yet where he wants it, and so the requirement that he be sharp is all the more unforgiving.
"I never just reared back and threw it, anyway. I always tried to hit spots. It's just been harder," Gooden explained. "I'm frustrated with the walks. I've walked leadoff guys, pitchers, guys with two outs. It's a lack of concentration."
 
Trouble in the Clutch
 The entire afternoon was concentrated into the squareoff involving Bonilla and Dibble in the seventh. Dibble had been summoned with the bases loaded and two out and Bonilla at the plate. The Mets' right fielderhad a lot to make up for. He has not had a home run since the season opener, he had only four extra-base hits in the last 27 games and he had gone 2 for 16 with men in scoring position over the last several weeks.
"Those are the moments where you get your memories from," said Bonilla. "I was going for it."
And Dibble, who had his best fastball of the season (96 miles per hour), was coming right at him. He threw six straight fastballs -- all away, the last one catching the last fraction of the right side of the plate.
"I said earlier in the season that there is no one in the game I'd want up more than Bobby in that situation," said Magadan.
Bonilla was left looking at the umpire's fist, the ninth time he has taken a called third strike in the last 12 times he has struck out.
"When it rains, it pours," said Bonilla. "But the sun has got to come out soon."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Mets on Thursday claimed Cubs utility man CHICO WALKER on waivers. Walker, 33 years old, was hitting .115 in 19 games with the Cubs this season. Last year, he hit .257 for the Cubs in 374 at-bats. To make room on the roster, the Mets sent CHRIS DONNELS to Tidewater.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GENERAL TIRE TO CUT U.S. WORK FORCE BY 3.3 PERCENT

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
General Tire Inc. said it would cut its United States salaried work force by 100, or about 3.3 percent, and transfer about 60 employees as part of a previously announced restructuring. The layoffs will take place between now and the end of the year, and most will occur at the company's operations in Akron, Ohio. Sixty technical-staff employees will be transferred to manufacturing operations at Charlotte, N.C.; Mayfield, Ky.; Mount Vernon, Ill., and Bryan, Ohio. 
 General Tire, a unit of Continental A.G. of Germany, has 3,000 domestic salaried employees and 5,000 hourly workers. The company said earlier this month that it would reorganize into three major business units: passenger and light-truck tires, commercial tires and corporate support.
