HEADLINE: Mr. Rohatyn's Proper Role

 BODY:
Once again, City Hall and Felix Rohatyn disagree over the use of $200 million in surplus money at New York's Municipal Assistance Corporation. Gov. Mario Cuomo and Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the M.A.C., want the money for public schools. Mayor David Dinkins would use it for productivity agreements with labor -- perhaps to grant raises in exchange for long-term savings.
Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez has put together a very attractive proposal for the money. The Dinkins administration has no specific plan yet, and the idea of using the surplus for wage increases in the 1993 mayoral election year is troubling. 
 Once City Hall does develop a proposal, who should decide where the money goes -- Mr. Rohatyn or Mr. Dinkins? The Mayor, accountable to the people who elected him, has to make the decision. Mr. Rohatyn, who is appointed by the governor, has a more limited role. His primary responsibility is to protect his bondholders. If he found City Hall's proposal financially irresponsible, he'd have every right to keep the surplus and use it to pay off M.A.C. debt. But if his objections are political rather than fiduciary, he should not be in a position to withhold the surplus.
Mr. Rohatyn objects to spending the surplus on labor, arguing that could hurt the city economy and, therefore, bondholders. But he needs to wait for the city's plan to make that judgment.
Mr. Rohatyn has chosen to impose not only his fiduciary values but his social values on the budget. Fortunately his values are sensible and humane. But his abiding concern for the city puts him in danger of overreaching. Indeed, the M.A.C. surplus is, in a sense, city money, because the interest and principal on M.A.C. bonds are paid using part of the city's sales tax revenues.
While Mr. Rohatyn prefers giving the surplus to schools, he will accept any fiscally responsible request the Mayor and Governor agree on. That approach has resolved the use of over $3 billion in past M.A.C. surpluses; it can work again.

HEADLINE: An Environmentalist? Bush? Forget It.

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former Editor of the Editorial Page of The New York Times.

 BODY:
With the environmental security of America and the world at risk, President Bush is playing a cynical political game. To support his claim that he is an environmentalist, he has apparently decided to attend the U.N. Conference on Environment and Development -- the so-called Earth summit -- in Rio de Janeiro next month. But Mr. Bush is no environmentalist.
If he were, he would long ago have discarded his fears of the right wings of both parties. He would have had the vision to grasp the leadership of this international effort to control forces that present a greater threat to civilization than the cold war ever did. 
 Instead, by longstanding indifference, if not hostility, to the Rio meeting and a negative approach to many of its complex issues, the Administration has nearly sabotaged it.
By holding off on accepting the Rio invitation for months, Mr. Bush discouraged other heads of state from coming, but not some close friends and keen competitors, including Japan, Britain, Germany and Canada. Their leaders understand what is at stake.
The third world's demand for first world economic and technical help to meet the environmental crisis has brought on a super-crisis of its own. This is the quandary the summit faces, and only first world leadership can solve it. Mr. Bush, supported by his party and Congress and untroubled by the flaccid Democrats, is not providing that leadership.
Whether he goes to the Rio meeting is now of less importance than the impact of Administration foot-dragging on the issues to be considered there. They include the advance of global warming and the linkage among poverty, population, destruction of forest resources and loss of species in the developing world. Combating these dangers requires major help from the first world.
No better example of the Government's obtuseness on environmental and economic issues can be found than in its near-sabotaging of the "climate convention" intended for signature at Rio. This treaty would require industrial countries to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
Carbon dioxide is the most profuse of the greenhouse gases that cause global warming: a catastrophe in the making that, unless checked, will raise sea levels, drown coastal areas and change agricultural production before the end of the 21st century.
Every major industrial nation has agreed to stabilize its carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels within eight years. Only the U.S. has refused to make a legally binding commitment to do so. President Bush has said such a treaty would "put a lot of Americans out of work."
This is disinformation. The truth has finally leaked out: The Government has just admitted that measures it has taken and is willing to take to increase energy efficiency would come close to meeting the proposed emission goals. The gas industry points out that cutting emissions even 10 percent below 1990 levels by the turn of the century would create more than 80,000 new jobs.
But without a legally binding commitment to reach these easily attainable levels, promises to try to meet them are evasive at best and deceptive at worst. Politicians' promises are valueless. Commitments in law are something else. Mr. Bush will long since have been out of office by the year 2000, the treaty's deadline. By then, he will (or should) have gone down in history, second only to Ronald Reagan, as America's anti-environmental President.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
More Arms, Less Aid

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Poor countries now spend about $175 billion yearly on arms and soldiers. That is more than double the development aid they receive from all sources.
With growth slowing in rich nations and with new demands for aid by states of the ex-Soviet empire, poor countries have only one place to turn for big government bucks -- themselves. To avoid deeper poverty they will have to shift their own funds from military accounts to economic development. 
 International lending institutions like the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have recently begun prodding poor states to think about this trade-off. The bankers use common sense and moral suasion -- not exactly heavy artillery.
Germany and Japan have just adopted a tougher and more direct approach. They are now explicitly tying their development aid to cuts in recipient military spending.
The idea is daring and promising, if they stick with it -- and more importantly, if the international banks play an even bolder role. It then could prove to be a major step forward in post-cold-war diplomacy, whose core will be to use economic power for both economic and security ends.
Tokyo and Bonn know that this power must be employed delicately. No nation, no matter how destitute, likes to be told how much military "security" to buy.
So Japan's strategy is mainly to reward, not bully. "If the recipient makes some effort to cut military expenditures and spend more on economic development, we appreciate that effort and give some kind of bonus," explained a Japanese diplomat.
Germany also prefers rewards for cuts, but is prepared to play rougher. One of its criteria for giving aid is that the recipient concentrate resources on health, education and the like. "In many countries," reads the official German policy, "it will not be possible to achieve this without reducing exaggerated defense expenditures." For this and other reasons, Bonn has announced reductions in aid to the likes of India, China and Pakistan.
Tokyo threatens stern measures when weapons of mass destruction are involved. For example, Japan delivered this hard, public message to North Korea: No diplomatic recognition or aid unless you open up all your nuclear facilities to international inspection. But the issue here for Tokyo was the nukes, not Pyongyang's overall military budget.
In any event, Germany and Japan cannot take on the military spending/ development challenge alone. It might help if the Bush Administration lent its weight. But the United States is not the problem here. Contrary to liberal hand-wringing, America has been pretty good over the years in not hawking arms to the poorest countries. Egypt and Pakistan have been the notable exceptions.
The principal arms merchants to the poor have been the old Soviet Union, Britain, France, China, India, Brazil and Czechoslovakia. These countries are not about to forfeit cash and restrain their sales. The Bush Administration is urging limits anyway, though it is not pushing very hard. And it is right not to invest much time or hope in such a complicated enterprise.
The problem is not going to be dented by individual donors and arms suppliers putting on a pretense of restraint -- or with ad hoc restraint by enlightened states like Germany and Japan. Which brings the discussion back to the big international banks.
"These banks have to take more of the lead," argues C. Fred Bergsten, a formidable international economist. "It's easy for Japan or the U.S. to tell others not to sell arms, but they'll sell anyway and poor nations will buy anyway. The banks give everyone an umbrella for agreeing on a consistent and comprehensive policy."
The appeal of this approach is that no one nation has to be out front. The I.M.F. and World Bank provide a cover for individual lenders to collar their own arms salesmen and be tougher on buyers.
Lewis T. Preston, president of the World Bank, and even more so Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, have already gotten their boards to agree on pressing borrowers to curb their defense spending. And bank officials have been rightly attentive to the complexities and sensitivities of the issue. But they owe it to the poor, now sinking further into despair, to press harder still.

HEADLINE: King Case Speaks of Our Grave Condition

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The 20th century should have taught us that to be silent in the face of egregious injustice is to be complicit in it. In the 1980's, in the wake of the bombing of a synagogue in Paris and desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, French citizens of all ethnic and racial backgrounds demonstrated under the slogan "We Are All Jews."
In this same spirit, following the verdict in the trial of four Los Angeles police officers for beating Rodney King and the understandable if unjustified avenging riots in several black ghettos, concerned Americans should rally around the battle cry "We Are All African-Americans." 
 This is particularly urgent in an increasingly brutalizing "free"-market and imperial society, in which too many politicians and intellectuals unwittingly contribute to turning African-Americans into helpless lightning rods for the spiraling frustrations and resentments of a vast but powerless lower middle class that spans the full ethnic spectrum.
As Washington preaches and dictates human rights around the globe it needs to be reminded that to fix excessively on the mote in the eyes of others is to risk ignoring or deflecting attention from the beam in our own.
The extravagant overrepresentation of African-Americans among the unemployed, the poor, the sick and prison inmates in this country is not acceptable, even by the minimum standards of the so-called "first" world. There is no way of understanding and changing the dehumanizing conditions in the ghettos of our inner cities without confronting and challenging the racist attitudes and policies that help foster them.
The road to the end of democracy will remain paved with compassion and lamentation unless combined with critical social thought, as well as systematic and massive programs for social and racial justice without exceptions. Ironically, should the verdict be nullified, it is likely to assuage the guilty liberal conscience without which even cosmetic reforms will remain stillborn.
But whatever the reasons for what Gunnar Myrdal even a half-century ago called "the American dilemma," it is nothing short of criminal to blame the victims.
 
ARNO J. MAYER
Dayton-Stockton Professor of European History, Princeton U.
Princeton, N.J., May 5, 1992

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
A Show of Attention Brings A Show of Wearied Shrugs

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 7

 BODY:
To the residents of South-Central Los Angeles, the visit of the President of the United States to their devastated neighborhood was at best welcomed as a needed show of attention, at worst rejected as irrelevant.
Mr. Bush came with the quiet of dawn and left with a whoosh of his motorcade at 9:59 A.M., almost before anybody knew he was in the " 'hood." 
 "Let's go, folks, hustle up -- we're moving out," shouted a Secret Service agent to drivers in the caravan of limousines and vans waiting on East 50th Street outside the Mount Zion Missionary Baptist Church, where the President met local leaders, among them Roger Cardinal Mahony. With that, the President's tour of South-Central Los Angeles was over, about three hours after it started.
"We appreciate he's here to help," said Coral Turner, an aircraft factory worker who has lived on East 50th Street for 46 years. "But you cannot drive in here in Mercedes-Benzes and feel how we live, how we feel."
Still, to the Rev. Edward V. Hill, the pastor of the church, the event was historic, a good omen. "We've never had a President come to the heart of the ghetto," he said. "The more he is exposed to these kinds of leaders, the Cardinal, ex-gang members, he cannot help but be impressed."
He added that he thought the visit would lead both to Federal indictments of four white police officers, whose acquittal on charges connected to the beating of a black motorist touched off the disorders, and to a cooperative effort to rebuild.
 
No 'Big Deal'
 The residents of the South-Central area, however, were mostly more cynical, more resigned, less hopeful. Edward Criswell, a 40-year-old tow-truck operator, barely took notice of the President's motorcade as it passed him on Crenshaw Boulevard.
"I don't get the feeling like he wanted to see anybody here," said Mr. Criswell, who is black. "He just wanted to see the damage and get out. He's not going to be any big deal in my life."
And James Jones, who is 18 years old and unemployed, stared at the dirt in front of his graffiti-scarred apartment around the corner from the Mount Zion church and said of Mr. Bush: "I've got nothing to say to him. Ain't nothing going to happen. I'm just going to live my little life."
After the first of his two stops -- an inspection of the burned and looted Crenshaw Town Center shopping plaza -- the President's motorcade sped east toward the church on Vernon Avenue. If he could see much at the high speed, the President witnessed terrible destruction: the burned Cashland Check Cashing store, boarded-up gas stations, the burned corner at Vernon and Central Avenue that resembled a scene from Beirut.
The neighborhood around the church is emblematic of the rapidly changing demographics of the South-Central area. Black families live alongside newcomers from Mexico and Latin America in small bungalow-style houses, some of them immaculately kept behind gardens of oleander and hibiscus, others in disrepair. Gang graffiti are everywhere; the alleys are littered with rotted old furniture, tires and trash.
Yolanda Limon, a clothing store clerk born in Mexico, stood before her green stucco house behind a white iron fence on 50th Street and watched the crowd of reporters and organizers at the church. "We think it's good because it makes a difference for him to see this," she said. "We expect something to come of it.
"But while he is in there talking, the drug dealers are out here selling," she said, pointing down the street.
For most of the young black men in the neighborhood, the President's visit elicited not even a glimmer of hope. In interviews, they expressed anger not so much at the poverty in which they lived as at a justice system that they say offers little justice.
"I'm surprised it took this to get him here," said Sammie Rhodes, a 26-year-old newspaper deliveryman. He said he and most other young black men in the neighborhood had been beaten by police officers at one time or another, like the motorist, Rodney G. King.
"The system does not work," he said. "They call it justice, but it's 'just us.' "
At age 37, Foster Mijares, a black truck driver, was not as angry as the younger men, though he was skeptical about the President. "He's sincere, in the sense he is worried about what happened," he said. "It could happen in any other city. It took something like this to bring him out."
 
Where Are 'Regular People'?
 The President, he went on, was seeing the wrong people, meeting mainly with the established black leadership. "He needs to see regular people, not just the representatives of the community who really don't live here. We need some people who'll tell the truth," he said.
His neighbor, Ms. Turner, agreed. She said she was a member of the church but had not been invited to the ecumenical service with the President.
"To me it feels like a political thing," she said. "It was done all wrong. They should take four or five people who could not go to the store, the park, who don't have jobs. If you have a carton of milk and take the cream off the top, you have no idea what the milk tastes like." (In fact, the President did meet at the church after the service with a group of neighborhood residents whose businesses and jobs had been wiped out.)
Asked who they looked to for leadership in the aftermath of the riots, if not President Bush, few could think of anyone else. A couple mentioned the Rev. Jesse Jackson or Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, without great enthusiasm. No one mentioned Tom Bradley, the black man who has been mayor of Los Angeles since 1974, or Gov. Pete Wilson of California.
"Bush doesn't speak to the problems, but I haven't heard anyone who does," said Ed Matthews, an unemployed real estate broker, standing in front of his house just a block from the burned shopping mall Mr. Bush visited.
 
No Different From Washington
 "It's a nice gesture that he came to see the damage but it's just the political maneuver that people in his position need to do," Mr. Matthews said. "I don't think it will make any difference to solving the underlying problems. He's not going to see anything all that different here than he could see in Washington: It's poverty."
Nearby, Jose Leal, the 23-year-old security guard at the shopping mall, was miffed that the Secret Service forced him to leave his post and move across the street, where he could not see the President he voted for. He was worried that the President's mission might fail.
"The word is out in the neighborhood: no justice, no peace," he said. "If Bush is really going to fix it, he's got to start with the Rodney King case. From there, a lot will be cleared from people's minds."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about residents' reactions to President Bush's visit to areas in South-Central Los Angeles damaged in riots referred incorrectly to Mayor Tom Bradley. He has been Mayor since 1973, not 1974.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1179 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
BUSH PLEDGES HELP TO RIOT-TORN AREA

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
President Bush concluded his 38-hour inspection tour of Los Angeles today, offering words of compassion for anguished welfare mothers and victims of street violence, and a promise that "government has an absolute responsibility to solve these problems."
He announced a $19 million aid package for Los Angeles that includes more money for Head Start programs, health and drug-treatment clinics, housing for about 175 low-income families, worker retraining and law enforcement to combat drug dealers. 
 As a point of comparison, $80 million alone will be spent on the Head Start programs in Los Angeles County in the year that will end in September, according to the Federal Department of Health and Human Services.
 
No 'Status Quo,' He Says
 As he left Los Angeles this afternoon for Washington, Mr. Bush vowed not to permit a "return to the status quo." Hoping to discourage any renewed violence, the White House went out of its way to let people know that Federal troops, while no longer on the streets, were still close at hand and that the National Guard remained under Federal command.
But Mr. Bush offered few long-term solutions to the problems he acknowledged, apart from announcing that he would ask Congress to reconsider proposals he has been making for more than three years. These include creating incentives for businesses to invest in urban areas, allowing parents to choose which public school their child attends and establishing new rules to cut down on lawsuits.
Aware that he was exposing himself again to criticism that he was repackaging old ideas to meet a new demand for action, Mr. Bush said: "I know some will say, 'Well, you've proposed this before.' And that's true. They're right. And I'm proposing it again. Because really, we must try something new."
 
'Take Time to Put Things Right'
 White House aides had billed today's speech, given to the Challenger Boys' and Girls' Club in the South-Central section, as the capstone of his trip to Los Angeles, a summation of how the nation had come to the nights of violence last week and what the President proposed to do about it.
Indeed, Mr. Bush sought to present a broader look at America's problems than he has previously offered in an Administration that has focused primarily on the problems of business and not the inner cities. "This tragedy seemed to come suddenly, but I think we would all agree it's been many years in the making," Mr. Bush said. "I know it will take time to put things right."
Criticized for years as lacking understanding of the problems of the poor, the homeless, the unemployed and minorities, Mr. Bush admitted that he "can hardly imagine the fear and the anger that people must feel to terrorize one another and burn each other's property."
But the address, which Administration officials were still wrangling over late Thursday night, was essentially a modified version of Mr. Bush's recent campaign speeches. After the sharp emotions and stark images of Mr. Bush's visit on Thursday to areas hit hardest by the riots in Los Angeles, today's schedule seemed to regain the flavor of a campaign swing.
On Thursday Mr. Bush listened to the angry complaints of black, Hispanic and Korean-American residents of Los Angeles. Touring the ruins of businesses and neighborhoods, he carried a stricken expression.
Today he returned to more familiar and comfortable territory. He spoke to firefighters, police officers and soldiers, who gave him a far friendlier reception than he got on Thursday. He tried on hats, including a firefighter's white helmet with the word "President" emblazoned on it, climbed aboard a red fire truck to watch a demonstration of how the hoses and water cannon work, shook hands, ate doughnuts and waved at men and women in uniforms.
Early this morning Mr. Bush went to Cedars-Sinai Hospital to visit Scott Miller, a firefighter who was shot in the neck and critically wounded while driving a hook-and-ladder truck to a blaze in South-Central Los Angeles on April 29, the day riots erupted after four white police officers were acquitted in the beating of a black motorist.
In the hospital room, Mr. Bush seemed uncomfortable and at a loss for words. "This is fantastic," Mr. Bush said at one point. "We're glad to be here. Absolutely." Looking at the young man, who lay in his bed partly paralyzed and unable to speak, Mr. Bush added to no one in particular, "Is this still the eighth?"
While Mr. Miller gazed at his wife, Kathi, Mr. Bush signed autographs and handed out tie pins. It would have been an awkward moment under any conditions, but Mr. Bush's attempt to express sympathy seemed to underscore the trouble he has had in shedding the image of a detached, aloof President.
Mr. Bush reminded the wife of a firefighter who was injured in the riots about the storm damage to his family estate in Kennebunkport, Me. "I'm sorry Barbara's not here," he said. "She's out repairing what's left of our house. Damn storm knocked down four or five walls. She said it's coming along."
In his speech to a chiefly black audience of adults and children at the Challenger club, Mr. Bush said it was important for him to come to Los Angeles. "The community has been the site of a terrible tragedy," he said. "Not just for you who were impacted the most, but for our entire country."
Mr. Bush said the nation had spent as much as $3 trillion over 25 years to stem "the tide of urban violence and drugs and crime and social decay." But he said, "Where this path has taken us I think we would all agree is not really where we wanted to go."
Using language and imagery that were a striking departure from his previous oratory, Mr. Bush said, "It's hard to read about a young black man dying when the odds are one out of two that he was murdered."
Mr. Bush said women benefiting from the Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, should be allowed to earn and save some money without losing their benefits. He did not mention his own increasingly frequent calls for reductions in other welfare benefits.
 
Bush's 'Action Agenda'
 Mr. Bush said the meetings on Thursday in which Los Angeles residents told him that the Federal Government had failed to help them improve their lives or protect them from violence and injustice had "confirmed why I believe the plan that we have proposed for urban America."
In addition to the $19 million in aid to Los Angeles, the President outlined an "action agenda to bring hope and opportunity back to our inner cities." These were its points:
*A renewal of his proposal to create urban "enterprise zones" in which there would be no tax on profits from investments, an idea that Mr. Bush has had on Capitol Hill for years but has not pushed very hard.
*His current education proposals that center on giving parents the option of choosing which public school their child attends.
*An existing Administration proposal, not pressed hard by the White House and largely ignored by Congress, to make it easier for residents of public housing to buy their homes.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Fights Pressure to Spend $200 Million Surplus on Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins insisted yesterday that it would be "a grave error in public policy" to use $200 million in surplus funds exclusively for schools.
In a strongly worded letter, Mr. Dinkins sent a clear message that he should be the arbiter of how the funds are spent rather than the Governor or the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the source of the money. 
 And to bolster that claim, he announced his choices to fill four positions on the nine-member board of the corporation. The move will strengthen his influence with the quasi-public corporation, headed by Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appoints the five other members.
 
Cuomo Endorsed School Plan
 Last week, Mr. Cuomo endorsed a plan to spend the surplus on programs to lengthen the school day in middle schools, expand a computerized teaching system to all schools and train teachers to help students to avoid falling into special-education classes.
On Tuesday, Mr. Rohatyn stepped up pressure on the Mayor to earmark the money for schools when he warned that unless the money flowed toward education, the city would risk losing it. He later said he would abide by any agreement that the Governor and the Mayor reached, though he favored using the money for education.
Mr. Dinkins's letter to Mr. Rohatyn expressed doubts that the Board of Education's spending plans would achieve significant long-term savings.
The city's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, has been waging a no-holds-barred lobbying campaign for the money since January, aggressively seeking support from the Governor and Mr. Rohatyn in a series of meetings. The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, has also put out a different proposal that would use the surpluses in the schools.
Yesterday, Mr. Dinkins's aides said, the Mayor sought to slow down the growing rush to commit the money -- which will not be available for at least 14 months -- to education.
"What we're saying is don't slam the door on the possibility that some other agencies may be able to come up with similarly innovative efficiencies," said Leland T. Jones, his spokesman.
In his letter to Mr. Rohatyn, the Mayor questioned the wisdom of using the entire $200 million on one agency and asserted that the Chancellor had not demonstrated the programs that the Governor wanted would save money in the long run.
"Just as it inefficient to put all of one's eggs in one basket, I believe it would be inefficient to use these limited, one-time resources to achieve productivity, streamlining and downsizing in just one agency," the Mayor wrote.
For months, the administration has supported using the money to improve efficiency, from early-retirement programs to buying computers, but it has advanced no specific plan yet.
The Mayor's top aides have made it no secret that they would like to keep the cache as a carrot to entice unions into swapping work-rule changes and other efficiencies for raises or some other incentive.
Mr. Rohatyn, who has dominated the city's fiscal politics for 20 years, has reacted coolly to such proposals, arguing that they could lead to higher labor costs over the long haul.
As pressure from several quarters has built to earmark the money for schools, the administration has found itself struggling this week to keep its options open as long as possible. City officials have worried about tagging the M.A.C. surplus money for schools during the recession, when multimillion-dollar budget shortfalls can open up overnight.
Mr. Rohatyn said yesterday that the Mayor's request to hold off a decision made sense, since the first $100 million of the surplus could not reach the city before July 1993.
 
'We Don't Have to Rush'
 "I think it's certainly reasonable to say we don't have to rush into this thing," he said. "On the other hand I don't think we should let too much time go by before we have a resolution on these issues."
A spokeswoman for the Governor, Anne W. Crowley, said the eventual fate of the funds would have to be agreed on by the Mayor, the Governor and Mr. Rohatyn. She said Mr. Dinkins's letter did not change the Governor's preference that the surplus should go to education.
"Nothing is really different," she said. "The three of them will now work out a solution on how the money should be spent."
Mayoral aides insisted that the letter's coming on the same day as the Mayor's appointments to the board was a coincidence. Mr. Dinkins told Mr. Rohatyn informally of his choices in December, they said.
 
Supporters Are Appointed
 "There should be no message to be read into it," Mr. Jones said.
The Mayor drew from his political supporters for the appointees. The three new members are Donald D. Kummerfeld, a former budget director and deputy mayor who owns an investment banking firm and serves on the Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force; Peggy Tishman, a philanthropist who is the former president of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, and Reginald F. Lewis, the chairman of TLC Beatrice International, a giant food corporation. They are replacing holdovers from the Koch and Beame administrations whose terms expired as long as two years ago.
Mr. Dinkins also requested that George M. Brooker, president of Webb & Brooker Inc., a Harlem real-estate company, be appointed to a second term on the M.A.C. board.

HEADLINE: Payrolls increase and Joibless Rate Retreats to 7.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
In the first clear sign that economic recovery has spread to the job market, company payrolls grew by 126,000 in April while the unemployment rate edged down to 7.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
The latest figures, which represented the first broad assessment of economic conditions for the month, were better than expected and solidified the view that the recovery had finally reached solid ground. 
 "This month we can say for the first time that there is improvement" in employment conditions, Thomas J. Plewes, an Associate Commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said after a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
 
First Drop Since July
 The jobless rate is widely considered the most politically sensitive economic statistic for an incumbent in an election year, and the drop from 7.3 percent was the first decline in the figure since July. The increase in company payrolls was the largest of three straight gains.
But political reaction in general was restrained as the White House continued to focus on the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots, and Democrats found less reason in the report to attack the Administration for its handling of the economy.
In addition to the gain in payrolls as evidence of improvement, Mr. Plewes and others cited stepped-up demand for temporary and full-time workers in business services, a six-point jump to 55.2 percent in the proportion of companies adding workers, another dip in the jobless rate for adult men and a rise in the number of people voluntarily leaving jobs, which is taken as a sign of confidence that another job could be readily obtained.
And while the one-tenth of a point decline in the unemployment rate is not viewed by the Labor Department as statistically significant, the fact that the rate declined at all was taken as another favorable sign.
 
Rate Cut Possible
 Yet the dominant view remained that the recovery, though almost certain to be sustained, would be subdued by historical standards and that another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve could not be ruled out. Average hourly earnings, in fact, eased slightly last month and a Federal Reserve report on Thursday showed two of its money supply measures were growing at rates below their target range.
"The figures suggest an economy that's growing -- but at a very sluggish pace," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist for the First Boston Corporation.
Speaking for the Bush Administration, Labor Secretary Lynn Martin termed the report evidence that recovery was "beginning to be reflected" in the hitherto languishing job market. But she said her encouragement was "tempered by the fact that too many people are still unemployed."
The department's survey of households showed that 327,000 people found jobs last month, exceeding the gain of 240,000 in the labor force. This reduced the ranks of the jobless by 87,000, to a total of 9.5 million. That compared with 6.7 million people unemployed when President Bush took office in January 1989 and 6.8 million when the recession began in July 1990.
For the Democrats, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland complained today at the outset of the monthly Joint Economic Committee hearing on the labor market report that while April's job growth "is welcome, it confirms that this recovery is far weaker than any we have experienced" since World War II.
 
Moving With the Economy
 In general, employment is considered a coincident indicator, which means it moves up and down at about the same time as the economy at large. The jobless rate, however, is regarded as a lagging indicator, one that at the end of recessions tends to keep rising for some months as people who had given up looking for a job are encouraged to think they might find one.
In rejoining the ranks of job seekers, these people once again become part of the jobless-rate calculation.
Among the 11 large states whose labor data were reported today, New York registered a four-tenths of a point decline, to 7.6 percent, while the unemployment rates in New Jersey and Pennsylvania both rose seven-tenths of a point, to 7.8 percent and 7.9 percent, respectively.
Because of smaller samples for the state figures, New York's change was not considered significant while the others were marginally so.
Nationally, the rise of 126,000 in payroll jobs caps three straight advances totaling 270,000. March growth was revised upward to show a gain of 39,000 instead of the 19,000 first reported.
All the increase, however, was in service-producing industries. Construction did not add as many jobs as its seasonal adjustment factor -- resulting in an 11,000 loss -- and manufacturing added just 8,000 jobs.
 
 
Where the Gains Were
 The gain in services, the biggest in almost two years, included an additional 30,000 jobs in health, 21,000 in business services, 46,000 in retail trade, 12,000 in local government and 7,000 in finance.
William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, called business services, which has climbed for two straight months, a bellwether of job growth, since employers tend to be reluctant to hire permanent employees until they become confident about the durability of a business rebound.
Instead, they turn initially to expanding the hours of their existing work force, to contracting work out and to temporary help, which has been particularly strong of late.
Factory overtime rose sharply in April as average weekly hours for the whole private sector edged down six minutes, to 34.4 hours.
But Lacy H. Hunt of the Hongkong Bank Group said he was disappointed in a second straight shorter workweek and in a related index of aggregate weekly hours, which fell in April to 121.6, a bit below its first-quarter average.
"I don't like this pattern," said Mr. Hunt, who for some time has been one of the more pessimistic analysts, adding that the gains in retail trade were probably overstated, in part because the April survey week included the days just before Easter.
Elsewhere in today's report, the number of people unemployed for 15 weeks or more fell by 167,000 last month, to three million, but this was still about twice the number of long-term jobless as when the recession began in mid-1990.
The jobless rate for teen-agers eased 1.4 points in April to 19.2 percent, after two months above 20 percent, but the rate for black teen-agers jumped 3.4 points to 39.9 percent. The Hispanic unemployment rate eased 1.3 points, to 10.3 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Brooks Bros. Strike Averted

 BODY:
The unionized sales staff of four Brooks Brothers stores in the New York area accepted management's latest contract offer last night after five weeks of wrangling, thus averting a threatened strike.
Jo-Ann Mort, a spokeswoman for the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union Local 340, said the union had ratified the contract late last night. The union represents 200 employees at Brooks Brothers stores on Madison Avenue and Liberty Place in Manhattan, as well as in Scarsdale and Manhasset, L.I. 
 She said it was a two-year contract, with a wage guarantee for the first year, but provided no further details.
William V. Roberti, president and chief executive of Brooks Brothers, said: "Our objective during the talks was to reach an agreement that was economically fair to our associates while also providing them with the tools they need to serve customers better. We believe this contract meets those goals."
The union and Brooks Brothers, which is owned by the British retailer Marks & Spencer, have been negotiating since March 31, when the old contract expired. Under that accord, the average annual pay of a sales associate was $47,000. About 40 percent was a guaranteed base salary, with the rest based on sales commissions.
Brooks Brothers has proposed raising the guaranteed portion of the salary in exchange for lowering or eliminating commissions.

HEADLINE: California Refunds By Insurer

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8

 BODY:
In the first case completed under a voter-initiated rollback of automobile insurance rates, California's Insurance Commissioner today ordered the 20th Century Insurance Company to pay more than $100 million in refunds to 650,000 policyholders.
But company officials, contending that their rates were among the industry's lowest, said they planned to appeal the refund order in California state courts. Insurers had fought the voter initiative, known as Proposition 103, before it was passed in November 1988, and most have continued to oppose its provisions in court. The measure, together with court rulings, requires rate rollbacks based on the profitability of the insurers. 
 The state Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, had adopted rollback regulations implementing the proposition in October 1991. The hearings on 20th Century, before an administrative law judge, Elizabeth Laporte, were the first to be completed under those regulations.
 
 
Sets a Precedent
 As the first rollback case to go through an administrative law hearing, the action on 20th Century sets a precedent for other insurance companies.
In his order today, Mr. Garamendi accepted a proposed decision submitted to him this week by Judge Laporte. She had determined that a 12.2 percent rollback, amounting to a total of $101.8 million, or an average of about $157 each, should be paid to 20th Century policyholders.
"This is a rock-solid legal decision, which finds that 20th Century owes its policyholders over $100 million," Mr. Garamendi said today. "The company's delay tactics have failed -- they should now do the right thing and pay their customers the money they've been owed for three years."
The company has 5.6 percent of the state's automobile insurance market. The majority of its policyholders are in Southern California.
 
 
'Unreasonable and Inconsistent'
 The insurance company's president and chief operating officer, James O. Curley, said in a statement, "A complete judicial review of the rollback provisions of Proposition 103 is necessary."
Mr. Curley added, "The Department of Insurance standards are unfair, unreasonable and inconsistent with Proposition 103 and the California Supreme Court's ruling interpreting Proposition 103."
Mr. Garamendi said he thought the commission would prevail. "The insurance industry has proven, through the expenditure of over $100 million and by its legions of pin-striped lawyers, that it is capable of tying up the will of the people," Mr. Garamendi said. "But it can't go on forever, and eventually they will lose."
 Under Proposition 103, all insurers that offered automobile coverage were required to roll back their premiums by 20 percent. In May 1989, ruling on a suit by insurers challenging the constitutionality of the proposition, the California Supreme Court upheld the rollback provision, provided that companies retained the opportunity to earn a fair rate of return.
The court also upheld provisions that eliminated the industry's exemption from antitrust lawsuits, that allowed banks to sell insurance and that curbed the insurers' ability to charge higher rates in some regions compared with others.
In her decision, Judge Laporte found that 20th Century's "economic evidence suffered from inconsistencies, unsubstantiated and self-serving assumptions which drive the conclusions, and implausible extreme positions, including advocacy of rates of return ranging as high as 33 percent to 99 percent, as constitutionally required."
Mr. Garamendi's rollback regulations specify an industrywide rate of return of 10 percent.
One other California insurer, Mercury Insurance, has completed an administrative law hearing and is in post-trial briefings. Hearings are scheduled for five other companies.
One large automobile insurer, the Automobile Club of Southern California, waived its right to an administrative hearing and paid its policyholders $104 million last year.
 
 
Can Restate Past Results
 Edward Howard, an attorney with Hall & Phillips in Los Angeles who represented Voter Revolt, the consumer advocacy group that sponsored Proposition 103, said, "We're happy that the rebate process is now on track, and we're anxious to see that the rebate checks go out to policyholders."
Mr. Howard was less pleased that Judge Laporte allowed 20th Century to recalculate its past financial results so as to lower its rollback by $5 million, and said he expected other companies to try a similar tactic.
Robert Gore, vice president of the Association of California Insurance Companies, contended that the ruling was contradictory and argued that it proved Proposition 103 was inherently unworkable.
"We think the ruling has a potential to do irreparable harm to motorists who are interested in low-cost auto insurance," he said.
The ruling places 20th Century "in fiscal danger and will certainly impact the rates it offers consumers by forcing it to take a huge financial hit," Mr. Gore said. He said rates could be lowered only by offering no-fault insurance.

HEADLINE: NWA's Loss Is Narrowed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, May 8

 BODY:
NWA Inc., the holding company for Northwest Airlines, reported a first-quarter loss of $103.1 million, down from a $158.1 million loss in the year-earlier quarter. The airline unit reported a 17.1 percent rise in revenue but posted a $44.5 million first-quarter net loss.
Differences between the airline and the parent, which is privately held, reflect lease and interest costs to carry aircraft assets, Northwest said. 
 The deficit for the airline was narrower than the $61.6 million lost during last year's first quarter, when the Persian Gulf war hurt results. Revenue rose to $1.92 billion from $1.64 billion.
"The key factors that limited our rebound were the recent weakness in the Japanese economy as well as continued sluggishness in the U.S.," John Dasburg, president, said.
Northwest reported an 18.7 percent increase in first-quarter traffic, to 12.8 billion revenue passenger-miles from 10.8 billion. Capacity rose 15.1 percent, to 21.2 billion available seat-miles from 18.4 billion, and the load factor increased to 60.6 percent, from 58.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Rise in Child Death Rates

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The rapid spread of AIDS and a resurgence of malaria and cholera threaten to wipe out more than a decade of health gains among the world's poorest children, according to the United States Agency for International Development.
"We are confronting a major problem with AIDS, seeing death rates we have never seen before," Richard E. Bissell, Assistant Administrator for the agency's research and development, said at a news conference today. 
 By the end of the decade, 10 million children will be affected by the human immunodeficiency virus, he said. More immediately, he added, "malaria is rapidly becoming the single largest killer of young children."
Mr. Bissell and other officials, releasing the agency's annual Report on Child Survival, prepared for Congress, said these new challenges were forcing changes in aiding health programs in the developing world. They said children in these countries had just begun to benefit from international campaigns against childhood diseases.
 
Strategy Shift Is Urged
 Ann Van Dusen, the agency's health office director, said that of a million infants who die each year of malaria, half are in their first month of life, when they have no immunities.
"Eradication clearly is not working," she said. Instead of attacking the mosquitoes that transmit malaria, she said, health workers will have to change attitudes, teaching people to sleep under mosquito netting and taking children to clinics, where they exist, for treatment as quickly as possible.
The report, focusing primarily on poor countries receiving American assistance, said that while immunizations prevented as many as 3.2 million deaths in 1990, and oral rehydration therapy for diarrhea saved a million lives, 13 million children worldwide were still dying each year from avoidable diseases.
Despite the efforts of governments, foreign aid agencies and international bodies like the World Health Organization and Unicef, the report said, a third of the 126 million children born each year in the developing world are malnourished at birth and therefore susceptible to childhood illnesses like measles, whooping cough, respiratory infections and diarrheal disorders.
 
AIDS Could Cancel Gains
 In this setting, the appearance of malaria strains resistant to widely used drugs, the comeback of cholera -- first in Africa and now in Latin America -- and most of all the spread of the human immunodeficiency virus and AIDS can create catastrophic problems for poor nations, the report said.
"In some developing countries, H.I.V./AIDS could become the leading killer of children by the year 2000," the report said, adding that in parts of Africa, the spread of AIDS could cancel out "virtually all the reductions in child mortality achieved through immunization and other health measures."
Life expectancy in sub-Saharan Africa could drop below already low levels, it said, and "10 million children could be orphaned by the death of one or more parents in the 1990's."
In Asia, where more than 4.3 million children die in infancy each year, many of them in South Asia, the impact of AIDS has yet to be assessed. Nations like Thailand, the Philippines and India have only begun to face up to the prevalence of AIDS among adults.
Urbanization is also creating new problems in child health, according to the Agency for International Development, which has been operating a child survival program since 1985. Urban growth rates in the developing world are about three times those experienced in the past by industrializing societies.
By the end of the decade, 44 percent of the world's poorest people will live in cities, the report said. Contrary to popular belief, it said, "more than 60 percent of the population growth in urban areas is attributable to natural increase; less than 40 percent is due to migration from rural areas."
In cities of the developing world, 50 to 75 percent of people live in extreme poverty, the report found. And health standards fall accordingly. In Kenya, the report said, infant mortality in the slums of Nairobi was 200 deaths per 1,000 live births, compared with 74 per 1,000 for the country as a whole.
The report suggested that child survival programs in huge third-world cities could learn from pilot projects in Bangladesh, Indonesia and several other countries where urban neighborhood health centers are being established in slums to serve as links to traditional medical services.
Helene Gayle, the agency's coordinator on AIDS, said at the news conference that more emphasis would have to be placed on education and treating women in the battle against pediatric AIDS since the disease is transmitted to children through their mothers.
Dr. Gayle, whose budget for AIDS assistance worldwide is $100 million -- less than half of the $250 million allocated by Congress for the agency's child survival program -- acknowledged that reaching many women will be difficult because of taboos about discussing sexual activity.

HEADLINE: Peenemunde Journal;
At Space Age Cradle: Shades of Nazi Rocketeers

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEENEMUNDE, Germany

 BODY:
The crisp white sign announcing, "Peenemunde, the Cradle of Space Flight," seems a mouthful, since about all that remains are the ruins of brick factories where rocket fuel was once made, and jagged concrete chunks jutting from moonscape-like dunes where prototype moon rockets were tested.
Some planners are working here to create a space park on the site of Nazi Germany's rocket testing grounds, where some 18,000 German technicians and scientists toiled feverishly for more than a decade. 
 Among their products were the V-1 buzzbomb, essentially the cruise missile of Persian Gulf war fame, and the V-2, the forerunner of the rockets that put astronauts on the moon, but also of ballistic weapons like America's Pershing missile and the Russian-designed Scud.
Indeed, the scientists who labored among the now deserted dunes, like Peenemunde's technical director, Wernher von Braun, were taken to the United States after World War II to begin America's missile program -- the defeated surrendering their secrets to the victors.
 
'A Negative Notion'
 There are reasons to build a space park here: to commemorate this spot and, not incidentally, to find employment for eastern Germans seeking to convert an economy long dependent on weapons to more peaceful needs.
But Peter Profe, a former propulsion engineer in Communist East Germany's air force who is now a spokesman for the park project, acknowledges that there is some resistance to the project. As he led a visitor through the center, which opened one year ago in a disused bunker, Mr. Profe said that, for many, "Peenemunde remains a negative notion."
First, there were the local residents who thought tiny Peenemunde, population 400, had seen enough without a space park luring endless carloads of visitors to clog narrow lanes that lead to the remote Baltic Sea promontory.
Others were appalled by the idea of celebrating the place where Hitler developed the weapon that killed thousands, employing tens of thousands of slave laborers from Russia, Poland, France and other conquered countries.
About 4,000 V-2 rockets, bearing 2,000 pounds of high explosive each and steered by pre-set guidance systems, were launched against Britain and the Low Countries in 1944 and 1945, causing thousands of deaths.
Discomfort over former Nazi sites in eastern Germany is not an isolated or dispassionate phenomenon. Berlin is trying to decide what to do with the remains of Hitler's bunker, and in the Harz Mountains near the Thuringian town of Nordhausen, where inmates of the Dora-Nordhausen camp produced the giant V-2 rockets, plans to exploit the huge underground factories as a source of gypsum have encountered bitter opposition from German Jews.
Local leaders have pledged not to develop the site of the camp, where a third to half of the 60,000 inmates died. At the recent unveiling of a memorial, Gottfried Muller, president of Thuringia's parliament, called the place a "thorn in the flesh of the German people that we should not extract."
The problem with Peenemunde is that it is the birthplace of modern space technology, and plans are going ahead for the park as part of a regional master plan to develop the island of Usedom, where Peenemunde lies. A dozen jobs paid for by the federal Government -- -- for model builders, decorators, archivists -- have been approved. But in fact there is not much left to preserve.
 
Group Led NASA Program
 In August 1943, 600 British bombers raked the area under Operation Hydra, so-called because it was planned to lop off the project's scientific heads. But faulty reconnaissance meant that most of the bombs fell on the forced labor camp, so that although 735 died in the raid, some 500 victims were forced laborers.
What the bombs didn't accomplish, the Allies did after the war, following a Potsdam Agreement mandate that the site be demolished as part of Germany's weapons-building capacity. But that was not until most of the technology had been carried off by Red Army units and 120 of the most important people, like Mr. von Braun -- who chose the Peenemunde site in 1935, when he was 23 years old -- had been taken to the United States.
"Basically, the Russians got the technology, but the Americans got the brains," Mr. Profe said.
The group's members later spearheaded the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space flight program, and some ultimately proved an embarrassment. In 1984, Arthur Rudolph, manager of the Saturn-5 rocket program in Huntsville, Ala., left the United States and surrendered his citizenship rather than face Justice Department charges that he had brutalized slave laborers at Peenemunde and Nordhausen.
Mr. von Braun, the program genius, who died in 1977, also came under attack. He defended his work as driven by the dream of space flight.
But critics like the satirist-singer Tom Lehrer, who mocked him in a 1960's travesty, painted him as the paragon of the amoral scientist, dedicated to his craft of sending rockets up, without caring where they came down or who paid him.
"We have frequently been attacked," Mr. Profe said. "But you cannot personify technology. It is man who misuses it. We cannot forget that this place brought much grief. But it was this technology that brought man into space and to the moon."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS: South-Central Journal;
Amid the Ruins, a Frustrating Struggle to Reconstruct Lives

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
Arms akimbo, weight on both feet, Juan David Soto stood patiently outside a check-cashing store in South-Central Los Angeles this week while his wife and a friend waited in line inside.
It has been a week to practice patience. People who live among the ruins of riot-devastated South-Central Los Angeles are trying to reconstruct their day-to-day lives. 
 Nine days ago, when the violence flared, Mr. Soto fled his home with his wife and two-month-old baby because a fire broke out next door at the trading center for vendors, known as a swap meet.
The Sotos returned the next day to find their home unscathed, but their electrical power had been knocked out in the rioting. "For us, the adults, it was not so difficult," Mr. Soto said. "But for the baby, who needs her milk, it was not easy. We kept buying ice to put in a cooler, where we kept her milk, and I connected a light bulb to my car battery so that we could have light at night when we had to get up to feed her."
Cashing a check and getting the baby fed were just two of the normal tasks that turned into time-consuming jobs because of the riot. The Sotos have to drive further to reach a super market and wait in longer lines. And for the first few days they had no bus service or mail delivery.
The three had driven around for more than an hour to find a check-cashing place that had not been looted, burned or closed. They arrived at the site on Vermont and Slauson, several miles from their apartment, to find a long line.
"The ABC supermarket near our house normally cashes it for us, but that's all burned down," said Mr. Soto, a construction worker. "We went to three or four other places I knew about, but those were burned down, too."
After days of huddling at home, watching the chaos on television, many people have devoted the last few days to the business of buying groceries, cashing checks and sending off Mother's Day cards.
At Vermont and Slauson, a security guard stood in the street, trying to untangle the traffic jam created by drivers wanting to get into one of the few shopping areas not swallowed up by the fires and the fury. Once inside, the shoppers stood in long lines.
Arson, looting and vandalism had claimed the businesses on the other three corners of the intersection. But somehow, they spared the southeast corner with its Kmart, Sav-On store, The Boys grocery store, McDonald's and other smaller businesses.
"I'm here to buy a birthday card for my son," said one woman rushing across the parking lot on Wednesday. "His birthday was really yesterday, but I wasn't ready to go out yet."
A sense of rebirth and cooperation filled the air. Shoppers greeted each other by name, merchants waved to passers-by. "Everybody's still closing early, but it's getting back to normal now," said Harriett Boyer, who operates a key-copying kiosk in the shopping center.
This center probably managed to avoid being hit by looters and arsonists, said a security guard, Lindberg Bernanrd, because it is ringed by a six-foot-high iron fence. Now it is one of the few places left to shop in a neighborhood that even before the riots had fewer banks, grocery stores and other service stores for each person than other parts of the city.
"It's been pretty rough on people because they have no more places to shop," said Larry Johnson, a cab driver sitting on a bench, waiting for a fare. "A lot of people lost power for four or five days. There were problems with food shortages, and getting to the places that aren't burned down. The buses are running now, but they're so crowded."
Lucill Johnson was just grateful to have a job. A cashier at The Boys for 29 years, she woke up a week ago to find the store where she normally worked had been burned down. Her employers transferred her to the store at Vernon and Slauson, four miles from the burned-out store. Other employees were not so lucky.
"There were eight or nine stores that we lost, and that's a lot of employees," she said. "You have to drive further to work, and you have to take whatever job or whatever hours they give you.
"It's kind of chaotic, but Boys is really, really taking care of its employees. It kept the employees that it could by transferring them to other stores, and it told the others that they should immediately file for unemployment until they can rebuild. So, we're surviving."

HEADLINE: Political Rarity: 2 Lawmakers Bask in Thanks

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., May 8

 BODY:
As Senator Christopher J. Dodd and Representative Sam Gejdenson arrived at the shipyard gate just after dawn today to meet the workers who build Seawolf submarines, an ebullient union leader exclaimed: "Say hello to Chris and Sam. They're the guys keeping us afloat. We would have lost our jobs without them!"
Those were the words that Mr. Dodd and Mr. Gejdenson woke up early to hear. Facing potentially difficult re-election races in November, they shook hands and joked with the workers at the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics, knowing that their jobs, too, may be riding on the Seawolf. 
 The two Democrats have led the fight to save the Seawolf program against the opposition of President Bush, who wants to stop building the submarines because, with the end of the cold war, the boats no longer seem to have a mission. A series of tough votes this week have suggested that the Democrats are quite likely to succeed.
One Seawolf is under construction, and the budget includes money for two more. Hoping to save $2.9 billion, President Bush had wanted to revise the budget to delete those two.
But General Dynamics said that would doom its operation here. This week, the House voted to include money for one more Seawolf. Thanks largely to Mr. Dodd's efforts, the Senate voted to build two more. The conflict is to be resolved in a conference committee next week.
Local needs often drive national politicians. In that sense it is not surprising that two Connecticut politicians would work hard to save a shipyard that employs more than 15,000 of their constituents and that is the cornerstone of the economy of southeastern Connecticut.
 
For a Higher National Cause
 But there is still a paradox. When the cold war was alive, Mr. Dodd and Mr. Gejdenson made careers of fighting the Reagan Administration's military buildup. Now they are warning that the country had better not cut military spending too sharply, even when peace is at hand.
"The Seawolf obviously affects our economy," Mr. Dodd said today at a union hall here. But he assured his audience, from labor and management, that their struggle was for a higher national cause.
"Stealth marine technology is critical to the country," he said.
The Defense Department does not see the Seawolf that way. Facing cutbacks, the department does not see the need to build submarines to track a hostile Soviet submarine fleet that no longer exists.
Mr. Bush went to Capitol Hill this week to lobby Senators to vote against the submarine program. But he failed.
"The problem with the Bush Administration is that they want to take $50 billion in defense spending out of the economy in a recession without replacing it," Mr. Gejdenson said.
He argued that the country had to wean itself gradually from 50 years of favoring military industries as it converts resources to cleaning up the environment, building infrastructure and improving education.
 
Inouye's Support Enlisted
 The restoration of at least one Seawolf was a result of a coordinated effort by almost the entire New England Congressional delegation. But the work of Mr. Dodd and Mr. Gejdenson stood out. The coalitions that they built were based on friendships and on some lawmakers' belief that the Groton shipyard should be preserved in case the international climate suddenly shifted course.
Mr. Dodd first lined up Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii and a powerful member of the Appropriations Committee, behind his efforts. As a conservative who believes that developing weapons systems is an efficient way to develop new technology, Mr. Inouye provided a national security rationale for what might otherwise have appeared as a pork-barrel project.
Then, Mr. Dodd persuaded Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, to pitch the case to liberals most anxious to cut military spending.
 
Murtha Under Pressure
 In the House, Mr. Gejdenson set his lobbying sights on his friend Representative John P. Murtha, the Pennsylvanian who heads the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee. Mr. Murtha had been reticent about the Seawolf program, in part because he favored building surface vessels that are serviced at the Philadelphia shipyards. Mr. Murtha also did not want to use money originally earmarked for the Strategic Defense Initiative, better known as Star Wars, as the Senate had done.
Mr. Gejdenson persuaded Mr. Murtha to allow the financing of one submarine.
"Would I have taken the lead on Seawolf if I was Senator of Nebraska?" Mr. Dodd said. "No. Would I have voted for Seawolf? I like to think yes."
At the shipyard several workers getting off the overnight shift and others just arriving at work walked right past the politicians, refusing to acknowledge their outstretched hands. One worker caustically asked another how many checks had Mr. Gejdenson "bounced" at the defunct House bank. His 51 overdrafts over the 39 months investigated by the Ethics Committee caused him political embarrassment.
Another worker grunted at the Congressman, "H. Ross Perot in '92."
Mr. Dodd noted that the workers may not yet be convinced that their battle had finally been won. He added that incumbent politicians were not any more popular in Connecticut than elsewhere.
The workers know their shipyard may be doomed, anyway, after one or two more Seawolfs have been built.
But generally, the welcome was warm.
"They've given us a sigh of relief," Sue Mack, 39 years old, a weight estimator, said. "We're going to be loyal to these legislators."
Ed Nevins, 32, an electrical designer, said, "Through the efforts of Gejdenson and Dodd, and the union leadership, we got over the hump."

They greeted workers at the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics in Groton, Conn., who build the submarines. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Third-Party Candidate;
In Petition for Texas Ballot, Perot Has Signers to Spare

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, May 8

 BODY:
At one o'clock next Monday afternoon, Ross Perot is expected to leap across one of the first big hurdles in his probable race for President with plenty of room to spare.
To get his name on the ballot in Texas, he has to deliver petitions with the signatures of at least 54,275 qualified, registered voters at the capitol in Austin by that day, and Mr. Perot plans to be on hand with thousands of his supporters -- and an overflow of signed petitions. 
 The low primary turnout in the March 10 primary, which drew 28 percent of eight million registered voters in Mr. Perot's home state, provided his supporters with legions of potential recruits. State officials told reporters this week that they are bracing for more than 200,000 Perot campaign signatures. To qualify, signers could not have voted in the primary.
At an old-style political rally on the last Sunday in April, Mr. Perot told 2,000 volunteers and their children that they and other supporters had collected "several times" the required signatures. "All the consultants said it couldn't be done," he said.
For what so far has been his only campaign-style rally, Mr. Perot appeared that day on a stage before an over-sized American flag, with a Dixieland band nearby wearing "Ross for Boss" T-shirts. He spoke for less than 10 minutes to a cheering crowd, but the Texas billionaire signed autographs on dollar bills, "Perot for President" hats, signs and other paraphernalia, for nearly two hours.
The head of the Bush-Quayle campaign in Texas, Jim Oberwetter, said that while a vast number of signatures would demonstrate significant grass-roots support for Mr. Perot, Republicans officials believe that his popularity will wane as his positions on issues become more defined and reporters analyze his record during the years he headed the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and often ventured into political arenas.
Bob Krueger, a former Democratic Congressman who ran Paul E. Tsongas's unsuccessful campaign in Texas this year, said Mr. Perot's appeal straddled a diverse group of Texas voters and that his slight edge over George Bush in a recent Texas poll reflected a disenchantment with the President and traditional politics.
"That clearly works to Perot's benefit," Mr. Krueger said. "When people are in desperate circumstances, they will turn to strong-minded individuals with simple solutions. Perot fits that. But he is still in the courtship phase. The time will come when both the courtship and the honeymoon will be over and that is when his testing time will be there. "
 
Standing the Test
 For now, Mr. Perot's supporters insist that his reputation as a man who keeps his word, knows how to make money in business and can solve complex government problems will stand those tests.
Ray Burgin, a retired factory worker, said he voted for Gov. Bill Clinton in the primary, but joined the Perot camp mainly because of Mr. Perot's sharp criticism of the growing national debt.
"I see hard times coming," said Mr. Burgin, 77 years old, who has been a volunteer answering telephones at the Perot Petition Campaign offices here for nearly two months. "Ross Perot is not a politician. He's the best possibility for the next four years,"
Another volunteer, Roy Vokey, a semi-retired salesman who was trained as an aerial gunnery specialist in the Air Force during the Korean War, said he has organized military veterans for Mr. Perot in dozens of states, including Texas.
"There are 27 million military veterans out there, plus their families," said Mr. Vokey, 62 years old. "These guys are workers, they vote and they don't mind participating in campaigns, for the most part." In Denison, Tex., a town near the Oklahoma border best known as a haven for the boaters and fishermen who flock to nearby Lake Texoma, Perot supporters collected more than 4,000 signatures.
Unemployment in the area, a traditionally Democratic enclave that includes Sherman, Tex., is on the rise. It was 7.7 percent in February, the most recent figure available from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as against 6.1 percent in the same month a year ago.
Many small factories in the area have trimmed their work force and overtime hours, shops that cater to Lake Texoma crowds also have suffered, and some residents think Mr. Perot, who keeps several speed boats moored at the lake, can improve things.
"He's so successful in his business, and we know that Mr. Perot can find the answers we need," said Linda Wilson, a housewife who organized a Perot petition-signing rally a few weeks ago.
Later that afternoon, in a park in Dallas known as Flagpole Hill where Perot supporters gathered to hand in petitions, an insurance agent from Arlington, Tex., Edmund Koch, said that Mr. Perot's views on issues like abortion and gun control should be secondary to the likely candidate's goal of erasing Federal budget deficits.
"Look, I'm a Catholic and I'm against abortion, but I'm willing to let that and other issues get sorted out later," said Mr. Koch, who said he and other Perot volunteers collected more than 3,000 signatures.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lobbies Business on Free Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8

 BODY:
Taking their trade lobbying from the marble corridors of Congress to the foggy hills of southwestern Virginia today, senior Government officials urged top corporate leaders here to support global free-trade talks and to invest in the former Soviet republics.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, asked executives gathered here for the semiannual meeting of the Business Council to obtain stronger backing from European companies for global trade talks in Geneva. The talks are aimed at lowering tariffs, limiting subsidies and eliminating obstacles to the international operation of service industries, like banking and insurance. 
 Mrs. Hills told them she would also need their political influence if an agreement is completed and submitted to Congress for approval.
 Mrs. Hills later told reporters that an agreement was still possible before the end of the year, but only if European Community nations mended their differences and developed a coherent negotiating position on agriculture. Disputes between the United States and the 12-nation community over farm subsidies have halted progress in the talks for 17 months.
 
Ambassador Urges Aid
 European leaders have consistently denied that their internal differences are the source of the continued stalemate.
Robert Strauss, the United States Ambassador to Russia, exhorted the assembled executives today to trade and invest more in the former Soviet republics as a way to strengthen newly emerging democracies there. "Governments can do a great deal, but governments can't do it all," he said.
Mr. Strauss said he was more optimistic about the republics' future than he was in January and February. The relaxation of food price controls has averted local shortages and possible civil unrest by encouraging people with food to sell it instead of hoarding, he said.
Corporate executives here responded cautiously to the two Administration officials' comments. James R. Houghton, chairman and chief executive of Corning Inc., said a couple of speeches were unlikely to change the views of corporate executives who have thought about these issues for a long time.
But he added that "most people in that room are probably in favor of a good" global trade agreement and a free-trade deal with Mexico, which Mrs. Hills said she hoped could be worked out this summer.
Founded in 1933, the Business Council comprises 100 chief executives of large American corporations. Many former chief executives are also affiliated with the council and also attended today's meetings.
Echoing the views of senior Treasury Department officials, Mr. Strauss also said the value of the ruble should not be supported with Western currency until basic legal and economic policy changes are made that would open up the Russian market. While Russian officials have spoken of giving the ruble a fixed value in terms of foreign currencies on July 1 and then using a $6 billion international fund to support that value by buying and selling rubles, Mr. Strauss said a date of Sept. 1 might be more reasonable.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Details Emerge on Proposed Trade Compromise

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8

 BODY:
New details emerged today about a tentative agreement between the United States and the European Community to limit government subsidies to commercial aircraft companies.
The compromise calls for government contracts to be limited to 4 percent of any single company's revenue and to 3 percent of each national industry's revenue, said a Bush Administration official today who insisted on anonymity. The original deal called for a 5 percent restriction on each company and a 4 percent industry limit. 
 The United States, with its heavy military spending, had sought higher limits. But American negotiators agreed to the lower limits this week in exchange for a slight narrowing of which government contracts are included in the definition, a clear statement that only existing companies are covered and not any possible future entrants into the market, and an exemption from the percentages when necessary for national security.
 
Fine-Tuning the Document
 The compromise document is being shown to various Federal agencies and Governments of the 12-nation European Community, while minor issues of wording are being worked out, the Administration official said. The final agreement could be announced as early as next week.
The sides had announced a draft agreement on April 1, but that quickly began to unravel as American and European officials quarreled over what they had been approved and accused each other of backtracking.
This week, the sides mended their differences, which concerned indirect government subsidies through military contracts and other government spending at companies that also produce large civilian aircraft.
The new compromise is important because it comes during broad deterioration in trade relations between the United States and the European Community. A meeting between President Bush and European leaders on April 22 failed to produce a breakthrough in global free-trade talks, and the United States said last week that it was drafting a list of European imports that it might restrict in retaliation for the community's continuing subsidies to soybean farmers.
 
A Closer Look
 The changes are being made to an agreement that already appears better for American companies than was initially apparent.
For example, direct subsidies to aircraft makers will now not only be capped at about a third of development costs, but they will even have to be repaid by aircraft companies out of their sales at fairly steep interest rates. If enough planes are sold, then the subsidies for all but 1 percent of the development costs would have to be repaid, a senior American official said recently.
European governments have been paying up to three-quarters of the development costs for Airbus Industrie, the four-nation constortium, without demanding repayment, according to American estimates.
The European Community had no immediate comment today on the breakthrough. "We certainly want to get this resolved," one European official said.
 
'Very, Very, Very Close'
 In an interview here today, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that the sides were "very, very, very, close" to a final deal, but she refused to elaborate.
Raymond J. Waldmann, the director of governmental affairs at the Boeing Company in Seattle, said the nation's largest commercial aircraft maker was still studying the tentative deal.
"We're generally satisfied; we're still reviewing some of the fine print," he said.
