PUB-DATE: May 10, 1992,

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2447 words

HEADLINE: Salem Remembers, 300 Years Later

BYLINE: By MARIALISA CALTA; MARIALISA CALTA lives in Vermont.

 BODY:
"I petition to your Honours, not for my own life, for I know I must die . . . but . . . that no more Innocent Blood be shed . . . ." So wrote Mary Esty from her prison cell on behalf of her fellow prisoners who were to be hanged -- as she herself was on Sept. 22, 1692 -- as witches.
It is in documents such as these, written on fragile-looking paper in ink now faded to the color of dried blood, that the history of the Salem, Mass., witch trials was written. To look upon these documents, even from a distance of 300 years, is a moving experience. It is, to borrow from the title of a recent 300th anniversary seminar, a process of "facing history and ourselves." 
 Visitors to Salem, an architecturally austere yet inviting New England city of 37,000 situated 15 miles north of Boston, will have ample opportunity to face history this summer. A starting point is the Essex Institute, a regional art and history museum and the repository of approximately 550 trial documents. About three dozen of these papers, usually available to the public only on microfilm, will be displayed beginning June 11. The exhibit, "Days of Judgment," promises to be a dignified and sobering collection aimed at helping visitors understand the social, economic, religious and political climate of 1692 that allowed for the accusations, trials and deaths of at least 25 people.
The painful saga actually began in Danvers, Mass., a town of 25,000 west of Salem, which, in the 1600's, was Salem Village. There, in the winter of 1691-92, in the tiny parsonage of the Rev. Samuel Parris, a West Indian slave, Tituba, is thought to have entertained the minister's 9-year-old daughter, Betty, and her 11-year-old cousin, Abigail Williams, with fortunetelling, an impious and forbidden amusement in that Puritan era.
Before long, it was said, the girls were suffering seizures, trancelike states and episodes of blasphemous screaming. The village doctor, unable to find a physical cause for these attacks, attributed them to Satan. Since it was believed that Satan could exercise his powers through intermediaries -- persons at that time called witches -- the community elders began trying to identify the evil in their midst. Pressed for names, the afflicted, who came to include many more girls and young women, named Tituba and two other local women. The trials began, during which "spectral evidence" -- testimony about purported apparitions involving the accused -- played a major part. In all, more than 200 people in northern New England were accused in 1692, 150 jailed and 20 killed: 14 women and 5 men by hanging, and one man by pressing under stone weights as the court attempted to elicit a plea.
In addition, it is believed that five persons, including the infant of a hanging victim, died in prison. The episode ended some nine months after it began, when a group of ministers publicly criticized the use of "spectral evidence," and the court was dissolved.
No one really knows the reasons for the "fits" (theories have included preadolescent psychosis and ergot poisoning from a rye fungus), and for years the trials were seen as an aberration involving repressed Puritans brought to the point of hysteria through ignorance and superstition. Recent scholarship, however, has suggested that economics, village rivalries and sexism played major roles.
THE Salem Witch Trials Tercentenary Committee, it appears, has approached the anniversary in a serious manner, no easy task in a city in which a silhouette of a witch astride a broomstick is emblazoned on everything from bags of potato chips to city police cars, where the local newspaper logo is a witch, and witch kitsch overwhelms the gift shops. Even Gallows Hill, generally accepted as the site where the victims were hanged, is partly surrounded by a housing development known as Witchcraft Heights.
In such an atmosphere, it would be easy to forget, to use Mary Esty's words, the innocent blood that was shed. But the Tercentenary Committee has organized a series of lectures, dramatic presentations and workshops geared toward illuminating the past and addressing such issues as intolerance that relate to the present.
Commemorative events began last November when the winning design in a competition for a memorial to the victims was unveiled by the playwright Arthur Miller, who based "The Crucible" on the Salem trials. The design incorporates a traditional New England stone wall surrounding a small park and entered through a threshold engraved with the victims' protestations of innocence. It is to be built adjacent to the Burying Point, a one-and-a-half-acre graveyard in the middle of the city where some of the graves date to the 17th century. A public dedication for the memorial is planned for July.
No one knows where the victims were buried; some histories record that the bodies were thrust into a shallow grave in a crevice of stone on Gallows Hill, and the children of at least one victim, Rebecca Nurse, reclaimed their mother's body for secret burial near her home. Even looking at the hill from today's perspective, with noisy groups of children playing ball in a nearby playground, the traveler can imagine the loneliness and fear that those convicted as witches must have felt.
VISITORS with an introspective bent might take the time to visit Danvers, where the Danvers Historical Society, housed in a brick building from the 1930's, has mounted a small but informative display of artifacts and text relating to life in 17th-century Salem Village. The exhibit makes little reference to the trials, but helps the 20th-century citizen understand the rigors of life in the 1690's. At the society one may obtain a map giving directions to the excavation of the parsonage where the Rev. Parris lived, and the Rebecca Nurse Homestead, the home of one of the early victims. The excavation site is approached through a narrow path sandwiched between two private, 19th-century homes. There is not much to see -- two holes in the ground, one from the 1600's, the other from the 1700's -- and it takes some imagination to conjure the image of Tituba, amusing the girls in the tiny kitchen-shed during what must have been, in those cramped quarters, a long winter indeed.
The approach to the Rebecca Nurse Homestead -- an imposing clapboard structure with a large brick chimney, at the end of a dirt lane bordered by 30 acres of open fields and split-rail fences -- gives the visitor a sense of traveling back in time. The homestead, where "Goody" Nurse was arrested in March of 1692, features three restored rooms, and will be the site of several commemorative events this summer, including a ceremony marking Nurse's execution on July 19. On the premises is a startlingly authentic-looking reproduction of the Salem Village Meeting House, built for the television movie "Three Sovereigns for Sarah," where an audio-visual show will be presented beginning June 15.
Beyond the house one can find the family cemetery, with a monument to Rebecca Nurse and a stone slab carved with the names of 40 friends and neighbors courageous enough to sign a petition in her behalf.
Like the Salem committee, the Witchcraft Tercentennial Committee of Danvers has also built a monument to the victims, across the street from the site of the original meeting house. Its main elements are a granite sarcophagal box and a large wall containing the names and some of the testimony of the trial victims. Danvers is also home to the Peabody Institute Library, which houses the largest collection of books and other imprints relating to the trials in the country.
Those who find such history too dry may prefer a visit to the Salem Witch Museum, in a neo-Gothic building on Salem Common. Billed as a "multisensory presentation," the Witch Museum purports -- though the use of 13 life-size stage settings -- to enable visitors to "witness to the awesome, ominous truth." Visitors stand in a darkened theater around a glowing circle of red light and listen to a narration taped by an actor with a deep voice vaguely reminiscent of the late Richard Burton's. A rather grotesque statue of a devil with glowing red eyes is first illuminated, and actually elicited chuckles from some recent visitors, although it might frighten small children. But despite the hokiness, the Witch Museum is one of the most popular attractions in town, and does manage to cram a fair amount of history into half an hour.
Open in the summer is the Salem Witch Dungeon Museum, which presents a dramatic reading and a tour of re-created dungeon cells. The Witch House, which is owned by the city, is open from spring through fall, and is a restoration of a 17th-century home of one of the trial judges.
For all the commercializing of the folk symbol of the witch, it is interesting to note that some 3,000 followers of the religion of Wicca -- witches -- have moved to Salem, according to Shawn Poirier, a High Priest of the Seventh Moon Tradition. Salem witches, Mr. Poirier says, are working to make the city a haven for other witches to practice their religion undisturbed. The Witches' League for Public Awareness has protested the Tercentenary Committee, saying that linking 17th-century notions of devil worship with witchcraft perpetuates inaccurate, negative stereotypes.
ONE place frequented by local witches is the Crystal Chamber and Cafe on Pickering Wharf, a restaurant that features psychic readings daily and also sells various stones, potions and crystals. Another is Crow Haven Corner, on Essex Street, which was opened by Laurie Cabot, named by the former Massachusetts Governor, Michael Dukakis, as the Official Witch of Salem. The store is now run by Ms. Cabot's daughter, Jodie Cabot, and offers a wide selection of books on witchcraft, as well as potions, wands and crystal balls.
While most visitors are interested in the witch trials, those who are not will find much to admire in this small city, which was the region's busiest port during the early 1800's. This seafaring history is chronicled at the Peabody Museum in a collection on maritime trade.
Salem's 1.3-mile Heritage Trail, marked on sidewalks with red paint, takes the visitor from the National Park Service Visitor Center in the middle of town, past the Peabody Museum, the Essex Institute and the Common, and down to the waterfront, where Pickering Wharf offers a variety of boutiques and restaurants. The Salem Maritime National Historic Site offers a short slide show on the seaport and a tour of preserved buildings and wharves from Salem's maritime era, including the elegant Customs House, where Nathaniel Hawthorne once worked. Other stops on the trail include the House of the Seven Gables, the inspiration for Hawthorne's novel.
Pioneer Village, on the east side of the city, is a re-creation of 17th-century Salem, where guides in period costume demonstrate how the people of the time lived.
A walking tour called the McIntire Tour takes visitors past many of the stately, Federal-style homes designed by Samuel McIntire, one of the first American architects. Especially noteworthy is Chestnut Street, a registered National Historic Landmark, where one of the homes is open to the public.
Those who don't want to walk may take the cheerful, red Salem Trolley, which offers hour-long narrated tours of the city.
But the best way to see Salem is to travel on foot, where a visitor can almost trip over history. In the case of the witch trials, the history is not pretty, but it bears looking at.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Development in Bayside;
At 32, a Shopping Center Will Grow Again

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE Meyer family goes back a long time as a Queens property owner. In 1896, Cord Meyer Jr. bought a farm in what was then called Newtown from the estate of Samuel Lord, a co-founder of Lord & Taylor. He laid out streets, installed sewers, renamed the land Elmhurst and sold off subdivisions to home builders.
The founder was the great-grandfather of the brothers who run Cord Meyer Development Company today, Charles G. Meyer Jr. and George S. Meyer. They manage the company's properties -- mainly stores, offices and Mitchell-Lama middle-income apartments -- from an office in Forest Hills. 
 Development under the auspices of this old-line real-estate investment company occurs on intermittent occasions. One such is now at hand, with the approval last month by the City Planning Commission of Cord Meyer's expansion plan for the Bay Terrace shopping center, at Bell Boulevard and 26th Avenue in the Bayside section of Queens.
Accordingly, from a company with a recent record of little in the way of new projects is coming what may well be the largest of all new commercial developments in Queens this year. The $20 million project provides an unusual demonstration of phased redevelopment in a shopping center. Bay Terrace has already gone through six stages of expansion in its 32-year history. The most recent, in the 80's, involved the conversion of a bowling alley into a 45,000-square-foot Waldbaum's supermarket.
The new Cord Meyer plan calls for building 87,000 additional square feet of space on 7 1/2 acres of land as an expansion of a shopping center that was started in 1960 and built, over time, into a center of 188,000 square feet on 14 acres.
The main element of the expansion is a new two-level structure with 67,050 square feet of shops on the lower level, its horseshoe shape facing toward the several existing buildings. The second level, on higher land at the western edge of the property, will be occupied by a new 20,000-square-foot, six-screen movie theater. In front of the theater, will be a separate parking area for theater patrons.
Loews Theaters will operate the multiplex, giving up the building at the center that it currently leases for two 600-seat theaters. Leasing negotiations are far advanced with various store chains -- the Gap, for 14,400 square feet; Ben's Deli, Foot Locker, and Lechters, the houseware chain, and others.
The existing theaters will eventually be converted to 27,000 square feet in an alternative use. Another existing building, with 21,000 square feet of shops and restaurants, will be demolished for additional parking. And in the future, 12,000 square feet of new stores and parking space will replace a gas station on Bell Boulevard at the northeastern edge of the property. The architect for the project is Stephen Sanders & Associates of Manhasset, L.I.
In all, the shopping center will grow ultimately to 288,000 square feet under the new plan. The surface parking capacity, now at 961 cars, will rise to 1,545 spaces.
"We want to provide high-end retailing -- clothes, shoes, leather goods, jewelry -- but keep local shopping and services as well," said Charles Meyer, president of Cord Meyer Development. Excavation for the new parking deck is expected to begin this summer, with store occupancy ready in the middle of summer next year. Negotiations for financing the project are under way. Base rents for space are expected to range from $30 to $40 a square foot.
For Queens, this project comes at an opportune time. Last year the value of total construction contracts stood at $700.3 million, the lowest level since 1985, according to the F.W. Dodge data-gathering service at McGraw-Hill Corporation. Residential construction in particular is depressed -- down to $29 million from $146 million in 1989.
IN both 1987 and 1988, five million square feet of new space of all kinds -- commercial, residential and institutional -- was produced in Queens, F.W. Dodge said. Declining steadily since then, the figure had reached 1.9 million square feet last year.
As brokers see it, the Bay Terrace shopping center, standing in a commercial niche of its own just east of the two 20-story towers of the Bay Club condominium of early-80's vintage, is a local facility outside the mainstream of northern Queens retailing locations. But its leasing pattern reflects the larger picture around it. Chains are on the move, the brokers say, finally finding availabilities at favorable prices in a more "reasonable" market. In one notable lease, a Staples office-furniture outlet took 16,000 square feet on Northern Boulevard, west of Bell Boulevard, once occupied by a Cadillac and Acura showroom. The broker, Steven Schwartz of S.B. Schwartz & Company of Great Neck, L.I., took the lease as evidence that because the car market is down, showroom space is now more available for retail chains.
Hard times are also putting pressure on mom-and-pop businesses, other brokers say. Rather than operate, there is a disposition by some older independent merchants to retire and rent out space in buildings they own or occupy on a long-term lease.
This has created an opportunity for credit-worthy chain operators, said Chris Conlon, director of retail brokerage for Breslin Realty Development Corporation in Garden City, L.I. It is also bringing mall tenants to nonmall Queens locations, he said. He noted the arrival of Lechters, to a 4,700-square-foot store at 31-53 Steinway Street in Astoria three months ago. Lechters also will move into a 3,600-square-foot space at 95-05 63d Drive in Rego Park when reconstruction is completed in a month, he said.
Harold Weidman, head of Store Finders, a commercial broker in Brooklyn, seconded the point. "Eddie Bauer, Dress Barn, Staples -- the large chains that had shied away from New York because of high prices -- are coming in now," he said.
APPROVAL of the Bay Terrace expansion by the Planning Commission was preceded by a long process of meetings between Cord Meyer and its representative, Scott Mollen of the Manhattan law firm of Graubard Mollen Horowitz Pomeranz & Shapiro, and local community and builder representatives. Community Board 7 supported the project by a 42 to 2 vote, and Borough President Claire Shulman backed it as well.
An earlier version of the expansion was approved by the Planning Commission a year ago, but Cord Meyer found it necessary to revise these plans to respond to merchant requirements. Part of the second floor in the new building was dropped, and the additional space was planned instead at the eastern end of the site where a gas station now stands.
The shopping center has developed in sections, with new buildings added as the market grew. The seven undeveloped acres were considered for condominium development in the 70's, but that plan was dropped, as was a plan for town houses.
For some retailers already in the center and wishing to expand, the addition is an opprtunity. For others who may lose their presence through the demolition of the existing building, it may be a setback. Operators must make considerable investment to outfit a new store, and not all of them are prepared to do this, particularly in a recession. For the expansion-minded the encouraging factor is the income level of the population living in the immediate vicinity. Median household income was estimated at $46,400 in 1990 in a population of 33,400 within one mile of the center.
In the expansion camp is Sweats Appeal, a nine-year-old, three-store chain selling camp outfits and sportswear. It started in Plainview, L.I., and now has outlets at East 88th Street on Madison Avenue and in the Bay Terrace mall.
"Recession stunted our growth," said Mark Dorfman, one of the owners. But he plans to take a 2,000-square-foot space in the Bay Terrace addition. "There's good 24-hour security here," he said. "The extra dollars a month will be worth it."

LENGTH: 197 words

HEADLINE: Abandonment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your "Taking Steps to Head Off Abandonment" on March 29 describes a bureaucratic shellgame that attempts to repeal the laws of economics. As long as there is an inadequate housing stock in New York City to meet demand, landlords will be able to force poor service on captive tenants or charge high rents. A simpler and more straightforward solution to the problem is to stimulate more low-cost housing. 
 One inexpensive way of doing this is to establish punitive taxes on vacant properties, which contribute to urban decay, and lower taxes on other property owners. If owners of vacant properties are forced into distress sales, more attractive opportunities for private redevelopment would result.
One free way to provide more housing is selling off some chunks of the city's sprawling housing empire and using the proceeds to stimulate new development. One additional advantage of this approach is that reducing the city's huge housing bureaucracy would also allow these employees to provide more productive services.
 
THOMAS O'BRIEN
 
The writer is director for research of the Horizon Institute for Policy Solution in Charlottesville, Va.

HEADLINE: Talking: Reserves;
Keeping The Fund Up to Snuff

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A GROWING number of co-ops are being forced to seek new ways to build their reserve funds because the traditional sources of such money -- flip taxes, rents from store space and special assessments -- may no longer prove adequate.
Revenues from flip taxes -- the charges a co-op board imposes at the time of an apartment sale -- have declined because sales have slowed. The recession has made it harder to find store tenants willing to pay good rents, and special assessments on the shareholders are difficult to levy in hard times. 
 A reserve fund is used to finance capital improvements and pay for unexpected repairs. Though some buildings operate without a reserve fund, this is considered risky by many experts.
"You never know what might happen tomorrow," said Martin Zacharius, a consulting engineer and president of M. P. Zacharius & Associates, a Manhattan firm that has dealt with co-ops for more than 20 years. "A boiler or an elevator could break down and have to be replaced. A piece might fall off the facade. A cooling tower could overflow. A lot of this isn't covered by insurance."
Moreover, relying upon banks for loans to cover such work may not be prudent for many buildings. If a long-established co-op has a small underlying mortgage and uncommitted borrowing power, it may safely assume that a loan will be available in an emergency. But keeping reserves at a minimum in the expectation that new capital may be borrowed at any time has put some buildings in a bind.
Martin Marin, a partner with the accounting firm of Marin & Montanye in Port Washington, L.I., with 250 co-op clients, said the prevailing wisdom of the 80's was to avoid dunning shareholders excessively to build reserves. Rather, it made more sense to finance capital improvements by borrowing the money as it was needed.
But bankers now say that only if a building has an underlying mortgage under 25 percent of its total market value can it borrow more with ease. And in the case of a co-op converted from a rental, at least 70 percent of the apartments must have been sold. "We're careful," said Ed Howe, vice president of the National Cooperative Bank in New York.
Some lenders also look at the financial strain on shareholders to make sure that payments on a new or larger loan will not exceed their resources, particularly in moderate-income co-ops. "We normally don't allow the debt service on any additional financing to cost each shareholder more than $50 a month more in maintenance fees," said Diane Papsidero, a loan officer with Washington Mortgage Financial Group of Jersey City, which specializes in co-op financing.
Some co-ops were loath to maintain large reserves because they feared much of the money would be taxed away. But, said Mr. Marin, there are many ways to keep the tax collector at bay.
Say, for example, the strategy was to build reserves by setting maintenance payments at a level that would produce a surplus or "profit" at year-end. The excess could, indeed, be taxed as corporate profits, said Mr. Marin, but in most buildings, the depreciation allowance would more than offset the surplus and no tax would be due.
Only if a building's depreciation allowance was all used up -- in most cases this would take 27.5 years under the 1986 Federal Tax Reform Act -- would the co-op have to pay a tax of about 30 percent on a surplus. And even this could be avoided if the building's budget clearly designated a portion of the income for future capital improvements and if the funds were placed in a separate account.
And if a board wanted to avoid tax on the interest income earned on its reserve, it could put the money into tax-exempt investments, as many buildings are now doing.
David Wagner, president of the 88-unit co-op at 150 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn Heights, said his co-op has moved most of its $890,000 reserve fund into a mix of municipal bonds and tax-exempt money-market funds.
A CO-OP'S reserve fund also may make the apartments more marketable by assuring buyers that they are not exposed to special assessments. "Many buyers are afraid to buy into a building that doesn't have reserves," said Arthur Weinstein, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and a lawyer in private practice in Manhattan.
And it is going to be much harder to hide a lack of reserves because beginning with the next fiscal year, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants will require its members to make fuller disclosure about the condition of reserves in any annual financial statement that they certify.
The audited statement will have to include an estimate of future replacement costs, the methods by which the board arrived at the estimate and ways the board intends to finance its capital needs.
Dennis Greenstein, a New York City lawyer with 225 co-op clients, recommends that every co-op should maintain a reserve fund equal to three months' maintenance payments. The sum should be doubled if the building is over 20 years old and is in greater peril of unanticipated expenditures, he added.
THE basic way to create such reserves is to raise maintenance and plow the excess into the fund. But since this still tends to be the least palatable method other alternatives should be explored.
Selling or leasing garage or storage space is another way. Mr. Weinstein cited a co-op client in Queens that recently raised $60,000 by selling long-term leases on its 20 garage spaces.
Funds could also be raised, he said, by creating personal storage areas in a basement or by transforming unused first-floor areas into professional space.
If a co-op is close to paying off its underlying mortgage it could earmark the amount set aside for debt service to rebuild the reserve fund. Michael Cantor, president of Cantor Management of the Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn, has a client co-op intending to do just that when its mortgae is paid off a year from now. This way, he said, the board anticipates having $500,000 in two years -- enough to cover the cost of a new roof and other work that will be needed by then.
If a special assessment is not feasible and bank financing is out of the question because the underlying mortgage still is large, the co-op might consider what the 200-unit co-op at 3777 Independence Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx is doing.
A VOLUNTARY loan program is being set up under which 40 shareholders have agreed to lend the co-op up to $10,000 each at a market rate of interest. The money will be used for replacement windows, a new roof and other repairs, said Errol Brett, who is acting as counsel to the co-op.
Another method is to spread out the smaller capital expenditures so more can be covered by operating funds, as the 562-unit co-op at 140 West End Avenue has been doing, said Gordon Dixon, the president. So far the strategy has permitted its $600,000 existing reserves to gain interest virtually undisturbed since it was established in 1987.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
In Chicago, 'Terrific' Bargains for Renters

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The good news, says Christine Williams, is that Chicago's residential developers appear to be holding their fire. None of the projected market-rate high-rise developments are moving into construction for the moment. The market neeeds time to absorb what is already built, she says.
Ms. Williams, vice president of the Real Estate Research Corporation, a consulting firm based here, has figures that show that new "luxury" residential construction has marched along at an average rate of 1,600 units a year over the last four years, recession notwithstanding. Five new projects with a total of 2,600 apartments have come on the market since the start of last year alone. 
 With few exceptions, these new buildings are rentals, not condominiums. And as they lease up steadily, with a nudge from a month or two of free rent, they demonstrate how a city with a fundamentally positive attitude toward new development has continued to sustain housing prices that are remarkably low by the standards of comparable cities.
Right now they are even low in relation to the cost of development. Too low, some specialists say, to sustain the mortgages that some have received.
"Chicago is a terrific housing bargain for the renter, relative to development costs and land costs, whether you're talking about San Franciso, New York, Los Angeles or Boston," said Jared Shlaes, a real-estate consultant and former developer himself. And in contrast with New York, no tax-abatement program has beeen necessary to keep market-rate housing flowing.
What people in New York City would define as middle- to upper-middle-income luxury high-rise apartments are on the market in new buildings for about $1.35 to $1.55 a square foot a month, Ms. Williams said. At $1.35 a square foot, or $16.20 a foot a year, an 800-square-foot one-bedroom apartment would rent for $1,080; at $1.55 a foot, or $18.60 a foot a year, it would rent for $1,240 a month.
Also at $1.55 a square foot, an 1,100-square-foot, two-bedroom, for example, would rent for $1,700 a month. In New York City, comparable new housing would rent for $27 to $30 a square foot a year; the 1,100-square-foot apartment would cost $2,000 to $2,500 a month.
How can the developers here do it?
One reason is that land costs are much lower than in New York City. Chicago is well endowed with well-situated vacant or nearly vacant land intended for residential or mixed-use developments. The bitter and lengthy New York battles over emptying old buildings of residential tenants with statutory rights to stay in place are unknown. The absence of rent regulation leads builders to hope that they will be able to take advantage of an eventually stronger market, whatever the level of initial rents.
In a word, development incentives are far stronger. But the competitive risks are greater.
In the mid-80's, Chicago developers were paying $12 to $20 a developable square foot for building sites. Even at the higher figure, the land cost embedded in an 800-square-foot one-bedroom apartment is only $16,000. In New York, rentals in new West Side buildings have a land cost of about $40,000 for a one-bedroom apartment. The developers paid roughly $50 a developable foot for ready-to-build land.
In addition, Chicago builders get a higher-density use of the land. Land is typically developed to a density of about 20 square feet of building for each square foot of site, a floor-area ratio of 20, under a "planned unit development" ordinance. Builders present a specific site plan for a project to the Department of Planning and Development. It is eventually voted upon by the Chicago Plan Commission and the City Council.
In the downtown area, at least, Chicago welcomes new development and favors density and height, as opposed to bulk, according to Jack Guthman, a lawyer with the firm of Sidley & Austin who represents many developers. "They are generous on F.A.R. but strict about other things -- like loading docks and parking spaces," said Mr. Guthman.
For all these factors, the supply-demand situation appears to be the principal one holding prices down. Some experienced developers say that major new projects cannot even break even at current market rents. They need rents of $1.65 to $1.75 a square foot a month for that, or about $20 a square foot a year. Accordingly, the projects may be renting at figures that in the present market are "uneconomic." Time and an upward swing in the market may change that.
But default rates on post-1980 projects that were insured by the Federal Government show that a price has already been paid for overambitiousness. At the Chicago office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Developmeent, 17 projects out of 27 built since 1980 with Government mortgage insurance have been taken back with an outlay of $510 million from the mortgage insurance fund. The largest is the $160 million mortgage on the 2,500-unit Presidential Towers project, which is four years old and 92 percent occupied.
With mortgage rates down, some of the projects may be candidates for refinancing at more favorable rates, said Joseph Garaffa, deputy regional administrator of the Chicago office of H.U.D. Meanwhile, the owners remain in possession, hoping that with time the value of the real estate will recover.
The Government insured about 9,800 housing units in Chicago during the period, but none after 1987. About 20,000 units have been built between 1980 and the present.
The Government stopped insuring new residential construction after 1987, but major new rentals projects went forward anyway. Among those that have been completed since the beginning of last year were Cityfront Place, two midrise building and one highrise totalling 904 apartments on the large Chcago Dock and Canal Trust site called Cityfront Center in the Streeterville area just north of the Chicago River.
Other new projects are North Pier Tower on Lake Shore Drive, a 505-unit 61-story tower that has 16 floors of parking; the Parkshore, at 195 North Harbor Drive near the lakefront just south of the Chicago River; Plaza 440, at 440 North Wabash Avenue near the Loop, the heart of the business district; and Goldcoast Galleria farther north.
Cityfront Place, to give one example, is offering two-bedroom apartments with cherrywood doors, Italian marble baths, built-in microwave ovens and garbage disposals for $1,650 a month, with two months' free rent. The building has a health club, a pool, a sun deck, a party room and a parking garage for 600 cars. James Watts, the project manager, said the project is over 70 percent leased.
The latest building to go on the market is the 50-story Plaza 440, with 457 apartments. It is in a mixed-use building that has a 336-room Marriott hotel as well as a 400-car garage. Two-bedroom apartments can be rented for $1,400 to $2,000 a month. One-bedrooms are available for $1,200 to $1,300.
The developer, the John Buck Company is known mainly as a real-estate services company for corporate users -- it has taken over management of the 4.5-million-square-foot Sears Towers and will lease out 2.8 million square feet in it as Sears's merchants group moves to the suburbs. It bought the 40,000-square-foot North Wabash Avenue parking lot four years ago.
"We're the last of the new stuff," said Bill Moody, the project manager. "There will be a pause in new investment now. Real estate is battered and everyone is cautious."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Plaza 440 is a new 50-story building at 440 North Wabash Avenue near the Loop. It has 457 apartments and 336 hotel rooms. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Connecticut's War of the Malls Intensifies

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FOR the last six years the wars of the malls have been intensifying in Connecticut's planning and zoning commissions and its courts.
In a major battle, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield, Mich., owners of the 18-year-old Westfarms Mall on the Farmington-West Hartford border, is determined to prevent the Wilmorite Company of Rochester from building a competing mall in Plainville, six miles away, that it feels could take up to 15 percent of its business. 
 But Wilmorite, having already won two court challenges by Taubman, is confident that it will prevail and break ground within a year. "There is more than enough market for Westfarms and us," said Alfred W. Friedrich, Wilmorite's president.
Westfarms will soon expand from 1 million to 1.38 million square feet, with a Nordstrom department store occupying almost half the new space. The mall serves Hartford's wealthy western suburbs. "If Plainville is developed as proposed, it would be a threat to traffic in the region, and a problem for our business," said Christopher Tennyson, Taubman's vice president of corporate affairs.
Plainville's municipal agencies have approved Wilmorite's plans for a 1.3-million-square-foot, $250 million mall on 77 acres, with three anchors and 225 small shops. The project is similar to Wilmorite's Danbury Fair Mall, which expanded from 1.2 million to 1.4 million square feet and is the largest in New England.
"Westfarms continues to interfere for the purpose of protecting itself," Mr. Friedrich said. "As a result our project has been slowed and subjected to unduly intense scrutiny. But Westfarms has not been successful in any litigation to date."
Last month the U. S. Supreme Court denied a petition to hear Taubman's case after the company was defeated in the Federal District Court in Hartford and the the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan.
The suit, filed in 1990, challenged the process by which the state's Traffic Commission operated in issuing a permit to Wilmorite to improve and reconfigure Interstate 84 and Route 72 at a cost to Wilmorite of $35 million.
Taubman has brought another suit in Superior Court in Hartford challenging issuance of the permit itself. "We are currently filing briefs," said Neil T. Proto, a lawyer for Taubman. "If we are turned down there is the possibility of further suits."
James Barakos, director of the Federal Highway Administration office in Hartford, said: "We have reviewed Wilmorite's road plans and approved them, subject to requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act and the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990. Westfarms has written to us here and in Washington, indicating that an environmental impact statement should be required. We don't share that view, and in any case our procedures are not affected by such communications."
MR. FRIEDRICH said Wilmorite expected to employ up to 2,000 construction workers for 14 months and eventually generate 4,000 retailing and service jobs. His company has contracted to buy the land from private owners and it has letters of agreement with Macy's and G. Fox as anchors. "An agreement with Sears is under review by the store," he said.
The Taubman Company, which built the Stamford Town Center, is busy in New Haven as well.
"They have entered into a memorandum of understanding with the city," said Sal Brancati, the city's Director of Economic Development, "to build a 1.2 million-square-foot mall over Interstate 95, connected to the existing Chapel Square Mall downtown and financed by $100 million in state bonds."
He said the state has been asked to pass legislation that would allow for sales-tax increment financing. The state would issue the bonds based on the project's ability to raise a like amount in sales tax revenues over a 25-year period, without negatively affecting the city or state.
If the plan succeeds it could kill an already stalled proposal by the Homart Company of Chicago for a 784,000-square-foot mall in Hamden, seven miles north. Homart owns most of a 34-acre parcel on Dixwell Avenue where a Sears store has been operating for decades. Recently, North Haven sued Hamden to protect its own mall, but lost on appeal.
BUT last month Hamden denied Homart's latest application, scaled down from a million square feet after a six-year tussle over size and traffic. "Homart has until mid-May to appeal the decision" said Daniel Kops, the town planner. James J. Farrell, Homart director of development, said, "we have no idea what we're going to do."
Since 1988 Waterbury has been prodding the Shopco Company of Manhattan to proceed with a proposed 1.2-million-square-foot mall to be built on 167 acres of city-owned property. "Shopco has kept up option payments on the land," said Howard Plomann, director of the Waterbury Economic Development Agency, "but they need three anchors, and the economy has not been kind to the department store industry." Shopco officials did not respond to telephone calls.
Northwest of Waterbury, in Watertown, Homart wants to build a million-square-foot mall on 160 acres. More than 800 people in the town of 20,000 showed up at a public hearing three years ago to oppose the project. After a zone change was denied, Homart sued the town and lost. The last of two appeals was denied in January.
Stanley Masayda, the town planner, said that Watertown would seek aid from the state to buy the property and develop an industrial park.
Plans for a 925,000-square-foot-mall in Cheshire, first proposed six years ago by John Errichetti, a Waterbury developer, have come to a halt after many setbacks.
Last year his partner, the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation of Youngstown, Ohio, and Nordstrom backed out.
"The region can tolerate at least one more mall," Mr. Errichetti said. "If Plainville wins out that would end it for us. But nobody knows what will happen."

HEADLINE: Why Some Love L.I. Anyway

 BODY:
JAMES L. LAROCCA, president of the Long Island Association, conceded that when a company decided to relocate "solely on numbers," the Island had difficulty being competitive.
Instead, such business and civic organizations try to convey quality-of-life factors, Mr. Larocca said, adding: "We have a highly educated and motivated work force here. Such a work force expects a higher quality of life. 
 "If you tie together our highly successful education system, the greater presence of higher education here, the abundant open spaces, the cultural opportunities, the very significant recreation sources which, mile for mile, are more publicly accessible than anywhere you can name, we can compete."
Mr. Larocca said he had been told by some companies that had moved to Pennsylvania that the employees and their families often found their new regions rather isolated compared to Long Island. "They miss the hustle and bustle," he said
Some aerospace workers who relocated to Florida, Mr. Larocca said, were at first enthusiastic about the lower cost of living and the lovely year-around climate, but soon became disillusioned and returned.
Sheldon R. Sackstein, chairman of Action Long Island, a 12-year-old group that works to keep companies on the Island and represents 250 companies with about 300,000 employees, said: "We have expertise on this Island that can't be rivaled anywhere. In addition to the excellent schools, the beaches, the educated work force, there are two national science laboratories here. We are within a stone's throw of New York City's cultural opportunities."
Because high costs for basics like electricity spur companies to move, Action Long Island has asked the Long Island Lighting Company to cut rates 10 percent for households as well as industries for the next three years. "We're running on austerity budgets, and they are not," Mr. Sackstein said. "That's wrong."
The educated work force is part of the problem, some companies say. The Jetson Direct Mail Service, which has more than 700 employees companywide, with 35 on the Island, had difficulty finding unskilled workers who spoke English, a spokesman for the company said. "Our first day in Pennsylvania we had 1,000 applicants to choose from," the spokesman added.
To address that problem, Monitor Aerospace has a classroom in its plant for the teaching of English. "Because I remember when I came here from Italy," its president, Guy Lepore, said. "I was earning $1.50 an hour, and it cost $7.50 an hour for English lessons."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1357 words

HEADLINE: The 'Baby Boom Echo' Reverberates Throughout the County

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
BABIES are back. As clues multiply around the county -- from crowded delivery rooms to noisy playgrounds and even noisier real estate offices -- newly released census data have confirmed that Westchester is in the throes of a baby boomlet.
"The greatest gain between censuses was registered by the under-5 population," Westchester County planners said in a recent report, the first of a series analyzing the 1990 census. Noting that the birth rate has steadily risen in the county since 1983, planners said the number of county pre-schoolers increased 22.7 percent over 1980 figures, a phenomenon planners have dubbed "the Baby Boom Echo." 
 Although the youngest residents still claim the smallest share of the county's population, 6.6 percent, the report issued by the Planning Department said there were 10,712 more children living in Westchester in 1990 than there were a decade earlier. The children's rate of increase outstripped their closest rivals, the 65 and older set, by more than 2 to 1, the report said.
The boomlet, which was forecast nationwide, has surprised many who believed that high housing costs, the large number of working women and a trend toward smaller families would keep the number of children down. Birth rates today, while still well below the levels reached in the 1960's, are generally higher than many demographers predicted.
 
'The Yuppies Fooled People'
 "This time the yuppies fooled people," said Mary E. Carlson, the Westchester County Planner who provided the recent census analysis. "These couples delayed having babies while they both worked," she said. "They both seemed intent on establishing careers," she said, "but the money they earned was for a down payment so mom would have a cushion when she stopped work or worked less."
The boomlet is beginning to have strong reverberations in the county's elementary schools, particularly those in southern Westchester where communities with shorter commuting times are more attractive to parents with jobs in New York City.
School administrators closely watching population trends say they knew enrollments would rise, but they concede that they were surprised by the sudden numbers of 5-year-olds registering for their schools and the difficulties of predicting what may still be an uneven curve.
"Three years ago, we 'grew' 50 kids over the summer," said Dr. Stanley Toll, the Ardsley Superintendent of Schools. "Last summer, it was 0, but this winter, we added 15."
 
Changes Impossible to Anticipate
 In Hastings-on-Hudson, where administrators are preparing for 136 kindergarten children at the Hillside Elementary School this fall, nearly double the enrollment five years ago, some demographic changes are impossible to anticipate. Two years ago, the 90 members of the kindergarten class almost overnight became 102 first graders, Dr. Vincent Beni, the Superintendent of Schools said, a demographic blip he attributes to a sudden drop in mortgage rates.
Accommodating the kindergarteners has become increasingly difficult, the superintendents said, because of reduced state aid and growing taxpayer resistance to school budget increases. The most difficult issue, they say, is how to reorganize existing space.
Parents protective of their elementary school children oppose moving them; administrators mindful of state mandates requiring more diverse programs that eat up classroom space guard what is available, while voters in a difficult economy resist paying for new construction. Last Wednesday, voters in the Ardsley School District approved in a 924 to 793 vote a $3.6 million bond referendum that included $1.4 million to add four classrooms and a library to the Concord Road Elementary School. The addition was needed to accommodate a kindergarten enrollment of 150 students predicted for this fall, Dr. Toll said, adding that 100 kindergarteners greeted him when he arrived in Ardsley five years ago.
There were nine other school district votes last Wednesday, and voters approved their budgets in each case.
 
'Out of Space at Concord Road'
 The bond issue was supported by the Ardsley Parent-Teacher Association, especially by parents who feared that the alternative -- moving the fifth grade out of the elementary school -- would result in their children's being unduly influenced by older students at the Ardsley Middle School.
While many Ardsley voters said there was space available at both schools without the need for new construction, Dr. Toll disagreed. "We are out of space at Concord Road," he said last week, citing the special-education programs, computer classes and day-care programs that occupy classrooms at the elementary school.
He said he was reluctant to use any of the 13 classrooms available in the middle school that are now rented to other education groups, like Montessori and Lyceum Kennedy. The average yearly rental of $10,600, which offsets school taxes, is more than the $8,800 it will cost the district to build permanent classroom space at the elementary school, Dr. Toll said.
The bond-issue approval was critical to the school district, Dr. Toll said, adding: "We are going to see even larger school population increases. We are just beginning the trend that is going to accelerate in areas perceived as school districts of choice. No one will move to Ardsley and pay our high taxes and prices if they don't get the benefit of good schools."
 
Classrooms Added in Irvington
 In Irvington, two study committees of community residents, teachers and administrators spent months studying ways that the school district could accommodate a projected school enrollment increase generated by the baby boomlet and fueled by the construction of 267 new housing units in three major developments in the last 10 years.
Three modular classrooms have been added to accommodate an elementary school enrollment that has added 72 students in three years, exceeding school capacity. Additional modular rooms were considered, said Dr. Stephen B. Fisher, the Superintendent, adding: "Both our architect and the demographics said we would soon need 9 to 12 more modulars. Nobody wanted a parking lot full of modulars."
Hoping to avoid moving fifth graders to the 80-year-old Irvington Middle School, the school board last spring proposed a $9.7 million bond issue to build an extension to the elementary school and to renovate the middle school. In one of the largest turnouts ever seen in Irvington, the referendum was narrowly defeated by 1,182 votes to 1,293 votes.
A second, smaller bond referendum will be placed before voters in the fall, Dr. Fisher said, while the fifth grade remains at the elementary school. Meanwhile, the school system has taken some unusual steps to handle curriculum needs. To replace a music room converted to classroom space, Dr. Fisher said, "We have an electronic synthesizer that can be wheeled from room to room. It gets music to the students, but we don't like doing it that way."
Just south of Irvington in Dobbs Ferry, one of the county's smallest school districts includes one of its largest elementary schools. With 222 students in the entire high school, 610 students are enrolled at the Springhurst Elementary School with 110 new kindergarten students expected in the fall.
Four modular classrooms have not been enough to relieve overcrowding, so next year the fifth grade at Springhurst will move to the middle school, despite objections from parents. Springhurst will still be quite full, said Dr. Raymond J. Gerson, the Superintendent of Schools. "We are bursting, and even new modulars can't ease crowding in the lunchroom or the physical education and art departments." The move will help free space for the computer program, which, Dr. Gerson said, now occupies space in a closet.
In the county's Planning Department, Ms. Carlson predicted that the Baby Boom Echo would stop reverberating when Baby Boom parents stop producing children. "There's a larger pool of them to start with," Ms. Carlson said. "The cycle will level out when children of low birth years, parents born in the 70's and 80's, begin to have their children."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

MUSICAL MEMORIES
Ruth and Skitch Henderson will share breakfast and anecdotes of their musical and culinary careers, and they will give a cooking demonstration for people attending the fund-raising event for the Jansen Memorial Hospice on Tuesday. Two sittings, at 9 or 10:30 A.M., are scheduled in the Zodiac Restaurant of Neiman-Marcus in White Plains. The cost is $65 a person.
In addition to their individual pursuits -- Mr. Henderson as a musician and conductor for 50 years; Mrs. Henderson as a lecturer and teacher of art, retailing and food preparation -- the couple manage a multifaceted art and kitchen-ware emporium and a cooking school at their New Milford, Conn., farm called the Silo. They have also written a cookbook together, called "Seasons in the Country," published by Viking-Penguin in 1990. Mrs. Henderson is working on a second book for Viking-Penguin, "Christmas in the Country," expected to be released before Christmas in 1993. 
 A professional chef will prepare the breakfast from the Hendersons' cookbook recipes while the Hendersons demonstrate their skills with buttermilk apple-berry pancakes and a lightly cooked compote of apples and lingonberries. A mysterious ingredient permits the pancakes to be pre-cooked without losing texture or flavor, Mrs. Henderson said.
The Jansen Hospice in Tuckahoe was founded in 1984 and serves terminally ill patients and their families in Bronxville, Eastchester, Scarsdale, Tuckahoe and parts of Mount Vernon and Yonkers. The number to call for breakfast tickets or more information is 961-2697.
 
DEALING WITH ARTHRITIS
 Arthritis is a disease that may strike children, the elderly and those in between. To help people understand and manage the illness better, the Hudson Valley branch of the Arthritis Foundation and Westchester Jewish Community Services have put together a six-part, self-help series of workshops for all ages.
Information on nutrition, exercise, relaxation, stress, conserving energy and protecting affected joints are some of the topics to be covered. Sessions will be held at the Renee Pollack Home Care and Geriatric Center at 456 North Street in White Plains from 1 to 3:30 P.M. on Mondays beginning this week. The cost of $30 includes a copy of a pamphlet called "The Arthritis Help Book." The number to call for more information or to register is 683-0842.
 
GLASNOST IN THE BRONX
 The final concert in the "Glasnost in the Bronx" series of the Bronx Arts Ensemble is scheduled at 2 P.M. today at the Russian Mission to the United Nations Residency in Riverdale. The soloist is the Russian pianist Alexander Peskanov, and the American component -- a feature of each concert -- is the world premiere of Robert Baska's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings. Paul Gallo, a Bronx Arts Ensemble member, will be the clarinet soloist.
Mr. Peskanov's program includes works by Scriabin and Shostakovich, some of them performed with the ensemble.
Tickets at $20, or $15 for students and people 65 and older, can be reserved by calling (212) 601-7399. The Russian Mission Residency is at Mosholu Avenue and West 225th Street.
 
CONFERENCE ON LEARNING
 "Meeting the Needs of Gifted Underachieving Students" is the theme of a conference to be held at the College of New Rochelle Friday from 8:30 A.M. to 9 P.M. and Saturday from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.
In spite of the attention focused on the problem by professional organizations and Federal and state programs developed to assist such youngsters, little progress has been made.
Principal speakers are Dr. Crystal Kuykendall, a Washington lawyer and lobbyist, whose subject is "Identifying and Enhancing the Potential of At-Risk Gifted Children," and Dr. James Delisle, associate professor of special education at Kent State University, who will talk about "Learning From Children."
A series of workshops will explore how children can break out of underachievement, developing strategies for working with children at risk, how to discover innovative programs and approaches, how to identify individual learning styles and how to enhance a positive self-image.
The college is at Castle Place in downtown New Rochelle. Registration costs $130 for two days, $90 for one day or $35 for dinner and Dr. Kuykendall's talk on Friday from 6 to 9 P.M. The number to call to register or get more information is 654-5336.
 
ENVIRONMENTAL ART
 Many contemporary artists are focusing on concerns for the environment in their work, creating images inspired by the denigration of the planet's soil, water and air.
"Against the Tide: Artists and the Water Cycle," an exhibition on view at the Pelham Art Center through June 27, concentrates on water and the creatures that need it to survive.
Hunched forms reminiscent of birds are the work of Mary Ting, and deformed tadpole-like creatures, dead at birth, were created by Gayil Nalls. "Investment No. 5," a vest created by Connie Jost, is covered with images of fish species that no longer exist, wiped out by pollution or loss of habitat. Judith Belzer, Noah Baen, Janet Culbertson, Jean Blackburn, Sandy Gellis, Pamela Hollinde and Michael Sandstorm are some of the other artists who have contributed unusual works to the show.
Christy Rupp, one of the sculptors, is offering a slide show and lecture on her piece, called "Sewer Fish," and on the interplay of art, economics and the environment on Thursday at 7:30 P.M. The fish has a sewer pipe protruding from its belly, through which it presumably must pass the unsavory matter it is forced to ingest.
The center is at 155 Fifth Avenue in Pelham. Information on viewing hours can be obtained by calling 738-2525.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
When a Name Outweighs a Market

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Jerrold Mitchell, the portfolio manager of First Investors Global Fund, has not liked the outlook for the Swiss stock market all year. Yet the two biggest holdings in his worldwide mutual fund are Swiss stocks: Ciba-Geigy and Nestle.
Mr. Mitchell, who is also a money manager at Wellington Management in Boston, has picked Ciba-Geigy, the chemical and pharmaceutical producer, and Nestle, the giant food company, for their international character. Just 2 percent of Nestle's business is in Switzerland. It is about the same for Ciba-Geigy. Unlike most other stocks, they depend very little on the overall performance of the economy of their home country. 
 Ignoring the influence of the domestic market can be dangerous for international investors. Generally, the performance of individual stocks is closely linked with the performance of the stock market where they are based.
Sushil Wadhwani, a strategist at Goldman Sachs in London, estimates that the performance of a local stock market can outweigh the performance of an entire European industry sector by 2 to 1. This is why two very similar companies in different countries can have very different stock performances.
In fact, investors interested in overseas stock can often do better by focusing on the country than on the specific stock or industry. But this approach is likely to be less reliable in the future as financial markets become more global. This is especially likely in Europe as the European Community expands and a single currency is created. These moves are expected to narrow the difference in economic performance between countries. Then the name of the stock will count more than the name of the country.
"We are at the beginning of that trend," Mr. Mitchell said. And Ciba-Geigy and Nestle are the kind of stocks that already can be played in that way. Of First Investors' $207 million in assets, 4.25 percent is in Ciba-Geigy and 2.55 percent is in Nestle.
He said he had thought that Sony was another stock insulated from its home market. But the collapse of the Japanese stock market proved him wrong.
So he is still giving considerable weight to a company's country. "The academics say that even with the globalization we have today, most stocks move with their market," he said. "So if we moved ahead of this trend, we could get hurt."
So far this year, Ciba-Geigy and Nestle have paid off. Ciba-Geigy is up 16.6 percent and Nestle, 14.4 percent. The surprise for Mr. Mitchell is that the Swiss stock market has moved almost exactly with the two stocks. The Swiss Market Index hit a 1992 high on Friday and is up 16.7 percent for the year.
But this only makes him happier. "We are even more convinced that these are the two stocks to own," Mr. Mitchell said. "Their value is better than the market over all. The growth is better." So he expects them to continue to perform well, while he believes the overall Swiss market will not.
Both Ciba-Geigy and Nestle have been gaining favor with analysts and portfolio managers lately. Nestle appears to be emerging from years of sluggish performance. This is powered in part by a new advertising drive intended to pick up sales and a large restructuring aimed at cutting costs. Ciba-Geigy, which has been offering the Habitrol nicotine patch for those who want to quit smoking, is emerging as a strong competitor in pharmaceuticals, Mr. Mitchell said, even though many investors still think of it as a chemical company.
In addition, the two stocks compare favorably in terms of price-earnings and other barometers of value with their rivals. For Nestle the important competitors include BSN of France and for Ciba-Geigy, Roche Group and Sandoz, two other Swiss concerns. Because of the sales outside of Switzerland, a rising dollar -- it's up 8 percent this year -- helps the earnings of both companies.
Tom Bannatyne, head of Swiss equity research for S. G. Warburg in Geneva, likes both stocks but he perfers Nestle, which recently won a battle with the Agnelli family of Italy for the right to take over the French water bottler, Source Perrier.
"It is easier to come up with a case that Nestle is cheap," he said, when comparing it with other international competitors. "It is harder to pull Ciba-Geigy apart and say you have to own it for itself." For an investor leery of investing in Switzerland, he said, Bayer, the German chemical and health care company, would be more attractive.
Mr. Bannatyne said both Swiss companies are trying to broaden their shareholder base by making their companies more accessible and their reporting more open to attract foreign investors. This is a reflection of another change that is coming slowly in stock markets outside the United States and Britain. "These are two companies which have realized that for the future they need more investors," he said.
Sylvain Massot, European food and beverage analyst for Morgan Stanley in London, agreed. "People tended to have a lot of prejudice about Nestle," he said. "Over 10 years, earnings growth lagged and the management was so secretive that you could not find out what was going on. That is changing."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

IRA D. HALL
 
Treasurer, I.B.M. United States, Purchase, N.Y.
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
 We need jobs, not lectures, right now. If we took the companies in Los Angeles and we coordinated the Government training programs and the school system as well, that concerted effort would start on the short term as well as the longer term. If people from I.B.M. were asked to do whatever the community is going to do, I.B.M. would do its fair share.
I.B.M. has had a long history of job training centers. We have over 100 around the country. I.B.M. donates the equipment and sometimes also makes a grant. More than 40,000 people have graduated from these centers, and the job placement rate exceeds 80 percent. The first one opened in Los Angeles in 1968. It's in a neighborhood that was burned, but they left that center standing. That says something to me -- they valued that center as a resource.
I've been involved with the National Urban Coalition almost since its inception in 1968. I took a leave of absence to create a local urban coalition in Northern California. We dealt with unemployment, health care, education, the like. Then I went back to my regular career. I'm still on the board of the National Urban Coalition.
I was born in Oklahoma in 1944. The official policy in housing, in education, in employment was segregation. I was fortunate to grow up in a household where both parents had master's degrees. People who grow up in such households understand how hard you have to work, what sacrifices you have to make. It's hard to get it if you don't get it from your home. In the longer term people need some success models, so they can touch success, feel success, see success, imagine themselves successful.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

RICHARD D. PARSONS
 
Chairman and chief executive, Dime Savings Bank of New York
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
 There's a short-term problem and a long-term problem. In the short term, you've got to get those kids off the street. The only entity big enough to really fund a program to do that is the Government. You have to have jobs that are fairly manual, that don't require a lot of skills, almost like a Works Progress Administration effort. There are enough jobs of a public nature, rebuilding infrastructure, that if I were President, I would have my advisers working on a W.P.A.-type jobs program right now.
But that's just a tourniquet to stop the bleeding. At best, Government has been the first step on the employment ladder for immigrant groups and minorities. I worked for Government -- for Nelson Rockefeller and President Ford -- for too many years not to have some understanding of its limitations, and the vulnerabilities of relying on just one sector for dealing with the problems of minority disenfranchisement. We can't get stopped on that first rung. This is a capitalistic country, you know, and the private sector is where the jobs are.
In the long term, we have to do something about the educational system. The schools need to turn out kids who have good technical skills and good communication skills. Kids who can read, write and speak the king's English. At my bank, I need either technicians or I need customer interaction people. They need to sit across from a customer, understand the customer's needs and communicate the bank's ability to meet those needs. I've spent time with kids in the schools, and I can barely understand these kids. It's a failure of our public school system.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 3-8

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Figuring the Odds on Rebuilding South-Central 

"We don't want to raise false expectations and then not deliver," said Peter V. Ueberroth, former Baseball Commissioner and Olympic organizer last week. Mr. Ueberroth has been charged by Mayor Tom Bradley with getting businesses to move back to riot-torn South-Central Los Angeles. That won't be easy. Not only is the infrastructure in shambles, but many of the incentives are gone: Federal aid to cities has been cut substantially in the Reagan and Bush eras."No one can point to even one example of an area that suffered from a civil disorder ever turning around," said Chris Walker, senior research associate at the Urban Institute in Washington. For businesses, the inner city is expensive. "Security costs are higher, insurance costs are higher, borrowing costs are higher, there's an overall risk premium," Mr. Walker said. "I think Mr. Ueberroth has between a 5 and 10 percent chance of succeeding."
 
Working It Out at Olympia
 
With $18.5 billion in debt and creditors threatening to seize its assets, the Reichmann family, owner of Olympia & York, North America's largest real estate developer, is turning over the sofa cushions searching for spare assets to sell. It found a few last week. Olympia said its would sell 32.5 million shares in the Santa Fe Corporation and 25.4 million shares of the Home Oil Company of Calgary. Total? Perhaps $740 million. But that's not enough to keep the global empire intact. Olympia's $7.3 billion Canary Wharf project in London is unfinished and unrented. The company needs $53 million to keep the cement mixers running through the end of the month. So Olympia said it would do something it had never done before -- let outsiders in. It will offer its 15 largest lenders 30 percent of the wharf project and 20 percent of Olympia. The lenders, in return, would have to extend Olympia's debt-principal payments for five years, provide more cash and give the Reichmann's the right to buy back their shares.

Out of Romance, Big Bucks
 
Though not exactly literature, women's fiction -- as the genre is called -- is one of the hottest-selling categories in the publishing business. Romance sells. Last week, Barbara Taylor Bradford, a master of the craft, signed a $20 million-plus contract with HarperCollins to write three novels. HarperCollins has published the English-language editions of her entire, seven-book oeuvre, including "Remember," which is being turned into a movie. "They made me in England and the Commonwealth one of the biggest authors in the world," Ms. Bradford said.

Coty Gets a New Home
 
Japanese companies may still be in their conglomerate phase, but American companies are shedding nonstrategic assets. That's why Pfizer Inc., the big pharmaceutical manufacturer, sold its Coty fragrance and cosmetics business last week to Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., the German household products company. Pfizer will get $440 million which it will invest in promising new drugs like Zoloft, an antidepressant, and Zithromax, an antibiotic. "Coty's a strong company but it is just not fitting strategically into Pfizer's long-term strategy," said Jay B. Silverman an analyst at Nomura Research Institute. Besides, gross margins in the drug business can range as high as 85 percent.
 
Ernst & Young at Fault?
 
The question the Arizona Board of Accountancy began asking last week in preparation for scheduling hearings, was whether Ernst & Young, one of the nation's Big Six accounting firms, was negligent for failing to uncover problems at the now-bankrupt American Continental Corporation and failed Lincoln Savings & Loan. Lincoln, which was seized by Federal regulators, cost the taxpayers $2.6 billion. Both companies were controlled by Charles H. Keating Jr., the imprisoned financier, and audited by Ernst & Young. The Arizona could bar the accounting firm from practicing in the state.

Three Men and a Horse
 
It was a steep price to pay for a horse that lost 12 races in a row since capturing the Kentucky Derby last year. But Bill Condren and Joe Cornacchia bid $2.9 million for the pleasure of getting back Strike the Gold. The bidders were two of three partners in BCC Gold Stable. BCC was when a bitter feud could not be resolved between Mr. Condren, Mr. Cornacchia and the third partner, B. Giles Brophy. And who was bidding for the horse against Mr. Condren, a lawyer, and Mr. Cornacchi, a publisher of games? Mr. Brophy, of course. He stopped bidding at $2.45 million.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Calling Japan
 
A Little Help? Last week, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, got a little miffed with Japan over its hesitancy to aid the ex-Soviet Union. While Germany has turned its pockets inside out by pledging $47 billion to aid the former Soviet Union and another $65 billion to rebuild and absorb eastern Germany into its economy as well as aid Eastern Europe, Tokyo has so far anteed up a measly $2.6 billion. Mr. Kohl warned that if the ex-Soviet Union does not make it through its economic crisis, a political crisis could result. And since Russia and the republics sit at Mr. Kohl's back door, he is eager for help. "Now especially is the time for Japan, an exporting nation, to assume a larger share of the West's common responsibility and, in keeping with her economic strength, to help insure the success of the reforms," Mr. Kohl said. So far, Japan has not replied.

Franco-American Aviation
 
Back in 1946, when France and the United States negotiated a commercial aviation accord, only Pan Am, T.W.A. and Air France flew the New York-Paris route. Pan Am is now extinct; T.W.A. is, well, hanging in there, and Air France has some French competition. Ten airlines now fly between 20 cities in France and America, with American carriers capturing two-thirds of the market. So when American airlines asked for permission to increase flights by 35 percent, under the rules of the old accord, the French Transport Ministry said it's time to scrap the agreement altogether and negotiate a new accord -- one that gives French carriers a larger share of the market. The pact "is clearly no longer suited to current conditions," the ministry said.

Lights Are On at Lucas
 
For a generation of British sports car enthusiasts, Lucas Industries P.L.C., which makes automobile electrical systems, was known as the Prince of Darkness. Switch on the lights and you never knew what would happen. Not anymore. Not only has Lucas gone high tech, it's also has gone Japanese. It has been partners in a joint venture with Japan's Sumitomo Wiring Systems for more than a year. Last week, the joint venture won a contract worth $36 million a year to do the wiring for a new car to be made by Honda and British Aerospace's Rover unit.

The Worth of a Ruble
 
Every year since 1985, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev first took power in the ex-Soviet Union, the Government vowed to make the ruble convertible -- next year. After seven years of waiting, the economists in Moscow finally appear to be getting serious. Last week, the Ministry of Finance said the ruble would be freely convertible by Aug. 1. According to Konstantin Kagalovsky, a ministry economist, the exchange rate is expected to be about 80 rubles to $1. Currently, the Government sets the rate at 120 rubles to $1 -- for most transactions. But with few exports other than oil and gold, what will Moscow use to stabilize the ruble at that rate? According to Mr. Kagalovsky, the ruble will be backed by dollars -- $6 billion in foreign aid from the International Monetary Fund. For a country the size of Russia, $6 billion may not last long.

Britain Breaks Step on Rates
 
The current consensus system for setting interest rates in the European Community is simple: When Germany raises rates, everyone else must raise theirs or the value of their currencies will fall. And when Germany lowers its rates, everyone else must do the same, or their currencies will become overvalued. But last week, Britain broke with Germany's high-interest-rate policy when the Bank of England cut its equivalent of the prime rate to 10 percent from 10.5 percent. The move was made to nudge Britain out of its longest recession since World War II. The cut "will provide a useful boost to business confidence at an important time," said Sir John Banham, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, a business group.
 
Germany agreed last week to union requests to raise salaries in the public sector by 5.4 percent and give a $650 lump sum payment to each worker. Analysts expect that to increase Germany's budget deficit even more and put pressure on the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, to raise interest rates even higher.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Detroit Finds a Little Steam
 
After suffering its worst year ever, Detroit is finally seeing a little showroom action. Sales of North American-built cars and light trucks increased by 18.3 percent in late April, the car companies reported last week. That brings Detroit's annual selling rate to 6.0 million for the month, compared with 5.5 million a year earlier. Though still not robust (7.5 million a year is robust) it may be enough to keep the Big Three in the black. And the April sales were at better prices than a year earlier, the analysts said. Fewer cars were sold either with incentives, at deep discount or to the car company's own rental fleets. "A lot of positive things are going on that the gross numbers are masking, such as overall profitability," said Wendy Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney in New York. "The quality of the sales are better this year."

Going Upside on Employment
 
People in business, skeptics that they are, don't get into the hiring mood until they are sure a turnaround is real. Why bring people on just to let them go? That's why unemployment stays stuck at recessionary levels until well after the recovery is in full swing. So when the Labor Department said last week that the nation's unemployment rate fell in April to 7.2 percent from 7.3 percent the month before, it was a real upper. Even more important, the department said 126,000 new jobs were added to the payroll, the largest increase in a year. "Thank God, the economy really is finally recovering," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "After over three years of depressed growth and recession and every kind of bad economic weather you could think of, we are beginning to move again."
