HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

EARL G. GRAVES
 
Editor and publisher, Black Enterprise magazine, New York
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
People have to be trained. You have to have a decent educational system. We're not going to fix these schools without enormous resources and enormous commitment to do it.
What else do you do to get those people trained? Apprentice programs, like the one at Chrysler. You can go to high school in the morning, go to work in the afternoon. You can learn a skill and get credit for it. We're going to get you ready for something besides flipping hamburgers. When you graduate from high school, you're guaranteed a job.
Why can't there be apprentice programs right now to rebuild Los Angeles? It's not terribly redeeming if everyday you're looking at things that are charred and burned out. Give the training and the job opportunities to inner-city youth. You will see the light in those kids' eyes.
In construction, you can make yourself $40,000 a year if you're able to get into those industries. But either in terms of blacks in the unions or minority contractors, you could count them on one hand. If you look at New York City, the construction industry has been the most racist you can think of. There are three million black people in New York City, and you don't see them. There should not have to be a special program, but historically we have been kept out. How does a person who has been closed out catch the train when it's already left the station?

HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

CAROLINE R. JONES
 
President, Caroline R. Jones Advertising Inc., New York
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
You have a whole generation of black youth between the ages of 16 and 21 who have never experienced one workday in their whole lives. If you have nothing to do, and no self-esteem, you affect mannerisms to try to call attention to yourself. It's also a defense mechanism: If I'm not working, you shouldn't be. It's depressing, but it's not surprising. We have to study them because they are our customers.
There's no mystery in how to get people involved in an industry: hire them. We have to train people how to come to work, be at work, give them the luxury of failure. When I started in business, I was the first black person ever trained as a copywriter in the 100-year history of J. Walter Thompson, and that was back in 1963.
I grew up in the 1950's. That was a different time. I didn't have to worry about the crowd influencing me. I grew up with a lot of rules. We pretend that the traditional family is still out there, and it's not.
I had three jobs when I was a teen-ager: a job at a newspaper, a stock girl and semi-salesperson at a dress shop, and then I went and washed dishes in a little greasy spoon. I couldn't be a waitress because they said that would be too upsetting to truck drivers. "Old-fashioned Okeefenokees," I called these people.
In the advertising business, a lot of white people were afraid to tell me I was doing something wrong. Those of us who are black have to learn to accept criticism without having a chip on our shoulders. You have to ask for criticism to grow, but you need a lot of self-esteem, because there are people who try to hurt you when they criticize.
I don't trust Government to do but so much. I don't expect them to know more than I do about how to run a business. But not everyone can afford to bring in these kids and train them, so that is where Government has a role. We hire interns, we always do. We give them real jobs and make sure that everyone has a one-on-one mentor.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

EDWARD G. GARDNER
 
Chairman and chief executive, Soft Sheen Products Inc., Chicago
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
I often ask my friends in Corporate America how they can so readily build factories in suburban Chicago, and how they can so readily build factories in Mexico, but can't seem to provide jobs for people on the South and West Sides of Chicago. We gave America hundreds of years of free labor, and yet we're sometimes 50 and 60 percent unemployed. They do not seem to be sensitive to the issue at all, even though they're taking millions and billions out of the inner-city community in sales. They turn their backs and wait for Government to do it.
Before you can ask a young man or woman to dedicate himself or herself to preparing for a job, you've got to have a job. We are one of the larger suppliers of jobs in the city of Chicago -- between 500 and 600 jobs. We're 99-percent black-owned and operated. We know the potential and capabilities of young black men and women.
We know what our customers expect from us and we're not going to shirk our responsibilities. We have a Cook County Jail program -- My Sister's Keeper. We're finding African-Americans who will meet those ladies when they come out of jail -- two women and one man who will become their mentors. It is painful for me to see my sisters degraded to that position. These women are the mothers of those kids out there with the Uzi guns.
We're also supporting a school for pregnant young girls. We have church feeding programs. And we're taking more risks to build more businesses. One of Soft Sheen's divisions manufactures most of the millions of bottles that we use annually, and we sell containers to Kraft and to other inner-city businesses. We have our own advertising agency. We're extremely happy to walk the streets of Chicago and see all our employees.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
After L.A., How to Revive Hope In the Inner City

 BODY:

JUANDA A. HONORE
 
Los Angeles School District police officer; owner, T. J. Cinnamons Bakery at Baldwin Hills Crenshaw Plaza, Los Angeles
For many black executives and business owners, the brutality of life in the ghettos commanded their attention long before the Rodney King verdict ignited the worst riots in recent history. Asking them how to bring those inner cities back to life called forth personal recollections melded with practical measures, anger shadowed by despair. 
 Their words come from interviews that began with the same question: Unemployment among black teen-agers in South-Central Los Angeles approaches 50 percent -- certainly an underlying cause of the recent strife. What is the single strongest recommendation they would make to create productive careers for young inner-city blacks around the nation?
 They spoke more of what business than Government could do; they see Government as a helpmate, not a savior. When blacks were virtually excluded from the business world they turned to Government; many are now turning back to the business world in frustration with Government. In an era when most debates about corporate obligations turn on the competing claims of lavishly paid executives and restive shareholders, all who spoke assumed that their companies have duties to their employees and their communities as well.
You have to start with the schooling. They need to be taught how to get the job and keep it. They have to get some understanding of what it is to interview for a job, and what they have to do to keep a job. I don't think they have a clue.
They know they need money. But they don't really understand the need to be successful. They think they can do the same things they could do when they were at school.
I've employed several students, but I haven't been able to keep them employed. They don't understand the meaning of being on time, of following through. They have the same excuses they use in school: "I forgot this, I forgot that." They use their parents for excuses. They feel it just isn't important for them to be here.
It gets to the point where either you feel frustrated with them or they feel frustrated with you. You just get fed up and say, "One of us has got to go."
You're talking about kids. Where are they going to get that responsibility from? If they're coming from disadvantaged situations, the parents haven't worked recently, so they don't have models at home. The best place has to be the school.
The schools need to teach the practical lessons. Now, you're giving them a high school diploma, but what does that mean? Nothing.
Most of them have an unrealistic idea of how much money they're going to make. If you're making $4 an hour, it takes a while before you can buy a $100 pair of tennis shoes. What's going to make you stick with it? You see your friends selling drugs or stealing, you're not going to think it's wrong if you see the immediate benefits. Most of them don't have the long-range goals. They know if I do this, I get what I want. They don't think about getting arrested.
We have a wrought-iron fence around most of the mall here, so they only started to get in. They looted the Broadway department store. Since then they have had the National Guard here.

HEADLINE: Guinness Takes a Luxury Tack

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
When Anthony J. Tennant, the Etonian who turned Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. into a world power in spirits and wines, was recruited to work similar magic at Guinness P.L.C. in 1987, the British brewer and distiller was in disarray. Its last chairman, Ernest W. Saunders, had been fired and later jailed for his part in illegally manipulating Guinness's stock price to win the 1986 takeover battle for the Distillers Company, which made Guinness the world leader in Scotch and gin. Distillers had tried to maintain sales volumes of its all-important Scotch business by cutting prices and granting a private label to any distributor who requested one. But that had only eroded market share and the power of its leading brands, which included Johnnie Walker, Dewar's, White Horse and Old Parr.
Mr. Tennant has abandoned that strategy and in the process has turned Guinness into one of the world's most profitable beverage companies. Only the Coca-Cola Company earns more in beverages. Today, Guinness is indisputably one of the most adept marketers of consumer goods around, a testimony to the power of selling liquor as a luxury rather than a commodity product. 
 Since 1987, Guinness's pretax earnings have more than doubled. Last year, when Britain and the United States were mired in recession and the war in the Persian Gulf and fears of terrorism slowed global travel, hurting the all-important duty-free business, Guinness's pretax income rose 13 percent, to 956 million pounds, or nearly $1.79 billion, on sales of just $ 7.6 billion.
Although Guinness stock is fairly expensive at $11.29 a share, or about 15 to 16 times expected 1991 earnings, many analysts are enthusiastic about its prospects. "Buy it! Buy it! Buy it!" said Christopher Wickham, an analyst at Lehman Brothers International Ltd. "You shouldn't be sleeping soundly at night if you don't own the stock."
"A lot of companies have risk areas," said Derek Brock of Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd. "This one doesn't."
While the Guinness name is still widely associated with the stout dark beer that bears its name, more than 75 percent of its operating profits now come from its spirits division, United Distillers, whose operating profits have more than doubled since 1987, to 749 million pounds, or $1.4 billion, last year.
This growth is largely the result of acquisitions made by Mr. Saunders and Mr. Tennant. Over the last seven years, Guinness has spent more than $8 billion on spirits and beer producers and distributors. Mr. Saunders bought both Bell's, the leading Scotch in Britain, and Distillers, whose brands include Gordon's and Tanqueray gins and Johnnie Walker and Dewar's Scotches.
In the last 18 months, Guinness has also purchased America's Glenmore Distilleries, a spirits producer and distributor whose Scoresby is the No. 1 Scotch in California. Glenmore has doubled Guinness's share of the American spirits market to 16 percent.
It also now owns Germany's leading premium brandy maker, Australia's most popular spirit and Venezuela's largest spirits company. Guinness is still looking for strong regional brands, both for their own potential and for the leverage they provide in marketing mainstay Guinness brands locally.
Under Mr. Tennant, Guinness has also followed its main competitors by gaining control of most of its spirits distributors, both improving its profitability and its ability to control the pricing and marketing of its brands. Such control was essential for Mr. Tennant to realize his dream of repositioning Guinness's labels as premium brands for which status- and quality-conscious consumers would pay ever more.
"The brand you drink is very much a demonstration of your life style, of your affluence," said Anthony A. Greener, who has driven the spirits division's expansion since 1987 and became Guinness's chief executive on Jan. 1. He becomes chairman when Mr. Tennant steps down at the end of the year at the mandatory retirement age of 62.
Still, expecting people to trade up to more expensive brands may have been more reasonable in the go-go 1980's than in the go-slow 90's. According to research by Impact International, the drinks industry magazine, volume sales of the top 100 spirit brands fell last year "for the first time in recent memory." The Gulf war and temporary problems plaguing some big economies were partly to blame. But David Fleming, Impact's managing editor, said: "The big question is whether it marks the beginning of a long-term trend."
In the United States, the decline in spirits consumption appears to be continuing. In Britain, consumption has long been flat. And in one big growth market, Japan, the economic slowdown seems to be taking a toll.
Other threats include rising excise taxes on alcohol in the United States and the possibility that taxes could soar in Europe: the European Community is debating how to tax alcohol in the single market after Jan. 1.
Nor can Guinness count on expanding its spirits business as aggressively through acquisitions. It has the money. "They could easily spend $2 billion on something," Mr. Brock said.
But the pickings are slim. Guinness now owns 85 percent of its spirits distributors, up from 20 percent when Mr. Tennant took the helm. Guinness would probably be barred from buying any of its major international rivals for antitrust reasons: United Distillers holds about 38 and 30 percent, respectively, of the world Scotch and gin markets.
An alliance that Mr. Tennant forged with LVMH Louis Vuitton Moet-Hennessey has given Guinness a valuable stake in champagne and cognac. Though it still lacks a major international vodka, none seems available. Grand Metropolitan owns Smirnoff and Popov and also has the American distribution rights to Absolut.
Guinness leaders confess to ambitions in liqueur and cordial companies. Obvious candidates include giant Pernod Ricard, Remy Cointreau, Campari Davide and Societe des Produits Marnier-Lapostolle. But many are controlled by families who seem to have little interest in parting with them.
There has been speculation that Guinness might copy other alcoholic-drinks giants by diversifying into new industries. But Mr. Greener, who is 52, insists that Guinness will stick to spirits and beer. "We intend to remain as single-minded as ever," he said. "The success of this company is dependent on how well we develop these brands."
Moreover, plenty of potential acquisitions remain in beer, he added. "The opportunities for growth by acquisitions are more likely to be on the beer side."
Unlike the spirits business, there are only a handful of international beer brands, including Heineken, Carlsberg and Guinness Stout. Regional brewers are plentiful and acquisition prices, which soared in the takeover wave of the 80's, have since plunged.
Ranking No. 11 in the world in terms of amount of beer sold, Guinness Brewing is fourth in operating profits, trailing only America's Anheuser-Busch, Japan's Kirin Brewery and Australia's Foster's Brewing Group. Brian F. Baldock, the head of Guinness Brewing Worldwide, cited Guinness's moves in Spain as the kind he would like to repeat. In early 1991 Guinness bought La Cruz del Campo, Spain's largest brewer. The new subsidiary then acquired control of Spain's No. 6 brewer, Union Cervecera, which expanded Cruzcampo's portfolio of brands and its reach into parts of Spain where it was weak. With Guinness's help, Cruzcampo also introduced a reformulated low-alcohol beer. Since the acquisition, Cruzcampo's Spanish share has jumped to 29.7 percent, from 22 percent.
In the United States, Guinness is taking a relatively cautious approach. Respectful of mighty Anheuser-Busch and Philip Morris's Miller, it is focusing on the imported beer segment. In early 1990, it bought All Brand Importers Inc., which raised the number of beers that Guinness distributes in the United States to 10 and more than doubled its share of the import market to 13 percent.
Even if beer is now more in the spotlight, the glory days aren't over for spirits, Guinness executives stress. They insist that they have only begun to tap the potential of whisky as a luxury item. In Japan, where gift-giving and social drinking are rituals of business life, it has become a custom to give a $75 bottle of 15-year-old Johnnie Walker Gold as an everyday business gift or to pay $400 at an exclusive bar or club for one's own bottle of Johnnie Walker Premier.
"Scotch is the major motor of our growth, and I'm sure will remain so," said Mr. Greener, who, before taking charge of United Distillers, transformed Dunhill Holdings P.L.C. from a cigarette company into a successful luxury fashion concern.
The LVMH-Guinness alliance has been a big help in Guinness's effort to position Scotch as a prestigious drink. Each owns 24 percent of the other and jointly own 14 distributors, which peddle Guinness's spirits brands alongside LVMH's cognac and champagne in the United States, East Asia, France and Ireland.
To reduce competition between its brands, Guinness slashed their number, eliminating most private labels, and concentrated its marketing resources on the regional leaders. This effort has enabled Dewar's and Johnnie Walker to to increase its share in the United States. Guinness is also making strides establishing bourbon as a fashionable drink in East Asia with I. W. Harper and in Europe with Rebel Yell.
Mr. Tennant predicts spirits sales will continue to grow strongly in Southern Europe and will soar in South Korea and Taiwan once trade barriers fall. China and Eastern Europe are potentially big markets, he added.
"In most of Eastern Europe," he maintained, "the two Western brands that are best known are Coca-Cola and Johnnie Walker. They don't currently have a great deal of money to buy Johnnie Walker but they might one day."
 
 
 
PEGGING GROWTH TO A FABLED STOUT
 Guinness's efforts to expand its beer portfolio globally by buying all or part of local brewers fits neatly into its plans to grow its flagship Guinness Stout. The world's 19th-largest-selling beer by volume, the "black beer" is brewed in 42 countries and sold in some 130.
It is typically much easier for an international brand, especially a specialty beer like Guinness, to penetrate a local market if it is distributed with a portfolio of strong local beers, said Brian F. Baldock, the Guinness deputy chairman who heads the beer business.
Revival of the brand, which had languished as a drink for mostly older, blue-collar men, began in the early 1980's, when it was repositioned with clever advertising as a fashionable drink for younger professionals.
"While the world beer market has been growing by about 1 percent a year, Guinness Stout has been growing 5 to 6 percent per annum for the last five or six years," Mr. Baldock said.
Guinness is also counting on improved taste to keep consumption of its stout growing. To that end, it has been investing heavily in refurbishing its breweries and in new dispensing equipment in bars.
Equally important is the continuing rollout of Canned Draught Guinness, which is sold as Pub Draught Guinness in the United States. Each can contains a device that injects nitrogen into the stout when the can is opened, making it really taste like bona fide creamy draught brew. Draught Guinness went on sale in 1988 in Britain, where it is now one of the top take-home brands. It is now being tested in New York, Boston and Washington as well as Canada, Germany, Spain and Australia. "Our biggest problem is capacity," Mr. Baldock said.
Guinness is scrambling to get more equipment for installing the device.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Winning Over the Community for a Mall

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
After a four-year struggle that included jousting over zoning and the complaints of abutting neighbors, ground was finally broken earlier this month for a large new shopping mall on Long Island. The opportunity for newly created jobs in a recession-weakened economy was one reason opposition crumbled. Another was the personal diplomacy of Alan Fortunoff.
Mr. Fortunoff, the 59-year-old president of the chain of houseware and jewelry stores that bears the family name, is the force behind the new mall, and he said last week in a telephone interview that he realized early in the planning that he needed to win over the community. 
 "We wanted to have the support of the local groups, rather than just neutralize them or have them in opposition," Mr. Fortunoff said. "We set out to bring them the exact details of the project. We reached out through luncheon groups -- the Chamber of Commerce and the Rotarians. And we reached out to civic associations by organizing barbecues and coffee hours in the homes."
Mr. Fortunoff has a long association with Long Island. His mother and father, Max and Clara, started the family business in 1922 with a housewares store in Brooklyn. In 1964, the Fortunoffs followed their customers to Long Island, where they built a store in Westbury. The business now has five stores in the New York area.
The Westbury store, at the site of the new mall in the heart of Nassau County, will be upgraded to be an anchor along with a new Price Club warehouse store. The 60-acre mall, to be called the Fortunoff Galleria, will expand on what was a vast parking lot for the now-shuttered 172-acre Roosevelt Raceway, which is being developed by others.
Mr. Fortunoff's original plans for the mall included upscale anchors like Nordstrom and Neiman Marcus, but these plans were scaled back, which solved many of the zoning tiffs.
"The biggest issue was density," Mr. Fortunoff said. "We reduced the size of the mall and came back with a project that met the code," meaning that no variance was needed.
The $194 million Galleria, which will be built in two phases, will employ 3,540 full-time workers with a payroll of some $97 million when it is fully finished in 1995.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Get a Life, They Said. And Did.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
John Barnum-Goodfriend gazes across the table, serenity in his eyes, calm in his voice, as he describes his encounter only minutes earlier with a Manhattan tow-truck driver.
"They had just hoisted it up when I got there," he said. "The agent said, 'You had exactly 30 minutes. I observed you parking at 9:15.' " Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend looked at his watch: 9:46. "I was calm. I even waved when my car went by on 42d Street." 
 As every New Yorker knows, the towing agents of Midtown have caused more bile to flow than all the clerks at all the motor vehicle departments, post offices, phone companies and cable television services across space and time put together. "A year ago, I would have gone crazy," Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend said. But a year ago he still lived in Manhattan, worked from 6 A.M. to midnight and fell asleep worrying about the day.
Now he still starts his day at 6 A.M., but instead of flipping a switch and sitting down to plot the details of his computer training business, he shrugs on his work clothes and heads out to free the dogs and milk the goats that form the nucleus of his family's incipient cheese business. For just over a year, John and Liz Barnum-Goodfriend and her son, Adam, who is 10, have lived in rural Sullivan County, about 120 miles northwest of the city that once consumed them. "We finally left because my son said he was going to explode if we had to stay another year in New York," said Ms. Barnum-Goodfriend, whose work schedule in the city was roughly the same as her husband's. "Kids want to get outside and feel some freedom," she said. "It wasn't safe in the city to let Adam have the independence he needed."
The Barnum-Goodfriends are hardly the first people to abandon New York for a less aggravating existence. Nor are they the first to head back to the land. Along the road between the house they bid for on an impulse more than a year ago and the Victorian farmhouse they moved to and now occupy is the real site of the Woodstock music festival, a constant reminder of previous experiments in rejecting one life style for another.
But they are a peculiarly contemporary incarnation of the people who preceded them.
Like many Americans, they watched their work take on a life of its own and seep its way into leisure and family time. A study earlier this year for the Economic Policy Institute in Washington provided some statistical confirmation of the observations of the senses: One of an occasional series on people
 coping with job dissatisfaction.
Americans on average work 158 hours a year more now and take 15 percent less time off than they did 20 years ago.
In the 90's, only the superwealthy -- like Morris Smith, head of the Fidelity Investments' huge Magellan mutual fund, who announced last week that he will take a year off to be with his family -- can do what the downwardly mobile did in the 60's: leave the fast track without looking back. One weekend last year, the Barnum-Goodfriend family went out for an innocent ride in the country and ended up leaving a deposit on a house about two hours from the city. All they had to do was figure out how to make a living.

"WE both knew direct mail pretty well, tried little feelers," Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend said. He has been involved in several ventures over the years, including consulting on political campaigns; directing murder mystery dinners at Sardi's, the theatrical district restaurant, and helping organize an alternative education project, which he once tried to publicize by throwing $10,000 off the Empire State Building. Ms. Barnum-Goodfriend was a partner in a thriving medical advertising business.
Having a history of job agility no doubt put the goat venture into the realm of possibility. Liz Barnum-Goodfriend liked goats and both thought goat products had untapped possibilities. "It was the venture that clicked," Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend said.
Until Adam got out of school for the year, the entire family commuted into Manhattan every day, a tortuous odyssey that began at 3 A.M. and involved several public transportation systems. As they learned "goating" and gradually moved their city ventures into the background, they have pared back the Manhattan trips to one each week per adult. It was a trip into town to check on his computer business and deliver cheese samples to Sardi's that brought Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend to his rendezvous with the dancing wu-li masters of the city's traffic division last week. As he headed off in an aura of equanimity for the impound lot on the Hudson River, he said in some ways his days are as busy as ever: "I am busy every minute, but at least I go to bed feeling good."
 
 
 
PINPOINTING A LIKELY MARKET
 Liz and John Barnum-Goodfriend are building their life in the 90's on the mortar of the 80's: chevre, or goat cheese. Some might accuse them of hubris for thinking they could learn goat farming in 60 to 90 days.
"It was really more naivete," said Mr. Barnum-Goodfriend. "You build a barn and then you have to build a road to get to the barn. And then you rebuild the barn to conform to regulations." Like any city slicker with brains, they headed straight for the nearest agriculture extension service and talked to other goat farmers.
Because the Barnum-Goodfriends face a market already saturated with goat-cheese options, they do not plan to go curd-to-curd with well-established operations. They believe the lower fat content of goat's milk will be a selling point in health-food and pediatric markets. "There are stories without end of infants who couldn't tolerate cow's milk surviving on goat's milk," Ms. Barnum-Goodfriend said.
The Barnum-Goodfriends can't help proselytizing. Next month, they plan to start offering seminars to prospective urban refugees in search of peace and an income.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
The 90's Chain Gang, A la Mother Teresa

BYLINE: By Mary Billard; Mary Billard writes frequently about business and legal issues from New York.

 BODY:
Here's the pitch: A tough, cool James Dean character -- perhaps played by Luke Perry -- is convicted of insider trading and sentenced to work in a Bronx soup kitchen. The greedy, selfish 80's fade into the socially conscious, politically correct 90's. The plot is a metaphor for our times. Rather than warehousing people in an overburdened prison, society punishes the guilty by having them serve the community.
Judges across the country hear this pitch by a rogues' gallery of savings-and-loan culprits, tax evaders and insider traders every day. Charles H. Keating Jr.'s legal team, for example, recently argued that he be punished for his swindling ways by taking a truly grueling job at an eye clinic for five years. 
 "It sounds like a joke," says Paul Turley, a deputy district attorney in Los Angeles County who helped put Mr. Keating behind bars, but the defense's report "said he'd be great at fund-raising."
"What would that say to the pool of potential securities defrauders?" Mr. Turley said. "Rip off millions and millions and you may have to work as an executive in an eye care clinic. Run a cost-benefit analysis on the upsides and downsides and I'll consider doing it."
The concept that community service could replace hard time came into vogue in the 70's as a way of reducing prison costs and overcrowding. And with white-collar crimes on the rise through the 80's, a cottage industry of consultants -- teams of psychiatrists, social workers and lawyers who manufacture sentencing reports -- is booming, according to Cessie Alfonso, president of Alfonso Associates in Jersey City, N.J., and president of the National Association of Sentencing Advocates.
For anywhere from $3,000 to $10,000, these consultants will devise alternatives to incarceration including community service work and restitution and will testify at sentencing hearings. And although the Wall Street and savings-and-loan industry prosecutions are winding down, environmental cases have increased, according to John Coffee Jr. of Columbia University Law School. The defendants are middle managers responsible for environmental controls. "They are calling them, the designated felons," said Mr. Coffee. Their offer is to clean up polluted areas rather than serve time.
But in white-collar sentencing circles, lawyers, judges and probation officers cite notorious examples of limp sentencing: An antitrust violater who was sentenced to endow a chair at a university; the bribing meat packers who had to teach the unemployed their trade; the convicted slumlord who was required to live in one of his tenements, and the New York City racketeer exiled from the city.
Andrew von Hirsch, a professor at Rutgers University of Criminal Justice and author, dismisses the more high-end types of community service punishments. "It is like sentencing me to write a book," he said.
In response, new Federal sentencing guidelines requiring that most offenders receive at least some hard time went into effect in 1989. "The guidelines increased the likelihood that the more privileged do some time for the same dollar offense regardless of race, gender or class," said Ilene Nagel, a commissioner on the United States Sentencing Commission.
The guideline forced defense lawyers to retool. "Defense lawyers' big thing used to be to tell clients whether they would be 'in or out,' " said Mr. Coffee. "There is no 'out' now."
Yet under the it-doesn't-hurt-to-ask theory, the guilty keep petitioning judges for community service in lieu of walking the big yard. And even with the mandatory guidelines there is a sentencing matrix granting points based on prior records, remorse and the jackpot escape hatch for cooperation, "Section 5K1.1."
Typically, friends, family and colleagues write the judge urging leniency. Mother Teresa, for example, asked the court to show mercy on Mr. Keating, a generous contributor to her charities. Among the impressive deluge of letters in support of junk-bond king Michael Milken was one from his junior high school teacher. "He always took time out to be kind and considerate of those less successful and popular than he," the teacher wrote.
Mr. Milken's defense spent 20 pages of its sentencing memo proposing community service work in a drug prevention program in Los Angeles. Mr. Milken, who did tutoring prior to sentencing, received 1,800 hours over five years in addition to prison time and fines.
What constitutes community service is in the eye of the beholder. "Some judges make sure it is onerous. Scrubbing urinals in a public health center," said Donald Chomlee, chief of the division of probation and pretrial sentencing of the administrative office of United States Courts. "Some judges think it is a deterrent for some guy with a $500 suit -- I'm dating myself, $1,500 suit -- to give speeches at the Kiwanis Club." Ivan Boesky did volunteer work before he was sentenced at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Even the tabloid's Queen of Mean, Leona Helmsley, asked for a stint in community service before being sentenced to four years for tax transgressions. But according to Mark Heller, the prosecuting Assistant United States Attorney, the request seemed like an "afterthought." There were no reports and no actual sponsor with a program. She received four years and 250 hours of community service. Visualize Mrs. Helmsley working as a maid in one of her hotels. Would justice be served?

HEADLINE: The Danger of Taxing Business Too Much

 BODY:
The April 19 article "Industry-Aid Bill Stirs Tax Battle" said that a bill recently passed by the New Jersey State Legislature to more equitably spread the tax burden between homeowners and industry could cost residential taxpayers "tens of millions of dollars." As the author of the Business Retention Act, I must disagree with that and point up some poignant facts concerning the bill.
As Mayor of the state's third largest city, I had to weigh arguments for and against the Business Retention Act, and I am convinced that the taxing of business machinery as real property is a very dangerous and real threat to the economic vitality of New Jersey's urban areas. 
The economic evidence supports the Legislature's action to overturn recent Tax Court decisions that would force industry to pay a higher percentage of taxes by taxing machinery necessary to production. For New Jersey to remain competitive with its neighbors in the battle to keep industrial jobs in this state, it was essential to approve the Business Retention Act.
Opponents of the measure, who say the act will produce a dramatic shift of the municipal tax burden from the industry to residential and commercial payers, are being very shortsighted. They fail to consider what has happened and what will continue to happen if industry simply closes its doors and leaves the cities. The cities will continue to lose not only ratables, but thousands of jobs as well.
New Jersey has lost 24.5 percent of durable-goods manufacturing jobs and 16.2 percent of its nondurable-goods manufacturing jobs between 1980 and 1990. Since the recession has hit in earnest in mid-1990, more manufacturing jobs have been lost and more plants closed.
The impact of those lost jobs is devastating to families and communities. Not only are income-producing manufacturing jobs eliminated, but so are thousands of ancillary service jobs that depend on a strong manufacturing base. And what urban officials must realize is that unemployed people can't pay taxes and that closed factories pay a lot less in taxes than those that are thriving.
It has often been said in this recession that the best social policy is a good-paying job. The Business Retention Act goes a long way toward insuring that people have good jobs, and that manufacturers continue to find a home in New Jersey, where they pay taxes and support the community.
Far from being a "giveaway to big business," the bill I have sponsored is indeed part of an even-handed economic development program fostered by the state. I hope that the opponents of this measure would stop their demagoguery of this issue and realize the positive aspects of pro-growth policies offered by the state.
 
WILLIAM J. PASCRELL
Assemblyman, 35th District
Paterson
Mr. Pascrell is also Mayor of Paterson.

HEADLINE: Needed: Help for Those Facing Loss of Homes

 BODY:
An April 26 article reported that thousands of New Jersey residents were losing their homes in mortgage foreclosures and that in some counties forced sales of homes have tripled. There can be no doubt that this surge in foreclosures is due principally to the recession.
At least 23,574 families were subject to mortgage foreclosure suits in 1991 alone. These are our neighbors, friends and relatives. President Kennedy once said that if a free society could not help the many who are poor, it could not protect the few who are rich. 
 Surely enlightened government in the last decade of the 20th century should be able to prevent these catastrophic mortgages without bankrupting the lending industry. Charitable organizations, which provide temporary payment schedules to members on hardship, might prove to be a workable model. Something must be done -- and now.
 
ROBERT R. SALMAN
President
Association for a Better New Jersey
Marlboro

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: The Jury Said, 'I'm White, and You're Wrong'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The not-guilty verdict for the police officers who beat Rodney King in Los Angeles is not justice but jive. Anyone who looks at the videotape of Mr. King's beating and says this was not a case of assault with a deadly weapon is missing a vital body nerve center. Yet it should surprise no one who has lived in this country and seen or participated in the hundreds of daily acts of division that have become politics as usual from the White House in Washington to the white houses in the suburbs. 
 White suburban juries as peers of black urban citizens? By what measure are they peers? Did this jury experience the poverty and prejudice and economic injustice that black people in the city go through every day? How could they know about informal civil rights abuse that goes with living in a poor part of town filled with blacks? Did they grow up under surveillance by the police?
The answer to these questions is "no." The white suburban jury is simply a reflection of the polarization of black and white communities over the last 20 years. Across this country white suburbs encircle core cities filled with people of color. How could any jury in any of these segregated suburban zones return a just verdict? Fear and prejudice sit smugly in their lounge chairs, safe in their sprawling suburban developments, watching everything through the surreal eye of television.
The jury's verdict sends a clear message: I am white, and you are wrong. President Bush is silent on the politics of racial disengagement. When was the last time a President of this country made a major speech or initiative on civil rights? But Mr. Bush's actions speak loudly about what he considers acceptable: from his vacations on de facto segregated white golf courses to white Kennebunkport to the $9 million fund raiser the other day, the message is clear.
The eyes of the people on the jury in Ventura County reflected the social perspectives encouraged and nourished by Ronald Reagan and George Bush for more than a decade. Their perception of Rodney King is colored by the social climate George Bush has propagated since his 1988 Presidential campaign's racist ads about Willie Horton made private white bigotry acceptable as public debate.
I grew up in a family that marched and went to jail singing "We Shall Overcome" with another King -- the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In my heart, I still want to say we shall overcome. But this verdict and these last 11 years of political and social separation make me angry and frustrated. I wonder if "some day" will ever come.
 
TIMOTHY S. COLMAN
Seattle, April 30, 1992

HEADLINE: Help From Many Sources;
Repairing Los Angeles: High Enthusiasm and Long Odds

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
FROM the ravaged streets of South-Central Los Angeles to City Hall to the boardrooms of big corporations, there was a whirl of activity last week directed at putting the nation's second-largest city back together again.
Yet even as the highly publicized efforts were beginning, questions were being raised about whether the momentum for real change can be sustained. 
 The Federal, state and local governments began providing aid to people left jobless or homeless and to the thousands of small businesses damaged or destroyed in the spasm of racial fury and general lawlessness of little more than a week ago. Local banks promised to do their part, and most of the big companies whose stores were looted or burned pledged to return and rebuild.
Peter V. Ueberroth, whom Mayor Tom Bradley enlisted to lead the rebuilding effort, flew frenetically around the country seeking commitments from corporations to create jobs and breathe new economic life into the area.
Black, Hispanic, Asian and white residents reached out to each other to begin a process of racial healing. A cross-section of the city's residents, from the homeless to movie stars, appeared in the streets with brooms, shovels and hope.
Even the Los Angeles Police Department, riven anew by criticism of its slow response to the violence, looked forward to a fresh start under Willie L. Williams, currently Philadelphia's police chief. Mr. Williams is to take over at the end of next month from Chief Daryl F. Gates, who is being pushed into retirement because of the repercussions from the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King.
Yet for all the optimism and good intentions, even a cursory examination of the city's underlying social and economic problems made clear that there would be no quick or easy fixes. Residents and local officials here could not help but look back to the aftermath of the Watts riots in 1965, when a flurry of initiatives and governmental attention faded quickly back into neglect. It was only natural to wonder whether anything would really change this time around.
"When we look at what occurred in 1965, and the change or lack thereof in the intervening years, the questions loom very large," said City Councilwoman Rita Walters, a Democrat who represents portions of the South-Central area. Addressing the problems of urban poverty and economic development will be even more difficult now than it was 27 years ago. Because of immigration, the once-predominantly black South-Central area is now almost 50 percent Hispanic, leaving it with no unified vision of its needs. In addition, the riots were preceded by several decades of steady economic decline, as factories closed and middle-class blacks moved away.
 
Different Approaches
 Corporations, already hit hard by the recession, are not likely to locate new operations in the area without substantial tax or financial incentives. And for all the political rhetoric, it is unclear how much the cash-strapped governments will prove willing or able to spend.
Despite his efforts to dampen expectations of any miracle cure, Mr. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who is best known here for organizing the 1984 Summer Olympics, is clearly under pressure to come up with some fast and concrete signs of progress.
Mr. Ueberroth, however, has few ties to the city's minorities, and his vision that Corporate America will thunder to the rescue does not sit well with some black leaders. They said the emphasis should be not so much on bringing large corporations into the area, but on helping local residents to build their own businesses and on giving them a direct stake in South-Central's economic future.
"I made absolutely clear to him that this was not an opportunity for white businesses to grab the land and get the credit for the recovery and then take their money out," said Representative Maxine Waters, a black Democrat who represents the South-Central area.
Ms. Waters said she told Mr. Ueberroth during a meeting last week that it is important not to allow the rebuilding efforts to wither away as they did after 1965, and that he will have to be willing to listen closely to minority voices to keep the process going.
"I let him know I'm going to ride herd on him," Ms. Waters said of her meeting with Mr. Ueberroth. "I'm going to take personal responsibility, because I'm not going to let it happen the way it did before."

HEADLINE: The World;
Food Production And the Birth Rate Are In a New Race

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
WITHOUT a huge increase in food production in the developing world, demographers are saying, millions more Africans, Latin Americans and Asians will be born in the coming century only to face short and miserable lives marked by poverty and near-starvation.
The United Nations is trying to prove the demographers wrong with a decade-long crash family planning program. But without success from such an effort, the United Nations warned last month, the world faces "four decades of the fastest growth in human numbers in all history," with its population likely to double from 5.4 billion today to 10 billion by 2050 before leveling off around 11.5 billion after the year 2150. Some 97 per cent of this increase is expected to occur in today's developing nations. 
 Such a population explosion would, of course, place immense new pressures on land, water, forests and other natural resources; it could also set off great migrations as the poor seek better lives in richer lands. And it would test anew the human race's ability to achieve a balance among its drive to reproduce, its ability to grow food, and nature's own capacity to trim back populations when they grow too large.
Two centuries ago, Thomas Malthus, the English demographer, gloomily argued that grinding poverty and famine would eventually accomplish the goal of population control -- at enormous human cost -- whenever a country's population grew faster than its food supply. In the 1950's, just such a Malthusian famine was widely expected to decimate the third world within three decades. Demographers were predicting at the time that the world's population, then about 2.5 billion, would double by 1990. The population figures proved accurate, but the so-called "green revolution" prevented famine on a cataclysmic scale.
Increased irrigation and fertilizer use, better farm management and above all the development of new high yielding varieties of wheat, rice, corn and other crops combined to produce explosive yield increases in developed and developing countries. In Mexico, for instance, wheat yields almost quadrupled between 1950 and 1980. Global grain output rose 2.6 times. Famine, once endemic to Asia and Africa, largely disappeared except in cases of war and civil strife.
"History records no increase in food production that was remotely comparable in scale, speed, spread or duration," the British economist Michael Lipton wrote in "New Seeds and Poor People," a study of the green revolution.
 
Harder This Time
 But now, with the global population continuing to explode, there is widespread agreement among agricultural experts that engineering a second green revolution is going to be harder than the first one. "It will be more difficult this time, though I still think we can do it with luck and good policies," said Stephen A. Vosti of the International Food Policy Research Institute in Washington. This means developing governments must pursue different goals simultaneously, making agriculture both more productive and environmentally sustainable while helping the rural poor earn money to improve their diet.
In earlier centuries food production was kept in line with population mainly by bringing more land under cultivation. But most of the world's arable land is in use, and even more intensive farming seems the only way to raise output. However, there is growing concern over environmental consequences of such farming and fears that much higher yields may not be sustainable. As Uma Lele of the University of Florida told a recent Rockefeller Foundation seminar on future food needs, "worries about environmental sustainability are weakening the intellectual foundations of the green revolution."
After explosive growth in recent decades, crop yields are rising more slowly or sometimes declining in many parts of the developing world, often because lack of water, deteriorating soil and urban advances force farmers to reduce cultivation. In four Indian villages surveyed by the food policy institute, high soil salinity caused by too much irrigation has forced farmers to leave one-quarter of their land fallow.
Biotechnology may eventually produce crop strains that are more disease resistant and better adapted to arid climes. But such breakthroughs remain in the future. Meanwhile, some environmentalists say Earth is approaching its maximum carrying load and its depleted soil and water resources cannot support another doubling of the population.
"I doubt we'll ever see 11 billion people because that is beyond the third world's agricultural capacity," says Lester R. Brown of the Worldwatch Institute in Washington.
Optimists believe that few agricultural areas are producing close to their theoretical limits, leaving room for a second big leap in food output. In 1979, Dutch scientists calculated the maximum possible annual crop yield at about 18,000 pounds of grain an acre in Latin America, 14,000 pounds in Africa, 13,000 pounds in Asia and between 10,000 and 11,000 pounds in North America, Europe and Australia. But according to Donald L. Plucknett, scientific adviser to the Consultative Group on Agricultural Research, which encourages development of more productive strains of crops, African grain yields an average of only about 800 to 1,200 pounds an acre outside the modern farms of Zimbabwe and South Africa.
 
Room for Growth?
 In Asia, yields on good lands have climbed as high as 5,000 to 6,000 pounds an acre but many pockets remain in the 1,000-to 1,500-pound area. In South America, some areas yield up to 5,000 pounds but others produce far less. Meanwhile, the United States and Europe pay farmers to take land out of production because of surplus stocks, while the farming potential of the lands that made up the Soviet Union is underexploited. "There is room for much more production with new genetic materials, improved management and more fertilizer use," Dr. Plucknett argues.
After Malthus predicted perpetual hunger and poverty in England as a growing population bumped against the limits of available food supply, the Industrial Revolution proved him wrong by raising living standards and encouraging smaller families and better farming. Economists hoped the first green revolution would do the same in the third world, providing what Dr. Lipton calls "a breathing space" from famine during which economic development and falling food prices would reduce poverty and cut the birth rate.
But that never happened, and the number of poor and hungry in the world continues to rise. The lesson of that first green revolution is that without smaller families many poor people may still lack money to buy the produce of a second green revolution -- when it comes.

HEADLINE: May 3-9: The Economy;
Unemployment Down, Payrolls Up - But Not by Much

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
For months the question among economic policymakers was whether the occasional signs of recovery were robins that portended a new spring. While last week's economic reports added further evidence that the season has indeed arrived, the problem is that it does not appear nearly as sunny as economists or Bush Administration officials would like. Most economists forecast growth of a moderate 2 to 3 percent this year; the average growth rate in the first year after other postwar recessions was a robust 6 percent. 
 The best economic news of the week came Friday, when the Labor Department announced that the statistic the public watches most closely, the jobless rate, fell in April for the first time in nine months. The rate dropped to 7.2 percent, from 7.3 percent in March, but remained well above the 5.4 percent it had been when President Bush took office. Payrolls jumped by 126,000 workers, and most companies said they were adding employees. Still, statisticians saw some weakness in the jobs report: average hourly earnings slipped and the average work week grew shorter in April.
Other good news was that sales of American-made cars rose 7 percent in April over the previous April, although car sales remain weak.
A Federal Reserve survey last week showed that the economy was picking up slowly, led by a resurgence in manufacturing. The following day, 14 leading retailers said sales grew modestly in April.
Not bad, all in all, but not brilliant. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the economy was improving, but added, "I would scarcely argue, however, that we are anywhere near back to normal."

HEADLINE: More Offices Are Shedding the Suit

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
WHEN the air-conditioning at L & F Products broke down last summer and the company was told it would take three weeks to fix it, Michael R. Gallagher started a small revolution.
Contemplating visions of middle managers sweating in the company's sealed office building in Montvale, N.J., Mr. Gallagher, the president, suggested that everyone come to work in chinos and polo shirts. 
 The air-conditioning is back on, but L & F employees are still dressing casually -- khakis, sportcoats, chambray shirts. "People's attitudes seemed to improve, there was more give-and-take and our productivity increased," said Mr. Gallagher, whose company makes Lysol, Ogilvie home permanents and other household items.
A growing number of companies, and not just computer designers and youthful advertising agencies, have adopted more informal standards. The look is what the fashion trade calls "business casual." Cut-offs and ripped t-shirts aren't in, but neither are wool suits or ties. Alcoa, the aluminum giant, has the look, as does the BIC Corporation. Citibank's marketing department has "casual days."
And, as bits of corporate America shed the suit, makers of tailored clothing are hurting. Sales of the traditional suit -- a jacket and pants cut from the same fabric and sold with the assumption that a tailor will make alterations -- have slumped, while sales of knit shirts are up. Levi Strauss & Company sold a record $850 million worth of casual twill trousers last year as Brooks Brothers' profits plummeted 50 percent.
"We're reducing our overall manufacturing capacity so that I don't have to try to sell suits into this tough environment," said Michael Sandler, vice president of merchandise and product development at the Greiff Companies, which makes men's suits for Perry Ellis, Ralph Lauren's Polo University and other labels.
Recessionary layoffs among lawyers, bankers and stockbrokers help explain the drop in sales. So do suit prices. Levi's Dockers pants sell for about $40 and a sportcoat costs about $250. But the cheapest line that Hartmarx, a major suit manufacturer, makes for full-price retailers sells for $450, and its Hickey-Freeman line retails for up to $1,250. Designer suits cost far more. Prices jumped with the price of wool in the late 1980's and have stayed up.
The increasing economic importance of Florida, southern California and other states where wearing wool suits borders on insanity has added to the malaise for manufacturers.
And the entry of women into the workplace has changed men's attitudes. Women have more choice in office attire, wearing suits, dresses and trousers in a wide variety of fabrics and colors. Now men want some of the same.
"Until the last few years, about the only choice men have had is, 'Do you wear cuffs or don't you?' " said Lynn Shnurnberger, a fashion historian and author of "Let There Be Clothes."
But women who can sport "business casual" embrace it as eagerly as their male colleagues. "You don't have to wear pantyhose in the summer," said Julie Sweeney, a category manager at L & F in a chambray shirt and khakis. "And my dry-cleaning bills have certainly gone down."
Fashion experts say the shift reflects a fundamental change in lifestyle -- now that those making the change can finally dare to make it. "The guy who was part of the jeans generation in the 1970's wasn't interested in wearing a wool flannel suit," said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report. "He may have had to when he started his career, but now he's running the corporation."
Someone like Bruno Bich, perhaps. "There's something strange about putting a tie around your windpipe," said Mr. Bich, the 45-year-old chairman of the BIC Corporation, where the engineers and sales people behind disposable pens, lighters and shavers have disposed of their neckwear too. They say creativity is enhanced.
Dominick Pisciotta, a senior product manager at L & F, said, "People tend to forget about who's the boss and who's the employee when everyone is wearing loafers and polo shirts."
But fashion authorities say the tailored suit still isn't at any risk of going the way of wide ties, Nehru jackets and the Full Cleveland (leisure suit with white belt and shoes).
"I was at the Harvard Club the other day and, believe me, they're still wearing tailored suits," said Ms. Shnurnberger. "Of course, they're still eating fried crabcakes and canned peas, too."

A CLOUD IN FRANCE
France's celebration of V-E Day has been overshadowed by intense debate about the country's less glorious wartime role, with more and more citizens demanding to know the truth about French support for German occupation forces in their campaign against the Jews. 1
 
SCANDINAVIA SECURITY SHIFTS

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Concern, Cash, But No Accord On Urban Woes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Despite trillions of dollars spent over the years on thousands of different Government social programs, politicians and scholars are no closer to agreement today than they were a generation ago about the best ways to lift people out of poverty and make the cities better places to live.
Experts at universities and research institutes and in Government agree that if a consensus could be reached about which programs have worked, the country would embrace those solutions, regardless of cost. But enormous ideological and political differences inhibit such a consensus, and the gulf has widened in the aftermath of the riots in Los Angeles. 
 "The problem all along," said Donald F. Kettl, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin, "is that we cannot agree on what it means that something works or doesn't work. The goals are always multiple and confused and vague. Conservatives look at it from one perspective, liberals from another. What people at the national level thought were mistakes, people at the local level often liked. Everything is just much more complicated than we ever thought."
In a few instances over the years a consensus emerged about what needed to be done, and in those cases the country responded. Take the elderly.
 
Better Off Now? Much.
 Thirty years ago, half of all Americans over 65 had no medical insurance, a third of the aged lived in poverty and millions avoided destitution only by living with their children.
Since then, with little complaint or political controversy, people's taxes have been repeatedly raised and the money has been spent on the elderly to the point where Social Security retirement benefits, health insurance under Medicare, nursing home payments under Medicaid and additional income supplements to the aged poor amount to well over one-third of the entire Federal budget.
Today, nearly everyone over 65 has medical insurance, the poverty rate among the elderly is substantially lower than it is for Americans as a whole and a vast majority of older people are financially self-sufficient.
The attacks from the Bush Administration in the last week to the contrary, the programs of the 1960's and 1970's have had other distinct successes.
 
Black Political Power
 Before the civil rights laws of 1964 and 1965, no major American city had ever had a black mayor, and there were only a couple of hundred black elected officials nationwide at all levels of government. More than 90 percent of the black adults in some cities were not registered to vote.
Now, blacks vote in about the same proportion as whites, and New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia, Detroit, Atlanta and Cleveland are among the many cities that have or have had black mayors.
In the early 60's, only one-third of the children 3 to 5 years old attended nursery school or kindergarten. Now, preschool programs are available to almost all children those ages.
Still, few people would argue that the nation's cities are better off. Old problems like poverty, crime, illegitimacy and violence seem to have worsened. New plagues like AIDS, crack and homelessness are pervasive.
So if the social programs succeeded in some respects, they failed in many others. More important, central questions increasingly seem to become irreconcilable the longer they are debated: how to strike a balance between work and welfare, to insure poor children a solid education, to put the jobless to work, to provide adequate housing for all, to fight crime while preserving civil liberties.
 
Leaders Are at a Loss
 Americans and the politicians they elect would love to have the inner cities flourish and to allow the people who live there to enjoy the fruits that nourish most Americans, said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief staff economist.
The difficulty, said Mr. Reischauer, whose academic specialty is social policy, is that no one knows how to do it. "The economic and demographic and political forces that have been undermining the vitality of our inner cities are so overwhelming," he said, "that policies of the sort we've engaged in really can't stem the tide."
Nearly all politicians and scholars agree that the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, has been at best seriously flawed and at worst disastrous. Almost no one defends rules that force families to split to qualify for welfare or that require families to be on welfare before they are eligible for Medicaid, the health care program for the poor.
But conservatives and liberals disagree so fundamentally on what a welfare program should be that many attempts to reform A.F.D.C. have failed for lack of consensus.
 
Welfare's Central Conflict
 Conservatives worry most about poor people's becoming dependent on welfare generation after generation and never bothering to fend for themselves. Liberals are most concerned that benefits are not high enough to enable the poor to live in dignity.
Almost everyone agrees that those who can work should work. But jobs in the inner cities are scarce, and a basic conflict has never been resolved: On one hand, if welfare benefits are withdrawn when poor people take jobs, then there is little incentive to work, because the difference between what they can earn and their welfare payments is small. On the other hand, if they are allowed to keep a good part of their welfare checks when they go to work, then they have considerably more income than people they are working with side by side who have never been on welfare.
One reason Federal aid to the elderly has been so universally accepted is that the aged are not expected to work, so the trade-off between work and benefits does not arise.
Like many other conservatives, Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, a Washington research institute, believes that the Aid to Families program is so fraught with misguided incentives that it has poisoned almost all Government social programs.
 
Bright Spots
 "Walk around the inner cities if you dare to, and all you see are people on the street corners not expected to do anything," Mr. Butler said. "The men would be crazy to look after their families and the women would be foolish to take a job because the welfare benefits would run out."
But even most ardent conservatives concede that some Government programs have basically been successes, like Head Start for poor preschool children and the Job Corps, the residential work-training program for the most seriously disadvantaged youth.
And other scholars have found small but valuable programs around the country. One, in Chicago, has helped thousands of poor black families move from the inner cities to better lives in federally subsidized housing in the suburbs. Another, called Youth Build, now in eight cities, has poor young men learn construction skills by restoring buildings. These programs rely on at least some Federal money, but they are locally organized and might not be applicable nationwide.
Some Government programs have distinctly failed. No one today defends the high-rise public housing projects that were built in the 1950's.
 
When Good Yielded Bad
 Other programs had unintended adverse consequences. The urban renewal grants of the 1950's and 60's placed modern buildings in the downtowns of cities, but in the process neighborhoods were destroyed and families were displaced. In the end, much more housing was lost than gained.
And the interstate highway program, the most important public works project in American history, facilitated the abandonment of the cities.
Many people now live in better housing because of Federal aid like rent subsidies, but the money has always been so short that only a small portion of poor people could benefit. On balance, developers and landlords have probably been the real winners from Federal housing programs.
Employment training programs have also had mixed results. They have been especially beneficial for many women but have failed most young black men. Most of the jobs programs have been guilty of "creaming," giving training to the best-qualified applicants, who would probably have succeeded without the special training.
"The problems are just so intractable," said Tom Joe, director of the nonprofit Center for the Study of Social Policy in Washington. "I hate to say it, but the programs that work, the ones that really work, are those that get people out of the inner city."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California;
CLINTON 'OBSESSED' WITH U.S. TROUBLES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL CAJON, Calif., May 9

 BODY:
Bill Clinton said today he wakes up every day obsessed with America's social and economic problems, and he suggested that President Bush had been so isolated that he took an interest in such problems only in an election year or after a crisis, like the riots in Los Angeles.
Mr. Clinton made the comments in an outdoor amphitheater in this suburb of San Diego as he began introducing himself to the voters of California, where he is not well known. California holds a Presidential primary on June 2. 
 Already focusing on the general election campaign, Mr. Clinton, the likely Presidential nominee of the Democratic Party, tried to underline differences between himself and Mr. Bush.
"You have got to understand, one big difference between me and Mr. Bush is the way we have lived for the last 11 years," said Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas. "I am not being critical of him, but he was Vice President and he was in the foreign policy establishment, the political party establishment of the Republican Party. I have been a Governor who has lived with people on a very personal basis. When people lose their jobs or their businesses or their farms, there is a good chance I'll know them by their names. I live in a small state."
 
Benefits of Prevention
 Mr. Clinton said: "The things I am talking about today are things that I will keep on the front burner as long as I am President because they are the things that drive me. I get up every morning obsessed with this stuff. You need a President now who basically will put the needs and interests of the American people first every day all the time. That's what we need right now."
Mr. Clinton was asked how he would sustain the nation's interest in race relations and the problems of America's cities, after people stopped focusing on the riots in South-Central Los Angeles.
"I hope to be able to persuade people who live in some states where there are no minorities that they should be very interested in the economic vitality of Los Angeles and New York because we all pay," Mr. Clinton said.
For example, he said, the cost of education and job training is much lower than the cost of imprisoning someone who turns to a life of crime rather than productive employment, and the cost of prenatal care for a pregnant woman is much lower than the cost of intensive care in a hospital for a baby born prematurely with birth defects.
 
Affirms 'Pro-Choice' Stance
 Mr. Clinton's message appeared to be well received. The applause was loud when he affirmed his support for a woman's right to choose abortion. "I am pro-choice," Mr. Clinton said. "But pro-choice is not the same thing as being pro-abortion." He said he favored sex education and other school programs to help reduce the number of pregnancies among teen-agers.
Mr. Clinton made an informal presentation of his political platform and then sat on a stool, fielding questions from the audience for about 40 minutes.
David Dickason, a 40-year-old research psychologist in the audience, said of Mr. Clinton: "I really like his style of campaigning. I like what he had to say. He is much more personable than I expected."
Carolyn Anderson, another listener, also praised Mr. Clinton. She said that Mr. Clinton, unlike Mr. Bush, "has lived like a majority of Americans have lived."
 
Noting 'Poor White Folks'
 Mr. Clinton asserted that Bush Administration officials were trying to use welfare as a political issue to divide Americans along racial lines. But the Governor said: "We should not pretend that welfare is a racial issue. There are more poor white folks in this country than poor non-white folk."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged today that he was not well known in California and that his position in the primary election campaign was therefore difficult. But he said: "I think it will get better and better. I have no presence out here. I am just beginning to establish it."

HEADLINE: 59 Are Chosen for National Academy of Sciences

 BODY:
The National Academy of Sciences, the 129-year-old private organization that advises the Federal Government on science and technology, has elected 59 new members. The election brings the academy's active membership to 1,651 scientists and engineers. Fourteen nonvoting foreign associates were also elected; their number is now 289. 
 Election to the academy is considered one of the highest honors that can be accorded an American scientist or engineer. The society said the new members were elected "in recognition of their distinguished and continuing achievements in original research." Following are the newly elected members and their affiliations at the time of the election.

HEADLINE: Iran's Leader Gets Support in a Runoff

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 9

 BODY:
Results of parliamentary runoff elections held on Friday confirm that President Hashemi Rafsanjani will have enough support to counter political rivals and carry out his policies of an opening to the West and liberalizing Iran's economy.
Supporters of Mr. Rafsanjani repeated their success in the first round of voting with a landslide victory in Teheran and a comfortable majority across the country. 
 With 75 percent of the vote counted, more than half the winners are candidates who have pledged support for the Society of Combatant Clergymen, a group that backs Mr. Rafsanjani, according to the Risalat newspaper. Nearly half the seats in the 270-seat Parliament were undecided after the first round of voting.
Although the final results in Teheran will not be announced until Sunday, partial returns indicated that all 30 Parliament seats in the capital will go to candidates who ran on the ticket of Spiritualist Combatants.
 
Former Minister Wins
 One of the leading vote getters in Teheran was Mohammad Javad Larijani, a foreign policy strategist in the Government and former Deputy Foreign Minister. Mr. Larijani last year called for safeguarding "common U.S.-Iranian interests in the Persian Gulf" which he said "could precede" the normalization of relations between Teheran and Washington.
Another winner in Teheran was Maryam Behroozi, who will be serving her fourth term in the Parliament as a member of Mr. Rafsanjani's party. She ran on a platform of improving the status of women in Iranian society.
In a recent interview with foreign journalists, Moussavi Khoeiniha, a hard-line candidate and editor of the Salam newspaper, voiced displeasure with the success of Mr. Rafsanjani's supporters in the first round of elections. About 80 pro-Rafsanjani candidates won in the first round compared with only about 20 hard-line fundamentalists. Other winners were independents whose political affiliations were not clear.
With a large majority of candidates running as independents, in early April Risalat published a list of 120 names of "candidates who pledge support for President Hashemi." The list was cited later as support for the contention that the majority of first-round winners supported Mr. Rafsanjani's policies.
Risalat editors indicated this morning that more than half of those elected so far in the runoffs backed Mr. Rafsanjani's party.
 
Backing for President
 "We have to show our support for the President," said Ihsan Kavian, a Western-educated businessman who voted in both elections. "Rafsanjani wants to change the image of Iran. It is vital that we vote for those who work to rebuild the country and return Iran to the international community."
Pocketbook issues of unemployment and inflation were paramount. People interviewed on state-run Iranian television generally expressed dissatisfaction with "candidates who bicker more than they work," in the words of one. Many Iranians see the hard-line majority as having slowed economic reform by their opposition to Mr. Rafsanjani's free-market economic policies.
And in a national trend of turning away from career politicians, voters overwhelmingly registered their support for technocrats or specialists in different fields who are new to the Parliament -- more than half the first-round winners.
Mr. Rafsanjani is reportedly considering major changes in his Cabinet by the end of the year, according to a recent editorial in the Teheran Times, which is close to the Rafsanjani camp.
The moves, Western diplomats say, would be intended to complete a cycle of changing the old guard. After a significant victory by his supporters in the Parliament, he would replace influential ministers from the early days of the Iran-Iraq war who are considered as not having moved fast enough with reform, with a group of technocrat "experts." A new political elite in the Parliament and the Administration, diplomats say, could help Iran attract more investment and loans.
