HEADLINE: South Korea's Vietnam Veterans Begin to Be Heard

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
The tales of chaotic battles in Vietnamese jungles are much the same as those heard in the United States. The anger at a government that some say used its young men as pawns in a cold war power game is also familiar. But the faces of these bitter Vietnam veterans are different: They are Korean, and after years of bearing their hurt in near silence, they are finally being recognized for their role in a war few know South Korea fought.
It is almost as little known here as it is in the West, but South Korea sent 312,853 solders to Vietnam from Sept. 22, 1963, to April 30, 1975, according to the Defense Ministry. After the United States, South Korea had the largest contingent of soldiers fighting Hanoi. 
 But with two big-budget movies on the Korean soldiers in Vietnam coming out here shortly and the Vietnam Veterans Association battling for better treatment for its members, South Koreans are starting to come to grips with their heavy involvement in Vietnam and the toll the war took on many of the young men who served there.
The veterans' stories are opening a little-explored chapter in South Korea's history, and are becoming a symbol of how this scarred country may finally be winning its own battle for free expression after years of authoritarian rule. The rough-and-tumble process of democracy, just five years old, is slowly giving South Koreans the chance to explore the difficult path they have taken to their current prosperity.
 
Like Others, Alienated
 "The Vietnam veterans in other countries who returned were very alienated," said Hwang Myung Chul, vice president of the Vietnam Veteran's Association, seated near the neat rows of jars filled with black and dun-colored Vietnamese earth that he hopes one day to place in an official memorial. "We were no exception. We wanted the media to relate our pain and difficulties, but they were told not to. The Government virtually ignored our problems. That is what we are fighting now."
For some, there is pride that South Korea, which was saved from Communist domination only because of United States military intervention in 1950, answered America's call for help. Soldiers from Thailand, the Philippines, Canada, Australia and New Zealand also served in Vietnam.
But South Korea's Government had a number of reasons for responding so energetically to America's call for assistance in Vietnam. The military-dominated Government in power at that time had to maintain a constant vigil against attack from Communist North Korea, bolstered by American troops stationed in South Korea, and was resisting pressure from its own people for the introduction of real democracy at home. It also was engaged in a struggle to free the country from its grinding poverty -- tasks that all required some aid or acquiescence from the United States.
Many South Koreans argue that their Government acted more out of a desire for the hundreds of millions of dollars in aid the United States offered, or that they feel shame because Koreans were killing and being killed in a land in which they had no place. Some complain, too, that the Government has still not told the whole story of South Korea's role in the war helping the United States support South Vietnam's fight against the Communist North.
 
4,687 Koreans Reported Killed
 According to the Defense Ministry, 4,687 Koreans were killed in the war, and more than 5,000 others wounded, but some veterans insist that the casualty figure is much higher, based on the death tolls in their own units. Also unexplored are reports of the particularly brutal methods the Korean soldiers were said to have used.
For the veterans, much of the focus now is on demands for greater Government assistance, which they say has been in meager. One particular complaint is that the Government neither recognizes nor offers treatment for problems related to Agent Orange, the powerful chemical used to kill dense jungle foliage during the war. The chemical is believed to have caused an array of health problems for some of the soldiers exposed to it.
Studies in the West have been unable to turn up clear evidence of ill effects, except for a temporary skin condition, called chloracne, and small increases in rates of a kind of cancer, soft-tissue sarcoma. As a result, even American veterans have been fighting with their Veteran Affairs Department, which limits the claims that it will pay. American veterans groups, like their Korean counterparts, continue to protest this policy.
American veterans, along with some Canadians, Australians and New Zealanders, are eligible, however, for compensation from the manufacturers of Agent Orange. Korean soldiers were not part of a 1984 court decision establishing the fund to make these payments. And the Korean Government says it will not assist them in efforts to qualify for the compensation.
Kim Young O, a director of the Ministry of Patriots and Veterans Affairs, said the Government had no programs to treat veterans claiming problems from exposure to Agent Orange because no illnesses have been detected.
 
Economic Benefits From War
 The war provided tremendous economic benefits for South Korea, but it was a political inconvenience. In the 1960's, South Korea had barely recovered from war and was still one of the poorest nations in Asia.
The Vietnam War provided what were by Korean standards generous salaries for soldiers. The Government also received huge amounts of aid, which helped catapult South Korea into its status as a newly industrialized country.
But politically South Korea was not ready to permit open debate on a war said to represent a battle between freedom and Communism, particularly when South Koreans were struggling for freedom against their unelected, military-dominated Government.
That, of course, has now changed. The first open presidential election was held five years ago, and in elections for the National Assembly last month the voters denied the governing party a majority.
 
Two Movies to Cost Millions
 The two multimillion-dollar Vietnam movies, one being made for the cinema and the other to be serialized on television, along with several new books depict a grim, dispiriting war.
One of the new movies, "White Badge," is based on a novel whose serialization in a magazine in 1983 caused the publication to be closed.
"Members of the younger generation do not even know that Koreans served in Vietnam," said Ahn Jungyo, a veteran and the author of the book, which depicts the horrors suffered by one group of soldiers. "Nobody talked about it. What the Government has done is a kind of mass cheating of the people."
"White Badge" will cost $2.6 million, a high figure for the Korean movie industry, and was filmed partly in Vietnam. The film being made for television, whose preliminary title is "Farewell to Songba River," also cost $2.6 million. This movie is described as a look at the relationship between two young soldiers as they come of age.
One of the soldiers in "White Badge" ponders: "The blood money we had to earn at the price of our lives fueled the modernization and development of the country. And owing to our contribution, the Republic of Korea, or at least a higher echelon of it, made a gigantic stride into the world market. Lives for sale. National mercenaries."

HEADLINE: The New Struggle for Afghanistan: On All Sides, Nations Seek Influence

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 9

 BODY:
Less than 24 hours after Islamic rebels took control of Kabul two weeks ago, Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, hurriedto the Afghan capital to express his support for the new Government.
But he went also to remind the country's new rulers of who had provided the bulk of support in their war against the Soviet Army and the Government it had backed, a broad hint that Pakistan intended to wield a heavy hand. 
 On Mr. Sharif's heels were a succession of Iranian and Saudi officials, a smattering of Sudanese, and, more quietly, representatives from the new republics of Central Asia. Even United Nations officials, whose peace plan evaporated in the face of guerrilla guns, still scurry around the capital.
The last of the cold war's battlegrounds, Afghanistan has become a new arena for regional competition, no longer between the superpowers, but among its neighbors, its new Islamic allies and the wary republics to the north. Exhausted by 14 years of war, impoverished, illiterate, littered with mines and bereft of anything resembling a functioning economy, Afghanistan has nonetheless become a choice morsel hungered after by everyone in the area.
 
No Role for the U.S.
 Some countries view it as an important economic crossroads and some as a testing ground of Islamic orthodoxy. Still others would like to head off the threat to regional stability they believe it poses.
Conspicuously absent from the fray are the United States, which gave hundreds of millions of dollars to the Islamic guerrilla armies to fight Soviet troops, and Russia, to the extent it is the most prominent successor of the Soviet Union.
Virtually all of the money from Washington -- the exact amount has yet to be disclosed -- was funneled by Pakistan to the most militant, fundamentalist parties, particularly the Hezb-i-Islami, led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. The seeming victors in Kabul, a confusing and uncertain coalition of northern guerrillas, western Shiites, southern fundamentalists and relative moderates, are well aware of the main beneficiary of American largesse: they are now confronting Mr. Hekmatyar's army along the southern flank of Kabul.
"The U.S. was led by the nose by Pakistan," said a senior Western diplomat in the Afghan capital last week. "Now they're out of the game."
The United States Embassy was closed in 1989 after Soviet troops withdrew from the country and there are no American diplomats in Kabul.
 
U.N. on the Sidelines
 The United Nations, whose special representative, Benon Sevan, invested four years searching for peace, was also marginalized by the sudden guerrilla occupation of Kabul. Mr. Sevan's main job now seems to be protecting former President Najibullah, who has taken sanctuary in the United Nations offices. Mr. Sevan has visited Kabul since the occupation, but appears to have found nothing to do.
Pakistan, whose interests intertwine most directly with Afghanistan's, is not without its own problems in Kabul. Just as memories of American policies are vivid there, so are they acute about Islamabad's favorite for more than a decade.
"You don't think Sharif's trip was a courtesy call," the Western diplomat commented. "He had to repair his bridges and stake his claim, not an easy job for him at this point."
Pakistan's problems with Kabul are aggravated not only by its past favoritism, but also by early signs that tensions on Pakistan's own political stage are soon to be played out in Afghanistan.
 
Arms Shipments Halted
 In January, Pakistan announced that it was halting all arms shipments to the Afghan guerrillas fighting the Government of Mr. Najibullah, a decision that was denounced by the arch-fundamentalist politician Qazi Hussain Ahmed. Two weeks ago, Mr. Hussain pulled his party out of Mr. Sharif's governing coalition, declaring that the Government was not moving fast enough in making Pakistan a pure Islamic society.
Although the party holds only a handful of seats in the National Assembly, its defection set the stage for a confrontation between Pakistan's well-organized fundamentalist political forces and the more secular elite.
Mr. Hussain, in conservative religious garb complete with a white head veil he rarely wears in Pakistan, appeared in Kabul last week declaring that he was ready to give guidance to the new Government on the introduction of Islamic laws. Well known for his fervent support of Mr. Hekmatyar, who embraces a similarly rigorous orthodox Islam, Mr. Hussain seemed to be trying to scuttle the advances of Mr. Sharif, and conceivably advance the fortunes of Mr. Hekmatyar.
For their part, the Pakistani Prime Minister and senior officials in his Government have said they hope Afghanistan will be the linchpin of regional economic stability. They see it as the major transit point for goods moving between the Central Asian republics and the port at Karachi. Without a unified, secure Afghanistan, those dreams will probably remain unfulfilled.
Pakistan is also burdened with more than three million Afghan refugees. Many of them have lived in border camps and villages for more than a decade and have children who were born there and are eligible for Pakistani citizenship. While the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has a well-organized program to repatriate these refugees, many have no homes to return to, their abandoned land having been either mined or appropriated, and no source of income.
Only the end of factional fighting in Afghanistan will enable Pakistan to unburden itself of the refugees.
 
New Republics Are Wary
 In the Central Asian republics to the north, where the echoes of Communist governance still resonate, the possibility of a fundamentalist neighbor is perceived with alarm in some quarters. And the ascension of Muslim forces in Tajikistan this week suggests that Islamic thought is spreading.
Diplomats at the Russian Embassy in Kabul, who have sometimes represented the interests of these republics, particularly Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, are apprehensive. For the administrations of some of these republics, religious fundamentalism remains an anathema. Indeed, in countries like Uzbekistan, religious political parties are outlawed.
On the west, Iran is also burdened by Afghan refugees, estimated at two and a half million to three million. But more important, Iran sees its mission as defending the rights of Afghanistan's minority Shiite population. No census has ever been successfully done in Afghanistan, but many authorities on the country suggest that Shiites may constitute between 25 and 30 percent of the population.
During the 14-year war, Iran armed and supported Shiite guerrilla groups, many of whom were of the ethnic Hazara minority. In Herat, Afghanistan's westernmost city, Iranian influence is considerable, with Iranian clerics and intelligence agents a common sight on the city's streets. Iran sees western Afghanistan as a natural thoroughfare to the Central Asian republics, which it considers fertile ground for spreading the faith.
The Saudis, too, have been active, pouring huge amounts of money into hard-line Sunni Muslim groups in the last year. And while the Sudanese have little or no money to dispense, they have also been trying to spread the religion.
 
Afghans Are Divided
 Thwarting all attempts to influence Kabul is the factionalism within the ruling coalition and the ethnic divides that threaten to fragment the country permanently. During the war, the welter of Islamic guerrilla groups spent as much time battling one another as they did the enemy in Kabul.
Virtually all of Afghanistan's cities are run by independent councils, alliances of local commanders, religious leaders and high-ranking former Government officials. In Jalalabad, for example, the city is run by a 22-member shura, or council, representing the seven rebel parties that were based in Peshawar and led by Abdul Qadir, the brother of Abdul Haq, a prominent rebel commander in Kabul.
Nonetheless, the shura in Jalalabad has thrived without guidance from Kabul, although Mr. Haq says it has sent a delegation to meet with the interim Government in the hope of gaining military representation on the governing council.
Other cities around Afghanistan, like Kandahar in the southeast and Herat in the west, which are also run by shuras, are also functioning effectively in isolation from the Afghan capital. While they too have sent delegations to Kabul, it is clear that they are not receiving directions from the capital.
In Kabul itself, guerrilla forces wrangle over sharing power, the extent to which Islamic principles should govern Afghan society and how to deal with Mr. Hekmatyar, who lurks outside the capital with thousands of heavily armed troops.
Divided by soaring mountain ranges, linguistic barriers and separate ethnic identities, Afghanistan has little to bind it. Kabul's weakness as a center of authority, combined with the often divisive tactics of the country's neighbors, offers little hope that genuine unity, or real peace, is within sight.

HEADLINE: More Sanctions May Be the Way To Push Libya, Mideast Aides Say

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, May 9

 BODY:
Western diplomats and Arab officials now say that additional sanctions may be the only way to force Libya to accede to United Nations demands to hand over two suspects in the bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet.
Western diplomats say the new sanctions under consideration include an embargo on Libyan oil, the mainstay of the country's economy. But Arab nations are reluctant to impose an oil embargo. 
 The assessment comes less than a month after the Security Council on April 15 imposed a cutoff of international air traffic to and from Libya, a reduction in Libya's diplomatic staff abroad and a ban on the sale of military equipment to Libya.
"We need a new kind of initiative, or initiatives, that will help move the situation," said Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, who wants to give the Libyans more time but said Tripoli had spurned Egyptian suggestions on ways to end the standoff.
 
Unsuccessful Arab Efforts
 "The Libyans do not yet realize the full seriousness of their situation," a high-ranking Western diplomat said. "They are not responding to it in a cohesive or coherent manner. The very least you can say is that a solution is still some way off. There may have to be consultations regarding the possibility of additional sanctions or additional action."
The existing sanctions were imposed after Libya refused to turn over two men believed to have been involved in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people.
The Libyans have also been asked to assist in the investigation of the bombing of a French U.T.A. plane over Niger in 1989 that killed 171 people and have been told to end support for terrorist organizations.
The decision by Arab countries to honor the sanctions has been accompanied by visits and appeals by Arab officials to persuade the Libyans to turn the two men over to Britain or the United States. Those efforts have been unsuccessful, as have three meetings of the Arab League to discuss a solution.
 
Feeling of Deadlock
 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, whose Government has close ties to the United States, has worked hard in the last two years to establish a relationship with the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The two countries clashed briefly in a border dispute in 1977 and did not resume normal diplomatic relations until 1989.
President Mubarak, who tried to slow the process toward sanctions and opposes military strikes against Libya, is widely considered to be the Arab leader with the most leverage to forge a solution to the impasse.
But despite rounds of meetings, including one between President Mubarak and Colonel Qaddafi on April 21, and frequent conversations between the two Ggovernments, Egyptian officials concede they have made little headway.
"There is a certain feeling that we might have reached a deadlock," said Mr. Moussa. "But this feeling is not definitive."

HEADLINE: More and More Look to a Post-Castro Cuba

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 9

 BODY:
The business consultant captured the mood of mounting anticipation here over Cuba.
"I know they are going to be selling their telephone company soon, and I have a client who is interested in buying," the animated businessman said between sessions of a two-day Florida Bar Association seminar called "Post-Castro Cuba." 
 With Cuba's economy sagging badly from the abrupt curtailment of all of its aid and most of its trade with the former Soviet Union, remarks like these have become commonplace at the now almost weekly gatherings of academics and potential investors around the country to discuss what many have begun calling the endgame for the Communist Government of President Fidel Castro.
But while many in this country eagerly hope for new economic opportunities in Cuba, both Havana and Washington continue to pursue policies that have kept relations in a deep freeze for over three decades.
In its recent efforts to stave off economic collapse and stem popular discontent, Mr. Castro's Government has recently moved to open the economy to private investment from abroad, and has introduced changes that academics say could mildly dilute the pervading control of the Communist Party.
The moves come on the heels of Cuba's withdrawal from Angola and disengagement from political and military struggles in Central America that were once cited as the principal irritants preventing more normal relations with Washington.
Along with its recent reform efforts, however, Havana has unleashed a harsh crackdown on dissenters, sternly lectured Cuban journalists that the Government is the sole repository of the truth and denounced as "garbage" multiparty electoral democracy, without which the United States now says there will be no normalization.
Republican and Democratic politicians in the United States are staking out tough positions on Cuba in this Presidential election year, at least in part as a political-season nod to conservative anti-Castro Cuban-Americans.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, has sponsored legislation that would punish American subsidiaries for trade with Cuba, ban ships that dock in Cuban harbors from the United States, and prohibit foreign assistance to countries that give aid or practice subsidized trade with Cuba. Trade between domestically based companies and Cuba has been banned, along with most other exchanges with the island, by a 30-year-old embargo.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic presidential candidate, recently endorsed the Torricelli bill during a campaign swing through south Florida. Not to be outdone in pleasing a constituency that in the past has voted heavily Republican, the Bush Administration has recently signaled its support for most of the bill, after ironing out portions that officials had warned would create serious frictions with major United States trading partners.
Havana has responded by denouncing the moves as the equivalent of war, and has turned up its anti-American propaganda several notches, focusing on the recent riots in Los Angeles as evidence of America's moral bankruptcy.
Asked if there were any prospect of a relaxation of American policies toward Cuba, Robert F. Gelbard, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America, answered with a concise "no." Referring to Mr. Castro's human rights record and statements about electoral democracy, he added "the question is, what do you open up to."
Several experts in Cuban affairs who met late last month at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington said they now expect little change in American policies toward Cuba until Mr. Castro dies or is somehow unseated.
"I view it as very similar to the Likud Party's attitude toward Arafat," said Mitchell A. Seligson, director of Latin American Studies at the University of Pittsburgh, using a Middle Eastern analogy to explain official American attitudes toward Mr. Castro. "Arafat simply has to go. There is no way people are going to start saying let's deal with our historical enemy."

HEADLINE: AMERICAN EXPORTS TO POOR COUNTRIES ARE RAPIDLY RISING

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9

 BODY:
The American economy, badly in need of bright spots, is gaining strength from an unlikely source: the third world, where purchases of American goods rose 15 percent last year.
Nonindustrialized nations have increased their purchases from American businesses and farmers to $146.79 billion last year. And this year they are expected to buy even more. The United States still runs a large, but shrinking, trade deficit with these nations through purchases of fruit and vegetables, steel and oil. 
 The United States is also increasing its share of these countries' expanding imports at the expense of other industrialized nations. In effect the United States is claiming a growing slice of a growing pie.
American exports to wealthy countries remain enormous -- $70 billion last year just to Japan and Britain -- but as those economies have slowed, the growth rate of American exports has dribbled down to a very small percentage.
 
Important U.S. Customers
 During the first two months of this year, nonindustrialized countries bought 35.6 percent of American exports, the highest rate since 1982. The nonindustrial countries are mainly those in Latin America, Africa (except for South Africa), the Middle East and Asia (except for China, Japan and some former Soviet republics). Most of the exports go to middle-income countries like Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Malaysia and South Korea.
As dozens of top corporate executives met here on Friday and Saturday, one of the strongest themes was the rise in business prospects overseas from Santiago, Chile, to Alma Ata, Kazakhstan. "It differs from industry to industry but I sense among my colleagues here a growing confidence about the calcuated risks and opportunities in nontraditional export markets," said Robert E. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
 
Economists Explain Trend
 Economists offer a variety of traditional explanations for the gains: American manufacturing productivity is on the rise while wage increases have been modest, the dollar has fallen precipitously since 1985 and developing economies in Latin America and Southeast Asia are prospering as they sell state-owned businesses to private investors.
But three other reasons help explain the American success. One is that the United States, while a weak competitor in consumer goods, remains the leading producer of goods used to build nations, like telephone company switches, trucks, commercial aircraft and personal computers. Another is that while large American companies increasingly use factories in Europe and Japan to serve markets there, they have fewer factories in nonindustrialized countries and export to them from the United States. A third is that large markets, including Brazil and India, have been removing trade barriers, like Brazil's outright ban on many car and computer imports.
According to figures compiled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of 24 industrialized nations, the American share of sales to poor countries by industrial nations climbed to 29.6 percent in the first nine months of last year from 27.3 percent in all of 1990.
The role of exports to developing countries in American trade last peaked in the late 1970's, when high oil prices and huge commercial bank loans to third world governments created an investment boom. But in the early 1980's falling oil prices and high interest rates crippled many debt-ridden developing countries, and their ability to buy American goods crumbled. But now new economic policies and lower interest rates have once again revived many of these countries, and their imports are increasing, too.
American companies large and small have benefited.
A.T.& T.'s sales of central office switches and other telephone gear tripled in Latin America last year, to $80 million, and are projected to double this year, the company says. And in Clive, Iowa, the tiny Hettinga Equipment Inc. expects its sales of plastic molding equipment in Malaysia, Thailand and elsewhere in Asia to triple this year.
 
Sales in India and Russia
 Jeanine S. Hettinga, the president and chief executive of the 51-employee company, said she was also beginning to sell to Russia and India. Demand is especially strong in these newly opening economies for molding equipment, which is used to make automobile dashboards, vinyl car door panels, toilet seats and plastic cupboard doors.
The European Community's move this year to drop internal trade barriers "is a very protectionist move, and Japan has never been easy," said Mrs. Hettinga. "We have to look for more open markets."
The gain in trade with developing nations is also helping the recent economic recovery in the United States, and, therefore, is important to President Bush's re-election chances.
The Commerce Department estimates that the increase in third-world exports was directly or indirectly responsible for up to 400,000 jobs, and that without the extra demand from developing countries, the nation's economy would have shrunk 1.1 percent last year instead of just seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Effect on Trade Policy
 The rising exports are also strongly affecting American trade policy. One reason the United States is negotiating a free-trade agreement with Mexico and considering similar negotiations with Chile is that American exports to Mexico have almost tripled since 1986 while sales to Chile have nearly doubled since 1988. The trade agreements, the Administration says, will broaden the current free-market policies in in these countries and make it harder for future governments there to change them.
To be sure, American trade relations with the developing countries still have problems. The United States ran a $28.23 billion trade deficit with them last year, although this was half the 1990 deficit. With the slowdown of the British and Japanese economies -- which together cut their imports from the United States by 2.6 percent last year, while increasing them slightly early this year -- even the Commerce Department predicts that the nation's overall trade deficit may widen slightly this year.
 
Bankers Are Wary
 Burned during the 1980's by Latin American debts, most commercial banks remain reluctant to lend to exporters on the basis of payments expected from foreign companies. This has made it difficult for companies to finance their trade, and while the problem may now be easing, it remains a subject of concern at the White House.
The growing exports have come although many American companies made only weak efforts to sell goods abroad.
Fred Zeder, the head of the Federal agency that insures American investments overseas, complained at a Cabinet-level meeting in the White House on April 22 that earlier on the same morning he had canceled a trade and investment mission to Indonesia and Singapore for lack of interest among corporate executives. "I had, after six months of work, only three people willing to go there," he said.
Yet American companies that looked east and west for new markets two or three years ago are now looking south in particular, said David Rockefeller, a former chairman and chief executive of Chase Manhattan Bank. "People are seeing that Latin America is probably the part of the world with the greatest potential for exports right now," he said.
 
Gains in South America
 American exports climbed 17.7 percent to Mexico last year and 19.6 percent to South America, but sales to other regions also surged. Exports to southeast Asia climbed 12.1 percent and shipments to the Soviet Union rose 15.9 percent.
The trend has surprised even some top policy makers. Brazil's Economics Minister, Marcilio Marques Moreira pointed out in a lunch discussion on April 28 that the United States's share of Brazil's imports had jumped to 24 percent last year from 20 percent in 1990, even though overall demand for imports there was stagnant.
"I really do not know exactly the reasons why," Mr. Moreira admitted.
A new study by Andrew M. Warner, an economist at the Federal Reserve, found that the level of investment spending worldwide determines the level of American exports more than the value of the dollar. The enormous widening of the United States trade deficit in the mid-1980's reflected not only the rise of the dollar but also weakness in investment abroad, especially in developing countries with large foreign debts.
 
Products People Don't See
 This trade deficit is most visible in any consumer electronics store or toy store. Most of the televisions or stuffed animals seem to be made in Korea or Taiwan or Hong Kong. Yet the United States remains very competitive internationally in products that many Americans seldom see.
"Developing countries traditionally have a greater need for capital goods and the United States is good at" making them, said Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
At the same time, American companies still tend to supply third world markets from the United States. When Corning Inc. finds increasing demand for its tableware or fiber optic cables in Europe or Japan, it steps up production at its factories in those places, said Richard Dulude, a vice chairman of the company. But Corning has very few factories in the nonindustrialized world, so that extra shipments to them are coming from places like Corning, N.Y., or Wilmington, N.C.
"We don't have the manufacturing bases in the developing countries that we do have in developed countries," Mr. Dulude said.
The combination of all these factors has produced a small glow of outright prosperity in an otherwise slowmoving economy. "Exports are the silver lining of this recession, and within exports, it's capital goods to less developed countries," Mr. Warner said.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Only Connect

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The events in Los Angeles have had one quite unexpected result. They have made millions of Americans see their President as a man curiously unconnected to realities of life in the country they share with him.
Mr. Bush muttered "unbelievable, unbelievable" as he toured Los Angeles last week. He saw desperate people, black and white and Asian -- people without jobs, without the simplest level of security, without hope. And he was evidently shocked by his discovery of that America. 
 But there are scenes of desolation and desperation all over this country, and it took no riots or fires to produce them. The next time Mr. Bush flies to New York he could drive from La Guardia Airport across the Triborough Bridge and straight through the desolate streets of Harlem.
Our cities are sick, their people numbed by poverty and crime, their public facilities degraded, their governments unable to keep up with even the need for such necessities as medical care and education. Open your eyes, and you see neglect.
Race is not the main problem, bad as it is. There are crumbling centers of cities and rural towns where there is no element of racial tension. The highest concentration of homeless people, per capita, is in New York's affluent Westchester County.
No, the problem is economics. The manufacturing that once provided jobs for Queens and South-Central Los Angeles and Peoria is vanishing. The men and women who did well-paid work in steel mills and auto plants are lucky to get half as much at a McDonald's. Fewer jobs have been created during the Bush years than in any administration for decades.
And it is as if George Bush were unaware of those realities. He flew around the country to business meetings and $10,000-a-table political dinners, insulated from the struggle for existence. He had a one-item economic program: reduce capital gains taxes.
Similarly, Mr. Bush has acted until now as if he had no idea -- none at all -- of the ugly realities that black Americans face in their lives.
The Boston Globe ran a piece last week on how some distinguished black men had been hassled by the police: among them a law professor, a television producer and Mr. Bush's own Associate Attorney General, Wayne Budd. Every black person in the country is aware of such experiences.
But George Bush knew nothing of that. Nor did he see anything wrong with playing the racial card in politics -- with arousing white fears by talk of Willie Horton and "quotas."
When the Simi Valley jury acquitted the Los Angeles policemen who brutalized Rodney King, President Bush was unable to come up with a meaningful response.
First he said, "The court system has worked, and what's needed now is calm and respect for the law until the appeals process takes place." Of course there is no appeal from an acquittal.
Then he talked about law and order, ignoring the hurt felt by blacks and many whites from that verdict. Next his press secretary tried to blame the riots on 25-year-old Democratic programs. Finally, in Los Angeles, Mr. Bush said, "We are embarrassed by interracial violence and prejudice."
The question is how George Bush can be so remote from the realities of his country. He is an intelligent man; no one can doubt that. The criticism of him as a "patrician" is silly; Franklin Roosevelt, more patrician, connected emotionally to ordinary Americans and their problems.
Perhaps Mr. Bush just reflects what has happened to our democracy. It is mostly the comfortable who vote and have political influence nowadays. Perhaps he exists only in that political cocoon. Or might he, at last, open his mind and heart?
The danger in not hearing, not seeing, is that more and more Americans will feel outside the system -- outside their country. James Jones, an unemployed black 18-year-old in Los Angeles, said as Mr. Bush toured there: "I've got nothing to say to him. Ain't nothing going to happen. I'm just going to live my little life."
A Korean-American woman in Los Angeles pleaded with Mr. Bush to listen as people were "reaching out to you to tell you what we are going through. . . . Please, please, please, these are lives, these are human beings."

HEADLINE: Stingley, in Cap and Gown, Hears Cheers Again

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 9

 BODY:
The brightness of his future in the National Football League blinded Darryl Stingley to a life beyond football.
After the New England Patriots drafted him in 1973, Stingley left Purdue University 24 credit hours short of a college degree, a standout receiver with all the hope and promise that is bestowed upon those fortunate enough to be a first-round draft pick. 
 But in one of football's most frightening moments, Stingley's N.F.L. career went dark after a vicious hit by Oakland Raiders safety Jack Tatum during an exhibition game in 1978. The blow left Stingley paralyzed from the neck down.
Stingley, 43 years old, returned to the Purdue campus today for the first time since 1973 to receive his bachelor of physical education degree, seeing things through different eyes and perhaps more clearly than he did when he left nearly two decades ago.
 
Man on a Mission
 "I'm guess I'm proof that it's never to late to finish your education and get your degree," Stingley said. "So many people look at black athletes and say that they're just going to college to play sports. But that's not the case all the time. I want to prove those people wrong."
Stingley, who uses a motorized wheelchair, sat on the stage of the Edward C. Elliott Hall of Music, in cap and gown, with his mother, Hilda Stingley, during the graduation ceremony this morning.
He was the last student to receive his degree and the moment brought a standing ovation from the more than 1,000 other graduates, most of whom were toddlers when Stingley was last on campus.
By receiving his degree, Stingley fulfilled a promise he made to his parents when he left their home in Chicago for Purdue in 1969. His father, Harold, never finished high school and was a semipro football player and laborer most of his life before he died in 1989; his mother, who has worked at Whitney Young High School in Chicago for 30 years, instilled in him a strong work ethic and the importance of an education.
"It was a given in my family that you would get an education," Stingley said. "I was the youngest of four children. My two brothers and my sister had all gone to school and gotten their degrees and I was the youngest one. I was expected to do the same thing. I'm bringing up the rear."
Because he uses a wheelchair, Stingley decided to take correspondence courses through a program set up by Citywide College of Chicago. He took business courses conducted by cable television, following lesson plans provided by Citywide.
Purdue accepted the course work and applied it toward Stingley's degree. It took him two years to complete the work.
Now, Stingley can exhort the two youngest of his three sons -- John, 22, who attends Chicago State University, and Derek, 21, who spent a year a Purdue and is enrolled at Kishawaukee Community College in DeKalb, Ill. -- to obtain their degrees.
Stingley said he did not know what he will do with his degree, perhaps coach or teach. But it has given him options.
"Education in some form or fashion allows you to empower yourself through knowledge," he said. "You don't have to go to a four-year college, but even if you develop some type of skill you help your economic future without waiting for someone to hand you something."
Getting a degree at this point was not a step toward economic empowerment for Stingley, who has a comfortable existence in a lakeshore condominium in Chicago, away from the gnawing poverty and crime of the Lawndale area on the West Side of the city, where he was raised.
But the degree gives him power of a different sort. It adds heft to his messages about education and perserverance. And now that he has accomplished this goal, he can pursue others.
 
Thoughts About Youth
 "As I ride through some of the neighborhoods in Chicago, I see that the kids don't have the same type of places to go that I had as a kid," Stingley said. "I went to the Y.M.C.A. when I was growing up. I'd like to start a place like that where a kid can develop his spiritual and mental side as well as the physical."
Stingley said that it wasn't until the fall of 1990 that he was healthy and stable enough "to redirect some of my goals and make a commitment to go back to school."
Stingley contacted his former coach, Bob DeMoss, now an assistant athletics director at Purdue, and Pete Miller, an administrator in the physical education department, to determine what it would take for him to finish work on his degree.
"It was very nice to hear that he wanted to come back and finish," DeMoss said. "But that's the type of person Darryl is. He's a competitor and very dedicated. And this is something that he really wanted to do."
DeMoss and Miller went over Stingley's transcript and discovered that he needed 24 hours of electives to earn his degree.
Stingley reiterated that he isn't bitter toward Tatum, even though Tatum has never contacted Stingley or apologized for the debilitating hit.
"I don't harbor any ill feelings toward him," Stingley said. "What good would it do me? I had to get on with my life. In my heart I forgave Jack Tatum a long time ago. But I will never understand why a man would deliberately try to maim another man and take him away from his family."
 
Patriots' Standing Offer
 Even though the Patriots list Stingley as a scout and he has a standing offer to work for the team, he said he had not worked in that capacity in quite some time. Mainly, he has been an advocate for the disabled, working to make buildings accessible to the handicap.
And, yes, Stingley said he was still working toward getting out of the wheelchair.
"Sometimes I feel like this chair is just a temporary pit stop on my way to doing some other things," he said. "All through my life God has given me strength and courage to take on some things, made me fight when I felt like giving up, and He's given me a great deal of hope. He's blessed me with an indomitable spirit. And if you have that, anything can be done."

HEADLINE: Rubble, Rubble, Toil and Yet More Trouble

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
When the backhoes and jackhammers began to rip up Daphne Mahoney's East 14th Street block two years ago, she thought it was for the best.
After all, the workers would be replacing aging water mains and cracked sidewalks. There would be new trees, lampposts and street signs. No mere run-of-the-mill street reconstruction, this was to be the burnishing of an entire business district, she was told. 
 It sounded like a good idea.
Today, Ms. Mahoney's restaurant, Daphne's Hibiscus, is barely clinging to life. She says business is off by 60%, many customers daunted by the lack of parking and a gantlet of bottlenecked intersections.
As if things could not get worse, construction workers have been pulled off the job, threatening to leave the street outside her door looking like an open wound.
"It's been a disaster," she said. "We're surviving just day to day."
For nearly the length of 14th Street, the wringing of merchants' hands is almost audible. Already buffeted by recession, dozens of stores have been pushed to the brink of collapse by the $30 million, river-to-river project, business owners and local officials said.
 
Litany of Disasters
 The project has been plagued by a catalogue of problems ranging from the absurd to the maddening. The two-way thoroughfare now only runs west to east; most curbside parking has been eliminated. The state government has withheld millions of dollars in Federal highway funds. And now the New York City Transit Authority is preparing to tear up two sections of roadway that were just rebuilt last fall.
To residents and merchants, it has become a textbook case in bureaucratic bungling and good intentions gone painfully awry.
"They were hopeful that it would be done in a way that would meet their concerns," said Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger. "But too much on this project has proved disruptive and frustrating. They're angry and they have a right to be."
The contractor, Perez Interboro Asphalt, and the city's Transportation Department said that inconveniences were endemic to major rebuilding projects and that reconstruction was on schedule to end by fall. "As far as we're concerned, it's gone smooth," said John Labozza, acting chief engineer for the contractor.
 
'Comedy of Errors'
 That's not the common view along 14th Street. "It's been a comedy of errors," said Joan Talbert, executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, a group of landlords and businesses.
Last year, three nuns were trapped inside their convent near Seventh Avenue when workers forgot to place a plank from their doorway over wet cement. An abandoned car that blocked work was lifted onto the sidewalk and left beneath a restaurant's awning for a week.
Sidewalks have cracked weeks after being poured, and many sections will probably be repoured, the contractor said. Dozens of building owners have complained that sidewalk work damaged their property.
The state Department of Transportation says its inspectors repeatedly notified its city counterpart that Perez used watered-down concrete and failed to install adequate pedestrian barriers and cover trenches.
Finding that the city failed to crack down on Perez and two other contractors accused of doing shoddy work, the state withheld $6 million in Federal highway funds last month.
Two weeks ago, the contractor pulled some workers off the job, saying the city owed him $3 million. Crews were scheduled to return to work Monday.
And last week, the Transit Authority announced it was planning to excavate two large holes, one near Avenue of the Americas and the other by Eighth Avenue, areas where reconstruction was completed last fall.
Transit officials said they were instructed by the Transportation Department to excavate. But a Transportation Department spokesman said the Transit Authority was at fault for seeking its construction permits too late.
"We lived it, awoke from the nightmare and now it's going to start again," said Dr. Robert B. Goldberg, a partner in the Chelsea Village Medical Center, which abuts the Eighth Avenue excavation site.
It wasn't supposed to be this way.
 
Get It Now, Get It Cheap
 With over 300 stores, 14th Street has long been a discount-shopping hub, generating more than $150 million in sales annually. Storekeepers hawk clothing and electronics, watches and furniture, $25 tuxedos and velvet wall hangings of Jesus, Marilyn Monroe and Elvis.
But the district fell on hard times in the 1980's, with storefronts becoming vacant and crack dealers working street corners. When the city announced the project in the mid-1980's, many local business and civic groups saw it as an opportunity to revitalize business.
They formed a task force to oversee construction and hired an architect whose plans included brass street signs in the sidewalks, new "bishop's crook" lampposts and sidewalks made to look like granite.
Many of the ideas were accepted by the Department of Transportation, and in 1987, a city arts commission gave the plan a design award.
Mr. Walsh hangs that award upside down on his wall because, he says, "The project has been such a joke."
Like many merchants, Sylvester Affam said he would have preferred aging sidewalks to what he has endured. Receipts are down by 50 percent at his business, Marie Antoinette Cleaners near Second Avenue, and his delivery trucks have been ticketed almost daily since No Standing signs were posted last month.
"With improvements, you have to have some inconveniences," he said. "But these improvements are not improvements."
Dr. Goldberg said he turned away scores of patients last summer because they could not navigate the unfinished sidewalks with their wheelchairs and crutches. He expects to do the same when the new excavation begins.
"Much of the damage being done here is to the city's credibility," Mr. Walsh said. "This has made merchants much more pessimistic. Everyone now asks, 'What is the city going to do to us next?' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Merchants along almost the length of 14th Street are suffering from the many snags in the two-year-old project to rebuild the street. Now construction workers have been pulled off the job, leaving stretches like the corner of West 14th Street and Fifth Avenue, above, blocked off; "It's been a disaster," said Daphne Mahoney, the owner of a restaurant, Daphne's Hibiscus, on East 14th Street. "We're surviving just day to day," she said. Business there is off by 60 percent. (Photographs by John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayor and Chancellor: Ties, Often Cool, Turn Icy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins and Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez face the same problem as castaways marooned on an island. While they need each other's help to survive, they also have to wrangle over the same scarce morsels.
Still, last week's clashes over money between City Hall and the Chancellor's office struck many officials as a little too nasty, like a playful fight that suddenly turns bloody. 
 Each side accused the other of lying about whether a $67 million bundle of state aid and a $200 million surplus generated by the Municipal Assistance Corporation were destined for education. Mr. Fernandez, like the anchor in the film "Network," called on New Yorkers to say they're "not going to take it anymore," while Norman Steisel, the Deputy Mayor, described Mr. Fernandez's conduct as "despicable."
 
Icier Than Usual
 While budget battles have their requisite theatrics, officials on both sides say the relationship between the staffs of the Mayor and Chancellor is more distrustful, even icy, than such relationships have been in many years.
"While historically there has always been tension between chancellors and City Hall, at this point in time it's much more real and far less rhetorical than in the past," said Robert F. Wagner Jr., a former president of the Board of Education. "It's not just part of the negotiating process on the budget."
At stake in the dispute is the financing of the nation's largest school system, with almost one million children, at a time when education officials fear that economic constraints could hinder their ability to help thousands of students who have been mired in failure. If the deadlock persists, it could threaten some of the Chancellor's major plans, including his proposals to lengthen the school day and to strengthen programs for the early grades.
The chancellor is hired by the independent seven-member Board of Education, two of whose members are named by the Mayor.
 
Underlying Tensions
 H. Carl McCall, the board's current president, who as a political ally of the Mayor often acts as a go-between in the feuds, concedes that there are underlying tensions between the Mayor and the Chancellor and said he had heard that among subordinate aides there has been "a serious level of deterioration."
On some level, the feud reflects a clash of personalities. Mr. Dinkins is comfortable with glib small talk while Mr. Fernandez is a man who hates to waste time and likes to get to the point. The two have had no more than two or three private chats in the 28 months since Mr. Fernandez became Chancellor.
Neither politician is a model of New Age openness. Mr. Dinkins spends much time working the rooms at rubber-chicken affairs, but far less in quiet evenings with intimates. It is said that Mr. Fernandez's idea of a pleasant evening is staying home watching sports on television.
Lower in the hierarchy, relationships grow even more frosty. City Hall aides have come to dislike Mr. Fernandez's deputy, Stanley S. Litow, seeing him as relentless, even Machiavellian, in pursuit of his goals. Mr. Litow is said to harbor similar suspicions toward Dinkins administration aides like Mr. Steisel and Philip R. Michael, the budget director. Associates say he has compiled a list of more than a dozen instances when he felt double-crossed by City Hall.
 
Opposite Interpretations
 For example, the two sides had diametrically opposite interpretations of the $67 million restoration of aid by the State Legislature. Mr. Litow thought that it was earmarked for education, while Mr. Steisel argued that it was pledged for general city uses. Both produced witnesses and letters to prove their cases.
There have been similarly opposite understandings of whether money furnished for weapons detectors in the wake of two murders at Thomas Jefferson High School was new or taken from elsewhere in the school budget.
Some school officials believe the conflict is the result of political rivalry between a Mayor whose standings in the polls have generally been lukewarm and a Chancellor who has made an unusually salient public impression. Some City Hall aides suspect that Mr. Fernandez wants Mr. Dinkins's job.
In battles with the Mayor, Mr. Fernandez has not always been able to win the backing of the seven members of the Board of Education. "Joe's been smarting over that," said one senior City Hall aid who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
No Advocate at City Hall
 Many at board headquarters at 110 Livingston Street complain that City Hall has no ardent advocate for education who is ready to tangle with the budget bottom-liners in the way that Mr. Wagner and Stanley Brezenoff did when they were deputy mayors in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch.
The feud must also be seen in perspective. The city's recession-clouded fiscal picture is its worst in almost 20 years. The pie is smaller and the clawing for the scraps is more feral.
"In a period where you have fiscal distress, I think the level of contention rises," was Mr. Steisel's diplomatic assessment.
The board may have a $7.27 billion budget, but class sizes are rising, books are growing more dog-eared and teachers more discontented.
Mr. Fernandez, a paladin called to New York from Miami to straighten a floundering system, is frustrated that he has had to preside over $750 million in cuts and now faces the loss of another $151 million. Yet, fiscal troubles have also made it difficult for Mayor Dinkins to realize his pledge to care for the city's children.
 
City Hall Suspicions
 Many City Hall officials feel that the Board of Education overspends what money it is given and then pleads poverty. Moreover, because power is decentralized among 32 local boards, Mr. Fernandez cannot insure that any money he receives is going to wind up where it was intended.
One person whom everyone is counting on to bridge the communications gap and cool passions is Mr. McCall, who has ties to both sides. He is deft at handling people, but is in a delicate position.
His statements asking for more money are softer than the Chancellor's. He never attacks the Mayor personally and he never charges anyone with lying. And on Thursday, when Mr. Fernandez joined the education unions and several state legislators in accusing the Dinkins administration of breaking its commitment on the $67 million in state aid, Mr. McCall was, as they say, conspicuous by his absence.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Helping the Poor: Some Suggestions

 BODY:
The New York Times asked people who live in the inner city, work there or study it, how to help blighted neighborhoods. Here are some of their answers:

SHAROD BAKER 

Age 17, Senior at Providence St. Mel High School in Chicago. He grew up in the Henry Horner Homes, a Chicago housing project, and will attend Columbia University in the fall:
" Blacks do want black businesses to be in the community but they can't get them established. Banks won't lend to them as easily. The Government has to fund blacks, to encourage them to start businesses.
 "The black businesses would hire blacks to work for them. That would start a money flow. Then children would have a tangible reason to attend school because they would see opportunities, which they have now, but it's hidden, it's so unseen."
 
REUBEN M. GREENBERG
Age 48. Police chief in Charleston, South Carolina
"The only people we can count on is ourselves. We don't hold people accountable for their criminal, anti-social, or irresponsible behavior. You need to stop making excuses for people who behaved that way, as just about every black politician has done.
 "Blacks are more prosperous in this counry than they've ever been. In Detroit, Atlanta, Washington, D.C., there are kids who've never known a white mayor or a white police chief...
 "We are capable of incredible things and we've shown that. It took only 30 years to get from the back of the bus in Montgomery, Alabama to the Governor's mansion in Virginia. Can the police help? No."
 
KATHRYN EDIN.
Age 29, sociologist with the Russell Sage Foundation. She has conducted in-depth interviews with welfare mothers in Boston, Chicago, San Antonio, Charleston, S.C., and Todd County, Minn.
 "The main problem I see in my interviews with single moms is that people can't live on the kinds of jobs that they're able to get. With the work skills they have and the wages they can command in today's economy, they simply can't earn enough to meet their basic needs. The moms I talk to call it 'the $5 an hour ghetto.'...
"You know, some of those angry black men I see in their mothers' home everyday. Those kids are giving up because they say, "Hey, look, what's out there for me?" If everyone who wanted to work was able to work, the welfare rolls would be virtually empty."
 
JOE VASQUEZ
Age 29, of New York City. Writer and director of the film, "Hangin' with the Homeboys."
"Creating more jobs, --and good jobs. I think job training programs would be a concrete act.
 "I was on welfare since the day I was born. It also helped me get through college. After I finished college and was trying to figure out where I was going to start, and was turned away and not taken seriously because I was a little Puerto Rican kid, welfare called the house and said, 'Look, you're not working and you're over 21, we're going to have to put you in a work program.'
"They put me cleaning toilets at a recreational center, --cleaning up the yard, picking up garbage. This is somebody with a college education. If they put me in that job, with a college education, imagine what they'd do to some guy who dropped out of high school."
 
WILL MARSHALL
Age 40. President of the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington.
" Law and order is first. Under community policing, you take the cops out of cars and put them on foot, on bicycles, in the malls, where the people are.
 "Education is second. Public school choice -- you've got to break the monopoly of the local school boards. Also, establish a youth apprenticeship option in every school, so at age 16 kids who aren't going to college can split their time between school and a local business. And national service, because it would guarantee college aid to any young person willing to put in a year or two.
 "Family and work is next. The Government should give the poor, not just the middle class, the incentive to save and build assets. What we propose is to create a poor man's I.R.A., which would match contributions made by poor people."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Bush Tries to Shift to Active Style on Domestic Policy

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots, influential Republicans are arguing that President Bush has reached the limit of the detached style of governing he has favored and must for the first time personally seize control of a broad range of domestic issues, Administration officials said today.
The President recognizes that he has committed himself to such a course in his response to the violence, the officials said. 
 In a radio address today, Mr. Bush said, "My first order of business now that I'm back in Washington is to build a bipartisan effort in support of immediate action on this agenda."
To keep up the impression that the President is staying engaged, he will make an appearance in Philadelphia on Monday to talk about ways to get drugs off the street and residents into jobs.
 
A New Challenge
 But what lies ahead is not only a major test of whether Mr. Bush and his White House team can meet the new challenge after squandering a series of political opportunities this year. It also is a test of whether the new prominence of advisers like Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, who have been highly visible in the last 10 days, will continue or whether they will be pushed back to the fringes of the Administration, where for years they have been arguing for more aggressive urban policies.
Administration officials said there was still debate over specific approaches and that Mr. Bush had rejected suggestions that he strike a radical new course as both unnecessary on policy grounds and politically unwise. Instead, the President will meet with leaders of Congress on Tuesday to discuss reconsidering some of his earlier proposals, like the creation of "enterprise zones" in blighted neighborhoods.
But there appears to be a consensus within the Administration and the Bush campaign that the appearance of passivity is a major political threat at a time when the country has been shocked by the violence in Los Angeles into focusing even more intensely on domestic problems.
 
Message Is Clear
 Officials said Mr. Bush received that message clearly from the rioting and from meetings afterward with civil rights leaders, members of Congress and his own advisers. But it remains to be seen whether he thinks that shifting from a reactive Presidency to an active one is simply a matter of appearances or whether he now feels he has to get the policy engines turning.
"Everyone agrees now," a senior Administration official said, "that the President has to commit, for political reasons if nothing else, has to remain engaged."
In the past, a range of White House advisers said, Mr. Bush has delegated the responsibility for domestic policy -- notably the 1990 budget agreement -- to powerful aides, like the former White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu; the budget director, Richard G. Darman; and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
And apart from his educational reform plan, the President has not pushed hard for the programs he is now re-offering, including the enterprise zones and a plan to help residents of public housing buy their homes.
"The President is now going to be judged not just on whether something passes into law, a senior official said, but whether he's really perceived to have fought seriously and articulately and in an engaged way for policies that reflect his principles."
 
Shifting Advisers
 The rioting forced Mr. Bush to bypass his normal domestic policy advisers, who have kept the Administration focused primarily on the problems of business, and turn to outside help from civil rights leaders and inside help from people like Mr. Kemp, always considered an outsider, and the Health and Human Services Secretary, Louis W. Sullivan, who has been tagged as largely ineffective.
Mr. Kemp, Mr. Sullivan, Administration aides like William Kristol, Vice President Dan Quayle's conservative chief of staff, and campaign advisers like James Pinkerton and James Cicconi, both proponents of so- called "empowerment" programs to revitalize the nation's cities, had influence over the drafting of Mr. Bush's speeches in Los Angeles, officials said.
In the hours following the outbreak of violence in Los Angeles, officials said, advisers like Mr. Darman prevailed with the argument that Mr. Bush must take a hard law-and-order stance. The officials said Mr. Bush shifted direction after a meeting on May 1 with civil rights leaders.
 
'Shaken' by Meeting
 "The President rejected some of the things they argued, like that police brutality is the core issue," an official said. "But he was shaken by that meeting and subsequent discussions with aides who told him how much trouble he was in over a perception that he was uncaring."
As the White House prepared for that night's address from the Oval Office, "the issue was how much Bush should criticize the Rodney King verdict against how much he should call for law and order," an official said.
White House officials rejected a draft by Anthony Snow, a speech writer, that one called "a deep-think piece on racial problems in the United States," and worked off a speech by another aide, David Demarest, that sought a more balanced approach.
Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, along with Mr. Demarest, Mr. Darman and Mr. Kristol, argued "that this was a time above all when you have people being killed and a city burning, and you have to talk about the absolute inadmissibilty of that," an official said.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, argued that the Oval Office address and Mr. Bush's subsequent actions must contain a strong element of compassion, a recognition that things had gone wrong and a vision for change, officials said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 14, 1992, Thursday

HEADLINE: All About/Art Sales;
The Market's Blue Period

BYLINE: By PETER C. T. ELSWORTH

 BODY:
The art market is still in the doldrums, judging from the results of last week's evening sales of contemporary art in New York at Christie's and Sotheby's, the world's largest auction houses. Sales next week of Impressionist and modern art will either confirm or confound that trend.
Just $23.5 million worth of contemporary art was sold, well below the pre-sale estimates of about $35 million. 
 The key sale -- "210 Coca-Cola Bottles" -- a silkscreen painting by the popmeister Andy Warhol, went for $2.1 million, just under its pre-sale estimate of $2.2 million to $2.8 million. Next week, the most important work offered will be a painting by the French modernist Georges Braque, which Christie's valued at $7 million to $10 million last September, an estimate now considered a little high by market experts.
"What has been affected is the level of confidence," said David Nash, head of Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern paintings. "People have the money, but they don't want to spend it," he said.
The news was not all bad. Lower-priced works sold better, as did most of the works from the estate of a Swedish businessman, Fredrik Roos, indicating at least some firmness for modestly priced, quality artwork.
However, no dramatic recovery is seen looming on the horizon. Instead the market seems to be bumbling along with the rest of the economy and certainly has a long way to go to get back to the high-rolling levels of the late 80's.
Back then, record art prices were as much a symbol of the decade as yuppies and corporate raiders. It all culminated in May 1990 when Vincent van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet" sold for $82.5 million -- a price comparable only to what might be paid for an office building or a commercial airliner.
Subsequently, the market tumbled as the high-flying 80's were grounded by the 90's and auction results became shadows of their former glory. Over the last two years, not only have prices been down but large numbers of works have failed to sell because no one was willing to meet or go above the reserve -- the minimum price the seller is willing to accept at auction.
"We've hit the bottom and are coming up slowly, but no one expects a boom now," said Amy Page, editor of Art and Auction magazine. "The Impressionist and modern market will take a very long time to come back."
Mary Boone, owner of the Mary Boone Gallery in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan, which has represented most of the important artists who emerged in the 80's, was more emphatic. "Where is the bottom of the market? We are in it," she said.

 
 
The New Conservatism
Paying the Piper For 80's Excess
 The auctions represent a secondary market for buyers and sellers to trade works of art. The primary market is made up of gallery owners who often have personal relationships with artists and collectors. As values have tumbled in the secondary market, so have hard times hit galleries, with a number closing over the last few years. The art market is notoriously secretive, and while annual turnover is generally thought to be in the multimillion dollar range, it is impossible to nail down an exact value.
"From what I've heard, the private market has been very slow," said Mr. Nash. "Some things have been ticking over, but for most dealers, it's been a hard slog."
However, sales seem to picking up there too, albeit slowly. "The market has been healthier, more active, with demand more in balance with supply," said the veteran SoHo art dealer Paula Cooper. "There's tremendous interest in younger artists." A younger artist who did particularly well at the auctions last week was Robert Gober. One of his works sold for $180,000, well above its pre-sale estimate of $80,000 to $120,000.
Ms. Cooper said she considers the market healthier not because prices are necessarily stronger, but because many of the more established collectors have returned after being put off by the go-go atmosphere of the 80's. "The pace became too fast and seemed to be more about money than art. They were quite repelled by the whole thing," she said.
Ms. Boone said she believes the questioning now under way in the art world reflects a larger change. "Value in everything is being questioned," she said. "The psychology in the 80's was excess; in the 90's, it's about conservation; it's about determining the value of everything."

 
 
Healthy Bidding
The 'Cats' Man Plays a Part
 The spring and fall sales of contemporary and Impressionist/modern art at Christie's and Sotheby's in London and New York are the indicators of the state of the international art market. While the identities of the buyers' and sellers' are rarely revealed by the houses, the bidding is public. Prices paid at auction affect market values in general.
Last week's sales followed some promising developments in the auction world, although in very different markets. Last month at Christie's in London, the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber purchased "Old House Guards, London, from St. James's Park," by Giovanni Antonio Canale, the 18th-century artist better known as Canaletto, for a record $17.7 million. Later in the month, a set of John James Audubon's "The Birds of America: From Original Drawings" sold at Christie's New York for $4.07 million, a record for an illustrated book.
In fact, other segments of the art market, like Old Masters, Latin American art and memorabilia, which includes everything from cookie jars to baseball cards, have generally fared better than Impressionist/ modern and contemporary art. Sotheby's, for example, estimates that it will sell a total of $165 million to $227 million worth of everything, from art to French furniture to paperweights, through the end of this month.
"The other markets did not boom and therefore did not fall as much," said Ms. Page. "Some of the things, like furniture and silver, have been doing very well. By and large, people did not speculate on silver."

 
 
Flaming-Out Youth
Can the Cult Of Schnabel Endure?
 Ms. Page of Art and Auction saw the auctions as a test for younger artists, such as Julian Schnabel and Eric Fischl, who became popular during the 80's.
At Christie's, a Schnabel failed to sell while a Fischl sold for just under the low end of its presale estimate. At Sotheby's, works by both artists sold within their ranges, with one by Schnabel selling for a record $319,000.
Ms. Boone said that price was still well below the high six figures that were being paid privately back in the late 80's. But she added the prices were good considering the recession and the historical pattern for new artists.
"Historically, every movement has suffered a backlash 10 years after it first came to prominence," she said. "Pop art had a difficult time in the early 1970's; minimalism was questioned in the early 1980's. It's no different for artists like Schnabel, [David] Salle, Fischl and [Ross] Bleckner in the early part of the 1990's.
"Unfortunately, that backlash comes with a major recession in the country, so it seems worse. But it's important to separate the artistic questioning from the financial problems," Ms. Boone said.
Michael Findlay, head of Impressionist and modern painting at Christie's, said he thought the market was correcting. "We've just seen an era when values for works by living artists not tested by time or the market reached half a million dollars," he said. "It's better for everyone that that be adjusted. It's one thing with Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat. You know what it is. It's finite. It's another thing with Schnabel. Will he go on, get better or fizzle out?"
"The boom was unprecedented and extreme," Ms. Cooper said. "It's not anything one would want to get back to."
 
 
 
THE POTENT EFFECT OF JAPANESE MONEY
 Most of the record prices made in the so-called 80's art boom came after the stock market crash in October 1987. Japanese speculative buyers of Impressionist art were particularly active during that period and their withdrawal in early 1991 had a negative impact on the market.
"It's difficult to exaggerate the importance that Japanese money played in distorting the market between 1987 and 1990," said David Nash, head of Impressionist and modern paintings at Sotheby's.
For example, three blockbuster sales to Japanese buyers were of paintings by everybody's favorite artist-as-suffering-genius, Vincent van Gogh. "Sunflowers" sold for $39.9 million in March 1987, at the time nearly four times the price ever paid for a work of art. That was followed by "Irises" selling for $53.9 million in November of the same year -- a month after the crash on Wall Street. Finally, his "Portrait of Dr. Gachet" sold for a staggering $82.5 million in May 1990, still the most ever paid for a work of art.
At the time, many art experts marveled at the frenzied Japanese buying of Impressionist works, particularly second-rate Renoirs. That was before newspaper accounts in Japan in early 1991 exposed much of the buying as a front for massive corporate fraud and tax avoidance. Almost immediately, the speculative buying ceased.
Michael Findlay, head of the Impressionist and modern painting department at Christie's, said many Japanese had bought indiscriminately for investment purposes, but cautioned against generalizing. "There always have been Japanese private collectors who operate like any other collector," he said.
The glut of Japanese-owned art raises an interesting question. "The Japanese are sitting on so much. Are they going to dump them at some time?" said Amy Page, editor of Art and Auction.
"The people holding the art don't seem to be in any hurry to sell them," said Mr. Nash, adding there was increasing interest from other Asian nations such as Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
"Maybe the Koreans will buy out the Japanese," said Ms. Page.
