HEADLINE: 143 Lands Adopt Treaty To Cut Emission of Gases

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 9

 BODY:
Representatives of 143 countries adopted a treaty today that commits the nations of the world to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and other heat-trapping gases that scientists fear could cause a catastrophic global warming in the next century.
The treaty, its key provisions hammered out in intensive talks over the last few days, is to be signed early next month at the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro. 
 Its long-term objective is to stabilize atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases soon enough to prevent dangerous disruption of the earth's climate and enable ecosystems to adapt naturally to any climate change. This stabilization could be achieved only by substantially reducing present emission levels.
The treaty calls for industrial nations, until now the biggest polluters, to aim at capping emissions at 1990 levels. But no timetable for achieving this has been set. Instead, the industrial nations would simply recognize that returning to "earlier levels" of emissions by the end of this decade would advance the treaty's overall objective.
 
Not a One-Shot Deal
 But it does require that these countries report periodically to all the treaty signers on their efforts to limit emissions. And in what many said would be the true significance of the pact, machinery would be set up to constantly assess the danger of climate change and to take further action, if necessary.
This approach has been successfully used in the case of chemicals that weaken the earth's protective ozone layer.
"It all adds up to a significant achievement," said Richard E. Benedick, a former United States diplomat who negotiated the ozone treaty and an amendment to it. "It is a very important first step in a process that is going to take us out of fossil fuels," said Mr. Benedick, who is now a senior fellow at the World Wildlife Fund.
The burning of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas produces carbon dioxide, the most significant of the greenhouse gases. Scientific advisers for these talks say the average global temperature will rise 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by some time in the next century if the greenhouse gases continue to build at current rates.
The proposed treaty is a compromise, and few negotiators said they were fully satisfied. Many environmentalists characterized it as disappointing and assailed its failure to establish clear targets and timetables on emissions, as the European Community advocated and the United States resisted.
Still, said David Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council, "if you cut through to the heart of the text, it does in effect establish an international benchmark against which U.S. action will be judged."
The proposed treaty also requires third world countries to develop plans to control their emissions, which are expected to grow substantially. And it commits the industrial nations to give them financial help to do this.
The United States, which produces more than 20 percent of carbon-dioxide emissions, has argued that energy-efficiency actions to which it is already committed will bring it close to limiting emissions in the year 2000 at 1990 levels. But it said strict adherence to timetables might harm its economy.
The treaty's provisions on emissions were described as "a measured approach" and a "reasonable response to the current state of scientific knowledge" by William K. Reilly, administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, who fought within the Bush Administration for a strong treaty.
The one that emerged, according to Mr. Reilly, "says, 'Do what you prudently can to restrain greenhouse gas emissions while pursuing other social and economic goals.'(TM)"
The treaty does not specify how much aid the industrial nations would give to the less-developed ones. The aid would be channeled, as an interim measure, through the Global Environmental Facility recently established by the United Nations Development Program, the United Nations Environment Program and the World Bank.
Many developing countries have resisted the idea of using the fund as the financial mechanism for the treaty for fear that industrialized countries would dominate the administration of the fund. The treaty calls for changes in the administration of the fund to reflect these concerns.
The negotiators were supposed to have completed their work sooner, but an attempt by Saudi Arabia to introduce a series of amendments derailed the effort temporarily. Because the Saudi economy is based on the sale of oil, many delegates interpreted the Saudis' actions as an attempt to scuttle the treaty.

HEADLINE: VOWS;
Kyoko Soda and Shuji Nakano

BYLINE: By Lois Smith Brady

 BODY:
ON Friday, May 1, at 12:30 P.M., a jet-lagged but nonetheless lovely Kyoko Soda, 27 years old, married Shuji Nakano, 32, in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.
The bride and groom, who had flown in from Tokyo a week before, arrived at the chapel in a white stretch limousine. Though few people were watching -- only Ms. Soda's parents and two brothers, who had also traveled from Japan -- the bride emerged from the car with the grace of a ballerina onstage. She wore a wildflower headband, a lace veil and a dress with big bow in back and long train, all of it as neatly assembled as origami. 
 It is increasingly popular among Japanese couples to journey to New York for their weddings, said Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, the chaplain of the nondenominational chapel. "In our chapel, it has reached a point of two or three couples a month," he said. For some, it is an economic decision: weddings in Japan are astronomically expensive, far more costly than a round trip to Manhattan. For others, a New York wedding is as fashionable as a closet filled with Levi's.
"Many Japanese couples come here because they want their weddings to be totally Western," Dr. Hawthorne said. "The brides wear a white formal wedding dress, even though there may be fewer than 10 people present. They do a formal entrance, even if there are no guests at all. Though we have Japanese-speaking clergy here, they want all of the service done in English, including vows they barely understand and must struggle to repeat. In most cases, they kiss at the end, which is a difficult decision in light of the Japanese custom of not kissing in public, but they want to have a complete Western wedding."
Moments before the wedding, Ms. Soda, a piano teacher, waited just inside the chapel doors with her father while Mr. Nakano, a photographer, did stretches against a wall. When the organist began to play "Here Comes the Bride," Ms. Soda began her poised -- and well documented -- procession. Three photographers surrounded her.
While Dr. Hawthorne conducted the ceremony, in English, the bride and groom, along with Ms. Soda's family, stood around the altar. Instead of kissing at the end, the newlyweds smiled at each other.
Ms. Soda and Mr. Nakano made all of their wedding arrangements through Yasuhisa Azuma, the New York representative of Altmann U.S.A. Inc., a company that offers Manhattan wedding packages for Japanese couples. The packages, which cost about $3,000, include the limousine (2 hours), organist, photographers, chaplain, hairstylist, gown and tuxedo rental and flowers for the bride's bouquet.
On their third day in New York, with Mr. Azuma's assistance, the couple rented Ms. Soda's wedding gown ("The shop was very busy, so I didn't even try it on," Ms. Soda said through a translator), picked out her flowers and purchased matching wedding rings of interwoven gold and steel at Bulgari.
Shortly after they were pronounced husband and wife, Ms. Soda and Mr. Nakano sat in their rented condominium (not included in Mr. Azuma's package) on the Upper West Side. There was a Cinderellalike feeling to the scene. The limousine was gone; Mr. Azuma had picked up the wedding dress to return it.
Thin and intense, with short spiky hair, Mr. Nakano spoke through a translator about his and Ms. Soda's decision to marry. "There was no need to propose, so we didn't say anything," he said. "It was fate, or 'en' in Japanese. Animals don't propose; they know in their hearts that they will be together."
Why did they endure jet lag and language barriers to get married in Manhattan? "In Japan, the marriage ceremony is family to family, a big occasion," Mr. Nakano said. "In New York, it is individual to individual. We like it that way. Of course, family is important, but the most important thing is the two people getting married. We need only two to get married."
The bride added that it was nice to escape the Japanese ritual of changing three times during the ceremony -- from a kimono to a Western-style gown to a long dress. "I like the simple way," she said. "Marriage is about how you feel, not about how you look."

LENGTH: 515 words

HEADLINE: Unbalanced

 BODY:
What's wrong with the proposed constitutional amendment to make Congress balance the budget each year? Only that it's wrong in principle and destructive in practice. It may sound like a direct remedy for Washington's toying with trillions in deficit spending. In fact, such an amendment would threaten precisely the long-term investments society needs most and risk pushing a soft economy into icy recession.
 These risks aren't warranted. Congress has to get control over spending on medical care and other entitlements. But that can be done without perilous grandstanding. The amendment is no solution; it's an unbalanced problem. 
Different versions of the amendment are moving briskly in both the House and Senate. Each would require Congress to match cash outlays with cash revenues each year unless a supermajority of, say, 60 percent votes otherwise. The supermajority is supposed to provide flexibility for emergencies.
 Difficulties with the idea start with the very definition of budget balance. By lumping all outlays together, the amendment discourages expensive investment in, for instance, cancer research as compared with short-term giveaways. This indiscriminate definition also invites evasion -- such as loading new entitlements onto the backs of state governments and employers.
 The amendment could do immeasurable harm. When Congress was forced to bail out depositors at bankrupt savings and loans, it wisely borrowed the money. Borrowing for that purpose does not harm the economy. Under the proposed amendment, Congress would have had to cut necessary programs, or raise taxes, by hundreds of billions. No rational business or government would balance a budget this way. Businesses borrow to invest. Even states, required to balance their operating budgets, borrow for capital investment.
 These objections of principle are matched by practical dangers. Now when the economy slips into recession, Federal spending helps break the fall. Spending for welfare and unemployment compensation rises; income tax collections fall. But under the proposed amendment, Congress would be forced to do the perverse opposite: raise taxes, cut spending -- and hammer the economy.
 What makes this constitutional remedy extreme is Congress's responsible record under the 1990 deficit reduction act. This year's deficit, nearing $400 billion, looks gargantuan. But that's because it includes temporary imbalances due to the recession and the S.& L. bailout. Congress has approved virtually no program that wasn't financed with higher taxes. Entitlement growth has slowed; and discretionary spending is headed downward in proportion to the size of the economy.
 There are other problems. The proposed amendment raises grave questions about responsible governance. It makes cutting spending much easier than raising taxes -- inviting the suspicion that its true purpose is to finish the assault on public spending that Ronald Reagan began. But there's one overriding objection. A balanced budget amendment would turn America of the future into a poorer place.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: DR. DAVID F. MUSTO;
Drug Laws and Attitudes in Closer Harmony

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
CONSIDERING the public's shift in attitude over the last 10 years, the possibility of legalizing drugs in the United States as a way to diminish illegal profiteering is unlikely, according to Dr. David F. Musto, a professor of psychiatry and of the history of medicine at Yale University.
He added that contrary to what many who favor legalization believe, allowing open access to cocaine or other substances will not eliminate the street market for drugs or lessen their destructive effects on society. Dr. Musto said that the nation's second drug epidemic is in the declining stage, though he estimated that it would last for 10 to 15 more years. 
 One of the nation's experts on the history of drug abuse and drug policy, Dr. Musto is the author of "The American Disease: Origins of Narcotic Control" (Oxford University Press, 1988) and has testified at several Senate hearings on drug abuse and drug trafficking.
In an interview in his office at Yale University School of Medicine, Dr. Musto discussed the nature of drug epidemics. Here are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What major developments  spurred the country's first drug epidemic, which lasted from 1880 to 1930?
A. What we consider the drug problem today is the product of scientific and medical advances of the 19th century. Advances in organic chemistry enabled us to isolate morphine from opium, and cocaine from the coca leaf. Morphine was isolated from opium in about 1806 and started to be produced in substantial amounts in the 1830's. Cocaine was isolated in 1860. Then in the mid-19th century scientists perfected the hypodermic syringe. So not only did you have these purified substances, which had never been available before, you also had a mechanism by which it could be injected into tissues or the bloodstream.
Q. What was the public's reaction?
A. When cocaine became available in America in 1884, it was completely legal and came with very high praise from the experts about its safety and benefits. It was also promoted as the first hay fever remedy by the United States Hay Fever Association. However, as the sad stories about the dangers of these drugs became prominent, people began to change their minds and started to become anti-drug. Over the next 10 to 15 years, the idea of cocaine being the ideal tonic changed and the public started perceiving it as the most dangerous of drugs.
Along with this change of attitude toward drugs, the public began demanding legal restrictions. In the early 1900's states began passing laws, at first, restricting cocaine use to a physician's perscription.
Finally, in 1914, the Federal Government passed the Harrison Act, which attempted to bring narcotics under control. Cocaine was still used through the 20's but by the 1930's it had declined. By the 1940's and 1950's few people used cocaine.
Q. Once the Federal Government outlawed cocaine, did there arise a profitable illicit market?
A. Some say that before the Harrison Act, cocaine and heroin were very cheap and that the passage of the act brought about a black market and created new problems with drugs and drug users. But if you look at the history, you'll see that before the Federal act was passed in 1914, cocaine was sold on the streets of New York at about 25 cents for 100 milligrams, even though you could have gone to a doctor and gotten a legal prescription.
In 1908 the average hourly industrial wage was 21 cents. That amount of cocaine in the mid-1980's -- when we had all these laws in place -- would have cost you about $10 on the street, which was also roughly the average hourly industrial wage. This indicates that the street market before the passage of Federal laws had profit margins comparable to today.
Q. Did the laws passed during the earlier epidemic have much of an impact?
A. Yes, because the laws coincided with the rise of an anti-drug attitude. Laws are much more effective if they're in sync with public attitude.
Q. How does that compare with today's drug epidemic?
A. When this epidemic started in the 1960's we had the most draconian measures against drugs already in place. However, like the beginning of the first epidemic in 1880, in the 1960's, large numbers of people thought that cocaine and other drugs were harmless, just so you used them with good judgment. Yet at the same time, we've had very severe criminal penalties. As a result, a profitable black market easily developed due to the gap between the laws and the opinions of a large segment of the population.
Many people thought the laws were ridiculous and not scientific. So unlike the first epidemic, we had severe laws without public support. Since the mid-1980's, public attitude has shifted and we're more intolerant of drugs and once again we're pretty much in harmony with the laws.
Q. Some who argue for the legalization of drugs say that open access will undercut costs from illicit sales, and  reduce turf wars among drug gangs  as well as the economic motivation to lure new drug users.
A. To successfully undercut the street market, you'd have to make cocaine very available in whatever amounts people wanted it. Yet, those I've spoken with who favor legalization don't think that drugs should be freely available, particularly to children. But every obstacle in the path of someone who wants drugs creates a black market. In addition, legalizing drugs is impossible to do politically and morally because the majority of the public is now convinced that drugs like cocaine are very dangerous substances for anyone who takes them.
Q. You said that we are now in the declining stage of the drug epidemic. What are some of the negative characteristics?
A. The great problem in a declining stage of a drug epidemic, which lasts for about 20 years, is that we tend to scapegoat foreign nations and minorities for the drug problem. As drug use among the middle class declines, there was this tremendous pressure to find some simple explanation for the problem. One explanation is that blacks and Hispanics in the inner city are responsible for the drug problem. We blamed blacks for the cocaine problem beginning around 1900 into the 1920's. But the reality is that only a small minority of people in the inner city use drugs. Instead of scapegoating the inner city, we should place our efforts into providing jobs or improving the education of its residents.
Q. What are some of the other myths about the drug trade?
A. There's this image that anybody dealing drugs is making huge amounts of money and is enjoying continued success. But studies indicate that the amount of time someone remains a drug dealer is relatively short. In fact, if you took everything into account, such as the time they may spend in jail on drug charges and how long they actually stay in this kind of work, a drug dealer's income is comparable to the minimum wage.
Q. Is incarceration the answer to solving the drug problem?
A. In the 1920's we also had a tremendous rise in people in Federal prisons who were in on drug charges, around 40 percent of all inmates. Laws can be very helpful when strategically used, but just relying on drug enforcement is not going to end the drug problem. It's very easy for the police to go out and arrest people. But what the public doesn't see is the jam-up in the criminal justice system and the turnstile justice that takes place. The average drug offender in Connecticut spends only about 10 percent of his time in prison.
The reality is that the problem is extremely complicated and deep-seated and comes down to an individual's decision whether to use drugs. The drug problem ends when people change their minds about drugs and stop using them or, even more significantly, don't start using them to begin with.
Q. Of all the popular illegal drugs, isn't marijuana the most likely to be legalized?
A. By 1980 almost a majority of Americans favored the legalization of marijuana for personal use. But the concern about the drug as being a dangerous substance is growing all the time. People feel that it decreases motivation and that it can be dangerous if someone is using machinery or driving under the influence. Its use declined by more than half among high school kids and you can't help but think they have learned something from watching their older siblings.
Q. Given the history of the first drug epidemic, how could we have fallen into another one?
A. The epidemic was simply eliminated from our memory bank. By 1931 all but two states in the country required anti-narcotic education for school kids, but when the drug problem declined, people feared that if you continued to talk about drugs, you might entice kids to take them. We expunged the epidemic from our textbooks. It became policy of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics to minimize drug information by dampening discussions in school. The Motion Picture Association of America had a policy that any picture that even mentioned drugs would not receive a seal of approval. If a drug had to be discussed, its effects were greatly exaggerated. So we improved a censorship over the previous epidemic, hoping that if we never mentioned it again, we'd never have another one. Because of our silence and exaggeration, we were later unable to convey a realistic appreciation of the effects of drugs to later generations.
Q. What's your view of the future?
A. Drug use will probably continue to decline over the next 10 to 15 years. We will probably become more angry at drug users and tend to rely on punishment without understanding that we can go too far in this area. However, I think the drug that will be of most concern in the 1990's will be alcohol. It may be put into the position that tobacco is in now. With a decline in alcohol consumption since the 1980's, the rise of the national drinking age and tighter drunken driving laws, along with the concern over fetal-alcohol syndrome, alcohol has taken on a very different image. I believe the image is going to darken even further.

HEADLINE: Focus: Adelanto, Calif.;
Marketing the Credible Shrinking House

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: ADELANTO, CALIF.

 BODY:
THE three-bedroom house that Jim and Lisa Richter bought in this high-desert city 80 miles northeast of Los Angeles is smaller than the house in which Mrs. Richter grew up. The lot also is smaller, as are the living room and the bedrooms.
With a price of $95,000, however, the Richters say they were happy to compromise on space. And they said they are pleased by the traditional look of the house, a two-story structure with a gabled roof, a front porch and a tree in the front yard. 
 "We wanted a house that looked like a house," said Mrs. Richter, a college student and mother of a 2-year-old boy.
As one of the current hot spots in Southern California for first-time home buyers, Adelanto, with a population just under 12,000, is a proving ground for the 1990's version of the starter home. Hard pressed by the rising cost of both land and labor, starter homes here are smaller, more compact, more simple in design and detailing than the typical suburban home of earlier decades.
Interior spaces merge in "open" floor plans. Front and back yards shrink. In most areas -- but not here, where plots average 7,000 square feet -- homes are closer to their neighbors. Wooden trim and other costly finishes have been minimized.
"Fussiness and gewgaws and details -- you don't see a lot of that on starter homes these days," said Randall Lewis, executive vice president of Lewis Homes in Upland, Calif., which built Country Fair, where the Richters bought. It will have 180 homes when completed.
At the same time, builders have been quick to notice and respond to a taste for traditional imagery among home buyers who seem to yearn for reassuring images of stability.
The demand for traditional imagery mirrors the insecurity of the recession, said Barry Berkus of Santa Barbara, Calif., an architect who specializes in production housing. When people feel they are in "a pressure cooker," he said, "they want to go back to their mother's house and the front porch."
Front porches, a symbol of old-fashioned neighborliness, can be found throughout the new tract homes here. And in an attempt to emphasize domestic above automotive imagery, Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation of Los Angeles is offering homes on wide lots, as opposed to the narrow lots more typical of subdivision building, to end the domination by the garage of the front exterior.
As it does elsewhere, price remains by far the most important selling point in Adelanto, despite the emphasis on design. Most homes in the area -- by the end of the year it is expected that 800 new ones will have been built -- are priced below $100,000, or about half of the statewide $199,390 median for an existing home and well under the $136,810 median in San Bernadino County and Riverside. At $69,999, Inco Homes of Upland, Calif., which has built 435 presold homes in Adelanto, claims to have the least expensive new home in Southern California, "at least of which we are aware," said its president, Ira Norris.
The very process of building a house has changed because, to make affordability and imagery work together, home builders and their architects are rethinking the tract home from the ground up -- a change that is especially noticeable in Adelanto because of the high proportion of new houses.
"Every big builder I know," Mr. Lewis said, "has said to himself in the last two or three years, 'Let's re-examine how we build a house.' Developers are going to their contractors and suppliers and saying, 'Let me know how you frame a house, let me know how you run your business, so I can change my way of business and get my prices down.' "
"The most important thing is to build at an affordable price," said Mr. Norris of Inco Homes.
Because home builders have been "overpaying for labor and materials," Mr. Norris said, he has redesigned his homes to complement changing building technologies.
Since suppliers sell kitchen countertops in two-foot sections, Mr. Norris has told his architects to order countertops only in multiples of two feet. Similarly, since sheet rock is manufactured in four-foot sections, room dimensions are to be in multiples of four feet. Most rooms have at least one wall 12 feet in length, since carpeting comes in 12-foot rolls.
Mr. Norris also uses scissor trusses to support the roof; the prefabricated trusses spare the carpenter the task of framing the roof and free the house from structural posts -- a must for the open-space planning that builders find desirable in small starter homes.
To preserve affordability, both builders and home buyers must make tough choices and accept trade-offs, Mr. Lewis said.
"Builders say, 'If I'm going to spend a couple of hundred dollars, should I put that bay window in the master bedroom or put another 10 square feet in the children's bedrooms?' Those are the kinds of questions where there are no simple answers," he said.
If exterior design seems conservative, interior design has changed radically, according to Michael Woodley, an architect and vice president of Kaufman & Broad.
"You design interiors for how people actually live, and the exterior for how people think of themselves living," Mr. Woodley said.
OPEN-SPACE planning can make small houses look large, according to Mr. Woodley, who said that the appearance of spaciousness can be a selling point for new homes. When home buyers open the front door, he said, "The first impression should be, 'This is bigger than I expected. I can live in this. I can afford this.' "
To create a sense of open space, home builders have combined kitchens, dining areas and living rooms into what Mr. Berkus, the architect, described as "concentrated entertainment rooms."
This strategy takes the kitchen away from the walls and into the center of the house and makes it the focus of the household. The sink and cooking range are placed so that people preparing food can face directly into the living-dining area. To compensate for the loss of kitchen windows, architects provide large windows that can be seen from the kitchens.
As kitchens expand, the large living rooms of yesteryear contract, as do formal dining rooms. Lewis Homes has consolidated the dining room and breakfast nook into one space and reports a good response from buyers.
The new starter house must provide privacy as well as openness because even with an open plan, said Mr. Berkus, "you still need retreats." Master bedroom suites are becoming complexes of space, with nooks for writing desks or exercise equipment.
Beyond design, Adelanto has other attractions. One homeowner, Kevin Rathbun, cited "clean air, return on investment and the atmosphere of the community" as his criteria for the decision to buy a three-bedroom home by Lewis last September for about $97,000.
Price, however, remains the ultimate amenity.
"This was the only house we could really afford," said Mr. Rathbun, a manufacturer's sales representative, who bought at Lewis Homes' Country Fair. "To get into a house for under $100,000 in California is unbelievable."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1301 words

HEADLINE: Shelter for the Rural Homeless: Trees and Sky

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COTTAGE GROVE, Ore., May 4

 BODY:
Millions of Americans will spend at least a night inside a national forest campground this year, but only a handful will ever call one home.
This week, a half-dozen families, most of them from this logging community, started setting up their shelters in the first campground in a national forest set aside exclusively for the homeless. 
 Amid the owls and the deer, the hawks and raccoons, the new residents began assembling a patchwork of tents, tarpaulins and small trailers in an abandoned quarry pit about 40 miles southeast of Eugene, Ore.
The scenery in these Cascade Mountain foothills -- a jungle-like ground cover of ferns and wildflowers shadowed by towering pines and steep cliffs -- is spectacular. But the site for the homeless, although surrounded by luxurious wilderness, is, by Forest Service standards, a barren lot devoid of the amenities found at other campgrounds.
For the next few months at least, Frances Davis will call the three-acre site her home. That will not amount to much of a change for Mrs. Davis, a quick-witted woman of 72, who has squatted in the Umpqua National Forest since November. The $580 she gets each month from Social Security is not enough to cover rent in town, she said, but out here in the woods the dollars stretch enough to buy groceries.
"I told my late husband in 1969 that I would never, ever go camping again, and here I've been living in a campground for six months," Mrs. Davis said. "I guess God is telling me, 'Lady, get out there and give it another chance.' "
Forest Service regulations prohibit campers from staying in any one campground for more than 14 days, but for years, hundreds of people have taken long-term refuge in tents or under tarpaulins deep inside the national forests. Some have lived out of sight in the high country or in thick brush. Others, like Mrs. Davis, have openly set up tent homes in campgrounds, where there are fire pits and latrines.
After tolerating Mrs. Davis through the winter, officials ordered her out of the recreational campground by May 12. She is moving a few miles up the hill to the newly cleared campsite, named Blodgett, where up to 25 homeless people will be allowed to stay indefinitely.
"We have a skunk, a bobcat, a raccoon and a little garden of flowers coming up over here," said Mrs. Davis, as she started to dismantle her plastic-roofed shelter. "It's going to be hard to leave this spot."
Of all the clashes in the national forests between groups like dirt bikers and solitude-seeking backpackers, few are more stark than the friction between the recreational camper and the forest squatter. When hard times hit the oil-dependent states of Wyoming and Colorado in the early 1980's, the campgrounds of the West filled with newly homeless people settling in next to vacationers with $20,000 camper trailers.
 
Winter Under a Tarpaulin
 Randy and Lori Lycett and their two children will be moving into a small trailer this week at the new site. They would prefer it if there were water at the campground and maybe a few more amenities, but for now they are happy to have a place other than the plastic tarpaulin under which they spent the winter in another part of the forest.
"We hope people will get along with each other and not kill this thing before it gets going," said Mrs. Lycett (pronounced lye-SET). Her husband is one of about 600 timber workers who have lost their jobs over the last five years in this community of 8,000 people. Mills have closed because of automation, a recession in the home-building industry and logging restrictions to protect the spotted owl, a threatened species.
The Lycett children, ages 9 and 12, will not be going to school, their parents said. Under Oregon's liberal home schooling laws, the children can be educated by their parents, who are deeply religious.
"The national forest is probably just about the last stop for these people," said C. Daniel Lindstrom, who runs Community Sharing, a private charity in Cottage Grove that is helping to place families in the new campground.
The families are chosen by the charity group, which also helps the families with food and supplies donated by the community. Mr. Lindstrom said about 100 people in the Cottage Grove area of southern Lane County are homeless.
 
Confounds Stereotypes
 The breed of homeless found here is a long way from the stereotype of the urban street dweller. Drug abuse and mental problems are seldom associated with the person who shows up at a national forest campground with sleeping bags and kids in the back seat, Mr. Lindstrom said. More often, he said, they are families who had been supporting themselves with minimum-wage jobs until prolonged unemployment pushed them into the streets.
Persuading the Forest Service, which has a proud tradition of well-built and well-tended campgrounds throughout its 171 million acres, to get in the business of social policy was not easy. Forest Service officials in Washington initially balked at the suggestion, then demanded that the homeless, through their Cottage Grove charity, put up a $1 million bond as insurance against forest fires. It is a requirement routinely demanded of loggers, miners and other long-term users of the national forests.
"We went everywhere, even Lloyd's of London, but could not get insurance," Mr. Lindstrom said. But then the Forest Service backed down, and agreed to set up the campground without the bond, as a pilot program. A similar campground is being considered north of here, in the Willamette National Forest. If the Oregon campsites work, the program may be tried in other forests nationwide, officials said.
"All we're doing is acknowledging something that already goes on in the national forests," said Kent Smith, an Umpqua forest ranger.
 
'Creative New Approach'
 Unlike the National Park System, with its many regulations and restrictions, the national forests have much more land and can be used for a variety of things: logging, mining, recreation, and in this case, a partial solution for rural homelessness.
"We've had this problem, first in the Rocky Mountain states and now in the Northwest," Ann Metejko, a spokeswoman for the Forest Service, said of the squatters. "We've tried not to be callous about it. This is a creative new approach, largely supported and funded by the local community. If it works, we may try it elsewhere."
Some people expressed fear that the new site would attract criminals or people with mental disorders to the area's bucolic forest valleys. But as the faces for the new campsite have appeared -- familiar faces, neighbors in many cases -- much of the opposition has faded.
Already, there is a waiting list for Blodgett, said Mr. Smith, adding, "We're trying to take care of people who live near here first."
Living in the woods, despite the bonus of scenery and clean air, is no picnic. Lori and Randy Lycett have struggled to keep rain from pouring through their tarpaulin. The nights can be cold and sometimes scary for their children, said Mrs. Lycett, whose husband recently found a part-time job to which he will commute from Blodgett.
After six months in the woods, Mrs. Davis has frankly grown tired of camping. With no electricity, she keeps her food in the shell of an old refrigerator. She lives with seven cats, and sleeps on pillows over a wooden cot. Today, during a week of warm weather, black flies buzzed around her head, distracting her from her book, "Murder at the Super Bowl" by Fran Tarkenton.
But even if she were able to get into subsidized housing for the elderly, she said she would prefer something else.
"I don't like the music they play in those old folks' homes," she said, ever cheerful. "I'm a rock 'n' roller myself. And out here, at least I can play my Huey Lewis tapes."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1558 words

HEADLINE: STATES ARE MOVING TO RE-REGULATION ON HEALTH COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:
After a decade in which health costs rose rapidly and many people could no longer afford care, state and local health officials around the country are returning to the kind of planning denounced by the Reagan Administration as a tool of heavy-handed government regulation.
State officials are adopting new laws and regulations to slow the construction of hospitals and nursing homes and the purchase of costly medical equipment. At the same time they are convening groups of doctors, consumers, hospital executives, insurers and employers to negotiate the distribution of health-care resources. 
 In 1974, Congress created a national network of state and local agencies to develop plans for the number and distribution of hospital beds. Hospitals generally had to get approval from a state agency before offering new services or buying major medical equipment. In the 1980's, at the urging of the Reagan Administration, Congress and many states abandoned formal health planning as an onerous form of regulation that choked off competition in the market for health care.
 
$448 Billion Rise in 10 Years
 But from 1981 to 1991, medical prices rose more than twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index for all items. Total national spending on health care soared to $738 billion last year, from $290 billion in 1981. Insurance premiums also soared, and health insurance became unaffordable for many people.
In 1981, the Government spent more than $150 million on health planning. President Ronald Reagan's argument for ending Federal support of the program was that it discouraged competition and protected high-cost suppliers of goods and services. Some California officials still express that view.
But in many other states, officials say the free-market model of unchecked competition failed to curb the growth of health costs and spending. The market, in fact, is not free in the traditional sense because private health insurers and the Government pay much of the cost of medical care, reducing the pressure that consumers might otherwise exert to hold down costs. The Commerce Department estimates that the United States will spend $817 billion on health care this year, up 11 percent from last year.
"Clearly, there's a revival of interest in health planning," said James R. Kimmey, dean of the School of Public Health at St. Louis University. "It comes from business coalitions that see planning as a way to control costs for their members. It comes also through the efforts of state and local governments, reflecting their concern with the problems of the uninsured and the escalating cost of Medicaid."
The White House plans several events this week to underline President Bush's concern about the nation's health-care problems, including infant mortality and the failure of many youngsters to get fully immunized against childhood diseases. Administration officials say the events are part of Mr. Bush's election-year effort to show that he is taking a more active interest in domestic issues, largely left to his subordinates over the last three years.
The President wants to set Federal standards for the underwriting practices of health insurance companies, to help slow the rapid increase in premiums for people with chronic medical problems.
But the Administration has shown no interest in reviving a national network of state and local health planning agencies. And it has opposed efforts by Democratic members of Congress to control costs by setting an overall annual budget for public and private spending on health care.
 
States Take Action
 Ted R. Mannen, executive vice president of the Health Industry Manufacturers Association, whose members produce medical equipment, said: "Unfortunately, it appears there has been an upturn in state regulation of medical technology. States are frustrated by the increase in health costs and are latching onto discredited tools of the past to deal with the problem."
Even in the South and the West, where commercial health-care ventures have been most popular, there is a resurgence of interest in health planning. Georgia and Virginia, for example, have passed legislation expanding the coverage of state laws that require a "certificate of need" for new medical services and equipment.
To be sure, medical technology can save lives and money. But health-care economists say that spending on new buildings and equipment often generates additional spending in later years, as hospitals and clinics hire employees and perform additional procedures to keep the machinery in continuous use.
In Georgia, investors must have a certificate of need from the State Health Planning Agency before they can buy or operate any medical equipment valued at $500,000 or more. The requirement, which previously applied to hospitals, now covers free-standing clinics and doctors' offices as well.
The Virginia General Assembly, which abolished such requirements a few years ago, did a 180-degree turn and reinstated them this year.
Adele B. Cohen, vice president of the Atlanta Health Care Alliance, which represents employers like Coca-Cola, Delta Air Lines and BellSouth, said: "We have supported the certificate-of-need law and health-planning regulations as a way to assist in the appropriate allocation of services and capital expenditures. Duplicative, unnecessary health-care services have been very costly to our members."
 
Colorado Governor's Proposal
 In Colorado, Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, wants to revive health planning as part of a comprehensive plan to control costs and guarantee health insurance coverage for all Coloradans.
In a speech to the Colorado General Assembly on Jan. 9, Mr. Romer said: "In 1987 we suspended the hospital certificate-of-need program. I think that was a mistake. We've seen an explosion of costly and duplicative services since then. Let's re-establish the certificate of need."
New Jersey has established an elaborate new system of health planning that includes a statewide limit of $225 million a year in hospital spending for construction, renovations and new medical equipment.
A plan proposed this year by the New Jersey Health Department would close 15 underused hospital pediatric units and convert six underused hospitals to other purposes, like long-term care of the elderly.
The proposal would also prevent the opening of additional open-heart surgery units, cardiac catheterization laboratories and magnetic resonance imaging centers, because they are not needed. New Jersey already has 80 M.R.I. machines, which cost $1 million to $2 million apiece.
 
Health Planning in New York
 Some states, like Connecticut and New York, never lost interest in health planning. The New York State Health Department approved $2 billion in projects last year, half of them in New York City.
In Kentucky, Gov. Brereton C. Jones has imposed a one-year ban on major new spending by hospitals, clinics and nursing homes so that the state will have time to put together "a comprehensive health-care plan."
The moratorium, imposed on March 26, was challenged in a lawsuit filed last month by two Kentucky hospitals and a nursing home company.
In Missouri, Thomas R. Piper, director of the state's certificate-of-need program, said, "Health planning is coming back into vogue."
Hospitals and nursing homes in Missouri need state approval for any construction project costing $600,000 or more. The current session of the Missouri Legislature is expected to pass a bill that would require a certificate of need for any new nursing home beds, regardless of the cost.
 
More Machines, Higher Costs
 Virginia has just reimposed a requirement for state approval of the equipment used for services like radiation therapy, neonatal intensive care, CAT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, organ transplants and lithotripsy, which smashes kidney stones. Since 1989, when Virginia abolished state review of such services, the number of magnetic resonance imaging machines in the state has doubled, to 58, and spending for other high-technology equipment has risen rapidly.
David G. Brickley, a member of the Virginia House of Delegates who sponsored the new law, said: "Our premise in 1989 was that health care was based on supply and demand. If there were more M.R.I. and CAT scanners available, the price would go down. What happened was just the opposite. More machines are available, they're not being fully used and costs are higher than ever."
On April 27, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin signed into law a measure that requires state review of hospital construction projects worth more than $1 million and purchases of medical equipment exceeding $500,000. The state repealed such requirements in 1987.
Under a Minnesota law, signed last week by Gov. Arne Carlson, health-care providers must report any spending of more than $500,000 for medical equipment, services or construction. While the outlays are not usually subject to state approval, the Health Commissioner can require companies to get such approval if they refuse to cooperate with state efforts to rein in health costs.
James F. Ahrens, president of the Montana Hospital Association, expressed concern over this trend, saying: "There's a rush back to command-and-control type legislation intended to restrain health costs. It's an overreaction."

HEADLINE: A Capitalist Itinerary for a Superpower Lecturer;
Gorbachev Arrives in New York for 3 Days of Meetings, Speeches and Fund-Raising

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Gone are the days when Communist propaganda posters showed American financiers with pig snouts and Vladimir I. Lenin railed against the "bloodsucking leeches" of capitalism.
Now, with the Marxist Soviet state defunct, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, its last leader, has been traveling the United States preaching that the world is evolving beyond capitalism and Communism. But as he arrives here today, for the New York City portion of a fund-raising tour, Mr. Gorbachev seems intent on seeing all of the most glittering monuments of capitalism. 
 In his three-day schedule in New York as Private Citizen Gorbachev, the former Soviet leader is to dabble in diplomacy and academia, but also attend a raft of events that will take him from the mogul-packed 75th anniversary party of Forbes magazine, to the New York Stock Exchange, Pepsico World Headquarters and the Economic Club of New York, an exclusive circle of business executives and financiers.
The still-loyal socialist will be rubbing shoulders with Rockefellers and the chief executives of such American business and financial giants as American Express, Salomon Brothers, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and Paramount Communications. He is to have a private breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria sponsored by Dr. Henry Kissinger. And he will receive awards from the Hugh O'Brian Youth Foundation and Yeshiva University.
Last night, Mr. Gorbachev was a guest of former President Jimmy Carter and Emory University at a reception at the Carter Presidential Center in Atlanta attended by more than 300 elected officials and chief executives of some of the region's largest companies.
One guest, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, described the meeting as a "get-acquainted session" with Mr. Gorbachev, who reportedly made no direct appeal for funds. Mr. Gorbachev is delivering a commencement address at Emory this morning.
 
Contrast from Last Visit
 Some of Mr. Gorbachev's former countrymen, who got to New York before him, said it was offensive to see the former Communist leader getting contributions from Americans as he tries to raise an initial $3 million for the Gorbachev Foundation.
"I must live on food stamps and he goes to the bank with his dollars," said Tamara Andreyeva, 59, who emigrated along with her daughter, son-in-law and three grandchildren two months ago from Gomel, one of the towns most contaminated by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident. "We didn't come here like him to rob America," she fumed in Russian, still unable to speak English. "We came with sick children."
But Tatyana Gnatyshnyak, 31, who left Odessa three years ago searching for a better life, expressed sympathy for Mr. Gorbachev. "I think even he would prefer to live here, but he doesn't have such a possibility," said the Brighton Beach resident. She wished him well, noting that it was he who loosened Soviet restrictions on travel and emigration. "If it weren't for him I wouldn't be here," she said.
The last time he came to New York, in December 1988, Mr. Gorbachev was in his prime, charming the world as the engaging Communist leader who kept upstaging the West with disarmament initiatives. He made another arms control proposal at the United Nations and met with President Ronald Reagan, who was about to leave office, and with George Bush, who was succeeding him.
As his motorcade raced through the city, tying up traffic, New Yorkers thronged several deep behind barricades to get a glimpse of Mr. Gorbachev and shout out his name. But the visit was abruptly cut short -- ending speculation that the Communist leader might appear on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange -- when a devastating earthquake struck Armenia.
 
A Superpower Lecturer
 These days, with the Soviet Union dissolved and Mr. Gorbachev in retirement, the trappings of statehood will be gone. The New York City police say they plan no street closings for him. The only expected street protest is by an anti-Castro group that has said it will be picketing the Pierre Hotel, where Mr. Gorbachev is to be honored by Yeshiva University Wednesday night.
Yet in its way, this New York visit is as emblematic of the changing world as Mr. Gorbachev's last one, for he is the first former Soviet Communist leader to be seen abroad as a private citizen. With the exception of Nikita Khrushchev, all other leaders of the Soviet state died in office.
Mr. Khrushchev, who made an earlier attempt at Gorbachev-style reforms, was deposed in a coup and left to live out his life in disgrace in a country dacha. "I now live like a hermit on the outskirts of Moscow," he wrote in his memoirs. "I have practically no communication with other people."
Mr. Gorbachev, by contrast, has become a superpower of the international lecture circuit, touring Germany, Japan and now flying across the United States in the Forbes jet, the words "Capitalist Tool" emblazoned dissonantly across its side. "We love it," said Don Garson, director of corporate communications for Forbes, Inc. "I don't think he minds."
 
An Emigre's Wishes
 Today Mr. Gorbachev plans to visit the United Nations, the institution he sought to boost as the new arbiter of world affairs. After a luncheon with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, he is to meet privately with Max M. Kampelman, the former United States arms control negotiator.
This evening, Mr. Gorbachev is to share the stage with former President Reagan at the Forbes magazine celebration at Radio City Music Hall, where the Forbes family will show a new documentary that the company describes as "the history of democracy and capitalism in its successful struggle to overcome the forces of fascism and communism."
Over the next two days, Mr. Gorbachev will intersperse his fund-raising activities with an appearance at the Council on Foreign Relations and two major addresses. At the Economic Club of New York, where the most recent speaker, Vice President Dan Quayle, declared New York the proof of the failure of the welfare state, Mr. Gorbachev is to speak on America's relations with Russia. Representatives of Yeshiva University say that Mr. Gorbachev will give an address condemning anti-Semitism at their banquet Wednesday.
In Brighton Beach, the Soviet emigre enclave that is not on Mr. Gorbachev's New York agenda, Izrail Bassov, who emigrated from Moscow seven years ago, praised his former leader extravagantly as a peacemaker and wished him the same well-being in America that he has found.
Enthusing that his adopted country his given him free health care and many unexpected government services, Mr. Bassov, 73, laughed puckishly and said, "Here, we older people have Communism."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Some credit market analysts assert that the Federal Reserve may cut short-term interest rates again by early June, even though recent data point to a recovery. Some, however, are skeptical that a cut will stimulate loan demand. [Page D1.]
Politicians and Government officials have joined the debate over whether the wealthy are indeed getting richer at the expense of the poor. [D1.] 
 Banks considering mergers should expect the Government to investigate the effects such combinations might have on small businesses, according to Justice Department officials. [D7.]
Some political experts, including many Democrats, predict that voters will judge President Bush harshly in November because of the weak economic growth during his Administration. [B8.]
 
Companies
Johnson & Johnson's advertising campaign encouraging mothers to get their infants off to a healthy start in life is off to a healthier start than most such public service efforts. [D1.]
Nissan's top American designer is responsible for two new sedans this year that buck the popular "wedge" shape in favor of ski-slope trunk lines and fluid, subtle curves. [D1.]
Chrysler is planning to eliminate one of its five car lines in the next year, according to its vice chairman, Robert J. Eaton. [D2.]
 
International
The World Bank will assess what it called nonproductive military spending by 85 third world countries in deciding how much to lend them in their battles against poverty. [D7.]
A Communist Party secretary in one of the richest cities in southern China is an example of a new breed of officials who would rather spread wealth than revolution. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
Newspaper executives are cautiously optimistic that the hard-won profit gains of the first quarter are the beginning of a turnaround year for the industry. [D3.]
Oreo cookies and "Murphy Brown" are both "core brands" at CBS, and both will be at the heart of the network's most ambitious promotional campaign yet for a new season. [D8.]
The New Yorker magazine joined a small number of publications offering scent-free issues to subscribers offended by or allergic to perfumed ads for fragrances. [D8.]
The announcement of ABC's fall schedule tomorrow is the beginning of the speculation season, in which the chances of success for prime-time shows are debated. [D8.]
 
Today's Columns
Property-casualty insurers can no longer rely on the investment income that has allowed them to remain profitable in recent years, some experts say. Market Place. [D.7]
Advertising agency realignments and executive changes came in a wave last week. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Riots Put Focus on Hispanic Growth and Problems in South-Central Area

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 10

 BODY:
Two days after the rioting began here on April 29, several politicians and community organizers huddled in a youth center to forge a strategy for maintaining calm among the city's Hispanic residents, who make up 40 percent of the Los Angeles population.
The meeting was held in East Los Angeles, an enclave of Mexican-Americans that is where most of the city's Hispanic leaders have their political roots. But they could not think of a single Hispanic leader to invite from South-Central Los Angeles, the area that was hardest hit by rioting and that is home to many recent Hispanic immigrants. 
 East Los Angeles, which was largely unaffected by the rioting, has been the home of generations of Mexican-Americans. But South-Central Los Angeles is quite different. The area has long been predominantly black, but in the last few years it has seen a dramatic influx of Latin Americans, many of whom immigrated to the United States recently or illegally.
The area has become a port of entry for Latin Americans coming from disparate cultures and countries, some torn by war, and many of the new immigrants are struggling to make a living in their first jobs in this country.
The changes to the sprawling South-Central area have caught many people, including local Hispanic officials, almost unaware.
 
'Lot of Work to Do'
 "At a time when we really needed to reach out there, we found that we were not as informed as we could have been about who the Latino leaders were in that area," Los Angeles County's only Hispanic Supervisor, Gloria Molina, said in an interview. "All of us have an awful lot of work to do to learn about the changing demographics of South-Central Los Angeles."
In the last decade, the number of Hispanic people, who can be of any race, has increased by 119 percent in that area, while the number of blacks declined by 17 percent. The 1990 census showed that South-Central Los Angeles was 45 percent Hispanic and 48 percent black.
But there is no Hispanic elected official from South-Central Los Angeles, partly because many of the Hispanic residents are recent arrivals. There are few social-service agencies that cater to Spanish speakers, and even in churches where the congregations are becoming more Hispanic, parishioners barely speak to newcomers because of the language barrier.
The riots have aroused the attention of Hispanic leaders about the huge bloc of Hispanic residents in the South-Central area, many of whom are going unserved and unrepresented.
 
Many Illegal Aliens Arrested
 "There was a void there," said Hector de Paz, an organizer with the California Immigrant Workers Association. "No one from the Latino leadership came out during the riots and assured the community that everything would be all right."
The police said that about a third of those arrested in the unrest were Hispanic people and that many were illegal aliens who were promptly handed over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service for deportation. Of the 58 people who died in the riots, more than a third were Hispanic people. Thirty percent to 40 percent of the businesses destroyed were Hispanic-owned, although officials with the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation said no one had done an accurate accounting yet.
"Latinos actually got the brunt of this," said Dr. David E. Hayes-Bautista, a demographer at the University of California at Los Angeles and head of its Chicano Studies Research Center. "They got beat up, burned out and arrested. Yet it is still being looked at as a black-white issue."
The Hispanic residents in the South-Central area are mostly Central Americans, or recent Mexican immigrants. Slowly, their presence is becoming more evident. In the shadow of the Watts Towers, a landmark rising over Watts, a row of small and colorfully painted houses are now inhabited mostly by Hispanic families. More than half of the babies born at the Martin Luther King Jr. Hospital are born to Hispanic mothers.
 
Immigrants Moving In
 As blacks have moved out of the South-Central area to better neighborhoods to the west or south, their homes have been bought by Hispanic immigrants attracted by the relatively affordable prices.
Carlos Vaquerano, an official with the Central American Refugee Center, said some moving in are entrepreneurs, who can better afford to begin small businesses here. Others are working at bottom-rung jobs and trying to support families who often live in crowded housing.
Central Americans began moving into the Pico-Union neighborhood, just west of downtown Los Angeles and north of the South-Central area, more than a decade ago, but as that area became severely overcrowded, Hispanic families have made their way south of the Santa Monica freeway to the South-Central area, a place of small California-style bungalows and numerous mom-and-pop businesses now in the midst of change.
At St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church on Western Avenue, a once predominantly black church is adapting for new Hispanic members. Now, one of its three Sunday Masses is in Spanish.
Last week, in response to the riots, church volunteers organized a clothing and food drive to help those who were burned out of their homes or their jobs. All the volunteers one morning were black, but many of those who came to seek help were Hispanic.
"I think a lot of the reason they don't participate is that they don't really speak English," said Iris Glover, who has attended St. Brigid for 11 years. "These are not Hispanics who were born here. They emigrated here. Many people do feel like if I can't speak your language, then I'm certainly not going to intermingle with you."
One priest has tried to persuade the two groups to begin to communicate, especially as they see each other at the church between each group's Mass.
"He told us to say hi to one another, if nothing else," said Ethel Hightower. "He tried to teach us the Spanish way to say hi, and them the English way, but most people don't want to bother to learn Spanish, so they nod to one another."
As Ms. Glover and Ms. Hightower were talking, Jose Humberto Diaz, who said he had recently moved into the neighborhood, came by to ask when they would begin giving out food. The women asked a visitor to translate for them, as Mr. Diaz did not speak English and they did not speak Spanish.
 
Satisfaction With Area
 Mr. Diaz, a native of El Salvador who has lived in the United States three years, said many of his friends were surprised when he decided to move to the South-Central area.
"People asked me why I would want to live here," Mr. Diaz said. "They said it was a terrible neighborhood. They told me that those who lived here did not get along with Latinos. But that has not been my experience at all."
Mr. Diaz, who works at a fish market, told of a time his car would not start. His neighbor, a black who does not speak Spanish, came out and helped him jump start his car with his own van.
"To me, they have been very good," Mr. Diaz said.
 
'Not Just a Black Problem'
 Some of those who work with the Central American community say many Hispanic residents of the South-Central area and other parts of Los Angeles were caught up in the violence after the verdict in the trial of four white police officers for beating Rodney G. King partly because they lack the deep roots in their communities that many Mexican-Americans have in East Los Angeles. Others said participation in the violence occurred because many Hispanic residents suffered from the same depressed economic conditions as others who were rioting and looting.
"The Rodney King incident demonstrated a profound dissatisfaction with the unequal treatment of people of all ethnic races in this country," said Mr. Vaquerano. "It provoked a lot of people who were not happy with the way things are. It was not just a black problem, it is one also for whites, Hispanics, Asians and any one who has human feelings."
Mr. Vaquerano, whose center for refugee assistance is in the Pico-Union area , where many Hispanic-owned businesses were burned, said he saw Hispanic people taking part in the looting like everyone else.
"Some of them were honest people who were pushed forward by the anarchy they saw around them," he said. "They saw others destroying and burning and they thought to themselves, 'We will be left with nothing.' And so they also began looting."
As the Hispanic presence in the South-Central area continues to increase, some community leaders said the Mexican-American political leaders, who are currently the Hispanic political establishment in Los Angeles, will have to accommodate them or risk more of the same kind of social unrest seen since April 29. Dr. Hayes-Bautista has also written scholarly works that portray that as a likely outcome.
There are already efforts to bring more leadership to the area. After the rioting and destruction, Mr. Vaquerano's group, along with Councilman Mike Hernandez, who represents the Pico-Union area and nearby Koreatown, organized clean-up crews, many of them Hispanic.
 
Need to Speak Out
 But Mr. Hernandez and other leaders said they realized that for Hispanic residents not to be overlooked in the rebuilding programs, Hispanic leaders must be more vocal and must speak for those in the South-Central area, where Hispanic residents have not yet developed their own leaders.
Supervisor Molina said this was a good time to lay the groundwork for the newcomers to become part of the political process. To that end, she held a meeting Friday afternoon with Mayor Tom Bradley, the leaders of some Central American groups and other community groups, "to start a unity dialogue."
Even though the South-Central area is not in her district, Ms. Molina sent six of her staff members there to insure that the agencies in charge of the recovery efforts were accommodating Spanish-speakers, too.
Ms. Molina said that many people here, including many Mexican-Americans, would not find it easy to learn the lessons of inclusion.
In the days when parts of Los Angeles were burning, Ms. Molina said, she received several telephone calls from Mexican-American constituents, wanting her to put some distance between them and the Hispanic Angelenos who took part in the riots.
"They would say, "Well, Gloria, it wasn't us doing the looting and the burning. It was those immigrants,' " she said. "They wanted me to denounce them. But I say, let's not let that divide us.
"What happened in South-Central tells us that what we have to do in the future is build bridges with each other."
 
AGENCIES COORDINATING AID
 The County of Los Angeles has issued a list of agencies to which money may be sent to assist victims of the Los Angeles riots.
Several 24-hour telephone lines provide general information on agencies that accept donations. The telephone numbers are, for Central Los Angeles, (213) 686-0950; West Los Angeles, (310) 671-7464; San Gabriel Valley, (818) 350-6833; San Fernando Valley, (818) 501-4447.

HEADLINE: 9 Deaths in Gulf: British Ask 'Why?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 10

 BODY:
They were casualties of what is called "friendly fire," nine British infantrymen killed in the closing days of the Persian Gulf war when two United States Air Force jets mistook their armored vehicles for Iraqi tanks and attacked them with missiles.
Nearly 15 months later, the grieving parents of those British soldiers sit inside a high-ceilinged hearing room in Oxford, listening as a parade of witnesses describe how their sons died that day in the desert. They are hoping to resolve the one question whose answer, they say, will put their hearts at rest: How could such a thing happen? 
 Although British and American investigators acknowledge that the American jets fired the fatal missiles on the afternoon of Feb. 26, 1991, the hearings by a coroner's court jury have inflamed a sense of public despair and anger here, since no Americans will be coming to England to testify about what went wrong.
The families and their lawyers insist such testimony is essential because, they say, they have been offered contradictory explanations of the incident over the last year, in part because Washington and London have not been able to agree about who is to blame.
At the heart of the debate is a belief here that the British families involved are being told less than American families who similarly lost relatives as a result of such incidents in the Persian Gulf war. According to the Pentagon, 35 of the 148 United States combat deaths were a result of allied rather than enemy fire.
On the steps of Oxford County Hall on Friday, Peter Atkinson, an unemployed machinist whose son, Paul, was killed in the incident, displayed a photograph of himself and President Bush. It was taken at a White House meeting last fall, when some of the families of the British soldiers killed in the incident were invited to meet the President.
"He told me he was sorry and promised me we would have all the facts, but we still don't," Mr. Atkinson said."
The United States Government has provided the inquest with a 26-page collection of letters and affidavits, including a series of statements obtained from the two American pilots. Their names and units were stricken from the material, underscoring a United States Government decision to protect their anonymity.
The hearings, which are expected to last three more days, will resume Monday morning.
 
U.S. Cites 'Good Faith'
 In a letter, Carl W. Ford Jr., a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, expressed the United States' regret and "deep compassion" for the families. But he said the pilots of the two A-10 jets had "acted in the good faith belief that they could attack in the area in which they were operating."
But lawyers for the family say the statements are inadequate, since British Defense Ministry investigators never interviewed the pilots, and the pilots' statements only underscore what the British have described as "a conflict of edvidence" over what happened.
In recent days, Britain's tabloid press has been ringing with articles sharply critical of President Bush and the Pentagon for refusing to produce the pilots as witnesses.
The hearings, which began in Oxford last week, are described as a coroner's inquest, a judicial proceeding convened at the insistence of the families to force some public determination of the cause of their sons' deaths. In many ways, the process has become less a legal exercise than a theater of despair, a last plaintive public appeal for help by the families, all of them working-class people from northeast England and Scotland.
 
'Let Them Come'

A dramatic measure of their plight were photographs and news film last week that showed Mr. Atkinson pursuing an American military observer outside the hearing room, pleading with him as he chased him down the sidewalk to ask Washington to allow the pilots to tell their side of the story.
"My son is dead," said Mr. Atkinson, close to tears. "Why won't the American pilots come over? Why don't they defend themselves? Let them come. Nothing's going to happen to them."
Mr. Atkinson and other parents say they are not seeking civil damages or criminal penalties against the pilots, since the law provides for neither possibility.
The American pilots say they mistook the two British armored vehicles for Iraqi tanks because they were not displaying colored panels or other markings identifying them as allied vehicles. The British Defense Ministry, as well as witnesses at the hearings, insisted all of the vehicles, 30-ton armored personnel carriers called Warriors, were clearly showing friendly markings.
 
A Corporal's Testimony
 The incident occurred on a bright afternoon as the British forces charged through a breach in Iraqi defenses opened earlier by American troops. At the time of the attack, the two Warriors were among a group of four that had come to a halt in the desert.
When the first missile hit, Lance Cpl. Peter Fyfe said at the inquest on Friday, the men had just returned to the vehicle after stretching their legs.
Suddenly, there was a tremendous explosion. "My mates were screaming and my hair was on fire and pieces of shrapnel were in my thigh," said Corporal Fyfe, who was badly wounded. Three or four minutes later, a second missile slammed into another of the vehicles.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Atkinson, whose son, Paul, a British infantryman, was killed by "friendly fire" in the closing days of the Persian Gulf war, displaying a photograph of himself and President Bush. "He told me he was sorry and promised me we would have all the facts, but we still don't," Mr. Atkinson said. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Executive Pay At New Highs

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The pay of corporate America's chief executives hit new highs in 1991 despite the recession, slimmer profits and widespread layoffs, Forbes magazine says in its latest issue.
Forbes said 407 of the chief executives at the country's 800 largest publicly held companies earned $1 million or more in total compensation last year, up from 386 in 1990. Total compensation includes salary and bonus, noncash stock gains (mainly from exercising options) and other benefits. 
 The top earner last year was the H. J. Heinz Company's chairman and chief executive, Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, who received $75 million, of which more than $71 million came from stock awards.
The second-highest-paid chief executive was Martin Wygod of Medco Containment Services Inc. He earned $34.6 million, followed by Leon Hirsch of the United States Surgical Corporation, with $23.3 million.

HEADLINE: A MIDEAST PUZZLE: TALKS THAT AREN'T

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The six-month-old Middle East peace process enters a new phase over the next week with international meetings in five capitals on a wide range of practical issues. The talks among Israel and its neighbors will cover arms control, economic development, refugees, water resources and the environment.
Israeli officials repeated today that they will boycott two of the sessions -- the economic development conference in Brussels on Monday and Tuesday and the the refugee talks in Ottawa Wednesday through Friday -- because Palestinians from outside the occupied territories are included in delegations. Jerusalem objects to such participation because it raises issues of Palestinians' right to return to the West Bank and Gaza Strip.. 
 The Palestinians, who are supported on this matter by the co-sponsors, Washington and Moscow, say that these topics, especially the future of refugees, are of special concern to Palestinians outside the disputed areas of the Mideast. The composition and status of Palestinian delegations have been a bone of contention for Israel in the continuing peace process.
Syria and Lebanon have said they see no point in attending the coming talks, which will include delegations from outside the Mideast, until direct discussions with Israel show progress.
 
Weapons, Water, Environment
 Israelis are expected to take part in talks on arms control and regional security beginning here in Washington on Monday, and in sessions on water resources in Vienna on Wednesday and Thursday. Most delegations are also expected to be in Tokyo on May 18 and 19 for discussions on the environment of the Mideast region.
This series of "working group" meetings was intended to complement the central peace talks between Israel and each of its Arab neighbors: Lebanon, Jordan, Syria and the Palestinians. The working-group talks over the next eight days are expected to culminate in a joint "steering group" session in Lisbon on May 27.
The Bush Administration says the talks beginning here on Monday are not to be regarded as negotiations. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, has described them as more like seminars at which papers on various topics will be presented and historical precedents recalled.
Miss Tutwiler said on Friday that the Washington working-group meeting on arms control "will include presentations and discussions on the methods and concepts of arms control, the evolution of the confidence and security-building process, the history of the U.S.-Soviet hot-line agreement, and the 'incidents at sea' and 'dangerous military activities' agreements."
 
Recent Chronology
 The Mideast regional conference began in October with an opening, essentially ceremonial session in Madrid. In December, the first of three rounds of direct talks between Israel and individual Arab delegations took place in Washington. A second large international conference was convened in Moscow in January.
Although substantive progress appears to have been slow or nonexistent, particularly in the separate Israeli meetings with individual Arab delegations, negotiators from both sides emphasize that Israelis and Arabs are meeting face to face and that this must be considered a huge step forward.
Arab delegation leaders have warmly praised Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for his persistence in brokering the peace process and gaining their governments' confidence.
In earlier rounds of talks, progress has been most noticeable in Israeli-Jordanian sessions. The least has been accomplished in Israeli-Syrian talks.
Jordan, however, plans to propose steps in the Ottawa refugee talks this week that are bound to be controversial in Israel. According to reports from Amman, Jordanian delegates will press for the right of Palestinians outside the West Bank and the Gaza Strip to return to homes there, and will also seek compensation for Jordanians and Palestinians who lost land when the state of Israel was created in 1948.
