"Krugman's 70 percent calculation is not the answer to meaningful questions you'd want to ask," he added. Besides, Republicans say, measuring income shares in a mobile society is as meaningless as measuring which bubbles are at the top of the blender at a given moment in time.
"The whole concept of a static layered society is false except for the underclass," said George Gilder, author of "The Spirit of Enterprise."
 
Liberals' Responses
 Liberals, including Mr. Krugman, see things differently. They argue that capital gains do not distort the overall income data nearly as much as conservatives have claimed, largely because the fastest-growing component of the income at the very top was salaries.
They also respond that measuring the growth of inequality from 1982, the bottom of the worst postwar recession, as Republicans wish to do, swamps any trend in the data. Even so, they point out, the rich even got richer during the expansionary portion of the business cycle -- a time when the poor usually increase their share of total income.
And they maintain that mobility was just as great in 1977 as in 1989, so the fact that people can move up and down the economic ladder does nothing to offset the trend toward greater inequality.
 
Republicans Foresaw a Problem
 And while no single calculation represents the truth and every data set has drawbacks, Mr. Krugman and others said, a large number of different measures using different data sources show that the very rich have done far better than everyone else.
Take wages. "There is complete unanimity on the facts," said Lawrence H. Katz, an economist at Harvard University.
Finis Welch, an economist at the Rand Corporation and the University of California at Los Angeles, said, "The farther up you were the more you gained; the farther down you were, the more you lost."
The fact is that even before Mr. Krugman rolled his grenade under the tent, the Republicans had recognized inequality as a potential political bombshell and had attempted to defuse it. Two out of nine chapters in this year's Economic Report of the President, for example, tackled the touchy topic.
Though the report acknowledges that the well-off gained more than anyone else, that poverty was higher in 1989 than in 1979, and that the income prospects of families headed by younger and less-educated workers were dismal, its main emphasis is on overall growth, rather than on how much more some benefited than others.
"It's much more important for economic policy to promote growth in family incomes than to redistribute it," Mr. Boskin said.
But some conservatives are fuming because of what they see as the White House's wimpishness on this issue. "The White House is terribly ill suited to take this issue on," said a Republican aide who spoke on the condition that he not be named. "Who's going to fight the fight over fairness? Nicholas Brady? Robert Mossbacher? George Bush? Dan Quayle? There's no one there who comes from the middle class."
And some Republicans are upset by the notion that some folks at the top got there not by hard work, entrepreneurship or even luck, but by pure thievery, often at the expense of middle-class consumers or taxpayers.
"Voters are less happy with the people at the top," said Kevin P. Phillips, the political commentator and author of "The Politics of Rich and Poor." "By the end of the 1980's, Horatio Alger got replaced by Charles Keating, Michael Milken and Leona Helmsley."
And Edward Gillespie, the Republican staff director of the Joint Economic Committee, said: "People are concerned whether their kids can do better than they did. When the economy is stagnating and middle-class workers are losing jobs, it's easier to stoke the class war."
But Richard B. Freeman, an economist at Harvard University, said, "If everybody had done better -- even if Donald Trump had gotten three times wealthier -- we wouldn't be worrying about inequality."

HEADLINE: Big Bird and Other Subversives

BYLINE: By Patricia Kean; Patricia Kean is writing a book of essays.

 BODY:
What's big, yellow and has a radical agenda? Now it can be told: It's Big Bird. Grown fat and happy off your tax dollars, he's the one to blame for a wide variety of urban ills.
Laurence Jarvik, a scholar at the conservative Heritage Foundation, was the first to see the vulture in that mass of feathers. In an interview in this newspaper last month, he charged that " 'Sesame Street' is just another kid's show, no better than 'Underdog' or 'The Flintstones.' " No better certainly, and potentially a serious threat, as Mr. Jarvik goes on to prove. "What did the taxpayers get for their investment in 'Sesame Street?' A generation of kids who spray graffiti on the walls of New York City. If 'Sesame Street' was so effective, why do we have such a literacy problem?" 
 Why, indeed? Suddenly the scales drop from our eyes. If it weren't for the insidious doings of the Children's Television Workshop, we'd be way ahead of the Japanese. Until the Heritage Foundation came along, most of us failed to see the links between Bert, Ernie and declining S.A.T. scores.
Sadly, it doesn't stop there. New evidence also shows that the public television gang is behind global warming, short skirts, the House banking scam and Pat Buchanan's candidacy. One thing is certain: The muppets didn't act alone. Somebody gave them a hand.
There's already an all-points bulletin out on a goofy looking guy whose tastes run to baggy cardigans. A real cool customer, he speaks in measured tones, does everything nice and slow and ties his shoelaces pretty as you please. Goes by the name of Rogers. Street name: "Mister." From the looks of him, butter wouldn't melt in his mouth. But he's wanted for taking generations of innocent youths on a magic trolley ride to a neighborhood of make believe riddled with fairies, elves and welfare queens.
For adults only, they have another con man, a real smoothie who speaks a mean BBC and has a way with a plot summary. Off camera, though, Alistair is strictly veneer, Naugahyde and a well-thumbed collection of Cliffs Notes. Every Sunday, "Cookie" works the same crowd, the easy marks with the big bucks, the good teeth and the Volvos. Before they know what's hit them, they've missed the latest Valerie Bertinelli flick and are hooked on a grueling, 12-part Evelyn Waugh masterpiece.
Who laid the foundation for all this? Most whisper it's the master carpenter himself. Norm appears out of nowhere, restoring this old house, then that old house, undermining the family structure as he goes. Children adore him. As a result, their Sheetrock-impaired dads slink away, take to hard liquor and eventually apply for public assistance. There's also Norm's effect on the economy. And what of the eggheads who clog our emergency rooms, all because Norm convinced them that being historically correct means handling easy-to-use power tools?
But before we join Mr. Jarvik in his cry for "Underdog," maybe we should take a closer look at his heroes. True, "Underdog" never took a dime of Federal funds, but something about his name sounds vaguely Democratic. In a certain light, he looks a lot like Paul Tsongas, and then there's the matter of his relationship with Polly "Sweet Polly" Purebread, and those secret energy pills he kept popping.
With Fred and Barney, though, you've got basic American values. Both were conservative Republicans, Goldwater men. They drank beer, bowled and worked at the quarry, while Wilma and Betty stayed home and made the Brontoburgers. You know what? This country could use a few more characters just like them. But until Congress reins in PBS -- they're expected to consider doing so this week -- we'll continue to watch in horror as our children count aloud from one to 10 and spray-paint tags like "Grover" and "Kermit" all over town.

HEADLINE: UTILITY IS SELLING RIGHT TO POLLUTE

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Two utilities hundreds of miles apart will announce today that they have signed a contract that calls for one to buy from the other the right to emit a chemical that causes acid rain, freeing the dirtier one from having to clean up its own plants as stringently.
It is the first such deal to be publicly disclosed, say those involved and other experts, and could break the ice for dozens of similar deals. 
 The Tennessee Valley Authority will buy the right to emit 10,000 tons of sulfur dioxide, the main cause of acid rain, from Wisconsin Power and Light. The Wisconsin company will reduce its emissions to a level 10,000 tons below what Federal law requires, and the T.V.A. will get additional time to install smokestack scrubbers or replace high-sulfur coal with cleaner fuels.
 
Deal Over $2.5 Million
 The price was not disclosed but is believed to be around $2.5 million to $3 million.
The deal was made under a system established in the Clean Air Act of 1990 and will be regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency. Acid rain, which is believed to be responsible for severe damage to lakes and forests, is one of two main targets of the Clean Air Act. The other target is smog and toxic chemical emissions.
Economists and some environmentalists have long called for a "market-based" system that encourages deals like the one to be announced today. They say such a system reduces the cost to the economy of cutting sulfur emissions, compared with a "command and control" system of ordering each utility to comply. The goal of the Clean Air Act is to reduce such emissions by 10 million tons a year. The T.V.A. is buying "emission allowances" because it believes that at least in the short run the purchase price is less than what it would cost to clean up its own plants enough. For its part, Wisconsin Power can turn a profit by "overcomplying" with the Federal law and selling the allowances.
The idea of trading emission allowances has generally won praise as creating a "win-win" deal, in which costs are minimized and everyone benefits. Some authorities estimate a savings of 20 percent compared with making each utility comply.
Such deals create the possibility that sulfur dioxide emissions will fall more in some locations than in others. In most cases, a local group that opposed plans by a utility to buy emission allowances rather than cut emissions could presumably contest the decision before state regulators, but in this case opponents, if they emerge, would appear to have few options because the T.V.A. is not subject to such state regulation.
But the 10,000 tons represents only a small fraction of the reduction required at the T.V.A., and the authority anticipates meeting the rest of it internally. In fact, experts say that most utilities that buy allowances will meet only a portion of their needs that way.
Utilities have thus far been slow to strike such deals. Since the first phase of the law takes effect in 1995 and scrubbers usually take 36 months to build, some appear to have decided to forgo the market.
But this deal could lead the way for others, said John S. Palmisano, president of Aer*x, a subsidiary of Electronic Data Systems, which is seeking to broker similar arrangements. "It's like going to a church dance, with the boys on one side and the girls on another," he said. "Sooner or later, somebody's going to walk into the middle."
This deal will form a benchmark, he said, with other potential buyers and sellers wanting to peg their prices against this one.
John B. Henry 2d, the president of Clean Air Capital Markets, a small Washington-based investment banking firm that arranged the contract, said the contract was important because it was the first and because the price was low. "It sends a clear signal to the industry that allowances can be purchased below the cost of most scrubbers," he said.
Mr. Henry said scrubbers would become financially attractive on a wide basis if the cost of allowances rose to $300 to $350 a ton.
In addition, Mr. Henry said, buying allowances could be easier for utilities than relying on cleaner fuels that would have to be shipped from far away. A utility that bought allowances, he said, would often, in effect, be buying the benefit of the seller's having switched to cleaner fuels available locally.
But for the moment, the terms of this contract, which was signed on May 1, are not clear. Mr. Henry refused to discuss its terms, and neither would top officials of the two utilities. But William F. Malec, the senior vice president and chief financial officer of the T.V.A., said that a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that first disclosed the deal and said the price would be $250 to $300 a ton was "in the ballpark."
Such a price would be on the low end of what experts had expected. But Mr. Malec and Erroll B. Davis Jr., the chief executive of Wisconsin Power, pointedly refused to say when the money would be paid -- now, in 1995 or later. If it is not paid now, the cost of money would have to be figured in, and the value could be less.
When the Clean Air Act was signed by President Bush, some had estimated that a single allowance, or the right to emit one ton of sulfur dioxide, would be worth about $1,000 on the open market, but with improving technology for lowering such emissions, along with other factors, recent estimates have been lower.
If the cost of removing a ton of sulfur dioxide from the air is in fact lower than expected, that is good news for electricity users because it means the total cost of compliance with the Clean Air Act will be lower. But it may be bad news for companies that invested heavily in expensive pollution-control hardware, expecting to recoup the cost through sales of allowances.
The limits are set in terms of pounds of sulfur dioxide per unit of heat produced in utility boilers, keying them, in effect, to electricity production. The limit is set at one level from 1995 to 1999, and a stricter level beginning in 2000. In addition, new plants will have a limit of zero, meaning that for each ton of sulfur dioxide they produce, they must buy an allowance from the owner of an older plant who is willing, for a price, to clean up.
In the case of the deal to be announced today, Mr. Davis said, "these prices are going to come out eventually, as we go into regulatory proceedings." But his company does not want to divulge the number now, he said, because "we're hoping that the market is a bit more robust" and prices of allowances will rise.
Establishing the market price is important, according to another expert, Robert D. Conley, the president of Pure Air Inc. of Allentown, Pa., because utilities that are considering buying pollution allowances are weighing that option against installing pollution-control hardware or switching to lower-sulfur fuel, or both. Likewise, a company that is considering making the investment to "overcomply" wants to know what the allowances would sell for. If this deal and others that will presumably follow in coming weeks do not establish a price, then the industry will probably have to wait for an auction of extra allowances that the Environmental Protection Agency is planning to hold in early 1993.
Mr. Conley said that the T.V.A.-Wisconsin deal was probably small by the standards of those that will follow. Utilities typically need tens of thousands of tons of allowances, or more than 100,000, each year, he said.
 
A Geographic Shift
 The Clean Air Act is meant to cut acid emissions roughly in half, but the trading system also has the potential to shift the emissions geographically, if buyers are concentrated in one region and sellers in another. Mr. Henry, the investment banker, described the establishment of the trading system as "like a magic legal wand was waved, and all utilities in the country became one utility for purposes of acid rain control."
Most environmentalists consider acid rain a national problem, not a regional one, unlike, for example, smog, which is more local in nature. The emissions trading system was passed largely at the impetus of the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit environmental group.
Acid created in power plants can be deposited hundreds of miles from the source, with rain or snow. Some state regulators, however, have proposed limiting allowance trading to within their borders, instead of allowing utilities in their jurisdictions to clean up their stacks and sell the allowances to utilities upwind, with the resulting pollution coming back to the original state. But experts yesterday said no state had yet instituted such restrictions.
Mr. Malec and others involved in the deal said it should not be construed as the sale of the right to pollute. He stressed that the sum of emissions by the T.V.A. and by Wisconsin Power and Light would be equal to the total permitted by the new law. The 10,000 allowances, a small fraction of the reduction the T.V.A. will need, will give the authority some breathing room in case modifications to boilers or fuel switching arrangements are delayed, he said.
It is also a small fraction of the allowances that Wisconsin has available to sell. Under a state law, it has been held to stricter standards than those set by Washington, and passage of the act turned that "overcompliance" into a salable asset.
Generally, however, sellers have been held back in part because state regulators have not ruled on the question of who benefits from the proceeds, the stockholders or the electric customers. Thus, utilities have been reluctant to take the risk of investing in scrubbers or other equipment to create "overcompliance" because their shareholders might not benefit, and if the sale of the allowances does not recoup the costs, their shareholders might actually suffer.
Wisconsin regulators have not decided how the sale proceeds will be treated.

HEADLINE: Pessimism Is Overshadowing Hope In Effort to End Yugoslav Fighting

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 11

 BODY:
For many in the old city of Sarajevo, the legend spray-painted on a wall in a predominantly Muslim quarter expressed the agonies of civil war: "Welcome to hell."
For weeks, some of the deadliest weapons in modern warfare have been used against civilians across Bosnia and Herzegovina and its capital, Sarajevo. 
 Artillery, tanks, mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns, as well as Yugoslav-built fighter-bombers, have been used to blast lives and property in every corner of the former Yugoslav republic. Atrocities, including summary executions of civilians, have been commonplace.
 
570,000 Refugees
 Piecing together reports from cities, towns and villages too dangerous for most outsiders to visit, international relief agencies say hundreds of people have been killed and at least 570,000 -- more than one civilian in eight, in a total population of 4.3 million -- have been left homeless. The figures for the dead and homeless are little more than guesses, and many diplomats believe they are probably low.
What is clear is that a tragedy is unfolding on a scale with few precedents in Europe since World War II, and that efforts to end it, or even to mitigate its scale, have failed.
 
28 Killed in Sarajevo
 Today, at least 28 more people were killed in a Yugoslav Army artillery and mortar barrage on Sarajevo. In Brussels, the Foreign Ministers of the 12-nation European Community announced the withdrawal of their Ambassadors from the truncated Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro, identified by the United States and the European Community as the main aggressor in Bosnia. [Page A10.]
Under threat of additional but unspecified economic sanctions, the European ministers also demanded the immediate withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from Bosnia, or its "dismantling." The wording was intended to discourage a process Serbia initiated after earlier demands for the army's withdrawal, the transfer of as many as 80 per cent of the army's troops, amounting to about 30,000 men, along with much of their equipment, to irregular Serbian units that have been fighting alongside the army.
But with one Bosnian cease-fire after another having been violated almost as soon as it has been proclaimed, Western diplomats in Belgrade, the Serbian and Yugoslav capital, say there may be no end to the fighting until the rival sides -- Serbs, Croats and Muslim Slavs -- exhaust themselves.
By then, the diplomats say, there may be no Bosnia and Herzegovina left to save, and the independent state proclaimed in Sarajevo in March, and recognized by the United States and the European Community in early April, may become little more than a footnote in the turbulent history of the Balkans.
 
Goal of Serbs and Croats
 Last week, at a meeting in Graz, Austria, leaders of the republic's Serbian and Croatian groups announced that they had agreed to partition Bosnia and Herzegovina. This brought them closer to what has long been seen as their objective: annexation of their respective enclaves to Serbia and Croatia.
The biggest losers in the arrangement would be the Muslim Slavs, who make up the largest group in the republic with almost half of the population. For them, partition would mean retreating into small, dispersed enclaves that would have little hope of coalescing into a viable independent state.
For the United States and the European Community, the situation represents a major diplomatic setback, since Bosnia is the archetype of the post-Communist, multi-ethnic nations that range all across eastern Europe and eastward to the Central Asian republics of the former Soviet Union.
For Bosnia, disintegration would mark the tearing of a social and political fabric developed over a millennium. Since the Slavic peoples now known as Serbs and Croats settled in the mountainous regions inland of the Adriatic Sea in the seventh century, Bosnia has developed into one of the most intricate societies in Europe.
Serbs, who are mostly Orthodox Christians, and Croats, who are mostly Roman Catholics, live intermingled with the third Slav group, Muslims who adopted their faith from Turkish conquerors in the 15th century.
Despite a violent history that included mass deportations of Serbs during World War II, when many died in the death camps run by Croatia's fascist government, Bosnia lived for most of the 45 years after the war, the period of Communist rule, in relative harmony.
 
Serbs Opposed Independence
 But a February referendum on independence for Bosnia and Herzegovina, although approved by 99 percent of the vote, reflected only the preferences of the republic's Croats, accounting for 17 percent of the population, and the Muslim Slavs, representing 44 percent.
Serbs, 31 percent of the population, boycotted the vote. When the Sarajevo Government declared independence anyway, the Serbs asserted that they were being railroaded into a new state without any guarantee that their minority rights would be protected.
While continuing to negotiate the structure of an independent Bosnia in talks sponsored by the European Community, the Serbs shifted in early April to a military offensive that took on the character of a land grab.
As he did during the fighting in Croatia, in which a similar aggregation of Serbian forces seized one-third of Croatia, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia offered a host of undertakings intended to head off sanctions threatened by Western governments angered by the offensive.
 
Denying Territorial Claims
 For one thing, Serbia proclaimed the founding of a truncated Yugoslavia, restricted to Serbia and Montenegro, and declared that the new state had no territorial claims on its neighbors. For another, Mr. Milosevic insisted publicly that neither the Yugoslav Army nor Serbia-based paramilitary groups had played any role in the fighting.
Last week, the Belgrade leadership announced that all officers and troops in Bosnia who are not Bosnians -- about 20 percent of the total, according to the army -- would be withdrawn from the republic by May 19.
But the announcement said the role of all other army personnel in Bosnia would be settled in negotiations among the republic's three ethnic groups. In recent days, as convoys of troops and equipment have begun heading out of Bosnia to Serbia, the remaining troops, almost all of them Serbs, have begin preparing to merge with irregular Serbian units.
Already, the army and Serbian irregulars have gained effective control of at least 60 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina, including towns and villages in the north, east and south where Muslim Slavs or Croats, or both, have traditionally outnumbered Serbs.
 
Offensive in East Bosnia
 The offensive has covered a broad swath of eastern Bosnia, capturing towns like Bijeljina, Zvornik, Bratunac, Visegrad, Gorazde and Foca. Another major target has been the southern city of Mostar, the hub of the Herzegovina region and traditionally a stronghold of Muslim Slavs and Croats. In the north, the offensive has concentrated on opening a corridor to Serb-held regions of Croatia captured during last year's fighting.
A Croatian counteroffensive, particularly in northern and northwestern Bosnia, and in southwestern regions adjacent to the finger of Croatia that extends down the Dalmatian coast, has been strongly supported by Croatia, which has dispatched troops to join in the fighting.
Still, in Western embassies in Belgrade, the main responsibility for the war is pinned firmly on Serbia, and on Bosnian Serbs. Military attaches say that the offensives have followed a similar pattern to the fighting in Croatia last year, with the army giving close support to the Serbian irregulars.
Terror tactics have played a major part. Western diplomats and international relief officials, citing interviews with refugees and reports from United Nations and European Community military observers in Bosnia, say Serbian irregulars have entered towns and villages with Muslim Slav and Croatian populations, ordered all non-Serbs to leave at gunpoint, and executed some who have resisted. Homes have been looted and burned, and Serbian irregulars have hijacked trucks carrying United Nations food to Sarajevo.
If a settlement makes Muslim Slavs the main losers in Bosnia, the outcome is likely to be seen in the Muslim world as a suppression of the largest indigenous Muslim population in Europe, outside the one in Albania.
As one Arab envoy here put it: "These are people who represent the largest group in a country whose independence has been recognized by the United States and the European Community. But they are Muslims, and their rights are being trampled on by people who are Christians, so the United States and Europe make a lot of noise, but they do nothing."

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: GRADUATES FACING WORST PROSPECTS IN LAST 2 DECADES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
When bands stop playing at college graduation ceremonies this spring, members of the class of '92, who came of age in a recession, will doff caps and gowns and enter one of the toughest job markets that any class has seen in decades.
Studies by two universities indicate that nearly one-third of the nation's entry-level jobs for new graduates have evaporated during the recession as many large employers have reduced their hiring. At the same time, the market is already glutted with nearly a million unemployed managers and professional workers. 
 Labor experts say the job market is the worst it has been in 50 years in the New York region. And it is not much better in the rest of the Northeast, California and Michigan. Elsewhere, particularly in the West, graduates are not having as hard of a time because either there has been no decline in jobs, or some growth in them. And nationally, the job market is expected to begin growing, though only slightly, over the next year.
 
Better Prepared for Job Search
 The class of '92 has been hearing about the dismal job market for three years, and, college placement officials say, its members seem better prepared for a grueling job search than the last two classes.
"Everyone knows it's a bad year, and everyone is working harder to find a job," said Jennifer A. Atkisson, a business major at Florida State College in Tallahassee who has interviewed at 15 companies without receiving an offer.
Hector Castillo, who is graduating from Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., said, "I am pretty marketable, but the job market is very small." Mr. Castillo, who majored in economics and Latin American studies, has been hunting for a marketing job in between his studies and a part-time job since November. "I am starting to dig a lot deeper, into alumni connections and things like that," he said.
 
Reduced Recruiting
 Liberal arts students have the toughest scramble ahead, while engineers and students with other technical degrees can expect a choice of jobs. And many graduates will try to skip the recession entirely, as shown by a substantial increase since last year in applications to graduate schools, especially law, business and journalism schools, and to not-for-profit or volunteer organizations.
Many companies have sharply reduced recruiting on campus. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, for example, recruited on 300 campuses in 1988 and hired 2,000 graduates. Gail Hiering Varma, the company's manager of college recruiting, said the company has reduced its hiring since then. This year, she said, the company recruited on 155 campuses and hired about 1,000 graduates.
But some companies, like the Procter & Gamble Company, have maintained their campus recruiting programs. The company hired more than 1,000 graduates this year, about the same number as it hired last year, said Linda Ulrey, a company spokeswoman.
Campus officials said the overall drop in recruitment combined with the anxiety caused by an eroding job market had noticeable effects.
College placement specialists at several Ivy League schools said that their graduates were adjusting well to the stagnant economy, but that more and more of them were heading for graduate schools. "I am concerned that students are making the graduate school decision by default and may end up in the wrong career," said Mary Giannini, executive director of the Center for Career Services at Columbia University in Manhattan.
At the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Patricia Rose, director of career planning and placement services, said she had found students to be much more serious about their preparations. "They have been scared into it," she said. "But last year we had fewer than 10 percent looking for work six months after graduation, and I don't expect any change this year."
 
100 Resumes, No Interview
 Liberal arts majors are the most fearful. Holly L. Young, an English major at Rice University in Houston, said she knew she was in trouble last summer when she sent out 100 resumes for an internship and did not get an interview. "I've been very nervous all senior year," she said. But she took career workshops at the placement office and narrowed her interests to consulting firms in business technology whose training programs she was interested in. After she had interviewed with more than 15 companies on campus this spring, Ernst & Young, one of the big accounting firms, recently offered her a $31,500-a-year job.
Two university studies suggest that the number of job openings for 1992 graduates has decreased by only 4 percent to 10 percent, but that decline comes on top of two previous annual declines that have, all together, eliminated almost a third of all entry-level positions since the 1989-90 school year. "We have a big pool of talent built up behind this recessionary dam, and it keeps getting bigger and bigger," said Victor R. Lindquist, a dean at Northwestern.
He is also the author of the university's Lindquist-Endicott Report, which has surveyed mid- to large-size businesses about their hiring plans every year since 1945. Nearly half of the 259 businesses surveyed this year said they planned to hire fewer new college graduates. "This is worse than anything I've seen in 20 years," Mr. Lindquist said. One bright spot in the survey: average salaries are up by a modest 2.7 percent over last year.
A Michigan State University survey of 464 employers in business, industry and government came to the same dismal conclusion as the Northwestern study. "This is the most serious cutback in the job market since we began surveying employers 21 years ago," said L. Patrick Scheetz, author of the survey and director of the Collegiate Employment Research Institute at Michigan State.
 
Reality Still Shocking
 The Michigan State study found that about 45 percent of this year's 1.1 million graduates -- the largest class ever to graduate from American colleges -- are in technical fields, like engineering and the health professions, that have more job openings than candidates. Another 13 percent of the graduates are heading for occupations like education and communication technology that have a balanced supply of jobs and candidates. And 42 percent of the graduates have degrees in areas like the social sciences and communications that are oversupplied with candidates.
Even though this year's graduates are prepared for a tough job search, the reality can still be shocking. "They tell you to start at the bottom, but even the bottom doesn't have much to offer," said Kristan Ginther, a would-be journalist who is graduating from the University of Wisconsin at Madison. Several graduate schools of journalism, havens in the storm, report that applications are up 25 to 75 percent.
What makes the job search more difficult for the class of '92 is that its members are competing with 933,000 unemployed managers and professionals, whose jobless rate has increased by 60 percent in two years, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York.
"There have been no employment declines in some states in the West, Southwest and South," he said. "But I would say college graduates are facing the toughest job market in a half-century in the New York region. The whole Northeast, Michigan and California are severely affected."
Economists say they expect the job market to improve slowly. Sara L. Johnson, the managing economist for the DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting and forecasting concern in Boston, said the strongest employment growth over the next 12 months will be in the Midwest, the Pacific Northwest and the Southwest, dominated by Texas. "The Northeast will be lagging," she said, "but other parts of the country should see employment gains of 2 percent over the next 12 months."
To some students, the tough market means living at home after college. "I'm going to live at home for at least another two or three years," said Lisa A. Blessing, an economics major at Rutgers University who expects a long search for a job with a modest salary.
For other graduates, the solution is to leave the country.
Maria L. Recchia, a zoology major at Connecticut College in New London, wants work at La Stazione Zoologica, a marine biology laboratory in Naples, Italy. She is waiting to hear if the Government-subsidized laboratory has a research position for her. "I have no idea about the salary," she said. "I just hope it's enough to live on."
The Peace Corps reports receiving 800 telephone inquiries a day on average, up from 250 a day prior to January. But even the Peace Corps does not have many openings for graduates without technical training. "We can place graduates with degrees in agriculture or forestry within three months, but it takes up to one or two years to place a liberal arts graduate," said Elaine L. Chao, director of the Peace Corps.
Some volunteers sound more pragmatic than idealistic. Sarah Welling hoff, a major in international relations at the University of Nevada in Reno, is heading off to teach English in the African country of Chad. "If there were more jobs available or teaching assistantships for grad school," she said, "I might not have signed up."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Hope and Fear in Los Angeles As Deadly Gangs Call Truce

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 11

 BODY:
When one of his brothers was thrown through a plate-glass window during the riots here and another was shot, Reggie Harris barely flinched.
Having spent most of his 22 years in street gangs, he has seen a civil war's worth of suffering. Violence in the streets seems commonplace and permanent to him. 
 What really stunned him, he said, was when he walked into a gymnasium in enemy territory a few days after the riots and saw members of the city's rival gangs, the Bloods and the Crips, talking and playing basketball like brothers.
 
'Like a Big Family'
 "It was cool," he said the other day. "I never thought I'd ever see anything like that: Crips and Bloods getting along like a big family at Thanksgiving."
A lot of people around Los Angeles are surprised to see signs of accord between the two dangerous gangs, whose members have been sworn enemies for more than two decades.
Because the truce roughly coincided with the April 29 acquittal of four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King, rumors are circulating that it was called so that the Bloods and Crips could join forces against their mutual foe, the Los Angeles Police Department. It is not hard to find police officers who believe this.
But community social workers, police specialists on gang crime and several gang members themselves say they are skeptical that any organized violence against the police is planned. The truce itself has also drawn skepticism, because previous cease-fires have proved short-lived.
The very nature of the Crips and Bloods makes it hard for them to reach such a deal, these experts say. The gangs are not tightly structured, hierarchical organizations, but loose confederations of small neighborhood gangs whose many leaders often act independently of one another.
"The truce ain't everywhere in the city," said Robert Horton, 17, a member of the Athens Park Boys, one of the many subgroups that make up the Bloods. "And it ain't going to last. Maybe a month."
"I hope it does, but it probably won't," said his friend, LaVelle Hayes, 18. Gang violence "has been going on too long," he added. "People's brothers been killed, their mothers, fathers. There are too many grudges."
But during the rioting, a truce of sorts was evident to people who saw Bloods and Crips looting together.
As the members of the Athens Park Boys talked, they constantly watched the passing cars for any sign of a drive-by attack, the most common method of gang retaliation. Mr. Hayes noted that he was still recovering from a gunshot wound from a gang affiliated with the Crips.
And yet, even today there were signs that the peace movement was gathering momentum.
Late today, Charles Norman, the regional director of Community Youth Gang Services, said the truce was spreading across the city.
"It seems solid," he said, adding that Sunday night about 1,600 Bloods and Crips peacefully met at a housing project. "Even the young guys, the ones who might be hardheaded, are being cool. I guess they got a look at what's happening."
Mr. Norman said one member of the Crips said that he had not seen his relatives for 20 years because they lived in a Blood neighborhood. But because of the truce, Mr. Norman said, the man and his relatives "had dinner together for the first time in 20 years."
"They were hugging and crying," Mr. Norman said. "It took the Watts riots to start the gangs. It took another riot to get them to see that they're all in this together."
 
More Than Colors?
 For all the enmity that has existed between the two gangs, an outsider cannot easily tell much difference between them -- except their colors. The Bloods wear red and the Crips wear blue.
Wearing the wrong color in the wrong neighborhood has caused many killings. But during this uncertain truce, Mr. Harris said he saw gang members at the gym with a blue rag hanging from one pocket and a red dangling from the other in a gesture of unity.
The gangs are rooted in the impoverished neighborhoods scattered throughout the South-Central area, other parts of Los Angeles and other cities including Kansas City, Seattle and Phoenix. Their members include all races.
The Crips were established in 1968 and the Bloods were born within the next year. There are no initiation rituals. But some groups within the gangs may require new members to run a gantlet of fist-swinging members, but even this routine is not followed by all Crips and Bloods.
The gangs have a strong grip on the city's imagination, from the studios of Hollywood to the halls of government, especially around election time. Separating fact from myth about their numbers and their influence is often as hard as grabbing a handful of smoke.
 
Riot 'Not a Gang Thing'
 But their grip is also real and dangerous, particularly in struggling inner-city neighborhoods. In Los Angeles County last year, 775 people were killed in gang-related violence. And now investigators are trying to determine exactly what role the street gangs played in the rioting.
That may never be completely known. But Steve Valdivia, executive director of Community Youth Gang Services, said that about a fourth of the area's gang members participated in the South-Central rioting.
"The riot was not a gang thing," he said, adding that most gang members raging through the streets were merely part of an angry mosaic of black, white and Hispanic people who also included residents with 9-to-5 jobs and mothers and their children.
John Mack, president of the Los Angeles Urban League, said too much attention had already been spent contemplating the gangs' role in the rioting. He said that focusing on the gangs obscured the riot's underlying causes: unemployment, poverty and racism.
 
Movement Toward Peace
 Mr. Valdivia said that many informal truce agreements have been reached among many of the gangs but he did not believe it was accompanied by a plan to kill police officers.
Rather, he said, "The gangs are starting to come to the realization that they're all the same, and that it doesn't make sense to be killing your mirror image."
Ed Turley, a field coordinator for Community Youth Gang Services in South-Central Los Angeles, said peace efforts had been in the works months before the officers were acquitted.
"But when the verdict came in," Mr. Turley said, "it was like a 10.0 earthquake that woke everyone up, especially gang members, to the injustice that is happening to minorities. The verdict helped push the process together. The across-the-board not-guilty verdict was a real slap in the face, whether you're a gang member or Joe Citizen."
He quickly added that the truce was an attempt to stop the senseless gang-related violence and not a call to arms against the police. He said there was no evidence that the gangs wanted to take on the police, whom many of the gang members see as simply another, well-armed gang.
"We don't respect them," Mr. Harris, a former member of the Crips, said of the police. "Why should we? They're always taking brothers to Bloods neighborhoods and leaving them to get messed up."
Glenn Newton, a 44-year-old manager of a roller skating rink, lives in South-Central Los Angeles near a wall where anti-police graffiti were scrawled. A week later, the graffiti were covered with fresh paint. "They may have painted it over, but it ain't over with," he said.
"This is just the beginning. This is a civil war that's going to go in and out."
That is what Officer Kevin Robinson and his colleagues at the 77th Division in South-Central Los Angeles are worried about.
Mr. Robinson, who grew up in the area and still lives there, said the police have been the targets of threats and sniper fire since the riots, but it was unclear whether the gangs were responsible.
The officer said the gangs had been talking of uniting for years and recently some of the gang members have become more politicized, wearing Malcolm X hats in their traditional gang colors of blue or red.
"A lot of people are fed up, and they feel that the Malcolm X theory of 'By Any Means Necessary' is the route to take," he said. "They're still fighting for their race. They want to pull together and fight this one battle."
Several current and former gang members and community advocates who work with them said the talk of waging war against the police is not serious and has little to do with the truce.
"They got tired of burying their dead," Mr. Turley said.
Leon Watkins, who operates a counseling service for gang members and their families, said there was no time to wait for the government to stir itself to action.
"We can't continue looking at rebuilding the buildings," he said. "What about the people? What a lot of these guys need is a break and a job."
So he is helping a group of former gang members who are trying to start a small T-shirt business. They call their product "Bone Out" street wear. "Bone out" is an expression used on the street to mean "run away." Gang members shout it out at times of danger.
"We want the kids to 'bone out' from the gangs," he said. "But they can't do it all by themselves. They need some help. This truce could be a peaceful situation or it could be business as usual after a few days. It's up to us, the adults."
Many gang experts, including Michael Genelin, head of the Los Angeles County District Attorney's hard-core gang unit, find it hard to imagine that the truce will spread throughout the 1,000 or more affiliates of the gangs, or that it will last.
"But even if the truce lasts a little while, it's worthwhile," he said, "because during that time someone isn't getting shot or killed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Signs of accord between the Bloods and the Crips, two gangs, have caused rumors that they may join forces against the police; the graffito "LAPD 187" refers to a penal code number for homicide. But many experts are skeptical that any organized violence against the police is planned. (Angel Franco/The New York Times) (pg. A21)

HEADLINE: Bush and Congress Facing a Showdown on Forests

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Galvanized by a classic conflict between jobs and the preservation of the Pacific Northwest's virgin timber and the home it provides wildlife, the Bush Administration and Democrats in Congress are heading for a showdown that could test the influence of a growing anti-environmental backlash.
At issue are unlogged forests in Northern California, Oregon and Washington. Even as a Cabinet-level committee votes this week on how much forest should be cut, two committees of the House are set to deal with proposals that would protect endangered species by identifying and preserving ranges covering millions of acres. 
 The competing ideas reflect radically different views of the value of saving untouched areas. They also represent the start of a high-stakes battle over the 19-year-old Endangered Species Act, the strongest legal tool for preserving wild areas.
In response to environmentalists' pressure, the Department of Interior in 1989 designated the northern spotted owl a threatened species across its range of temperate rain forests in the Pacific Northwest. The law required the Government to develop a plan to safeguard the owl by identifying and preserving the areas where it lives.
 
Outcry in Communities
 But environmentalists said the Administration was ignoring that requirement. They brought three lawsuits that resulted in court orders temporarily setting aside almost eight million acres of timberland from clear cutting, a process in which the land is cleared of every tree, the brush burned and the ground replanted.
The result was an outcry in dozens of communities that rely on timber. "The Endangered Species Act leaves economic consideration, human considerations, jobs and common sense out of the loop," said Bill Moshofsky, a vice president of Oregonians in Action, a statewide group that is seeking to rewrite environmental laws. "The sense people have here is that this was a manufactured crisis in order for the preservationists to achieve their objective, which was to stop harvesting trees."
On Thursday, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is to deliver the long-awaited plan for preserving the owl, but the chances of its being put into effect are slim.
The reason, White House aides say, is that the Administration is intent on using the timber struggle to loosen the Endangered Species Act, which it says restricts economic development and intrudes on the lives of citizens. Saying that he wanted to bypass the law, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. cast the struggle in the Northwest as one that put a few little owls in the path of thousands of jobs.
In the last year, Mr. Lujan convened a Cabinet-level group, known as the God Squad, to decide how much timber should be cut on 44 tracts of Federal timberland in Oregon that otherwise would be virtually off limits under the Endangered Species Act.
Mr. Lujan also called on aides to develop a separate plan for cutting the forests that would waive many of the requirements of the Endangered Species Act. The proposal is likely to be introduced as legislation by Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. The Cabinet vote and the public disclosure of the Administration's forest plan are also scheduled for Thursday.
"This Administration is not going to stand by and have 32,000 people lose their jobs," said Steve Goldstein, the chief spokesman for the Interior Department. "At some point Congress has to step up to the plate and determine whether the loss of 32,000 jobs is too high a price."
Democrats in Congress would take a much different approach. Both bills now in the House would slow the harvest of ancient timber and make available millions of dollars for retraining workers and restoring lands ruined by clear cutting. The issue, Democrats say, is not jobs versus owls but finding a new way to prevent plants and animals from going extinct by protecting the areas in which they live.
"My view is that the Administration has politicized the process and trivialized the Endangered Species Act by talking about one animal at a time," said Representative Bruce F. Vento, a Minnesota Democrat who is a co-sponsor of one of the House proposals.
Mr. Vento's proposal, which he developed with Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Interior Committee, would set aside roughly eight million acres of land to remain uncut, and put one million acres out of reach of loggers temporarily for research.
In addition, the bill would provide millions of dollars to timber communities for replanting the forest and restoring streams and slopes scarred by clear cutting. A separate proposal approved by a House Agriculture subcommittee would preserve fewer acres.
Both bills are to be considered by the full Interior and Agriculture committees soon.

HEADLINE: Judge Finds Driver Union In Contempt

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled last night that a newspaper truck-drivers' union was in contempt of court for disrupting circulation of The New York Times in a labor dispute involving the newspaper, the union and a wholesale delivery operation. He ordered the union to pay The Times $100,000 for every hour of further disruption of the newspaper's weekday and Saturday deliveries and $500,000 for every hour of disruption of the paper's Sunday delivery.
The judge's ruling came on a day in which action on many fronts significantly intensified the union's six-day-old labor dispute with the wholesaler, Imperial Delivery Service, and The Times. Arthur E. Imperatore, who owns Imperial, said one of his employees had been kidnapped and threatened with death. 
 Union and company officials said that a meeting of the membership of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity this afternoon would be pivotal in trying to resolve the dispute.
 
Meeting This Afternoon
 The Allied Printing Trades Council, which includes all the unions working at The Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, invited representatives of Imperial and The Times to meet with it this morning. But both The Times and Imperial declined on the grounds that such a meeting would serve no purpose, and their refusal focused importance on the drivers' union meeting this afternoon.
In a ruling issued at 10:12 P.M. yesterday, Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court found the union in contempt of a temporary restraining order that he had granted on Thursday. Earlier in the day, he had extended the order through May 22.
In addition to asking for fines for further damage, The Times had also asked for restitution to compensate for losses of more than $2 million that had already been incurred because of delivery disruptions. The judge agreed last night to grant compensatory damages, but did not specify the award, pending the receipt of further documents from the newspaper. In documents filed with Judge Leval, The Times had cited a burned truck, punctured brake lines of four trucks, two bomb threats, stink bombs planted at printing plants, punctured tires and other incidents that it said violated the order.
In issuing his decision, Judge Leval criticized the union leadership for making only "token" efforts to ensure that union members obeyed the restraining order. "Virtually no effort was made to induce picketing members to allow deliveries to take place," the judge wrote in his seven-page decision. "No efforts were made to enforce union discipline against violators."
Michael J. Kurtz, the vice president for human resources at The Times, applauded the judge's ruling last night, saying he hoped the union would take the fines more seriously than it had taken the temporary restraining order. "It puts the entire union treasury at stake," he said.
George McDonald, the president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, agreed that the fines, if imposed, would be costly. "I don't think they have $100,000 in the union treasury," Mr. McDonald said. "The fines that the judge put down are awfully heavy. I think they are ridiculous."
On what was described as the kidnapping of an Imperial employee, Mr. Imperatore, the owner of the wholesaler, said at a news conference yesterday that one of his foremen was abducted at gunpoint, roughed up and held for 12 hours before being released.
Shaking with rage, Mr. Imperatore denounced the unknown men he said abducted the foreman, Munir Fahreddine, as "gangsters and terrorists" who were "using labor to justify extortion, blackmail and violence." He offered a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the kidnappers.
Douglas LaChance, president of the union, "totally disavowed" the kidnapping. "If a radical fringe did it, they did a disservice to the union, the union's unemployed members and the labor movement," he said. But he characterized Mr. Fahreddine as "a turncoat" who had been a union member until switching to a management position for Imperial just before the labor dispute began last week.
At his news conference, Mr. Imperatore seemed to rule out any accommodation with the union because of what had happened to his foreman. "I won't hire hoodlums and gangsters," he said. Asked if he was referring to the entire union, Mr. Imperatore said, "I'm talking about the hoodlums, gangsters and terrorists, and I can't separate them out."
But despite Mr. Imperatore's comments, John M. O'Brien, a deputy general manager at The Times who is in charge of the negotiations, said late yesterday that The Times still believed the only solution to the labor dispute was for the union to pass the contracts it had previously rejected. Implicit in such a solution is that, should the contracts be approved, Imperial would rehire union members whose jobs were filled by new employees on Thursday.
 
Rehiring Is Critical
 Mr. O'Brien added, though, that "Anything The New York Times would consider would not in any way offend Mr. Imperatore; our interests are identical."
The issue of rehiring is critical because, should Imperial not offer to rehire the drivers, the prospects would dim for winning approval of other contracts covering The Times's new $450 million printing plant in Edison, N.J., and another wholesaler operation that may be acquired by The New York Times.
The drivers who lost their jobs were employees of Westfair Newspaper Distributors, located north of the city in New Rochelle, where Mr. Fahreddine works, and Newspaper Distributors Company, in East Farmingdale, L.I. Mr. Imperatore bought the two wholesalers in a transaction that did not include their existing contracts.
In February, The Times announced its intention to buy two other distributors, Newark Newsdealers Supply Company and Metropolitan News Company, which distribute The Times in New Jersey and New York City. The Times and Mr. Imperatore negotiated new contracts with the union in an effort to keep the old workers, but at a lower cost.
From The Times's perspective, the union negotiations were part of a broader effort to cut labor costs to justify its investment in the Edison printing plant. From the union's perspective, the strategy was to extract the best possible deal from The Times and Imperial in exchange for concessions in work rules and overtime.
The union's leaders had agreed to the contracts because the alternative was to lose jobs or live with work rules greatly altered by binding arbitration without the inducements included in the contracts.
But the contracts were subject to approval by the entire 2,900-member union, which includes groups working at The Times, The New York Post, The Daily News, The Newark Star-Ledger, the wholesalers and some other operations. Such unionwide voting is common among printing trade unions, but the procedure allows union members not directly involved to determine the fate of groups at individual operations.
Though the union's leadership endorsed the contracts, about 57 percent of the membership voted against them, and they remain intensely unpopular with many union members, who have called them attempts to break the union.
When the contracts were defeated, Imperial hired new drivers the following day to fill 220 jobs previously held by union members, prompting the union to picket the centers. Members of the same union drive Times trucks loaded with papers to the distribution centers, where they are delivered to newsstands and other outlets by the wholesaler.
The battle for popular support in the dispute mounted yesterday, as Mr. Imperatore purchased a full-page advertisement in The Times to defend his record as a longtime successful employer of union labor. Both Mr. Imperatore and The Times called news conferences to defend their positions.
Lance R. Primis, president of The Times, said that there was successful delivery yesterday of about 92 percent of the 227,000 papers intended for newsstands and residences in Fairfield County and Westchester County and Long Island. In comparison, about 30 percent of the 342,000 Sunday papers for the area reached their destination. But Mr. LaChance disputed the number, saying that copies of The Times were very hard to find Monday morning in the affected area.
The kidnapping incident seems to have escalated the violence level well beyond what union leaders said was understandable or forgivable in such a situation. Indeed, some union leaders said that the incident was so shocking that it could trigger a reconsideration of the contracts, as an alternative to a further potential escalation of violence, which could spread to other unions and widen the conflict dangerously.
Milt Ahlerich, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Connecticut office, said yesterday that the office, in New Haven, was conducting a "preliminary investigation to ascertain whether or not to initiate a full field investigation" under Federal kidnapping statutes. Mr. Ahlerich said in an interview that the decision on whether to proceed would be made quickly, possibly by today.
 
'Alleged Abduction'
 The police in Danbury, Conn., said only that they were investigating "an alleged abduction and assault" in which an unnamed complainant said he was abducted at gunpoint, forced to abandon his vehicle, forced into another vehicle and dropped later in Pawling, N.Y.
A lawyer for Mr. Imperatore, Jerold Glassman of Grotta, Glassman & Hoffman, yesterday made available a videotape that he said showed Mr. Fahreddine being interviewed by another lawyer of the firm at Mr. Fahreddine's Danbury home after his release and questioning by the Danbury police.
Mr. Fahreddine has an unlisted number and could not be reached directly. Mr. Glassman said Mr. Fahreddine was still too upset to be interviewed yesterday.
On the tape, Mr. Fahreddine appeared to have a bruise on his upper right forehead. He said he was stopped in his car about 6:45 P.M. Saturday near Route 7 when a gunman jumped in his car, stuck a .38 revolver in his stomach and made him drive a short distance to where he was forced into a dark gray Pathfinder van with three other men.
He said he was blindfolded and driven about an hour to a gravel road where he was taken out of the car, forced into a house or building told to take off his clothes and lie on a bedsheet. One of the men, he said, then started "bouncing" on his back, where he had suffered a job injury several months ago.
He said one of the men said, "You call the cops and we'll blow your head off." The man also threatened his children, Mr. Fahreddine said on the tape.
About eight hours later, he said he was told to dress, driven to route 22 near Pawling, and told to walk away across the highway where he telephoned the police from a Grand Union.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I won't hire hoodlums and gangsters," Arthur E. Imperatore, owner of Imperial Delivery Service, said at a news conference. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. B4)
 
Chart: "The Issues: The Background of the Labor Dispute"
 
When the dispute began
 On Wednesday, the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity rejected contracts covering drivers for four wholesale newspaper delivery companies.
 
Who was involved
 Two of the companies are in the process of being acquired by The New York Times. They are Newark Newsdealers Supply Company and Metropolitan News Company, which deliver in New Jersey and New York City. Two were bought on Thrusday by Arthur E. Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking and real estate entrepreneur. They are Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle and Newspaper Distributors Company in East Farmingdale.
 
How it occurred
Since labor contracts do not survive the sale of assets, the purchases, in effect, invalidated contracts with the former owner which would have expired in 1993. This greatly upset drivers. New contracts were agreed to last month by The Times, Mr. Imperatore and the union's president and executive committee.
 
What was in the contract
 The contracts would have given drivers job security at The Times and at the wholesale operations, increases in base pay, contributions to welfare and pension funds and severance bonuses but would have eliminated over-time - cutting the income of most drivers in half, to about $40,000 a year - and would have changed work rules.
 
What followed the rejection
 In response to the drivers' rejection of the contract, Mr. Imperatore on Thursday hired new workers at the New Rochelle and East Farmingdale wholesalers. The union then sent up picket lines and the scattered violence and delivery disruption began. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
In the first swap of emissions allowances, the T.V.A. and Wisconsin Power and Light will announce that they have signed a contract that calls for the T.V.A. to buy the right to emit some sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, freeing it from having to clean up its own plants as stringently. It could break the ice for dozens of similar deals. The price was not disclosed but is believed to be around $2.5 million to $3 million. [Page A1.] 
 Seeking to block an increase in the premiums banks pay to the deposit insurance fund, bankers and Administration officials said they were close to victory on the eve of a pivotal vote. [D1.]
Investors who bring complaints against brokers cannot be sure of getting a competent and impartial hearing, the G.A.O. concluded, unless improvements are made in the way arbitrators are recruited and trained. [D1.]
College graduates are entering one of the toughest job markets that any class has seen in decades. [A1.]
The percentage of workers earning less than $12,195 grew sharply in the last decade, a long-delayed U.S. report shows. [A15.]
 
Companies
G. Heileman Brewing is introducing a malt liquor similar to Power Master, which it withdrew when regulators said the name emphasized its high alcohol content and advocates complained that the product was aimed at young black men. [D1.]
Wal-Mart produced another set of stunning numbers -- profits up 26.1 percent -- as retailers started reporting earnings. [D5.]
Hughes Aircraft agreed to acquire General Dynamics' missile business for stock worth at least $450 million. [D5.]
Thrifty Rent-a-Car plans to push its personality in a new direction: more fun for both employees and customers. [D5.]
Has Oldsmobile's Achieva lived up to its name? The evidence is mixed. [D5.]
Scott C. Newquist suddenly left Kidder, Peabody, where he was head of investment banking, because of what he called "differences of management style and philosophy." [D6.]
Astra is cutting the price of Foscavir, an eye drug that is one of the most expensive treatments for an AIDS-related disease, for patients in Federal public health programs. [D6.]
Ecogen will name James P. Reilly Jr. as its president and chief operating officer. [D6.]
Some U.S. wine makers have learned a new word, value, after decades of using mystique, prestige and cachet. [D1.]
A judge found a newspaper truck-drivers' union in contempt of court for disrupting circulation of The New York Times. [B1.]
 
International
In Japan, a powerful sense of anxiety underlies the thinking of most business executives these days. [D1.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks rose to record highs, propelled by optimism that the Fed will lower interest rates another notch. The Dow gained 28.17, to 3,397.58. [D1.]
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in quiet action, as traders awaited other economic data. [D19.]
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet dealings. Gold prices were mixed. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Universal Health Care Plan Is Goal of Law in Vermont

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BENNINGTON, Vt., May 11

 BODY:
Gov. Howard Dean, the only Governor who is a doctor, signed a law here today that sets in motion a plan to give Vermont universal health care by 1995.
The law is one of the more ambitious in a series of recent efforts by states to tackle the problems of runaway medical costs and the increasing numbers of uninsured. Oregon, Minnesota and Florida have also passed comprehensive health insurance plans, as states have begun to act in the absence of Federal initiatives. 
 The Vermont law creates a state agency, the Health Care Authority, that will have the power to bargain for health insurance for the state's residents, using what Governor Dean called "enormous leverage" to gain better coverage at lower rates.
 
Final Decisions in 1994
 The agency will draw up proposals on how to pay for universal health care by next year. And it will provide detailed studies to the Legislature on whether the state should rely on private insurance companies or should follow the example of Canada and insure itself. The Legislature must decide on the final shape of the new system in late 1994.
"This is an incredibly exciting moment that should make all Vermonters proud," said Governor Dean, who signed the bill in a ceremony at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center here.
The law was supported by both parties in the Legislature, as well as the Vermont Medical Society and some insurers, including Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Vermont. The support of Governor Dean, a moderate Democrat and a specialist in internal medicine, was considered critical to the law's passage, as his backing reassured the health care industry and other businesses worried about the practicality of a new system.
 
Too Much or Not Enough?
 Nonetheless, several insurance companies, fearing increased regulation and decreased profits, have threatened to leave the state.
And some Democrats here have criticized the law for not going far enough or moving soon enough. The law's only immediate impact, for example, will be to extend state-sponsored health insurance to all children in low-income families.
Senator Cheryl Rivers, a Democrat who sponsored a rival bill that would have gone into effect sooner and would have created a Canadian-style system with Vermont insuring itself, said: "This is only a small step forward. The main thing it does is postpone the major decisions for two years, when the costs will be even higher."
But Governor Dean and Republicans here opposed her plan -- called a "single-payer" scheme -- as too expensive.
"Their package would have cost $500 million in a state with a total budget of $1.3 billion," Governor Dean said. "They would have created an entitlement program we can't pay for. We've got to control costs first to get an effective health care plan."
In the end, the two sides negotiated a compromise, agreeing to have the new health care agency study the costs of both a single-payer and a multi-payer plan that included private insurance companies closely regulated by the state.
The centerpiece of the new law is the Health Care Authority, which will have three executives, all selected by Governor Dean. It will consolidate the functions of several overlapping state agencies, a duplication that the state estimates accounts for 15 to 17 percent of annual health care costs.
 
Financing the System
 The authority will study how much medical procedures cost in Vermont, and will eventually set a ceiling on the state's overall health-care budget, Governor Dean said. Vermonters will use common claim forms.
"The two broad aims are to guarantee access to all by limiting costs and to reallocate resources away from expensive procedures to emphasizing primary and preventive care," Governor Dean said in an interview. "We do twice as many high-tech procedures as many other countries but the results aren't any different."
The new law also aims to reduce the cost of malpractice insurance by setting up an arbitration panel before malpractice cases go to court. It bans "cherry picking," a practice in which some insurance companies offer coverage only to groups of people who are low risk. And it sets up a common health insurance purchasing pool for state employees, which can be joined later by other groups.
There will be two basic options of how to pay for the new system. In one, individuals and group plans would continue to make payments, to be channeled through the state system. Under the other, backed by Governor Dean, payments would be made by a state trust fund, supported by some combination of new taxes.
"We've got to divorce health insurance from the employer-employee relationship," the Governor said, calling that relationship an accident of history that has created inequality and made reform difficult.
If health insurance is not separated from employment, he said, "we're going to continue to have problems with unemployed people, with people who change jobs" and with people who work for small employers that do not provide insurance.
 
Other States' Plans
 Among other states that have expanded access to health insurance, Hawaii has the oldest and the most comprehensive laws, requiring employers to pay for insurance premiums for any employee working more than 20 hours a week.
Most recently, Minnesota enacted legislation that would, among other things, provide health insurance to the uninsured by taxing hospitals, doctors, and other health care businesses.
Under a bill passed in March, insurers in Florida have two years to demonstrate they can come up with health care packages that most employers can afford; after that, mandates are recommended to the legislature.
Oregon is awaiting approval from the Federal Government for its plan to insure under its Medicaid program all families living at or below the poverty level. The Oregon law would also force employers of three or more people to provide health insurance or pay into an insurance fund by July 1995.
In Massachusetts, the Legislature pushed back, to 1995, the deadline for a similar proposal requiring employers of six or more to provide health insurance.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont signing into law a health bill that would give the state universal health care by 1995. (Jon Gilbert Fox for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Study Says Big Cities Don't Get Fair Share of Military Spending

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
A study made public today says most of the nation's major cities are paying out far more in taxes for the Pentagon than they receive in military spending, contributing to their severe financial problems.
The Boston Redevelopment Authority study, done by Employment Research Associates, an economic consulting firm based in Lansing, Mich., found that in 1990, New York City experienced a net loss of $8.38 billion to the Pentagon, Los Angeles a loss of $3.27 billion, and Chicago a loss of $3.1 billion. In each of those cities, according to the study, the loss to military spending came to $3,000 or more per family. 
 "The riots in Los Angeles show what happens when billions of tax dollars are annually drained from a city," said Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, who is president of the United States Conference of Mayors.
The study said that 19 of the nation's 25 largest cities paid out more to the Pentagon than they received from military contracts, salaries and bases. Houston had a net loss of $1.77 billion, Phoenix of $1.08 billion and Boston of $682 million.
The study found that San Diego enjoyed a $3.97 billion net gain in military spending, and the District of Columbia had a $1.49 billion net gain. Seattle, New Orleans and Baltimore were among the cities that had a net gain.
"The military budget guarantees depletion and deprivation for large areas of our country," said James Anderson, an economics professor at Michigan State University who directed the study. He criticized the Pentagon as diverting money away from public and private investment, which he said does more than military spending to increase productivity.
According to the study, the net loss suffered by New York costs the city 250,000 permanent jobs, while the loss for Los Angeles and Chicago cost each of those cities 100,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Democrats Agree to Assist Bush On Investing in Poor Urban Areas

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders, who have long been unenthusiastic about urban enterprise zones, pledged today to work with President Bush to encourage investment in the impoverished inner cities.
The idea of enterprise zones, which has long been promoted by Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was embraced by President Bush in the aftermath of the recent riots in Los Angeles after he had given it only tepid support in the last three years. 
 Today, Democratic leaders in Congress made public a letter they had sent Mr. Bush telling him they planned to work with him to pass legislation for creating urban enterprise zones without delay.
"Americans need to know that their President and Congress, whatever their differences, can work together to meet urgent national needs," said the letter, which was signed by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
 
Criticism for Bush
 At the same time, Mr. Mitchell chided the President for vetoing a recent tax measure that was primarily intended to give relief to the middle class and that included incentives for business to invest in the inner cities.
And Mr. Gephardt criticized Mr. Bush for his record on domestic affairs, saying: "The President has pushed the snooze button on the domestic alarm clock long enough. Now he can afford to slumber no longer."
The Democratic leaders proposed that the plan for enterprise zones be considered separately from a tax bill.
Generally, the Democrats appeared to be striving for a conciliatory tone in preparation for a meeting with Mr. Bush and Republican Congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday, the first such meeting to discuss domestic policy this year.
In the letter, the Democrats commended Mr. Bush's tour of South-Central Los Angeles last week and proposed to cooperate because "no one benefits if differences of opinion paralyze our society's response."
The letter continued: "We believe incentives for economic growth and restoration; the urgent need to combat crime and random violence; and a deeper commitment by Government, business, and individuals to constructive, supportive family policy. All these constitute a common ground."
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, responded positively to the Democratic gesture as Mr. Bush toured an area in North Philadelphia that was once a thriving manufacturing district but now is home to a lively drug trade.
"We'll probably have a good debate over the methods and means, the tax rates and enterprise zones," Mr. Fitzwater said, "but these things can be worked out. We're willing to compromise."
The tour of the blighted area was added at the last minute. Mr. Bush had already planned the trip to Philadelphia, where tonight he attended a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner.
The Democratic leaders urged Mr. Bush to extend unemployment insurance to many thousands of workers who currently do not qualify, add to financing for a summer youth jobs program and revise his budget request to provide for $3.6 billion in additional public works projects under the 1991 transportation act.
The Democrats also called on Mr. Bush to back a Democratic-inspired crime bill, including extensions of gun control and the death penalty, that has been pending in the Senate for months because of threats of a Republican filibuster. The Republicans charge that the bill would allow endless appeals to death-row inmates.
Democratic Senate strategists are considering calling the Republicans' bluff and embarrassing Mr. Bush, by daring them to filibuster a bill that they contend would strengthen the hand of local police in stemming gang violence and drug offenses.
