HEADLINE: Banks Aim To Block Fee Rise

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
On the eve of a pivotal regulatory vote for the banking industry, bankers and Bush Administration officials said today that they were close to victory in their drive to block any increase in the premiums banks pay to the deposit insurance fund.
Bank representatives who have met with the five members of the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in anticipation of Tuesday's decision said today that they had at least two votes to put off a premium increase and thought that they would be able to convince a swing vote. 
 The insurance fund says it has a deficit, and Congress and some regulators believe it must be buttressed with additional funds. But bankers argue that a premium increase will weaken their industry just as it has begun to recover, and the Administration says any premium increase will ripple through the economy and slow down growth.
 
Now 23 on Every $100
 Premium costs, now 23 cents for every $100 in deposits, are ultimately paid by stockholders, who will get lower returns if premiums are raised, and bank customers, who will pay higher fees and receive lower yields. They are also borne to some extent by taxpayers, since banks can write off a percentage of their premiums on their corporate taxes.
Besieged by intense lobbying from the industry and the Bush Administration, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which had said last year that it would consider an increase in 1992, decided last month to postpone any increase before Jan. 1. The vote on Tuesday will be on a proposal to raise premiums, probably by between 2 cents and 7 cents for every $100 in deposits, starting in 1993.
"It's a substantial money decision," said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. "It will have an impact on banks' profitability, and it will have a macroeconomic impact."
The issue puts William Taylor, the head of the deposit insurer and chief proponent of an increase, in a difficult position. His term expires in February, and he faces the strongly conflicting crosscurrents of the Bush Administration, with its belief that an increase will dampen the economic recovery, and Congress, which has urged a premium increase to avoid an embarrassing repeat of the huge bailout of the savings industry.
The proposed increase would differ among institutions because the F.D.I.C. is expected to vote to phase out the flat rate in favor of a new fee structure that assesses each institution depending upon its financial health, with weaker banks paying more. The strongest institutions, which are generally smaller ones, would be expected to pay an increase of about 2 cents, while the weaker ones might end up paying an additional 7 cents.
An increase has been repeatedly demanded by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee, which will have to decide whether to confirm Mr. Taylor if he is nominated for a second term.
At the urging of the banks, the proposed premium increase has been just as staunchly opposed by Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, who says the F.D.I.C. should wait until the end of the year to decide whether to increase premiums. He says the proposal is a threat to easier lending and a serious impediment to economic growth.
 
A Fundamental Disagreement
 The debate also reflects a fundamental disagreement between the banks and Mr. Taylor about the condition of both the industry and the bank insurance fund. Mr. Taylor has told associates that he is not firmly convinced that the worst is over for the banks. He says he believes that the insurance fund will once again lose more money this year than it receives in premiums and that if he errs, it should be on the side of reserving too much instead of not enough.
He has also said that the fund, with a deficit of $7 billion to $9 billion, is already dangerously undercapitalized and needs to be rebuilt as quickly as possible.
But bank lobbyists say that those figures already have reserves built into them for anticipated losses and that Mr. Taylor is unreasonably pessimistic about an industry that has begun to recover. They point to the fact that the agency has already seized far fewer institutions this year than it had predicted.
 
51 Banks Seized This Year
 Last year, Mr. Taylor said that 200 bank failures were expected in 1992 involving institutions that hold $86 billion in assets. So far this year, the F.D.I.C. has seized only 51 banks holding $16.1 billion.
"Taylor's crying wolf," said Bert Ely, a banking consultant who has been lobbying the deposit insurer for the industry. "He hasn't made the case. The losses aren't there and they don't need the money."
He added that a defeat for Mr. Taylor would be a serious setback for his ability to lead the agency.
"The chairman doesn't look very chairman-like and very powerful if he's losing votes," Mr. Ely said. "It does not enhance his stature."
Two of the board members -- T. Timothy Ryan Jr. and Stephen R. Steinbrink -- head agencies in the Treasury Department and are expected by the industry to support the Administration's view and reject an increase. Mr. Taylor is expected to have the support of C. C. Hope Jr., a former North Carolina banker. The swing vote of Andrew C. Hove Jr., the board's vice chairman, is unknown.
 
'A Compelling Argument'
 "The fund is still losing a lot of money, and that's a compelling argument to do something," Mr. Hove said in an interview this afternoon. "The decision is going to affect the costs to the entire industry. It affects the fund's viability, and the public's perception of it."
Board members including Mr. Taylor have said they have never faced more intense industry and political pressures than over the proposed rate increase.
"We get kind of passionate about this," said Thomas L. Ashley, a friend and adviser of President Bush and head of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, which represents many of the nation's largest institutions.
Mr. Ashley has met with most of the board members in recent days to tell them that he thinks the increase is unnecessary.
"The losses are not there," he said. "But the F.D.I.C. is acceding to the General Accounting Office's view that more reserves are needed, and the G.A.O. is reflecting the embarrassment of Congress from the thrift disaster.
"Taylor sees the world, as he should, as a regulator. He doesn't see the world in the broad economic terms of the economy and what's needed to promote and sustain a recovery."

HEADLINE: Thais Plan a Way to End Army Rule

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 11

 BODY:
A weeklong demonstration that has effectively paralyzed Thailand's military-dominated Government was suspended early this morning after opposition leaders said they would support an amendment to the Constitution to require the Prime Minister to be an elected member of Parliament.
Tens of thousands of students, workers and members of this rapidly developing country's prosperous new middle class have turned out to protest the appointment of a former commander of the armed forces, Suchinda Kraprayoon, to head the Government. The former general, who led a military coup last year, had not run in the March 22 parliamentary elections. 
 Early this morning, Chamlong Srimuang, who set off the mass demonstrations on May 3 by going on a hunger strike until the Prime Minister stepped down, called on his followers to go home but to return Sunday if the Suchinda Government does not live up to its commitment to constitutional changes.
 
King May Have Intervened
 Mr. Chamlong, also a former general, had ended his fast on Saturday, saying he was doing so in order to continue more effectively the struggle for democracy.
There have been widespread reports that Mr. Chamlong's decision followed a discreet intervention by King Bhumibol Adulyadej. The revered ruler, whose influence reaches far beyond his limited political power, is said to have obtained agreement from Mr. Suchinda not to use force to disperse the demonstrators if Mr. Chamlong abandons his threat to commit slow public suicide.
The fast by Mr. Chamlong, who as Governor of Bangkok gained a reputation for austere honesty in a country that has long tolerated considerable corruption, had raised the political temperature to heights rarely experienced in this blase nation.
On Saturday, to the open disappointment of the students most committed to breaking the cycle of military intrusion into supposedly democratic politics, leaders of the five Government and four opposition parties agreed to put forward constitutional amendments that would enhance the power of elected officials. But Arthit Urairath, the Speaker of Parliament, rejected demands from many of the protesters that the governing parties commit themselves in writing not to oppose the amendments.
 
A Sign of Stubbornness
 Today, Mr. Suchinda reaffirmed his refusal to resign. In political circles it is assumed that Mr. Suchinda could comply with a constitutional change by obtaining a parliamentary seat in a district where support for him is strong.
The former commander, who pledged last year that the coup he led was not intended to make him leader of the Government, was appointed by the majority parties after a civilian candidate put forward by the governing coalition had to step down because of suspicions of drug-dealing. The news was leaked in Washington that his suspected involvement in narcotics would make him ineligible to visit the United States, Thailand's principal international supporter.
Despite today's agreement, the crisis appears far from resolved. A former member of Parliament, Chalard Worachat, went on a public hunger strike to demand Mr. Suchinda's resignation even before Mr. Chamlong did. He interrupted his fast earlier but returned to it when Mr. Chamlong announced his action. Today he said he would continue to his death unless Mr. Suchinda gave up.
Given the continuing tension, such a death, or any other major incident, could bring out masses of protesters even before Sunday and might provoke military action.
 
A New Pool of Protesters
 Television coverage has suffered from clear signs of military censorship, but the press, which has remained free throughout the dispute, has emphasized that no public support for the Prime Minister has been evident in response to the mass opposition.
Political commentators have described Mr. Suchinda as greatly weakened by the protests and unlikely to remain Prime Minister for long.
The presence among the demonstrators of middle-aged and young professionals, including Government officials, is a new element in Thai politics. Speculation centers on whether the growth of a politically active middle class, spawned by the rapid economic expansion in recent years, has now become a serious obstacle to the traditional role of the military as the ultimate arbiter of politics

HEADLINE: European Nations to Recall Envoys From Belgrade

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 11

 BODY:
Struggling to force Serbia to end its military attacks in the newly independent republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, European Community governments decided today to recall their ambassadors from Belgrade and seek the international isolation of what remains of Yugoslavia.
At a meeting in Brussels, community foreign ministers also backed United States efforts to have Serbia and Montenegro suspended from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and threatened to tighten existing economic sanctions against Belgrade into "a total embargo." 
 Coming 10 months after Western Europe first tried to broker a peace in Yugoslavia, however, today's meeting was dominated by the 12 nations' deep sense of frustration at their failure to curb military offensives by the Serb-dominated federal Yugoslav Army.
 
'Just Have to Persevere'
 "Cease-fires are negotiated and broken, agreements are negotiated and broken," Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said after the daylong meeting. "You just have to persevere."
In a statement, the 12 ministers said Belgrade's role in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where 1,300 people have died in fighting over the past six weeks, deserved "universal condemnation." They also described the Serbian forces as an army of occupation.
Among the former Yugoslav republics, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Slovenia and Croatia have won recognition from the European Community and the United States. Serbia and Montenegro have decided to remain united in a reduced Yugoslavia, although Serbia claims to represent Serbian minorities in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
The Question of Macedonia
 The sixth republic of the old Yugoslav federation, Macedonia, has also declared its independence, but Greece has so far blocked its recognition by the community, arguing that the republic's determination to be called Macedonia masks territorial ambitions over the adjacent Greek province of the same name.
Although Greece's community partners are growing impatient with its use of its veto, the foreign ministers today once again postponed recognizing Macedonia.
The foreign ministers also said they would seek to exclude Serbia and Montenegro from taking part in debates on the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina at the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is meeting in Helsinki, Finland.
The Helsinki European Conference normally works through consensus, permitting any single government to block decisions. To break this deadlock, a draft resolution calls for Belgrade's suspension from the Yugoslav debate until June 30, but this proposal has so far been blocked by Russia, which fears setting a precedent that could one day affect its own interests.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
No U.S. Move Announced
 WASHINGTON, May 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- The deputy State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today that the United States had not had time to discuss with the European Community the decision to recall ambassadors from Yugoslavia.
Asked if the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia was likely to be withdrawn, Mr. Boucher said that a number of options were available and that "I can't at this point really speculate on how quickly or when we might move on any specific one."

HEADLINE: A Downturn With a Difference

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 11

 BODY:
With Japanese economic growth slowing, Sadahiko Hidaka took a few minutes recently to tally the costs of the downturn on the metal fabrication company he heads.
He said he expected his company's sales to drop 20 percent this year from last year's $15 million, because of cutbacks by his customers, which are big manufacturers like auto, shipbuilding and weapons companies. 
 But, Mr. Hidaka said, he does not plan to lay off any of his 130 employees or to shut a plant.
The most visible sign of adjustment may be that Mr. Hidaka has decided not to replace his company's almost-new autos this year.
 
Not the Usual Symptoms
 The responses of companies like Mr. Hidaka's, a subcontractor at the core of Japan's industrial machine, make the looming economic downturn puzzling to many in the West, where a slumping economy is synonymous with unemployment, plant closings and cost controls.
But even if Japan's jobless rate does not rise much above its current level of 2.1 percent, a powerful sense of anxiety underlies the thinking of most business executives these days. Economists are warning that this could prove the deepest recession in several decades, particularly for Japan's manufacturing sector.
Perhaps worse, there are signs that companies like Mr. Hidaka's face a daunting test because their markets are not simply weak, but changing. The lack of unemployment is concealing an array of other problems, many experts are saying.
"The key thing to be watching is not whether there is unemployment, but whether people are cutting their expenditures," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "That is why we are getting more and more worried about where we are going. Some indicators may be holding up, but my feeling is that they are barely holding up."
For instance, though nobody is being laid off at the Hidaka Seiki Company, Mr. Hidaka's precision fabrication concern, all overtime has been stopped, which means workers are losing a significant portion of their income and spending power.
The company is also squeezing its own suppliers by placing fewer orders, another blow to wages and spending.
And, perhaps most important, the company cannot resort to its old cure-all -- an export drive -- to bolster sales. Weak markets overseas and heavy political pressure at home to ease tense trade relations with the United States have made it difficult for companies to unload their goods at cut-rate prices abroad. Japan's trade surplus is already headed for a record this year, of more than $125 billion, and the Government is urging companies to focus on imports to mitigate the problem.
 
New-Products Time
 The point, Mr. Hidaka said, is that he will have to steer his company in a new direction, looking for new markets and new products during the slowdown.
"We see this as a period of adjustment that is different from slowdowns we've experienced in the past," he said. "Every product has a life span, and so do industries. We don't think automobiles will be the leading industry forever. The only answer is to develop new products during this period. You have to be forward looking in this kind of time or you won't survive.
"In one way it is more serious because we can't see the future. If this does continue next year, then we will have an entirely new situation. We would have to start thinking about layoffs."
Of course, what Mr. Hidaka did not say, but what many in the West fear, is that if he and other Japanese manufacturers succeed, they may emerge from the grip of this slowdown even more competitive relative to their American counterparts.
Although the Government has not officially declared the economy in recession -- the definition is vague but it is usually growth of less than 3 percent a year -- the signs of a severe slowdown are everywhere, side by side with continuing signs of underlying strength, remnants of the five-year boom that left Japanese industry in a far more competitive position.
The economy shrank at an annualized rate of two-tenths of a percent in the last three months of 1991, and the signs are pointing to more contraction for a while.
Nonetheless, most economists are forecasting growth of around 2 percent for the entire year, a sharp slowdown from last year's 4.5 percent rate, but a respectable pace by American standards.
Department store sales fell 4.1 percent in March, the largest decline since the Japan Department Store Association began collecting the figures in 1965 (with the exception of March 1990, when there was an aberrational decline caused by the introduction of a new 3 percent sales tax the year before).
Yet there are about 125 job vacancies for every 100 people seeking jobs.
Housing starts fell 19.4 percent in the 1991 fiscal year, which ended March 31, the steepest decline in 17 years. Industrial production fell 2.8 percent in March from February, according to preliminary figures, and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry is predicting a further decline in April.
 
Pay Cuts for Executives

 
 Electronics companies have been at the forefront of reductions of top executives' salaries, and some securities companies have told their directors to take trains to work instead of company limousines. But still none have resorted to layoffs
Tokyo Shoko Research Ltd., a private credit agency, reported that there were 10,723 corporate bankruptcies last fiscal year involving debts of more than 10 million yen, or about $80,000. Those companies left behind total debts of about $61.3 billion, nearly twice the previous record for a year.
There is concern that these loan losses could so hurt Japanese banks that cash-starved companies will find it harder to get the capital they need to grow.
 
Loans Are Scarce

 
 Indeed, Mr. Hidaka said banks were willing to make loans to meet routine operating expenses, but that money for long-term expansion or improvement projects had already disappeared.
"An established company like ours can do all right," he said. "But smaller companies or new companies are in trouble."
Sales of new autos fell 4.8 percent in April from the year earlier, the 12th straight monthly decline. Even sales of imported autos, which are mostly European luxury cars, an increasingly popular status symbol here, have been falling.
In fact, a pattern is developing in which sales of the most luxurious products have been hit hardest, but the basics have been less affected.
Sachio Takamine, head of the large gourmet foods department at the Tobu department store, said he began to see signs of the slowdown last year. "The first indication we got was that party-related goods, such as expensive wines and pate, began to decline," Mr. Takamine said. "It was the more expensive items."
He and others said that sales of gift packages of food, which are very popular among corporate executives, had also declined as companies trimmed their expenses. But, he said, the Japanese are still enjoying their new sense of affluence, in spite of the slowdown, and are not giving up all luxuries. Sales of caviar, for instance, are still rising at his store, Mr. Takamine said, and overall sales of gourmet foods continue to grow.
 
Fewer Rolls-Royces
 On the other hand, Shin Watari, president of Cornes & Company, which imports and distributes Rolls-Royce autos here, said his business had been devastated.
Before the powerful economic boom of the late 1980's, he sold only 50 to 60 of the cars a year. With the soaring stock and real estate markets and the general expansion of the last five years, sales rocketed as high as 500 in 1990. But this year, he said, he expected sales of just 150 to 180 of the cars, which retail for more than $200,000 each.
"Until last August there was still a six-month waiting list for some models," Mr. Watari said. "Now I fear that things will continue to slow down. I don't think the environment will improve soon."
This patchwork of indicators is being read by industrial planners as a sign that eventually they will have to find new products. Toyota Motor, Japan's largest auto maker, is eliminating one of the two eight-hour shifts at a plant near Nagoya that produces luxury sedans. It is also reducing the blizzard of different models it has been offering and is contemplating slowing the development time of new models to cut costs.
"Until the 1980's, we could always resort to exports to jack up sales when times were tough," said Tsunehiko Fujii, assistant manager of Toyota's research division. "But now we are trying to moderate our exports. So we cannot find a simple means to get out of the current recession. The only way is through boosting domestic demand."
 
Strategy Not Working
 He added that Toyota had sought since last year to increase demand in Japan for recreational vehicles. "But most standard sedans are just not selling well," Mr. Fujii said. "It hasn't worked so far."
Hidaka Seiki faces a similar problem. Its business comes 60 percent from the auto industry, 20 percent from producing parts for merchant ship radar systems, and 20 percent from military-related products.
Not only is the auto industry suffering, but with the end of the cold war, Hidaka Seiki is facing up to the reality that its military contracting business will never grow as it did in the days of superpower confrontation.
From 1.073 trillion yen in the fiscal year that ended March 31, 1991, the Government's spending on new weapons is expected to decline to 865 billion yen in the current fiscal year, which ends next March 31.
"That is one reason why this time lowering prices does not really help," Mr. Hidaka said. "There just is no demand. The only way out in the long term is to develop new products. The old businesses just are not going to grow as fast as before."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Announces New Effort to Immunize Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
President Bush announced at a Rose Garden ceremony today that the Federal Government would begin a nationwide campaign to immunize children against preventable diseases by the age of 2.
Pediatricians and other public health experts said Mr. Bush's proposal was belated and inadequate. 
 Mr. Bush also announced a Federal program intended to reduce infant mortality by increasing the number of women who get prenatal care. This program is called Healthy Start, but Democrats derided it as a "late start," saying it was prompted more by the political calendar than by genuine interest in child health problems. The centerpiece of the program announced today is a 30-second television commercial saying, "Every 13 minutes another infant dies."
Today's announcements were part of Mr. Bush's effort to show an active interest in domestic social and economic problems. Democrats, including Gov. Bill Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, say Mr. Bush has neglected those problems since he took office.
 
Similar Ceremony Last Year
 Mr. Bush's announcements come 11 months after a similar Rose Garden ceremony in which he said he was sending senior officials to six cities to investigate why children were not being vaccinated against measles and other diseases.
In an interview, Dr. Samuel L. Katz, professor of pediatrics at Duke University and chairman of the Federal Immunization Practices Advisory Committee, said Administration officials "finked out and did not follow through after they had a big Rose Garden show" last year.
"Other than Haiti and Bolivia, we probably have the worst record in the Western Hemisphere of immunizing children in the first two years of life," said Dr. Katz, who was appointed to the advisory panel by Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
The Administration says the effort last year was "phenomenally successful," because it produced plans for immunizing children in the six cities: Dallas, Detroit, Philadelphia, Phoenix, San Diego and Rapid City, S.D. But officials of the Public Health Service said they did not have data showing that the number of immunizations had actually increased in those cities.
Mr. Bush's new effort to underline his interest in domestic affairs forces him into a politically awkward position: He is choosing to emphasize the very problems his critics say he has ignored. Thus, for example, the Department of Health and Human Services today issued a statement saying, "The Bush Administration recognizes the under-immunization problem in our children from 2 months to 2 years."
In a separate statement, the department acknowledged that the infant mortality rate was higher in the United States than in 21 other industrial countries and that "the incidence of low birth weight is at the highest level observed" in this country since 1978. Low birth weight is the most important predictor of infant mortality. Babies weighing less than 5.5 pounds have a higher than average risk of dying in the first year of life.
The American Academy of Pediatrics welcomed Mr. Bush's proposals today, but said he was not providing enough money. For immunizations in the next fiscal year, Mr. Bush has requested $349 million, up from the $298 million appropriated for this year. But the academy said $489 million is needed.
Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat who heads the Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families, said: "I'm getting tired of the President mouthing his great concern for children, families and babies. He loves them to death up to the door of the budget office; then he drops them like a hot rock."
Under Mr. Bush's plan, four Cabinet departments will work together to get children immunized against diseases like polio, measles, mumps, rubella and hepatitis B. The four departments -- Health and Human Services, Agriculture, Education and Housing and Urban Development -- operate a range of health, welfare and nutrition programs.
"Thousands of our young children suffer crippling effects each year from measles and other communicable childhood diseases, and some even die," Mr. Bush said.
While the President is now declaring his commitment to child health, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said the Administration previously opposed efforts to require Medicaid coverage for all pregnant women and infants in families with income up to 85 percent over the official poverty level. (The poverty level for a family of three was $10,857 in 1991.)
In an interview, Mr. Waxman, who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and Environment, said: "Today's announcements show the President's business-as-usual approach to public health -- too little and too late. He proposes immunizations after a measles epidemic breaks out. He proposes tuberculosis services after TB has spread through our cities. Today's media blitz is no substitute for vaccines and nurses."
But Dr. Vincent A. Fulginiti, a pediatrician who serves as dean of the Tulane University School of Medicine, praised the steps announced today. The steps result from recommendations made in January 1991 by the National Vaccine Advisory Committee, of which Dr. Fulginiti is chairman.
"We have four major Government departments that did not previously work together on immunization," Dr. Fulginiti said.

HEADLINE: Adirondacks Plan Offered by Assembly

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 11

 BODY:
The Assembly today renewed long-stalled efforts to strengthen protections for the Adirondack wilderness, offering a new package of economic enticements for local governments to go along with tougher zoning restrictions for many lakeside and forest areas.
The package, which comes in the six-million-acre park's centennial year, was a clear bid by the Democratic-led Assembly to make new park regulations more palatable to the Republican-controlled Senate. 
 The package proposed today by Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin and two other Assembly Democrats, Maurice Hinchey of Ulster County and Alexander B. Grannis of Manhattan, would significantly decrease the number of houses that could be built in many wilderness tracts and virtually forbid residential development in many of the back-country areas that are now held by timber companies.
For four years the Senate has resisted proposals intended to ward off development in the Adirondacks, arguing it could stifle the economy.

HEADLINE: MCI Planning More Growth

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest telecommunications company, said today that it planned to continue to grow in the United States market and capture a hefty slice of world business.
"We will be among the five or six truly global telecommunications companies," said Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's chief executive, at the 20th annual meeting of the company. 
 Its recent $250 million contract to provide long-distance telephone service for four years to Citicorp symbolizes its expansion into the financial market, he said.
Despite the sluggish economy last year, MCI maintained a 16 percent growth rate for traffic carried on its telephone lines, double the industry average. And its profits nearly doubled from 1990's weak level of $299 million, or $1.06 a share, to $551 million, or $2.01 a share, last year.
This year the company is predicting 10 to 15 percent profit growth. But some analysts worry that the price paid to achieve that growth is proving too high, shaving its margins too close. MCI's operating profit margins have slipped from 15.7 percent in the 1990 first quarter to 12.7 percent in the 1992 first quarter. William McGowan, MCI's chairman, said the company would pay close attention to costs.
MCI shares closed today at $32.50, down 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Perot and Riots Redraw Bush Campaign Plans

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
It has been a turbulent year for the people whose job it is to get George Bush re-elected, not at all the kind of stately progress toward an emphatic November victory many of them had expected.
In late January and February, Patrick J. Buchanan was the nemesis. Then, gradually, Mr. Bush rallied and the troubles of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumptive Democratic nominee, accumulated on several fronts. Polls and politicians concluded that the President, for all his troubles, was a likely winner after all. 
 Now a third phase has begun, with twin threats to Mr. Bush's ambition to become only the third President since World War II to serve two full terms. With the primary elections coming to a close, quite successfuly from his standpoint, Mr. Bush's managers are struggling to come to grips with the putative third-party candidacy of Ross Perot and with the new politicial agenda generated by the arson and looting that swept Los Angeles 12 days ago.
While some people in the White House debate how sweeping a program Mr. Bush should offer to help cure the problems that underlay the rioting in California, some at campaign headquarters worry that the President may focus too closely on the question.
"What I want," said one of Mr. Bush's top strategists, "is a few more days of this -- a simple, clear program with three or points, then get off it. The longer the President seems preoccupied with Los Angeles, the more he and his urban policies become the issue, and that's not good for us."
But others involved in the campaign think it would be a major mistake for the President not to seem deeply involved in trying to alleviate the anxieties that have been stirred by the vivid events in Los Angeles.
To move on to other themes too quickly, a senior Republican operative insisted, "will make it look like we don't understand how deep all this runs -- not only the frustration of the blacks, which a lot of yuppies who voted for Bush sympathize with, but also the fears of the law-and-order voters, who also helped elect him four years ago." The problem, as he outlined it, is how to avoid letting the riots drive a wedge into the Bush constituency.
That may already have happened to some extent; private polls taken for both parties, as well as a few public polls, show Mr. Bush falling back in the wake of the riots.
But the Perot problem is no less severe, as seen from the Bush camp.
According to one campaign planner, the original intention had been to aim the Republican campaign mainly at the South, where Mr. Clinton was considered a threat in only two or three states on the periphery of the region, at the West, and at the industrial states of the Midwest, which were thought likely to be the main battleground. In the Northeast, only New York seemed likely to the Bush strategists to provide useful hunting grounds.
Now, the planner said, all that has been swept aside and "we're all looking for a new strategic concept that accounts for Perot's strength."
While Bush strategists, especially those from Texas, readily tell stories intended to point up Mr. Perot's alleged authoritarianism and shortness of temper, one who has known him for years said the other day, "He's a master salesman, remember, and he may cause us real trouble."
In an attempt to stop the erosion in Mr. Bush's support, the campaign is studying the possibility of running television commercials created by a new media team, which includes several Madison Avenue experts, well before the fall campaign. One plan would involve a heavy media expenditure before the California primary on June 2, even though Mr. Buchanan is considered more a bother than a threat there; another would schedule Bush ads before, during and after the Democratic National Convention in New York this summer, in an effort to deny most of the usual convention-week lift to Mr. Clinton.
All of these discussions are taking place against a backdrop of considerable personal animosity and organizational confusion. Tensions among some of the principal figures around Mr. Bush are one of the main reasons there is still no detailed set of goals for a second Bush Administration, which many Republican politicians consider a key to victory in November.
For example, it is difficult to overstate the degree of animosity some of the senior campaign personnel feel toward Richard Darman, the tough political infighter who heads the Office of Management and Budget. Many members of the campaign staff are convinced, they say, that he is making it impossible for Sam Skinner, the new White House chief of staff, to pull operations there together as they had counted upon Mr. Skinner to do.
In addition, Mr. Darman is seen as the principal author of the White House compromise with Congress that led to the tax increases that have eaten into the President's popularity. One of Mr. Bush's senior campaign aides said of Mr. Darman last week, "He's hurt the President more than any Democrat."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Reviewing Sanctions On Pretoria

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he was reviewing New York City's sanctions against companies doing business in South Africa and had dispatched four of his top aides to Johannesburg for talks with black political leaders about possible changes in the city's position.
But the Mayor said he would stand fast on sanctions until the African National Congress, led by Nelson Mandela, requests that they be lifted. He said he was considering lifting some sanctions that hurt black South Africans while keeping those that punish the Government and the military. He said he would also push for guarantees that workers in those companies that are removed from the sanction list are treated fairly. 
 "For instance, those that do business directly with the military, it may not be time to deal with those folks," he said. "And then where sanctions are lifted, it may be desirable, I think, that there be some ground rules about how workers will be treated."
Under a 1990 local law, the city is prohibited from contracting with companies or banks with business ties to South Africa. The city also ranks banks according to how much they have done to encourage the end of the racist system and gives its business to those with the highest rankings. In addition, the city has avoided investing the $43.1 billion in pension funds it controls in companies that do business in South Africa.
 
'Sensitive Negotiations'
 On Sunday, a delegation of four top mayoral aides, a Board of Education official and a prominent Harlem businessman arrived in South Africa. Their hastily arranged trip was never announced because it involves "sensitive negotiations" on "the city's trading relationships as well as the city's investment," said Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's spokesman.
But other City Hall aides, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch kept the trip quiet because he feared it would stir controversy, as the Mayor's trip in November did. That journey raised eyebrows among good-government lobbyists when the Mayor used a quasi-public corporation to solicit contributions from companies that do business with the city. This time press aides to the Mayor did not tell reporters until after Mr. Lynch and others were on the ground in Johannesburg.
Asked whether the trip was kept under wraps to avoid criticism, the Mayor said, "It wasn't kept a secret. We just didn't announce it, per se."
The city paid for the officials' passage. The businessman, Percy E. Sutton, a former Manhattan Borough President, paid his own way. The rest of the delegation were Mr. Lynch; Carol O'Cleireacain, the Finance Commissioner; O. Peter Sherwood, the city's Corporation Counsel, and David Scott, a Board of Education staff member. The cost to the city will be about $10,000, officials said.
 
Behind Closed Doors
 Yesterday, the Mayor's delegation met behind closed doors with Walter Sisulu, deputy president of the African National Congress, Gill Marcus, the congress's spokeswoman, said in Johannesburg. No announcement was made after the meeting.
Ms. Marcus insisted that the city delegation's visit did not signal that the national congress had dropped its opposition to lifting sanctions before an interim government was installed.
City officials said the trip was planned early last week after the A.N.C. foreign minister, Thabo Mbeki, telephoned Mr. Lynch and said the time was right to talk about the city's sanctions. On May 14, the parties trying to negotiate a new constitution are to sit down for another round of talks that could lead to an interim government.
Victor Mashabela, a New York representative of the African National Congress, said Mr. Lynch's mission was timed to coincide with the talks.
At home, Mr. Dinkins has been under more and more pressure from banks and some large corporations to consider changing the sanctions at once since some progress has been made toward establishing a new government, city officials said.

HEADLINE: Gain of 28.17 Lifts the Dow To a Record

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply to record highs yesterday, propelled by optimism that the Federal Reserve Board will lower interest rates another notch.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 28.17 points, to 3,397.58. It was the 19th record close for the Dow this year, surpassing the high of 3,378.13 set on May 4. 
 In the broad market, advances led declines by 1,100 to 660, but New York Stock Exchange volume was a light 155.6 million shares, compared with 168.7 million Friday, as investors stayed away ahead of inflation data due out today.
 
Help From Abroad
Wall Street sentiment was also helped by increases in overseas markets, especially Japan, where the 225-share Nikkei average rose 1.3 percent.
"The foreign markets certainly were a help, Japan particularly," said Jack Conlon, managing director at Rothschild Inc. "Clearly, the bond market has been helpful here, too. The market is anticipating a rate cut."
Analysts said investors were betting that the Fed would lower interest rates to make sure the recovering economy did not suffer a recessionary relapse. The Fed last cut rates on April 9.
"Today's strength is not reflective of any economic data that should push the market up at this point," said Joseph Barthel, director of investment strategy at Fahnestock & Company. "What we will ultimately need is some Fed easing."
Rates were little changed in the Treasury market yesterday, where the key 30-year bond was off slightly from Friday afternoon to yield 7.88 percent.
Many analysts said the central bank would cut rates in the short term despite unexpected strength in the April jobs report, released Friday. They noted that although the economy was recovering, the strength of the rebound varied considerably by region and industry.
"The perception is that with weak money supply, the Fed still has to do something," said Ned Collins, executive vice president in charge of United States equity trading at Daiwa Securities. "I felt we would see a minor new high this week, but I'm not sure it means much unless the Fed does something."
Analysts said the easing could follow a meeting of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee meeting May 19.
 
Concern for Profit Taking
Some traders are concerned that the market could drop back in profit taking even if the Fed does move to cut rates.
If, by the time of a rate cut, "we are still going at anything that resembles the clip we are going at now, I think that will be the news you sell on," said Mr. Conlon of Rothschild.
Many investors stayed on the sidelines yesterday ahead of the Government's report today on April wholesale inflation.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.44, to 418.49; the American Stock Exchange index rose 1.72, to 395.84, and the composite index of all common stocks on the Big Board was up 1.27 points, to 230.47. The Nasdaq over-the-counter index was up 1.37, to 587.13.
Among active issues, Wal-Mart Stores rose 7/8, to 52 7/8, after the retailer posted a 26 percent increase in first-quarter sales and earnings.
I.B.M. added 3/4, to 93 7/8, as Barry Bosak, a Smith Barney analyst, reiterated a buy recommendation.
 
Strength in Banking
Banks and financial shares gained on renewed rumors of merger speculation among several large banks, traders said. First Interstate surged 2 1/2, to 44 3/8; Wells Fargo rallied 4 5/8, to 86 3/8, and Citicorp added 3/8, to 19 1/2.
Banc One rose 3/4, to 44 3/4, as Nancy Bush, a Brown Brothers analyst, upgraded her rating.
Synoptics Communications rallied 1 1/2, to 26 5/8, as Wessels, Arnold & Henderson upgraded its rating on the computer network manufacturer.
Wellfleet Communications rose 2 1/4, to 33 1/4, as Alex. Brown repeated a strong buy rating on the computer equipment maker.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wal-Mart's And May's Profits Up

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. produced another set of stunning numbers yesterday -- profits up 26.1 percent -- as the major retailers started reporting first-quarter earnings.
Sales were up across the board, reflecting improved consumer spending, and earnings benefited from strict cost controls imposed during the recession. The May Department Stores Company said profits rose 6.6 percent. May, like many retailers, had a weak first quarter last year, when the Persian Gulf war cut into consumer spending. Nordstrom Inc.'s earnings fell 16 percent from the extremely strong level of last year. 
 Easter was celebrated in April this year but in March last year, which skewed monthly sales comparisons in the last two months of the quarter. While retailers anticipated weaker March sales because of the switch in Easter dates, they expected April sales to offset them.
But inclement weather in April dampened demand for spring clothing, so markedly better sales failed to materialize before the end of the quarter.
Following are the details of the retailers' results:
 
Wal-Mart
 Wal-Mart posted record sales that raised its first-quarter profits to $387 million, or 34 cents a share, up from $307 million, or 27 cents a share, last year.
Earnings for the nation's largest retailer came in about a cent a share better than analysts' predictions. Wal-Mart shares closed yesterday at $52.875, up 87.5 cents.
"They're constantly upgrading their technical gadgetry," said William W. Whyte, an analyst at Stephens Inc., an investment bank in Little Rock, Ark. "While that incurs capital expenditures, the efficiencies they gain far outweigh the costs."
Mr. Whyte estimated that the retailer would post similar income gains throughout the year, ending up with earnings between $1.70 and $1.75 a share for the year.
Wal-Mart's sales grew 26 percent, to $11.6 billion, from $9.3 billion in the comparable period last year.
 
May Stores
 Earnings at May Department Stores rose to $81 million, or 60 cents a share, for the 13 weeks that ended May 2, compared with $76 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ag,o when the company's profits fell 5 percent.
May's performance was a bit below analysts' expectations. Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Securities Inc., said neither March nor April sales met the company's plans, which forced May to take greater markdowns. Sales increased 6 percent anyway, to $2.3 billion, from $2.17 billion in the first quarter of 1991.
The company's attention to costs helped bolster the bottom line in spite of weaker sales. "I think they're the best in the department store industry at controlling their expenses," Mr. Hood said. "What that means is that in spite of unexpected factors, if the economic recovery continues, they will have a better year."
He estimated that the company, which operates a number of department store chains including Foley's, the May Company and Lord & Taylor, will post earnings of about $4.50 a share this year. Shares of May closed yesterday at $55.875, up 37.5 cents
 
Nordstrom
 Nordstrom's profits dropped 16 percent in the quarter that ended April 30 to $21.6 million, or 26 cents a share, from $25.7 million, or 31 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.
But sales climbed to $663.8 million, up 9 percent from $610.6 million in the first quarter of last year.
John A. Goesling, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Nordstrom, attributed the declining earnings to higher expenses. "Sales were up some, but when you subtract the higher costs in general in all our stores, they weren't up enough to offset higher expenses," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Slightly Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in quiet trading yesterday, as credit market participants readied themselves for release later in the week of economic statistics that most expect will be favorable for fixed-income investors.
"People have money to put to work, and we should get good statistics over the next week," said one Government-bond trader. "Right now is not an occasion to be aggressively bullish, but it is a time to be involved." 
 Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, estimated that the Treasury would make interest payments of just under $25 billion on Friday.
"There is a boodle of cash to be put to work," he said. "The question is whether investors perceive that this market has more to run. I tend to be a little more cautious than what seems to be the prevailing market sentiment."
 
Producer Price Numbers
 This week's stream of new data begins to flow today, with the release of April producer price numbers.
Most economists are forecasting that the Producer Price Index rose by a relatively modest three-tenths of 1 percent last month, and by the same amount when volatile energy and food prices are excluded.
Consumer price statistics, retail sales figures and industrial production data are among the other reports scheduled to be released over the next four days.
Aside from expectations that the data will show that the economy is recovering slowly and that inflation pressures are mild, traders began buying back short-term bills and notes on the chance that the Federal Reserve Board might decide to ease monetary policy once more.
Prices of short-term issues fell fairly sharply on Friday after the Labor Department reported that non-farm payroll employment rose by 126,000 in April, a bigger increase than most analysts had anticipated.
 
Making a Difference
 Victor Chang, president of VC Management, a New York-based money management firm, said, "I don't think the Fed needs to ease policy any more, but another quarter-point cut in the Federal funds rate would not make a material difference."
What is needed now, Mr. Chang said, is for the Fed to convey the message that it will maintain a stable monetary policy even as economic activity begins to pick up.
"The Fed can do that because inflation is not going to be a problem for the rest of this year and into 1993," Mr. Chang added. "That sort of signal would allow long-term interest rates to come down a bit."
Hopes that the Fed might ease helped fuel demand at the weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills yesterday.
At the auction, new three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.64 percent, down slightly from the 3.65 percent average rate at last week's sale.
Six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.74 percent, compared with 3.78 percent at the auction a week earlier.
 
Long Bond Rises
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10110/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 7.88 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Friday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10027/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 7.37 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 10011/32 , up 5/32 , to yield 5.18 percent.
Corporations, which were notably absent from the new-issue market last week because of the Treasury's refunding auctions, were more active yesterday.
Roughly $1.25 billion worth of new securities were priced yesterday, including 30-year debentures by the Georgia Pacific Corporation and Dow Capital B.V.
The $250 million worth of 9.50 percent Georgia Pacific securities were priced at $99.15 to yield 9.587 percent, 1.70 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the 8 percent 29 1/2-year Treasury bonds at the time of pricing.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
The securities, which are noncallable for 10 years, are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
$150 Million Offering
 Dow Capital B.V. offered $150 million of 8.70 percent debentures through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The securities were priced at $98.781 to yield 8.816 percent, 92 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for 10 years, is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities said that trading was slow and that prices of most outstanding securities were unchanged.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet foreign exchange dealings yesterday.
Gold prices were mostly mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $336.70 a troy ounce, up 70 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose 90 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $336.30. 
 Analysts said the dollar remained locked in a trading range, with virtually no news to influence its direction.
Michael Malpede, an analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago, attributed the dollar's decline to two factors -- steady monetary policy in Germany and skepticism over the strength of the United States economic recovery.
He said that until monetary policy changed in Germany, interest-rate differentials favored a lower dollar. German interest rates are at historically high levels, which translate to attractive returns for those who invest in mark-denominated securities.
Mr. Malpede said that traders, meanwhile, wanted to see further confirmation that the economic recovery in the United States would not be derailed. If the recovery slows -- or worse, vanishes -- the Federal Reserve would be more inclined to lower rates here, a further disadvantage for the dollar.
"So until Germany eases rates or the U.S. economy strengthens more, we're caught in a trading range," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 133.17 yen, up 0.62 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 133.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 133.00 yen, down from 133.45 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7935, up from $1.7885 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.7945 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.7910.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6390 German marks, down from 1.6445; 1.5255 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.5095 French francs, down from 5.5335; 1,233.25 Italian lire, down from 1,238.00, and 1.2056 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2028.
